像我们这样的机器

Machines like Us

像我们这样的机器

Machines like Us

用常识走向人工智能

Toward AI with Common Sense

Ronald J. Brachman 和 Hector J. Levesque

Ronald J. Brachman and Hector J. Levesque

麻省理工学院出版社

The MIT Press

马萨诸塞州剑桥市

Cambridge, Massachusetts

伦敦，英国

London, England

© 2022 麻省理工学院

© 2022 Massachusetts Institute of Technology

版权所有。未经出版商书面许可，不得通过任何电子或机械方式（包括影印、录音或信息存储和检索）以任何形式复制本书的任何部分。

All rights reserved. No part of this book may be reproduced in any form by any electronic or mechanical means (including photocopying, recording, or information storage and retrieval) without permission in writing from the publisher.

麻省理工学院出版社要感谢为本书草稿提供评论的匿名同行审稿人。学术专家的慷慨工作对于确立我们出版物的权威性和质量至关重要。我们感谢这些未经认可的读者所做的贡献。

The MIT Press would like to thank the anonymous peer reviewers who provided comments on drafts of this book. The generous work of academic experts is essential for establishing the authority and quality of our publications. We acknowledge with gratitude the contributions of these otherwise uncredited readers.

本书由 New Best-set Typesetters Ltd 设置为 ITC Stone Serif Std 和 ITC Stone Sans Std。

This book was set in ITC Stone Serif Std and ITC Stone Sans Std by New Best-set Typesetters Ltd.

美国国会图书馆出版编目数据可用。

Library of Congress Cataloging-in-Publication Data is available.

姓名：Brachman, Ronald J., 1949- 作者。| Levesque, Hector J., 1951-作者。

Names: Brachman, Ronald J., 1949- author. | Levesque, Hector J., 1951-author.

标题：像我们这样的机器：用常识走向 AI / Ronald J. Brachman 和 Hector J. Levesque。

Title: Machines like us : toward AI with common sense / Ronald J. Brachman and Hector J. Levesque.

说明：马萨诸塞州剑桥市：麻省理工学院出版社，[2022] | 包括参考书目和索引。

Description: Cambridge, Massachusetts : The MIT Press, [2022] | Includes bibliographical references and index.

d_r0

d_r0

为了爸爸妈妈，为了一生的爱。

For Mom and Dad, for lifetimes of love.

—RJB

—RJB

献给我亲爱的兄弟约翰、雷，以及已故的彼得和保罗。

For my dear brothers John, Ray, and the late Peter and Paul.

—HJL

—HJL

笔记

指数

关于作者

About the Authors

预览

Preview

想象一下，如果你愿意，未来的自动驾驶汽车会比现在好得多。他们可靠地避开障碍物，遵守交通信号灯和标志，甚至响应其他司机的转向信号。无人驾驶汽车普遍部署在高尔夫球场、电影院和居民社区，自动驾驶面包车在许多城市全面服务城市通勤者。他们多年来没有造成伤害事故。事实上，这些想象中的汽车非常安全可靠，甚至不需要人类司机作为后援。

Imagine, if you will, a future where self-driving cars are much better than they are now. They reliably avoid obstacles, obey traffic lights and signs, and even respond to turn signals from other drivers. Autonomous carts are universally deployed at golf courses, movie lots, and residential communities, and self-driving vans fully service urban commuters in many cities. They have not caused an injury accident in years. In fact, these imagined cars are so safe and dependable that they don’t even need human drivers as backup.

该技术已经触及了第一波消费者，您的许多邻居现在的车道上都有自动驾驶汽车。你加入了他们。你的新车太棒了，在暴风雪等不利条件下驾驶、在交通繁忙时变道，以及在挤满行人、狗、婴儿车、自行车和其他车辆的十字路口行驶方面，你的新车都比你好。您只需设置目的地，然后就可以出发了。值得注意的是，许多商店现在都为像您这样的汽车提供路边停放点，让他们在回家的路上装上行李箱——根本不需要人在车里。

The technology has reached the first wave of consumers, and many of your neighbors now have self-driving cars in their driveways. You’ve joined them. Your new car is amazing, better than you at driving in adverse conditions like blizzards, changing lanes in heavy traffic, and navigating through intersections crowded with pedestrians, dogs, strollers, bicycles, and other vehicles. You just set the destination, and off it goes. Remarkably, many stores now provide curbside spots for cars like yours to have their trunks loaded up and sent on their way home—no human needed in the car at all.

现在想象一下：

Now picture this:

就在星期一中午之前，您派车去 Jones 的杂货店购物。今天是全国独立日假期，Jones's 正在出售其优质牛排，您打算在今天下午烧烤。您希望这次旅行很快，因为很多人都在海滩度假，而且商店也不远。

It’s just before noon on Monday, and you send your car on a shopping run to Jones’s Grocery Store. Today is the national Independence Day holiday, and Jones’s is having a sale on its great steaks, which you’re planning to barbecue this afternoon. You expect the trip to be quick because so many people are at the beach for the holiday and the store is not far away.

汽车驶近布拉德福德和维多利亚的交叉路口。交通灯是红色的，所以汽车平稳地滑行停下来等待绿灯。三分钟过去了，指示灯仍然是红色。五分钟过去了，灯还是红的。汽车的摄像头检测到十字路口远端有一些活动，但没有建议采取任何行动。你的汽车电脑——在避障和车道跟踪方面表现出色——无法理解另一边的司机正在下车、互相交谈、 并指向。你的汽车的新外部音频传感器经过训练可以检测喇叭和警报器，但无法感知来自右侧的稍远的音乐声。

The car approaches the intersection of Bradford and Victoria. The traffic light is red so the car glides smoothly to a stop and waits for the light to turn green. Three minutes go by, and the light stays red. Five minutes go by, and the light is still red. The car’s cameras detect some activity on the far side of the intersection, but no action is suggested. Your car’s computers—excellent with obstacle avoidance and lane following—are not equipped to understand that drivers on the other side are getting out of their cars, talking to each other, and pointing. Your car’s new external audio sensors, trained to detect honking and sirens, cannot make any sense of a somewhat distant musical sound coming from the right.

汽车的导航系统没有改道建议；没有交通可言，沿途也没有已知的施工或事故。所以汽车就停在那里，耐心地等待信号灯变亮。十分钟过去了，然后是十五分钟。

The car’s navigation system has no rerouting suggestions; there is no traffic to speak of, and no known construction or accidents along the route. So the car sits there, waiting patiently for the light to change. Ten minutes go by, and then fifteen.

与此同时，在家里，你开始想知道为什么汽车没有报告去取杂货。你知道如果它有机械问题，它会给你发短信提醒。您检查您的应用程序，看到汽车在十字路口等候，并注意到它在一刻钟内没有移动。然而没有什么不对劲。你的远程监控器显示汽车只是在遵守法律，等待绿灯。为什么它不做某事？你举起双手，哀叹虽然你的车像专业人士一样驾驶，但它偶尔会犯下这些莫名其妙的错误——比如在你的客人即将到来时永远在红绿灯处等待。

Meanwhile, at home, you begin to wonder why the car hasn’t reported picking up the groceries. You know if it had a mechanical problem it would text you an alert. You check your app and see the car waiting at the intersection, and note that it hasn’t moved in a quarter hour. Yet nothing is amiss. Your remote monitor shows that the car is just obeying the law, waiting for the light to turn green. Why isn’t it doing something? You throw your hands up, bemoaning the fact that while your car drives like a pro, it occasionally makes these inexplicable blunders—like waiting forever at a traffic light while your guests are about to arrive.

现在想象一个替代场景。这次是你开车 同样的十字路口，同样的灯，同样的五分钟过去了：

Now imagine an alternate scenario. It’s you driving this time. Same intersection, same stuck light, same five minutes gone by:

你问自己，到底发生了什么事？为了以防万一，我应该再等一会儿吗？开车闯红灯？右转绕过十字路口？以其他方式去商店？忘掉 Jones's 去另一家商店吧？完全放弃杂货然后回家？（你随时可以叫外卖。）你关掉收音机，沉思了几秒钟。十字路口另一边的司机引起了你的注意。你看看他们似乎指向的地方。你看到远处有一堆旗帜，看起来像一辆敞篷车，后座上坐着一些人。您会听到从那个方向传来一些铜管乐般的音乐。

You ask yourself, What on earth is going on? Should I wait a bit longer just in case? Drive through the red light? Make a right turn to get around the intersection? Get to the store some other way? Forget about Jones’s and go to another store? Give up on groceries altogether and head back home? (You can always order takeout.) You turn off the radio and ponder for a few seconds. The drivers on the other side of the intersection catch your eye. You look where they seem to be pointing. You see a bunch of flags in the distance and what looks like an open convertible with some people sitting atop the back seat. You hear some brassy-sounding music coming from that direction.

片刻之后，您放弃了 Jones's，调转车头，前往另一家商店。

After a moment, you give up on Jones’s, turn the car around, and head off to a different store.

想一想当您想出要做什么时，您的脑子里在想什么。这并不是说您记得某个特定的规则可以为您解决问题。当然，你在驾校学到的东西并没有告诉你应该采取什么行动。在这种情况下，真的没有任何单一的驾驶动作是正确的。也许您以前遇到过交通信号灯坏掉的情况，并且一直跟着其他司机穿过十字路口（当然要非常小心）。但是在这种特殊情况下，您认为灯一直是红色是因为十字路口即将举行游行。“哦，是的，”你记得，“今天是独立日！” 你本可以转身尝试另一条路线，但这要么会花费太多时间，要么会在不同的十字路口撞上游行队伍。所以你决定去别的地方。您本可以去离您所在的地方更近的 Smith's Grocery Store，但那里的肉类和农产品都没有那么好。所以你决定改去罗伯特家。

Think about what was going through your head as you figured out what to do. It’s not as if you remembered some specific rule that solved the problem for you. Certainly nothing you learned in driving school told you what action to take. There’s really no single driving move that is the right thing to do in cases like this. Maybe you’ve experienced broken traffic lights before and followed other drivers right through the intersection (with great caution, of course). But in this particular case, you figured that the light was staying red because a parade was coming on the cross street. “Oh yeah,” you remembered, “it’s Independence Day!” You could have turned around and tried another route, but this was either going to take too much time or run into the parade at a different intersection. So you decided to go elsewhere. You could have gone to Smith’s Grocery Store, which is closer to where you are, but the meat and produce there are nowhere as good. So you decided to head to Robert’s instead.

你不必成为某种驾驶专家，比如在路上行驶了数千小时的出租车司机，才能想出这样的驾驶行为。也许这不是一个习得的例行程序，您可以在专注于其他事情（例如刷牙或遛狗）的同时盲目地遵循。但这也不是火箭科学。不需要铅笔和纸。你必须能够考虑到一些关于你当前情况的事情，但除此之外，这实际上只是任何聪明人都应该具备的普通常识。

You don’t have to be some sort of driving expert, like a cabbie with thousands of hours on the road, to come up with driving behavior like this. Maybe it’s not a learned routine you can just follow mindlessly while concentrating on something else like brushing your teeth or walking the dog. But it’s not rocket science either. No pencil and paper required. You have to be able to take into account some things about your current situation, but beyond that, it’s really just the ordinary common sense that any intelligent person would be expected to have.

一个普通的成年人会知道很多相关的、平凡的事情：你不会永远在红绿灯前等待；人们说话和打手势可能表明发生了一些有趣的事情；旗帜和铜管乐队的音乐可能预示着游行。他们会迅速将所有内容放在一起，并快速、合理地猜测下一步该怎么做：如果第一个看起来不再有希望，就选择第二好的选择。这只是常识。你所谓的智能汽车，虽然是一位优秀的司机——甚至可能是一位杰出的司机——但显然没有。

An average adult will know many relevant, mundane things: you don’t just wait forever at a traffic light; people talking and gesticulating likely indicates something interesting going on; flags and brassy band music likely presage a parade. And they’ll put it all together quickly and make a fast, reasonable guess at what to do next: take the second-best choice if the first one no longer looks as promising. It’s just common sense. And your supposedly intelligent car, while an excellent driver—maybe even an outstanding one—clearly doesn’t have it.

这本书不是关于想象中的商店的虚构作品。它从当今实际存在的人工智能 (AI) 的艺术和科学开始，以及当前的 AI 系统如何出色地完成一些对智力要求很高的任务——在许多情况下，比人类做得更好——但仍然缺少人类独有的特征常识。

This book is not a work of fiction about imaginary drives to imaginary stores. It starts with the art and science of artificial intelligence (AI) as it actually exists today, and how current AI systems can be amazingly good at some intellectually demanding tasks—in many cases, better than humans—but still be missing that uniquely human characteristic of common sense.

如果上面的例子让你觉得不太可能，那么最近的许多书籍都说明了当前人工智能世界中许多类似的失误实例。简而言之，人工智能系统是脆弱的。尽管他们非常擅长某些事情，但在陌生的环境中，他们会以一种奇怪的不可预测的方式崩溃，因为他们缺乏应对人类从常识中获得的开放世界的广泛能力。

If the example above strikes you as improbable, numerous recent books illustrate many similar instances of blunders in the current world of AI. Simply put, AI systems are fragile. While they are quite adept at some things, they break down in unfamiliar circumstances in oddly unpredictable ways because they lack the broad capacity to deal with the open-ended world that humans get from common sense.

那么，大多数人拥有的这种常识是什么？自动驾驶汽车等机器也需要具备什么样的常识呢？非人类司机如何变得更像我们中的一员？这就是我们打算在本书中探索的内容。

So what is this common sense that most people have, and what would it take for machines like self-driving cars to have it too? How could a nonhuman driver become more like one of us? This is what we set out to explore in this book.

正如我们将看到的，答案并不是特别简单。没有单一的神奇成分，没有灵丹妙药；只有一些问题需要调查和解决。在这里，我们汇集了 AI 研究的大量观察结果、技术想法和建议，它们将帮助我们直面常识挑战。

As we will see, the answer is not a particularly easy one. There’s no single magic ingredient, no silver bullet; just a number of issues to look into and resolve. Here we bring together a host of observations, technical ideas, and proposals from AI research that will help us address the challenge of common sense head-on.

本书不适合那些主要想听听专家认为未来几年人工智能研究会或不会产生什么、自动驾驶汽车实际会变得多好，或者自主人工智能系统是否最终会成为现实的读者。反人类。还有其他地方可以做到这一点。相反，我们希望引起读者的兴趣并让他们满意，因为他们想要思考与人工智能相关的常识的本质、它的主要组成部分是什么，以及它是如何工作的。它适用于对 AI 为何尚未生产出功能齐全的自主机器人感到好奇，并想看看是否有通往更强大 AI 的途径的人。如果你希望你未来的自动驾驶汽车能够在我们生活的复杂、不可预测的世界中真正自行管理——并准时送你你的杂货——这本书就是为你而写的。

This book is not intended for readers who mainly want to hear what the experts think will or will not come out of AI research in the next few years, how good self-driving cars are actually going to get, or whether autonomous AI systems will eventually rebel against humanity. There are other places to go for that. Instead, we hope to intrigue and satisfy the reader who wants to think about the nature of common sense as it relates to AI, what its main components are, and how it all works. It’s for someone who is curious as to why AI has not yet produced fully functional autonomous robots, and wants to see if there is a route to a more capable AI. If you’d like your future self-driving car to truly manage on its own in the complex, unpredictable world we live in—and get you your groceries on time—this book is for you.

对于这样的读者，我们表示欢迎，让我们开始吧。

To such a reader we say welcome and let’s get started.

1个

1

常识之路

The Road to Common Sense

我们只能看到前方很短的距离，但我们可以看到那里有很多需要做的事情。

We can only see a short distance ahead, but we can see plenty there that needs to be done.

——艾伦·图灵，《计算机器与智能》

—Alan Turing, “Computing Machinery and Intelligence”

这是一本从人工智能 (AI) 的角度讲述常识的书。虽然只有少数 AI 研究人员真正直接研究常识，但这个话题从该领域一开始就存在。AI 在 1950 年代由美国计算机科学家 John McCarthy（1927-2011）命名，他在 1958 年发表的第一篇关于 AI 的论文中有一篇名为“Programs with Common Sense”。

This is a book about common sense from the standpoint of artificial intelligence (AI). While only a small number of AI researchers actually work on common sense directly, the topic has been around since the beginning of the field. AI was given its name in the 1950s by US computer scientist John McCarthy (1927–2011), and one of the first papers ever written about AI is one he presented in 1958 called “Programs with Common Sense.”

有了这样的历史，人们可能会认为 AI 的常识部分现在已经掌握得很好，六十多年后。但在 2019 年出版的一本名为《重启人工智能》的书中，加里马库斯和欧内斯特戴维斯做出了这样的观察：“不幸的是，获得常识比人们想象的要难得多。正如我们将看到的，让机器获得常识的需求也比人们想象的要普遍得多。”

With a history like this, one might think that the common sense part of AI would be well in hand by now, more than sixty years later. But in a 2019 book called Rebooting AI, Gary Marcus and Ernest Davis make this observation: “Unfortunately acquiring common sense is much harder than one might think. And as we will see, the need for getting machines to acquire common sense is also far more pervasive than one might have imagined.”

这里的含义很明确：人工智能系统确实可以使用某种常识，但还没有人想出如何为它们提供常识。似乎没有人认为常识是智力的次要方面；可以说，它是最核心的。

The implication here is clear: AI systems could really use some sort of common sense, but nobody has yet figured out how to provide them with it. And it’s not as if anyone thinks that common sense is some minor aspect of intelligence; arguably, it’s at the very core.

我们打算在本书中做的是仔细研究常识的概念，以更好地了解它是什么、为什么重要，以及如何让它在人工智能系统中发挥作用。但在踏上这条漫长而曲折的道路之前，让我们先看看我们将要去哪里。

What we propose to do in this book is to take a hard look at this notion of common sense to get a better sense of what it is, why it is important, and what it might take to make it work in an AI system. But before setting out on this long and winding road, let us have a look at where we will be going.

常识指南指南

A Guide to Commonsense Guides

在亚马逊上快速搜索一下就会发现，有七千多本书名中带有“常识”（或“常识”或“常识”）的书籍。其中大约十分之一还包含“指南”一词。要了解它们的范围，这里有一些指南：

A quick search on Amazon will reveal that there are over seven thousand books with “common sense” (or “common-sense” or “commonsense”) in the title. About a tenth of them also include the word “guide.” To get an idea of their range, here are a dozen of those guides:

  • 房地产投资常识指南
  • The Common Sense Guide to Real Estate Investing
  • 书中的保姆：育儿常识指南
  • Nanny in a Book: The Common-Sense Guide to Childcare
  • 在埃博拉病毒中幸存下来：热带医生的常识指南
  • Surviving the Ebola Virus: A Tropical Doctor’s Commonsense Guide
  • 禁食常识指南
  • A Commonsense Guide to Fasting
  • 自由的最后立场：理解集体主义意识形态暴政的常识性指南
  • Freedom’s Last Stand: A Common-Sense Guide to Understanding the Tyranny of Collectivist Ideology
  • 不常见的水果和蔬菜：常识指南
  • Uncommon Fruits & Vegetables: A Commonsense Guide
  • 技术写作 AZ：工程报告和论文的常识指南
  • Technical Writing A-Z: A Commonsense Guide to Engineering Reports and Theses
  • 手工喂养幼鸟的常识指南
  • The Common Sense Guide to Handfeeding Baby Birds
  • 你的第一把枪：新手和傻瓜选择和使用的常识性指南
  • Your First Gun: A Common Sense Guide to Selection and Usage for Novices and Dummies
  • 伙计！你在想什么？约会和人际关系常识指南
  • Dude! What Were You Thinking? A Common Sense Guide to Dating & Relationships
  • 骡子问题的答案：了解骡子观点的常识指南
  • Answers to Your Mule Questions: A Common Sense Guide to Understanding the Mule’s Point of View
  • 裸体园艺：通过增加对自然的接触、培养绿色心态和建立强大社区来改善健康和生活方式的常识性指南
  • Gardening Nude: A Common Sense Guide to Improving Your Health and Lifestyle by Increasing Exposure to Nature, Cultivating a Green Mindset, and Building a Strong Community

除了“常识”部分，很难看出这些书有什么共同点！

Other than the “common sense” part, it is hard to see what these books could possibly have in common!

在本书的上下文中需要考虑的一件事是这些指南中的术语“常识”旨在传达什么。这显然不仅仅是使用常识的劝告；禁食常识指南应该不仅仅是“禁食时使用常识”。书名《禁食常识指南》所暗示的大概是这样的：“这里有一些关于禁食的知识，不是为了成为专家，而是为了在平常的情况下以明智的方式指导你的行动。” 这同样适用于投资房地产、了解骡子，大概还有裸体园艺。

One thing to think about in the context of this book is what the term “common sense” in these guides is intended to convey. It is clearly not just an exhortation to use common sense; a commonsense guide to fasting should be a bit more than “use common sense when fasting.” What the title A Commonsense Guide to Fasting suggests is perhaps something like this: “Here are some things to know about fasting, not to become an expert, but to guide your actions in a sensible way in ordinary situations.” The same applies to investing in real estate, understanding mules, and presumably, gardening in the nude.

这里的前提是，虽然有可能成为这些主题中任何一个的专家，但也有一些基本的、常识性的东西，即使是非专家也会觉得有用。这是亚马逊上关于手工喂养幼鸟的书的宣传：

The premise here is that while it might be possible to become an expert on any of these topics, there are also some basic, commonsense things that even nonexperts will find useful. Here’s the pitch at Amazon for the book on hand-feeding baby birds:

本指南打破了用手喂养幼鸟需要多年训练的神话，提供了一个常识性的解决方案。本书详细介绍了幼鸟对温暖、清洁、喂食频率、适当的配方、正确的温度和正确的技术等基本和实用的知识，这本书将让您立即像专业人士一样喂养幼鸟。

Breaking the myth that handfeeding baby birds requires years and years of training, this guide offers a common sense solution. Detailing a basic and workable knowledge of a baby bird’s requirements for warmth, cleanliness, frequency of feeding, proper formulas, correct temperature and correct technique, this book will have you feeding baby birds like a pro in no time.

这个目标似乎很合理。显然，人类每天处理的事情范围很广，不是以专家的身份，而是以简单、普通的方式。事实上，我们当中有多少人真正了解 LED 电视如何播放电影或 Alexa 告诉我们天气？对于我们大多数人来说，我们所拥有的只是对技术的常识性理解。在某些情况下，我们通过反复的经验获得理解（例如如何在炎热的夏日吃到融化的冰淇淋甜筒）；在某些情况下，我们会从朋友那里得到建议（比如参加派对穿什么，不穿什么）；在其他情况下，我们的理解很可能来自指南或手册之类的东西（例如如何设置家用打印机）。

The goal seems reasonable enough. There is clearly a wide range of things that humans deal with every day not as experts, but in simple, ordinary terms. Indeed, how many of us truly understand how an LED TV displays a movie or Alexa tells us the weather? For most of us, a commonsense understanding of the technology is all we have. In some cases, we get our understanding through repeated experience (like how to eat a melting ice cream cone on a hot summer day); in some cases, we get advice from friends (such as what to wear—and not wear—for a party); and in other cases, our understanding may well come from something like a guide or manual (like how to set up a home printer).

我们打算在本书中做的是从埃博拉病毒和用手喂养幼鸟等个别主题退后一步，看看常识本身的基本思想。我们需要对常识的理解，使其清楚它如何依赖于从先前经验、朋友的建议和常识指南等事物中获得的知识。作为计算机科学家，我们的目标是对常识的描述足够具体和详细，以至于我们至少可以想象构建一台拥有它的计算机器。

What we intend to do in this book is to step back from individual topics like the Ebola virus and hand-feeding baby birds, and look at the underlying idea of common sense itself. We want an understanding of common sense that makes it clear how it leans on the knowledge gained from things such as prior experience, advice from friends, and commonsense guides. As computer scientists, we want to aim for an account of common sense that is specific and detailed enough that we could at least imagine building a computational machine that has it.

人工智能

Artificial Intelligence

这将我们带回到人工智能的主题。一般来说，人工智能是研究如何通过计算手段产生智能行为。在一个极端，我们想象复杂的行为，比如下棋、解读诗歌和对肿瘤进行分类；在另一个极端，我们设想了更常见的活动，比如照看蹒跚学步的孩子、准备饭菜和开车。

This takes us back to the topic of AI. In general terms, AI is the study of how intelligent behavior can be produced through computational means. At one extreme, we imagine sophisticated behaviors like playing chess, interpreting poetry, and classifying tumors; at the other extreme, we envision more commonplace activities like babysitting a toddler, preparing a meal, and driving a car.

这些与常识有什么关系？这将在接下来的两章中进行一些梳理，但基本思想是人工智能系统可能能够在某些需要人类智能的特定任务上做得非常好，但仍然无法以更广泛的智能方式行事. 我们最终要说的是，这些人工智能系统展示的是专业知识，而不是常识。

What do these have to do with common sense? This will take some sorting out in the next two chapters, but the basic idea is that an AI system may be able to do remarkably well on certain specific tasks that demand intelligence in humans, but still be unable to behave in an intelligent way more broadly. What we will end up saying is that these AI systems display expertise, not common sense.

考虑由 DeepMind Technologies 开发的名为 AlphaGo 的著名人工智能系统。在玩围棋游戏时，这个系统无疑是专家，并且可能是世界顶级围棋选手。但它什么都不做。它甚至没有与世界其他地方打交道的基本能力。我们永远不会期望它能够订购披萨、推荐电影或诊断血液感染。系统不能因此而受到批评；除了下围棋之外，它从未打算做任何事情。

Consider the well-known AI system called AlphaGo developed by DeepMind Technologies. This system is unquestionably an expert when it comes to playing the game of Go and likely the top Go player in the world. But it does nothing else. It doesn’t have even a rudimentary ability to deal with the rest of the world. We would never expect it to be able to order a pizza, recommend a movie, or diagnose a blood infection. The system can’t really be criticized for this; it was never intended to do anything other than play Go.

对于 AI 领域以外的人来说，不同的 AI 系统执行不同的任务这一事实似乎只是一个小细节。难道你不能把像 AlphaGo 这样的东西与 Roomba 和 Siri 结合起来，最终得到一个可以下围棋、吸尘地板和响应语音命令的系统吗？加上谷歌翻译，系统会不会不响应任何语言的语音命令？继续这样做足够长的时间，我们最终不会得到一个具有足够多功能性的系统来在现实世界中做好工作吗？

To someone outside the field of AI, the fact that different AI systems perform different tasks might seem like a small detail. Can’t you just take something like AlphaGo, marry it with Roomba and Siri, and end up with a system that plays Go, vacuums floors, and responds to voice commands? Throw in Google Translate, and will the system not respond to voice commands in any language? Keep on doing this long enough and will we not end up with a system with enough versatility to do a good job out there in the real world?

事情并没有变成这样。无论这些人工智能系统中的每一个都令人印象深刻，它们仍然相互隔离。它们就像可能行为的大海中的小岛，成就很高。在 AI 社区内，对于如何让系统在这些本地化专业领域之外以合理的方式运行，仍然没有明确的认识。即使我们想象一个人工智能系统配备了上述数百个常识指南，它仍然会在这些特定主题之外不知所措。

Things have not turned out this way. However impressive each of these AI systems is individually, they remain isolated from each other. They are like small islands of high achievement in a large sea of possible behaviors. There is still no clear sense within the AI community of how to get a system to behave in a reasonable way outside these localized areas of expertise. Even if we were to imagine an AI system armed with the hundreds of commonsense guides mentioned above, it would still be at a loss outside those specific topics.

举个小例子，上面列出的罕见水果和蔬菜指南可能会提到石榴，但几乎可以肯定没有提到洗衣篮。我们也不希望洗衣篮指南（或任何直接使用洗衣篮的经验）与石榴打交道。因此，如果我们现在想象一个 AI 系统必须决定一个石榴是否适合放入洗衣篮（出于某种原因），它需要的东西超出了它在每个单独主题上的能力。如果无法以有意义的方式将这两个独立的主题结合在一起，它将无法做出明智的决定。

To give a small example, the guide to uncommon fruits and vegetables listed above might well talk about pomegranates, but it almost certainly does not mention laundry baskets. Nor would we expect a guide for laundry baskets (or any direct experience with laundry baskets) to ever deal with pomegranates. So if we now imagine an AI system that has to decide whether a pomegranate would fit inside a laundry basket (for some reason), it will need something beyond what it has on each individual topic. It will be unable to make a sensible decision if it has no way of bringing these two separate topics together in a meaningful way.

人当然不是这样。我们完全希望一个擅长下围棋的人在广泛的非围棋活动中仍然表现出色，包括但不限于（如律师所说）吸尘地板和处理有关洗衣篮中石榴的问题. 这种以一种与任何特定领域的能力无关的方式处理出现的事情的能力正是我们对常识的期望。

This is of course not how things are in humans. We fully expect that a person who gets to be good at playing Go will still do well on a broad range of non-Go activities including, but not limited to (as the lawyers say), vacuuming floors and handling questions about pomegranates in laundry baskets. This ability to deal with what comes up in a way that is not tied to prowess in any particular domain is precisely what we expect of common sense.

我们并不是第一个观察到当前人工智能系统和人类在这方面存在差异的人。这是几乎所有人工智能科学家和技术专家都同意的一件事。然而，他们不同意的地方——有时甚至是非常大声地——是在其含义上。

We are not the first to observe that current AI systems and humans are different in this regard. It is one thing that virtually all AI scientists and technologists agree on. Where they do disagree, however—and sometimes quite loudly—is on what the implications are.

对于（可能被称为）AI 助推器，图片有点像这样：

For (what might be called) AI boosters, the picture is somewhat like this:

我们正处于人工智能的早期阶段，迄今为止构建的最好的系统已经具备智能，但显然与人类不同。“智能”终究不是一个有用的标签。这些系统在某些方面比人类做得更好，而在其他方面则更差。目标不是完全模仿人类的所有局限性和缺点，而是在各种各样的任务中以有用的智能方式行事。人工智能系统和与之共事的人类之间总会有强大的协同作用；每个人都会弥补另一个人的弱点。

We are in the early stages of AI, and the best of the systems built so far are already intelligent, but clearly not in the same way humans are. “Intelligent” is not a useful label in the end. The systems do better than humans in some ways, and worse in others. The goal is not to emulate humans to the letter, with all their limitations and failings, but rather to behave in a usefully intelligent way on a wide variety of tasks. There will always be a powerful synergy between AI systems and the humans they work with; each will make up for weaknesses in the other.

对于（可能被称为）AI 怀疑论者，包括许多 AI 研究人员自己，情况完全不同：

For (what might be called) AI skeptics, including many of the AI researchers themselves, the picture is quite different:

迄今为止构建的人工智能系统一点也不像智能。如果真正的人类智能是你所追求的，那么当前的整个人工智能方法都是错误的。撇开在围棋等超专业领域的熟练程度不谈。如果你不能像一个 6 岁的孩子一样好，那么你就不能在一般情况下比人类做得更好。迄今为止，还没有证据表明人工智能系统将拥有六岁儿童的一般智力。

The AI systems built to date are nothing like intelligent. If real human-level intelligence is what you are after, the whole current AI approach is wrongheaded. Put aside proficiency in ultraspecialized areas like playing Go. You can’t do better than humans in general terms if you can’t do as well as a six-year-old child. And there is no evidence to date that an AI system will ever have the general intelligence of a six-year-old.

继续这场争论不是我们本书的目标。其他人已经写过。我们的目标是只关注常识部分：常识意味着什么，它是如何工作的，构建具有它的计算系统可能需要什么，以及我们为什么要费心。

It is not our goal in this book to continue this debate; others have written about it. What we aim to do is to focus on just the common sense part: what common sense means, how it works, what it might take to build computational systems that have it, and why we should bother.

前方的路

The Road Ahead

冒着破坏所有悬念的风险，这里是本书的去向：

At the risk of spoiling all the suspense, here is where the book is going:

  • 第 2 章：人类的常识

    我们看看存在于人类中的常识。我们证明它与了解某些普通事物有关。我们认为常识是在决定行为方式时有效利用这些知识的能力，并且在人类认知能力范围内发挥着关键作用。

  • Chapter 2: Common Sense in Humans

    We look at the idea of common sense as it exists in humans. We make the case that it is tied to knowing certain ordinary things. We argue that common sense is the ability to make effective use of this knowledge in deciding how to behave and plays a critical role in the spectrum of human cognitive capabilities.

  • 第 3 章：AI 系统的专业知识

    我们将注意力转向过去和现在的人工智能系统。我们认为，无论这些系统是如何构建的，它们都提供了某些任务的专业知识，而不是常识。我们认为，常识不是另一个领域的额外专业知识的问题。如果我们想要 AI 系统能够处理现实生活中出现的各种意想不到的事情，就需要采用不同的方法。

  • Chapter 3: Expertise in AI Systems

    We turn our attention to AI systems past and present. We make the case that no matter how these systems are built, they deliver expertise on certain tasks, not common sense. We argue that common sense is not a matter of additional expertise in yet another area. If we want AI systems that can deal with the wide range of unanticipated things that come up in real life, a different approach is called for.

  • 第 4 章：知识及其表示

    我们考虑知识问题以及利用它可能意味着什么。我们认为，一项知识有点像一个数字，因为我们可以通过象征性地表示它并处理这些符号来使用它。对于数字，符号应该是什么以及如何对其进行操作是很好理解的；这就是我们所说的算术。这对于知识来说应该如何发挥作用还不太清楚，这是本书中间部分的主题。

  • Chapter 4: Knowledge and Its Representation

    We consider the issue of knowledge and what it might mean to make use of it. We contend that an item of knowledge is somewhat like a number in that we can make use of it by representing it symbolically and working on the symbols. In the case of numbers, what the symbols should be and how to operate on them is well understood; it’s what we call arithmetic. How this should play out for knowledge is much less clear and is the subject of the middle part of the book.

  • 第 5 章：对世界的常识性理解

    我们开始通过检查它所假定的世界的高级图景来考虑常识性知识：世界上有些事物的属性会随着事件的发生而随时间变化；在这些东西中，有些物理对象具有大小和空间位置等属性；在这些物理对象中，有具有信念和目标的生命代理人可以导致事件发生。

  • Chapter 5: A Commonsense Understanding of the World

    We begin to consider commonsense knowledge by examining the high-level picture of the world it presupposes: there are things in the world with properties that change over time as a result of events that occur; among these things, there are physical objects with properties like size and location in space; and among these physical objects, there are animate agents with beliefs and goals who can cause events to occur.

  • 第6章：常识性知识

    我们考虑如何制定特定的常识性知识项目。我们证明，除了处理事物及其属性之外，我们还需要处理概念——即关于可能存在的事物种类的想法。我们坚持认为，这些概念是根据典型、非典型和边缘案例来理解的。

  • Chapter 6: Commonsense Knowledge

    We consider how specific items of commonsense knowledge might be formulated. We make the case that in addition to dealing with things and their properties, we need to deal with concepts—that is, ideas about the kinds of things there can be. We maintain that these concepts are understood in terms of typical, atypical, and borderline cases.

  • 第 7 章：表示和推理，第一部分

    我们迈出了以符号形式表示常识性知识的第一步。我们争辩说我们想要代表事物及其属性与所涉及的概念分开。我们还讨论了计算系统如何使用这些表示进行推理。

  • Chapter 7: Representation and Reasoning, Part I

    We take the first step toward representing commonsense knowledge in symbolic form. We argue that we want to represent things and their properties separately from the concepts involved. We also talk about how a computational system would reason with these representations.

  • 第 8 章：表示和推理，第二部分

    我们在使用符号表示方面迈出了第二步。我们认为我们需要能够表示命题——可以为真或为假的句子——而不相信它们是真的。这对于推理使命题为真所需的条件是必不可少的——计划的基础。再一次，我们讨论计算系统如何对这些表示进行操作。

  • Chapter 8: Representation and Reasoning, Part II

    We take a second step in the use of symbolic representations. We contend that we need to be able to represent propositions—sentences that can be either true or false—without believing them to be true. This will be essential for reasoning about what it would take to make a proposition true—the basis for planning. And again, we talk about how a computational system would operate on these representations.

  • 第 9 章：行动常识

    我们回到高层次的常识，并展示各个部分如何组合在一起。我们考虑这样一种场景：代理人在执行例行任务时遇到完全出乎意料的事情，需要使用常识来弄清楚下一步该做什么。我们展示了如何将常识的这种应用理解为从前面章节中看到的那种符号表示计算特定结果。

  • Chapter 9: Common Sense in Action

    We return to common sense at a high level and show how the pieces fit together. We consider a scenario where an agent, while engaging in a routine task, encounters something totally unexpected and needs to use common sense to figure out what to do next. We show how this application of common sense can be understood as computing a certain result from symbolic representations of the sort seen in earlier chapters.

  • 第 10 章：实施步骤

    我们从更实际的角度来看如何构建具有常识的 AI 系统。除了考虑常识性推理之外，我们还花一些时间思考所有常识性知识的来源，并研究未来人工智能系统需要从经验和书面文本中学习的一些有趣方式。

  • Chapter 10: Steps toward Implementation

    We look in more practical terms at what it would take to build an AI system with common sense. Besides considering commonsense reasoners, we spend some time thinking about where all the commonsense knowledge will come from, and looking at some interesting ways in which AI systems of the future will need to learn from experience and written texts.

  • 第 11 章：建立信任

    我们开始考虑社会是否应该考虑用常识来构建人工智能系统。我们提出的理由是，如果我们要构建自己做出决定的系统，我们将希望他们对他们所做的事情有人类可以理解的理由，然后同意或不同意。特别是，我们希望他们拥有常识性知识和目标，并希望他们决定做什么是应用这些知识追求这些目标的结果。

  • Chapter 11: Building Trust

    We begin to wrap up by considering whether society should even be thinking about building AI systems with common sense. We make the case that if we are ever going to build systems that make decisions for themselves, we will want them to have reasons for what they do that humans can understand, and then agree or disagree with. In particular, we will want them to have commonsense knowledge and goals, and for their decisions about what to do to be the result of applying this knowledge in pursuit of those goals.

这本书还包括一个关于逻辑和常识推理之间联系的爱好者的奖励章节，以及为文本增添色彩并为感兴趣的读者提供更多资源的逐章注释。

The book also includes a bonus chapter for aficionados on the connection between logic and commonsense reasoning as well as chapter-by-chapter notes that add some color to the text and suggest further resources for the interested reader.

放样

Setting Out

因此，简而言之，这就是我们的旅程：从常识到常识知识，再到常识知识表示和推理。吃的东西很多。正如歌中所说，路漫漫其修远兮。这是一本关于常识的书，但并不是真正的常识指南。

So this is our journey in a nutshell: from common sense, to commonsense knowledge, to commonsense knowledge representation and reasoning. It’s a lot to take in. As the song says, the road is long with many a winding turn. This is a book about common sense, but not really much of a commonsense guide.

有些人想要相信人工智能的一个更简单的故事，我们可以采用某种学习系统，将其连接到互联网（或者可能将机器人推出门外），让它学会解决问题为自己。为什么某些版本的常识不能在一段时间内根植于世界而自发出现？所有这些关于通过知识的符号表示进行计算的讨论，对于常识来说可能感觉过于拘谨、过于拘束、过于理智。

There are those who want to believe in a much simpler story for AI, where we would take some sort of learning system, hook it up to the internet (or maybe push a robot out the door), and have it learn to figure things out for itself. Why can’t some version of common sense just emerge spontaneously from being embedded in the world over a period of time? All of this talk about computation over symbolic representations of knowledge might feel too mannered, too regimented, too cerebral for common sense.

虽然我们理解这个更简单的故事的直观吸引力，但目前还没有很好的说明它是如何工作的。也就是说，我们需要明确一点，我们将要在这里讲述的更复杂的故事只是一个假设——通向常识的一条可能途径。实际上，它很可能会变成死胡同，或者最终被更直接的高速公路所取代。但正如我们希望读者会看到的那样，从知识的角度来看，这仍然是一条值得追随的道路，沿途可以参观哲学、心理学、语言学、逻辑学和计算机科学方面的精彩站点。

While we understand the intuitive appeal of this simpler story, there is as yet no good specification of how it could possibly work. That said, we need to be clear that the more involved story we are about to tell here is only a hypothesis—one possible road to common sense. In practical terms, it could well turn out to be a dead end, or eventually be supplanted by more direct highways. But as we hope the reader will see, in intellectual terms, it is still a rewarding road to follow, with wonderful sites to visit along the way in philosophy, psychology, linguistics, logic, and computer science.

我们走的这条路，是我们自己在自己的工作中摸索了四十年的路。我们构建了 AI 系统，证明了 AI 定理，并领导了 AI 项目。与我们共事过的所有杰出人士以及我们参与主要国际 AI 组织的经历都让我们深受鼓舞。作为您这段旅程的向导，我们将尽最大努力使事情变得信息丰富、有趣和有趣。因此，系好安全带，享受旅途吧！

The road we are setting out on is one that we ourselves have explored for four decades in our own work. We have built AI systems, proved AI theorems, and led AI projects. We have been inspired by all the terrific people we have worked with and our involvement with the major international AI organizations. As your guides on this journey, we will do our best to make things informative, interesting, and fun. So buckle your seat belt and enjoy the trip!

2个

2

人类常识

Common Sense in Humans

常识是穿着工作服的天才。

Common sense is genius dressed in its working clothes.

——普遍归因于拉尔夫·沃尔多·爱默生

—popularly attributed to Ralph Waldo Emerson

在我们认真考虑赋予机器常识之前，我们首先需要很好地理解它是什么。作为一个严肃研究的课题，关于它的科学文献并不多。当然，我们确实对这个想法有某种直观的理解。我们在日常生活中经常使用这个词，例如互相告诫“使用一点常识”。那么这是什么意思呢？

Before we can seriously contemplate endowing machines with common sense, we first need to get a good understanding of what it is. As a topic of serious study, there is not much scientific literature on it. Of course, we do have some sort of intuitive understanding of the idea. We use the term frequently in daily life, admonishing each other to “use a little common sense,” for instance. So what do we mean by this?

在本章中，我们从多个角度审视了人类的常识，并创建了一个我们自己的工作定义——这是我们迈向具有常识的 AI 之旅的第一步。

In this chapter, we take a look at common sense in humans from several angles and create a working definition of our own—the first step on our journey toward AI with common sense.

常识的某些方面

Some Aspects of Common Sense

不难找到关于常识的有趣引述，除了上述爱默生的引述。这里有些例子：

It is not hard to find interesting quotes about common sense, beyond the one by Emerson above. Here are some examples:

  • • 爱因斯坦：“常识是 18 岁时形成的偏见的集合。”
  • • Albert Einstein: “Common sense is the collection of prejudices acquired by age eighteen.”
  • • Baron d'Holbach：“当我们审视人们的意见时[原文如此]，我们发现没有什么比常识更不寻常的了；或者，换句话说，他们缺乏判断力，无法发现明显的真理或拒绝荒谬和明显的矛盾。”
  • • Baron d’Holbach: “When we examine the opinions of men [sic], we find that nothing is more uncommon than common sense; or, in other words, they lack judgment to discover plain truths or to reject absurdities and palpable contradictions.”
  • • Josh Billings：“常识是按事物本来面目看待事物并按其应该做的方式做事的诀窍。”
  • • Josh Billings: “Common sense is the knack of seeing things as they are, and doing things as they ought to be done.”
  • • Bob Marley：“我是一个有常识的人。这意味着当我解释事情时，我会以一种非常简单的方式解释它；这意味着如果我向婴儿解释，婴儿也会理解，你知道的。”
  • • Bob Marley: “Me is a common sense man. That mean when me explain things, me explain it in a very simple way; that mean if I explain it to a baby, the baby will understand too, you know.”

这里有一些启发性的见解，突出了许多其他主题所强调的主题：常识来自经验；它是关于容易理解的事实和容易预见的问题；它支持做合理和适当的事情；它赞成简单的解释。

There are some revealing insights here, highlighting themes reinforced by many others: common sense is derived from experience; it’s about easily apprehended facts and easily foreseen problems; it supports doing things that are reasonable and appropriate; and it favors simple explanations.

让我们更详细地探讨这些元素。首先，人们普遍认为常识是通过个人经验而不是在学校或阅读中习得的。当然，一些常识性理解是通过与他人交谈或阅读指南等内容而形成的，但总的来说，我们对世界事物运作方式的理解是通过亲身体验来巩固的。

Let’s explore these elements in a little more detail. First, there is general agreement that common sense is learned through personal experience rather than in school or by reading. Certainly some commonsense understanding is seeded through conversations with others or reading things like guides, but by and large, our understanding of how things work in the world is solidified by experiencing them ourselves.

与常识相关的经验通常是相对平凡的、为一大群人所共有的日常生活的经验。这个群体可以是一种文化、一个民族，甚至可能是所有人类。我们希望群体中几乎所有成年人都知道某些事实和趋势。如果有人得出的结论没有利用这些众所周知的信息，我们认为他们没有使用常识。关于忽视“人人都知道”的批评很常见：“他为什么要那样做？每个人都知道你不能用叉子喝汤。” 我们在成长过程中学到了很多东西，我们希望其他人都知道，我们希望他们利用这些知识做出我们认为会做出的相同类型的决定。（这是“常识”的“共同”部分。）

The experiences that matter to common sense are generally those of relatively mundane, everyday life common to a large group of people. This group can be a culture, nationality, or maybe even all humans. We expect certain facts and tendencies to be known by virtually all the adults in the group. If someone draws a conclusion that fails to utilize such commonly known information, we think of them as not using common sense. Critiques about ignoring what “everyone knows” are familiar: “Why is he doing that? Everyone knows that you can’t eat soup with a fork.” There are many things that we learn growing up that we expect everyone else to know, and we expect them to use that knowledge to make the same kinds of decisions we believe we would make. (This is the “common” part of “common sense.”)

常识包括注意任何正常人应该显而易见的事情。例如，如果我们处于共享环境中，我们希望其他人考虑到该环境。如果一个朋友认为邻居家门前台阶上系着皮带的哈士奇犬是狼，我们会说他们没有使用常识。那将是对一个容易观察到的上下文的蔑视。相反，将那种情况下的动物判定为狗，即使它看起来有点像狼，也是符合常识的。

Common sense involves noticing things that ought to be apparent to any normal person. If we are in a shared context, for example, we expect others to take that context into account. If a friend thinks that a husky-looking canine on a leash sitting on a neighbor’s front doorstep is a wolf, we’d say they weren’t using common sense. That would be flouting an easily observable context. Conversely, deciding that an animal in that situation was a dog, even if it looked somewhat wolflike, would be commonsensical.

看到这些“平淡的事实”和“荒谬的事情”对于我们的内心世界也是必不可少的。常识的一个关键部分是能够（至少粗略地）想象行为的后果。我们使用大量经验的记忆以及对因果关系的直觉理解来预见什么会导致什么。因此，当常识建议一项行动优于另一项行动时，它是基于对将要发生的事情的预期在每种情况下。因此，常识可以帮助我们设想一项计划好的行动，比如试图驾车爬上一座被冰覆盖的陡峭山坡，是否会失败。在多个行动方案之间进行选择时，常识还可以让我们大致了解每个方案的成本和收益，以便我们可以快速比较选项。例如，它会告诉我们向邻居借东西的社会成本与去某个地方购买或租用它所带来的不便和货币成本相比如何。

Seeing these kinds of “plain truths” and “absurdities” is also essential in our internal mental world. A key part of common sense is being able to imagine (at least roughly) the consequences of actions. We use memories of lots of experiences along with an intuitive understanding of cause and effect to foresee what will lead to what. So when common sense suggests one action over another, it’s based on an expectation of what will happen in each case. Thus common sense helps us envision whether a planned action, like trying to drive up a steep hill covered in ice, might fail. When choosing between multiple courses of action, common sense also gives us a rough idea of the costs and benefits of each, so that we can quickly compare the options. For instance, it will tell us how the social cost of asking a neighbor to borrow something might compare to the inconvenience and monetary cost of going somewhere to buy or rent it.

所有这一切的基础是常识性思维通常是合理的。常识依赖于推理：从前提得出合理的结论。我们设想计划的一个步骤的结果将如何使下一步成为可能，例如乘出租车去机场、登机去罗马。我们直观地理解多个事实如何结合起来产生有用的新事实。我们希望常识能够根据逻辑依据和证据得出合理的结论。除非我们能够真正看到我们的观察结果、预期结果和其他事实如何组合在一起，否则我们无法做出常识性决定。（这是“常识”的“感觉”部分。）

Underlying all of this is the fact that commonsense thinking is generally sound. Common sense relies on inference: the drawing of sound conclusions from premises. We envision how the results of one step of a plan will make the next step possible, such as getting into a taxi in order to get to the airport in order to board a flight in order to get to Rome. We understand intuitively how multiple facts can combine to yield useful new ones. We expect common sense to illuminate a reasonable conclusion based on logical justifications and evidence. We cannot make a commonsensical decision unless we can actually see how the pieces of our observations, envisioned outcomes, and other facts fit together. (This is the “sense” part of “common sense.”)

重要的是，这些常识性推理既快速又容易。它们对我们来说是直觉的，而不是有意识的和详尽的推理。我们会想起与当前情况相关的一些过去的经验，并调整记忆中的观察以适应当前的需要。常识是一种肤浅的认知现象，与深思熟虑、有条不紊的分析相比，它的运作速度更快。如果需要大量的脑力劳动才能弄清楚，这不是常识。我们可以将其视为“反思性思维”，“反思性”与“思考”一样重要。

Importantly, these kinds of commonsense inferences are quick and easy. They occur to us as intuitive rather than as consciously and exhaustively reasoned. We’re reminded of some past experience related to our current situation, and adapt a remembered observation to fit a current need. Common sense is a shallow cognitive phenomenon, operating quickly compared to thoughtful, methodical analysis. It’s not common sense if it takes a sizable amount of mental effort to figure it out. We can think of it as “reflexive thinking,” with the “reflexive” being as significant as the “thinking.”

与复杂推理形成鲜明对比的是，常识对简单的解释表现出强烈的亲和力。它遵循奥卡姆剃刀原则：当一个明显更简单的现象可用时，对某些现象的复杂解释是不合常理的。作家詹姆斯·惠特科姆·赖利 (James Whitcomb Riley) 抓住了其中的一个重要部分，他有一句名言：“当我看到一只鸟走路像鸭子、游泳像鸭子、叫声像鸭子时，我就称那只鸟为鸭子。” 虽然对于类似鸭子的物体可能还有其他可能的解释，但如果它像鸭子一样走路、游泳和嘎嘎叫，那么常识性的结论是它是一只鸭子。

Related to its contrast with complex reasoning, common sense displays a strong affinity for simple explanations. It follows Occam’s razor: a convoluted account of some phenomenon when a clearly simpler one is available is not commonsensical. Author James Whitcomb Riley captured an important part of this when he famously said, “When I see a bird that walks like a duck and swims like a duck and quacks like a duck, I call that bird a duck.” While there may be other possible explanations for a duck-like object, if it walks and swims and quacks like one, the commonsensical conclusion is that it’s a duck.

最后，正如我们在前一章的常识指南中指出的那样，常识通常与专业知识有所区别。常识指南帮助我们学习如何以快速、直观的方式做事，明确针对那些不渴望专家的专业能力的观众。稍后我们将更多地谈论专业知识，但简而言之，我们不会要求常识来指导我们计算行星外太空飞行器的轨迹，甚至用六个不同的遥控器重新配置家庭影院系统（这有时感觉就像火箭科学）。但我们确实依靠常识来防止我们做一些愚蠢的事情，比如在一个小时内什么都没有发生后继续等待炉子上的水烧开，或者把一把锋利的刀放在幼儿可以拿到的矮咖啡桌上。

Finally, as we noted with the commonsense guides in the previous chapter, common sense is often distinguished from expertise. Commonsense guides help us learn how to do things in quick, intuitive ways, explicitly targeting audiences that don’t aspire to the specialized proficiency of experts. We will have much more to say about expertise later, but in a nutshell, we would not call on common sense to guide us in computing the trajectory of an extraplanetary space vehicle or even reconfiguring a home theater system with its six different remote controls (which can sometimes feel like rocket science). But we do rely on common sense to keep us from doing silly things like continuing to wait for water to boil on the stove after nothing has happened for an hour, or leaving a sharp knife on a low coffee table where a toddler could reach it.

常识的定义

A Definition of Common Sense

列出了基础知识后，我们现在可以考虑更精心设计的常识视图。关于什么是常识，有很多观点，而且很容易与人们可能提出的几乎任何定义争论不休。但正如我们所见，有一些关键因素将它与其他精神现象区分开来，并且人们普遍同意这些因素。基于此（以及我们在知识及其在 AI 系统中的应用方面的经验），我们提出了一个工作定义，它将指导我们在本书其余部分的处理：

Having laid out the basics, we can now consider a more carefully crafted view of common sense. There are many opinions on what common sense is about, and it is easy to argue with almost any definition one might propose. But as we have seen, there are some key elements that distinguish it from other mental phenomena and on which there is much general agreement. Based on this (and our experience with knowledge and its use in AI systems), we propose a working definition that will guide our treatment in the rest of the book:

  • 常识是有效利用普通的、日常的、经验性的知识来实现​​普通的、日常的、实际的目标的能力。
  • Common sense is the ability to make effective use of ordinary, everyday, experiential knowledge in achieving ordinary, everyday, practical goals.

我们在这里使用的许多词都是通用的和非技术性的，因此有必要进行一些详细说明。鉴于我们到目前为止所说的内容，该定义反映了以下要点：

Many of the words we’ve used here are general and nontechnical, so a bit of elaboration is warranted. Given what we have said so far, the definition reflects these important points:

  • • “有效”提醒我们仅仅知道很多相关的事情是不够的。使用常识意味着能够成功地运用这些知识，而不会被淹没以找出它如何与手头的目标相关。这些知识的应用应该是快速和轻松的。
  • • “Effective” reminds us that it is not enough to merely know a lot of relevant things. Using common sense means being able to work through this knowledge successfully without being overwhelmed in order to find out how it bears on the goals at hand. The application of this knowledge should be fast and effortless.
  • • “普通”和“日常”暗示常识处理人类在日常生活中经常遇到的那种情况。开发和展示它不需要专门的教育和专家分析技能。它最常见的是关于平凡、熟悉的事物。
  • • “Ordinary” and “everyday” imply that common sense deals with situations of the sort that humans regularly encounter in day-to-day life. Specialized education and expert analytic skills are not needed to develop and exhibit it. It is most frequently about mundane, familiar things.
  • • “经验”强调常识是从重复经验中获得的知识。它通常不是来自学校教育或技术阅读。常识可以从一个人传给另一个人，但它通常来自个人经验。
  • • “Experiential” emphasizes that what counts as common sense is knowledge gained from repeated experience. It generally does not come from schooling or technical reading. Common wisdom can be passed from one person to another, but it is generally derived from personal experiences.
  • • “实用”强调常识是用来选择在日常生活中要做什么才能取得成功。我们不认为它是某种学术追求或哲学论证的基础。
  • • “Practical” stresses that common sense is for making choices about what to do to be successful in the everyday world. We do not think of it as some kind of academic pursuit or foundation for philosophical argumentation.

心理学文献强调了常识的实用性。心理学家罗伯特·斯腾伯格 (Robert Sternberg) 花了数年时间发展了一种他称之为“成功智力”的理论，该理论与在一个人的文化背景下设定和完成对个人有意义的目标的能力有关。Sternberg 的框架主要关注适应性行为，将智能理解为主要关于适应环境的能力。他假设了四种关键的能力类型：分析能力、创造性能力、实践能力和基于智慧的能力。关于其中的第三个，他是这样说的：“实用的智慧就是大多数人所说的常识。” 斯腾伯格和他的合作者理查德·瓦格纳认为，实用智能主要基于隐性知识——也就是说，“在特定环境中，一个人需要知道什么才能取得成功，这些知识没有明确说明，而且通常甚至没有用语言表达。” 他们的理论强调个人经验的作用，并表明这种隐性知识是程序性的——关于知道如何在特定情况下采取行动。正如我们已经明确表示的，我们同意前者，但据我们估计，常识推理背后的大部分隐性知识都是陈述性的（即事实性的）。

The practicality aspect of common sense is one that is underscored by the psychology literature. Psychologist Robert Sternberg has spent years developing a theory of what he calls “successful intelligence,” related to the ability to set and accomplish personally meaningful goals within one’s cultural context. Sternberg’s framework focuses heavily on adaptive behavior, understanding intelligence as primarily about the ability to adapt to the environment. He postulates four key types of abilities: analytical, creative, practical, and wisdom based. Regarding the third of these, he says this: “Practical intelligence is what most people call common sense.” Sternberg and his collaborator, Richard Wagner, contend that practical intelligence is based largely on tacit knowledge—that is, “what one needs to know to succeed in a particular environment that is not explicitly stated and often that is not even verbalized.” Their theory emphasizes the role of personal experience and suggests that this tacit knowledge is procedural—about knowing how to act in particular situations. As we have made clear, we agree with the former, but in our estimation, much of the tacit knowledge underlying commonsense inference is declarative (that is, factual).

我们对常识的定义显然与通常所说的理性相关，心理学家史蒂芬平克将其描述为“运用知识实现目标的能力”。这两个概念的不同之处在于理性要广泛得多；它不限制可以应用的知识或推理的种类或复杂性。常识处理的是世俗的、经验性的知识，而理性可以处理专家知识，需要比单纯的常识更仔细、更彻底地应用。例如，医生可能想要决定患者是否应该接受某种癌症治疗。考虑到患者刚刚检测出这种癌症呈阳性，做出理性决策需要仔细权衡检测的可靠性与癌症排在首位。毫无疑问，这是一件明智的事情，但远远超出了我们对常识的期望。

Our definition of common sense is clearly related to what is usually called rationality, characterized by the psychologist Steven Pinker as “the ability to use knowledge to attain goals.” Where the two concepts differ is that rationality is much broader; it does not constrain the kind or complexity of knowledge or reasoning that can be applied. Whereas common sense deals with mundane, experiential knowledge, rationality can deal with expert knowledge and require a more careful and thorough application than mere common sense. For example, a doctor may want to decide if a patient should undergo a certain cancer therapy. Given that the patient has just tested positive for this cancer, rational decision-making requires carefully weighing the reliability of the test against the unlikeliness of the cancer in the first place. A sensible thing to do, no doubt, but well beyond what we would expect of common sense.

请注意，我们需要将常识性知识（事实、模式、原则和概括）与常识性推理（以特定方式利用该知识的能力）区分开来。当我们说某人有常识或使用常识时，我们通常是指他们不仅拥有相关知识，而且能够适当地使用它。

Note that we need to distinguish commonsense knowledge—facts, patterns, principles, and generalizations—from commonsense reasoning—the ability to make use of that knowledge in certain ways. When we say that someone has common sense or uses common sense, we usually mean that they not only have the relevant knowledge but also can make appropriate use of it.

关于“知识”这个词本身，我们正在遵循 AI 中常见的做法，即抛开知识和信念之间的区别，或多或少地互换使用这两个术语。（哲学上的区分更仔细。）当我们谈论常识性知识时，严格来说，我们真正的意思是常识性信念，允许其中一些信念可能是错误的或出于错误的原因而持有。常识并不局限于保证正确或完全相信的信念；这些太少了。有利的是，“知识”一词的使用方式与“信仰”一词不同：我们可以用“知道”来组成有用的句子，而我们不能用“相信”来组成。例如，我们可以说，“哈利知道安拿着什么牌”，但我们不能说，“哈利相信安拿着什么牌。” （要正确使用“信念”，我们需要说些尴尬的话，比如“有一张牌，哈利相信安拿着那张牌。”）顺便说一句，虽然我们当然意识到有度数就信念而言，从最单纯的怀疑到绝对确定，我们不会在本书中过多讨论如何得出或管理这些度数的数值，或者这如何与其他常识相吻合。

Regarding the word “knowledge” itself, we are following the practice common in AI of putting aside the difference between knowledge and belief, and using the terms more or less interchangeably. (The distinction is made more carefully in philosophy.) When we talk about commonsense knowledge, what we really mean, strictly speaking, is commonsense belief, allowing that some of these beliefs might be mistaken or held for the wrong reasons. Common sense does not limit itself to beliefs that are guaranteed to be correct or held with total conviction; there are too few of those. To its advantage, the term “knowledge” can be used in ways that have no equivalent with the term “belief”: we can form useful sentences with “know” that we can’t with “believe.” For example, we can say, “Harry knows what card Ann is holding,” but we can’t say, “Harry believes what card Ann is holding.” (To use “belief” correctly, we would need to say something awkward like, “There is a card such that Harry believes that Ann is holding that card.”) Incidentally, while we certainly realize that there are degrees of belief, from the merest of suspicions to absolute certainty, we will not have much to say in this book about how numerical values for these degrees might be arrived at or managed, or how this would dovetail with the rest of common sense.

常识的自下而上和自上而下的使用

Bottom-up and Top-down Uses of Common Sense

既然我们已经了解了常识的关键方面，那么讨论何时以及如何使用它是很有用的。如前所述，常识是关于对日常情况的实际反应。我们可以将它的调用方式分为两大类，我们可以称之为自下而上和自上而下的类型：

Now that we have an understanding of the crucial aspects of common sense, it is useful to talk about when and how it is used. As noted, common sense is about practical responses to everyday situations. We can divide the ways in which it is invoked into two general categories, which we might call bottom-up and top-down types:

  • • 自下而上（或事件驱动）是您观察、注意或察觉到不寻常的事情并想对其有所了解的地方。它可以是当你从事一些以目标为导向的活动或只是坐在椅子放松。不寻常的事情可以是意外发生的事情，也可以是预期中没有发生的事情。你觉得有必要为你所看到的找到一个简单、直观的解释。
  • • The bottom-up (or event-driven) ones are where you observe, notice, or perceive something unusual and want to make some sense of it. It can be while you’re engaged in some goal-directed activity or just sitting in a chair relaxing. The unusual thing can be something that happens unexpectedly or something expected that does not happen. You feel compelled to find a simple, intuitive explanation for what you have seen.
  • • 自上而下（或目标驱动）的是您正在考虑做什么，并且需要比较当前情况或未来情况下的备选方案。这可能涉及从事一项活动相对于另一项活动的潜在成本和收益。对于成本，有风险、失败的机会、负面影响、社会考虑等因素。收益方面涉及备选方案可能有多成功，或者其结果有多可取。
  • • The top-down (or goal-driven) ones are where you are considering what to do, and need to compare alternatives in your current situation or a future circumstance. This can involve the potential cost and benefit of engaging in one activity over another. For the cost, there are things like risk, the chance of failure, negative side effects, social considerations, and the like. The benefit aspect involves how successful an alternative is likely to be, or how preferable its result.

让我们从自下而上的场景开始。我们每天所做的很多事情就像在自动驾驶仪上运行。我们经常陷入例行公事，使我们从一个地方到另一个地方，并允许我们反射性地执行许多正常生活的活动。我们走路、刷牙、运动，甚至在大部分时间里都没有太多有意识地去上班。即使我们遵循了一个深思熟虑的计划，当我们开始执行计划的步骤时，我们也会陷入例行公事的行为，比如关上我们家的门，走向我们的车，打开车门，调整我们的座位在开始有意识地计划的汽车旅行之前。基于重复的经验，这些例行化的步骤具有一定的内在期望。当期望得到满足时，我们甚至不会注意到。当我们关上前门时，我们希望它能锁住；当我们启动汽车时，我们希望仪表盘亮起，风扇启动，收音机继续播放。这些事情是自动完成的，以至于我们完成后甚至都不记得它们。我们的思想可以自由地考虑其他事情，例如我们计划去哪里买晚餐吃的食物或工作中的重要演讲。

Let’s start with the bottom-up scenario. Much of what we do each day is like running on a kind of autopilot. We regularly fall into routines that get us from one place to another and allow us to reflexively perform many of the activities of regular life. We walk, brush our teeth, play sports, and even commute to work for the most part without much conscious thought. Even if we are following a well thought-out plan, as we are starting to execute the plan’s steps, we lapse into routinized behavior, like closing the door to our house, walking to our car, unlocking the car door, and adjusting our seat before setting out on a consciously planned car trip. These routinized steps have a certain set of expectations built in, based on repeated experience. When the expectations are met, we don’t even notice. When we close the front door, we expect it to latch and lock; when we start the car, we expect the dashboard to light up, fan to start, and radio to go on. These things are done so automatically that we don’t even remember them after we’ve done them. Our minds are free to think about other things, such as where we’re planning to pick up food for dinner or an important presentation at work.

但有时，建立在例行公事期望中的事情并没有发生。如果门没有关好或汽车没有启动，我们换个心理档位；我们从例行公事中惊醒，进入某种解决问题的模式。我们对自己说，“等一下。这里发生了什么？” （请注意，意外情况可能是在定期经历的时间间隔后不会发生的事情，例如当我们等了 20 分钟但我们点的咖啡仍未送达。）

But sometimes things built into a routine’s expectations fail to occur. If the door doesn’t close well or the car doesn’t start, we change mental gears; we are jolted from the routine and go into some sort of problem-solving mode. We say to ourselves, “Hold on a second. What’s going on here?” (Note that the unexpected could be something that does not happen after a regularly experienced time interval, as when we’ve waited for twenty minutes and our coffee order still has not arrived.)

当我们被这些干扰扰乱时，常识是直接的解决办法。在某些情况下，我们以前也遇到过类似的问题，以前学习的套路可以帮助我们快速诊断和修复：如果一扇门没有关上，我们会不自觉地低头看看门和门框之间是否有东西卡住，然后把一个玩具推开；如果车灯不亮，我们试着记住昨晚是否开着车头灯，并检查汽车的电池是否没电。这些不像我们以前从事的活动那样无脑，但我们也没有使用任何复杂的问题解决方法。如前所述，常识的一部分是与生俱来的寻找简单、熟悉的解释的冲动。如果我们第一个基于常识的问题诊断方法不起作用，当然我们仍然可以求助于更详细的问题解决，并想象我们的方法来解决更罕见或更不寻常的原因：也许有人在前面系了一根弹力绳开玩笑的门；也许新的警报系统联锁关闭了汽车。但我们不会先去那里。当我们的常规行为遇到意想不到的事情时，常识会作为第一响应者发挥作用。它针对常见问题提供基于经验的快速解释和解决方案。

Common sense is the immediate resort when we are jarred by these interruptions. In some cases, we’ve experienced similar problems before, and previously learned routines help us make quick diagnoses and repairs: if a door is not closing, we automatically look down to see if something is caught between the door and jamb, and push a toy out of the way; if the car lights do not come on, we try to remember if we left the headlights on last night, and check to see if the car’s battery is dead. These are not as mindless as the activities we were engaged in before, but we don’t use any kind of complex problem-solving either. As mentioned, one part of common sense is the innate urge to find simple, familiar explanations. If our first, commonsense-based approach to diagnosing a problem doesn’t work, of course we may still resort to more detailed problem-solving, and imagine our way through rarer or more unusual causes: maybe someone attached a bungee cord to the front door as a joke; perhaps the new alarm system interlock shut down the car. But we don’t go there first. Common sense jumps into play as the first responder when our regular behavior is met with something unexpected. It provides rapid, experience-based explanations and solutions for common problems.

顺便说一句，我们似乎特别倾向于注意到其他人未能使用常识的情况。许多父母都熟悉需要解决这些失误：“你在 11 点 55 分离开萨莉的家，你知道开车回家需要 20 分钟。你没想过会错过午夜宵禁吗？” 我们的常识识别技能得到了很好的磨练，我们常常倾向于要求别人“使用一些常识”。

Incidentally, we seem especially inclined to notice when others fail to use common sense. Familiar to many parents is the need to address these lapses: “You left Sally’s house at 11:55 and you know it takes twenty minutes to drive home. Didn’t it occur to you that you’d miss your midnight curfew?” Our commonsense recognition skills are well honed, and we are often inclined to ask others to “use some common sense.”

现在转向自上而下的场景，在这些场景中我们正在制定计划以实现目标。在制定简单的计划时——无需笔和纸或计算机来帮助我们——我们利用基于经验的力量在脑海中设想关键步骤及其可能的结果。即使没有世界一流的逻辑技能，我们也可以在心理上以定性的方式将我们的活动投射到未来。我们在日常活动中一直这样做，只考虑提前一两步，比如想象步行到厨房打开冰箱寻找饮料，或者提前很多步，比如想象去机场的旅行，海外航班，以及我们将如何在抵达休息室会面。常识是这种前瞻性预测的有力帮助，也是我们决定做某事时通常的第一选择。

Turning now to top-down scenarios, these are situations in which we are making plans in order to achieve goals. In making simple plans—without pen and paper or a computer to assist us—we use our experience-based power to mentally envision the key steps and their likely outcomes. Even without world-class skills in logic, we can all mentally project our activity into the future in a qualitative way. We do this all the time in everyday activity, thinking only a step or two ahead, like picturing a walk to the kitchen to open the refrigerator to look for something to drink, or many steps ahead, such as imagining a trip to the airport, a flight overseas, and how we will be met at the arrival lounge. Common sense is a powerful aid in such forward projection and our usual first resort when we decide we want to do something.

如前所述，在此计划活动中，以前的经验使我们能够将明显的因素考虑在内，以快速确定预期的行动是否可能失败（如果是星期天，邮局关闭将阻止我们取包裹），是否有可能是计划步骤中的风险（如果即将到来的高速公路没有加油站，我们可能会用完燃料），或者实现相同目标的两种替代方式的相对风险和回报（如果是高峰时间，通常较快的高速公路可能会堵塞，但表面街道上有许多红绿灯）。

As noted, in this planning activity, previous experience allows us to take the obvious factors into account to quickly determine if a contemplated action might fail (if it’s Sunday, the post office being closed will prevent us from picking up a package), whether there could be risks in a plan’s step (if the upcoming stretch of highway has no gas stations, we could run out of fuel), or the relative risks and rewards of two alternative ways to achieve the same goal (if it’s rush hour, the normally faster expressway may be jammed, but the surface streets have many traffic lights).

然而，尽管我们都有能力进行深思熟虑，但有些人至少偶尔会很不善于权衡预期计划步骤的资产和负债。地铁站需要张贴告示，告诫人们不要跳到轨道上找回掉落的手机。喜剧演员 Jerry Seinfeld 讲述了一件万圣节超级英雄服装的故事，制造商认为有义务在其中加入一条警告，禁止穿着它尝试飞行。这些类型的通知清楚地证明常识并不总能赢得我们注意力的心理战。

While we are all capable of forethought, however, some people are at least occasionally quite poor at weighing the assets and liabilities of contemplated plan steps. Subway stations need to post signs admonishing people not to jump onto the tracks to recover dropped cell phones. Comedian Jerry Seinfeld tells the story of a Halloween superhero costume whose manufacturer felt obligated to include a warning not to attempt to fly while wearing it. These kinds of notices are clear evidence that common sense doesn’t always win the mental battle for our attention.

请注意，自下而上和自上而下的上下文可以交织在一起。意外事件打断了正在进行的计划。如果我们在去参加会议的途中把咖啡洒在自己身上，我们将进入常识性的重新计划模式，设想我们是否有时间回家进行改变，以及走什么路线。有时在执行计划时，我们会在潜在问题发生之前对其做出反应。例如，当我们将托盘放在咖啡桌上时，我们可能会想，“等等。我可能不应该把这些开胃小菜留在这里，否则狗会跑过来吃掉它们。” 我们没有预料到这一点，因为我们专注于为客人提供食物并俯身将托盘放在桌子上。在这种情况下，我们例行执行一个熟悉的计划可能会让我们处于麻烦的边缘，

Note that bottom-up and top-down contexts can be intertwined. Unexpected events interrupt plans that are underway. If we spill coffee on ourselves during our travel to a meeting, we will spring into commonsense replanning mode to envision whether we have time to return home to change, and by what route. Sometimes while executing plans, we react to potential problems just before they happen. For example, just as we’re placing a tray on a coffee table, we might think, “Hang on. I probably shouldn’t leave these hors d’oeuvres here, or the dog will run over and start eating them.” We didn’t envision that as we were focused on getting food to our guests and leaned down to place the tray on the table. In this kind of case, our routine execution of a familiar plan can leave us on the brink of trouble, but then we catch ourselves—hopefully before something bad happens—and know that what we’re about to do or have just done is problematic.

我们可以很容易地看到常识自下而上和自上而下运作的一个生活领域是语言的使用。一方面，我们倾听人们的声音并试图理解他们所说的话，另一方面，我们为了自己的目的决定自己说些什么。有时语言是如此浅薄以至于我们将单词连接在一起，比如动词和它们的主语、名词和它们的修饰语，或者代词和它们的指代物，就像我们上面提到的自动驾驶仪一样。但在存在潜在歧义的情况下，常识就会发挥作用。

One area of life where we can easily see both the bottom-up and top-down operation of common sense is in the use of language. On the one hand, we listen to people and try to make sense of what they are saying, and on the other hand, we decide on things to say ourselves for our own purposes. Sometimes the language is so shallow that we connect words together, like verbs and their subjects, nouns and their modifiers, or pronouns and their referents, on what feels like the autopilot we mentioned above. But in instances where there is potential ambiguity, common sense comes into play.

要了解这一点，请阅读以下句子：

To see this, read the following sentence:

大球撞穿了桌子，因为它是钢制的。

The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of steel.

句子中的“它”在技术上是模棱两可的：它可能是球，也可能是桌子。然而，我们立即并本能地想象一个沉重的金属球落在桌子上并撞穿。我们不认为“它”指的是桌子，我们甚至不考虑桌子可能是由什么制成的。重金属物品可以击穿非金属物品，这是常识。有趣的是，如果我们改变句子中的单个词，推理就会大不相同：

The “it” in the sentence is technically ambiguous: it could be the ball, or it could be the table. Yet we immediately and instinctively picture a heavy metal ball falling on a table and crashing through. We don’t think of the “it” as referring to the table, and we don’t even think about what the table might be made of. It’s just common sense that heavy, metal things can break through items not made of metal. Interestingly, the reasoning is quite different if we change a single word in the sentence:

那个大球从桌子上掉了下来，因为它是硬纸板做的。

The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of cardboard.

我们对易碎物体的了解让我们想象一张硬纸板桌子，几乎所有中等重量的球都能突破。我们只是不记得另一种可能性，即“它”可能是一个纸板做的球。这些类型的推论是快速自动做出的，并且牢固地基于对世界的常识性理解。

Our knowledge of flimsy objects causes us to picture a cardboard table with almost any moderately heavy kind of ball breaking through. We just don’t call to mind the other possibility that the “it” could be a ball made of cardboard. These kinds of inferences are made quickly and automatically, and are firmly based on a commonsense understanding of the world.

以上所有关键的共同特征是推理不需要专业领域的专家，如材料科学或动物行为或汽车机械师，来解决问题或预测结果。它们代表了日常情况，在这些情况下，具有正常经验的普通人可以在很大程度上基于他们自己过去所做的观察，而无需多少认知努力就可以预测或解释事件。

The crucial shared characteristic of all the above is that the reasoning does not take an expert in a specialized domain, like materials science or animal behavior or car mechanics, to figure things out or predict consequences. They represent everyday situations in which average people with normal experiences can predict or explain events with little cognitive effort, based heavily on observations they themselves have made in the past.

什么是常识？

What Is Common Sense For?

鉴于其运作方式，常识如何在人类认知的大局中提供价值？为什么我们有它？

Given the way it works, how does common sense provide value in the big picture of human cognition? Why exactly do we have it?

人类认知架构通常被认为有两个端点：运行我们日常自动驾驶活动的反射性动作组件，以及支持深入思考和有意识解决问题的更有条理的分析组件。反身动作自动驾驶仪让我们从有意识的注意力中卸下我们每天所做的大部分工作。分析部分使我们能够利用我们特别是人类的更高层次的智慧来解决复杂的技术问题、未来的计划、深思熟虑的写作以及建设和维护文明的一般活动。

The human cognitive architecture is generally conceived of as having two end points: a reflexive action component that runs our routine autopilot activity, and a more methodical analytic component that supports in-depth deliberation and conscious problem-solving. The reflexive action autopilot lets us off-load from our conscious attention a huge portion of what we do every day. The analytic component allows us to bring our particularly human higher-level intelligence to bear on complex technical problems, future plans, thoughtful writing, and the general activity of building and maintaining civilization.

常识是让这一切在外力导致事情超出我们控制的世界中有效运作的关键。通过对日常活动中出现的问题提供第一反应，它避免了为出现的每个小问题调用我们更高层次的认知系统的全部力量。常识提供的那种浅薄的经验驱动的思维可以解决我们每天遇到的大部分小障碍，因此它为我们的自动驾驶仪提供了强大的后盾。常识背后的经验范围使其适用于广泛的环境，而其对世界模式的广泛观察的基础使其在大多数情况下都能取得成功。

Common sense is the key to allowing this all to work effectively in a world where exogenous forces cause things to happen outside our control. By providing the first response to problems arising during routine activities, it avoids calling on the full power of our higher-level cognitive system for every little issue that comes up. The kind of shallow experience-driven thinking that common sense offers can handle a majority of the small hurdles we encounter every day, and thus it supplies a robust backstop for our autopilot. The scope of experience underlying common sense allows it to apply in a broad set of circumstances, and its basis in extensive observation of patterns in the world allows it to be successful most of the time.

复杂的思考和解决问题需要耗费大量精力和时间。因此，作为中介的常识可以帮助我们的大脑节省宝贵的能量，并提供快速的基于经验的捷径来得出结论，否则这些结论可能需要冗长的推理。在许多情况下，反应时间至关重要，常识使我们能够迅速采取行动。在这方面，它实际上可以成为救星。因此，常识提供了一种位于我们认知范围的反身端和分析端之间的关键能力。它使前者更加健壮，并保留后者以用于它最适合的更具挑战性的工作。

Complex thinking and problem-solving is energy intensive and time-consuming. So common sense as an intermediary helps our brains to save precious energy and provides fast experience-based shortcuts to conclusions that might otherwise take lengthy reasoning. In many situations, reaction time is critical, and common sense allows us to act quickly. In that respect, it can be literally a lifesaver. Thus common sense provides a linchpin capability situated between the reflexive and analytic ends of our cognitive spectrum. It makes the former more robust and preserves the latter for the more challenging work for which it is best suited.

这个想法得到了一些有趣的心理学研究的支持。判断和决策领域的心理学家肯尼斯哈蒙德和其他人声称，在他们称之为直觉和分析的端点之间存在认知连续体。在他们看来，认知的中间形式包括直觉和分析的结合，这与我们对常识的理解相一致，即常识基本上是合乎逻辑的，但快速、浅薄且由记忆驱动。哈蒙德称常识在连续体上的位置为“准理性”。（这描述得很好，但我们将在接下来的旅程中坚持使用“常识”。）

This idea is backed up by some interesting work in psychology. Psychologist Kenneth Hammond and others in the field of judgment and decision-making claim that there is a cognitive continuum between endpoints that they call intuition and analysis. In their view, intermediate forms of cognition include combinations of both intuition and analysis, which aligns with our understanding of common sense as basically logical, but rapid, shallow, and memory driven. Hammond calls the position of common sense on the continuum “quasi-rationality.” (That’s nicely descriptive, but we’ll stick with “common sense” for the rest of our journey.)

即使我们的分析能力得到充分利用，常识仍将继续发挥关键作用。在使用互联网和电子表格计划复杂的旅行时，我们仍然依靠常识来填补许多子步骤的空白。例如，我们不打算将手放在车门的哪个位置才能上出租车。常识允许我们跳过那部分，并设想去机场的旅程的开始和结束。换句话说，即使是最深思熟虑和最分析性的问题解决也依赖于常识的基础。这实际上对于一般的推理来说是正确的：常识用普通的胶水填补了更深奥的步骤之间的空白，使我们能够得出完整的合理推理链。

Even when our analytic capabilities are fully engaged, common sense continues to play a key role. When planning a complex trip using the internet and a spreadsheet, we still rely on common sense to fill in gaps for many of the substeps. For example, we don’t plan on where we will put our hand on the door to get into a taxi. Common sense allows us to skip that part, and envision the start and end of a ride to the airport. In other words, even the most thoughtful and analytic problem-solving relies on a foundation of common sense. This is in fact true for reasoning in general: common sense fills in the blanks between more esoteric steps with the mundane glue that allows us to derive complete chains of sound inferences.

最后，我们注意到常识以一种使我们能够有效利用大量经验的方式发挥作用。也许我们可以进化到记住我们曾经有过的每一次经历的每一个细节，就像一个完美的录像机。但如果真是这样，寻找相关的先前经验来指导我们在新情况下的工作将是一项繁重的搜索任务。相反，我们的记忆通常更加刻板。我们将我们经历过的许多相似事物聚合成通用模式，从而合并多种体验。像弗雷德里克·巴特利特爵士这样的心理学家已经表明，我们以图式化的方式记住事物，并且记忆的使用是重建的，而不是简单地等同于重播电影。我们都知道我们的记忆是多么的有缺陷，以及我们有时如何将一个记忆中的经历与另一个相似的经历混淆。但是，尽管这种普遍的记忆会导致问题（例如，众所周知，它会使人们成为糟糕的目击者），出于常识的目的，这是一个功能，而不是错误。有了这个机制，我们就可以学习跨越多个经验的聚合课程，而不必单独记住它们，当我们需要将这些经验带入承担时，我们可以使用一个通用的记忆版本，而不必理清大量相似经验之间的差异回忆。

Finally, we note that common sense plays its roles in a way that allows us to make efficient use of enormous amounts of experience. Perhaps we could have evolved to remember every single detail of every single experience we ever had, like a perfect video recorder. But if that were the case, finding a relevant prior experience to guide us in a new situation would be a burdensome search task. Instead, our memories are generally more stereotyped; we aggregate many similar things we experience into generic patterns that coalesce multiple experiences. Psychologists like Sir Frederic Bartlett have shown that we remember things in a schematized way and that memory use is reconstructive, rather than simply the equivalent of replaying a movie. We all know how our memories are flawed, and how we sometimes confuse one remembered experience with another that was similar. But while this kind of generalized memory can lead to problems (it famously makes people bad eyewitnesses, for example), for the purposes of common sense, it’s a feature, not a bug. With this mechanism, we can learn aggregated lessons across multiple experiences and not have to remember them individually, and when we need to bring these experiences to bear, we can use a generic remembered version without having to sort out the differences between large numbers of similar memories.

正如我们将在本书后面看到的那样，如果只有有限数量的事情会发生在我们身上，或者如果每件事都在我们的控制之下，我们可能甚至不需要常识。但鉴于我们生活在现实世界中，其他代理人和现象不断增加发生在我们身上的事情，因此拥有某种机制来处理我们更多的机器人例程无法自动处理的事情范围是至关重要的。常识可能不是最后的手段，但它是一个很好的第一手段。其直观的、总体上健全的实践基础使我们能够灵活地处理意外情况，以及快速有效地应对不可预测的世界的稳健性。在这方面，鉴于智力通常被认为是成功地学习和适应环境，常识是智慧的核心。

As we will see later in the book, if only a limited number of things could ever happen to us, or if every event was under our control, we probably would not even need common sense. But given that we live in the real world with other agents and phenomena constantly adding to what happens to us, it is critical to have some mechanism to handle the range of things that our more robotic routines can’t cope with automatically. Common sense might not be the last resort, but it is an excellent first resort. Its intuitive, generally sound practical basis gives us the flexibility to deal with unanticipated situations, and the robustness to cope quickly and effectively with an unpredictable world. In that respect, given that intelligence is generally regarded as learning and adapting successfully to the environment, common sense is the core of intelligence.

这很重要，但不是全部

It’s Important, but It’s Not Everything

虽然常识是我们日常生活的重要组成部分，但显然并非所有人类思维都是常识性的。有时它就是行不通，要么是因为我们没有使用它，要么是因为它简单的经验匹配方法无法应对挑战。我们的大部分精神生活都超出了我们可能认为仅仅是常识的范围，居住在不同的地方放在认知连续体上。在结束本章时，我们想简要地考虑一下稍后将再次出现的常识的一些背离和局限性。

While common sense is a critical element of our everyday lives, clearly not all human thinking is commonsensical. And sometimes it just doesn’t work, either because we fail to use it or its simple experience-matching approach is not up to the challenge. Much of our mental lives goes beyond what we might consider to be mere common sense, inhabiting different places on the cognitive continuum. To conclude this chapter, we want to briefly consider some departures from and limitations to common sense that will show up again later.

专家知识：大多数人在工作中学习某种专业或在学校学习日常经验之外的科目。我们可以称之为专家知识，通过明确教授和实践经验的某种组合获得，是创造新技术、解决复杂问题以及社会进步的重要组成部分。这种知识通常建立在对事物如何运作以及事物为何如此的更深入理解之上，而不是我们用常识所看到的，而常识往往更多的是经验性的，而不太倾向于潜在的原因和原则。专家知识的交流和学习方式不同于常识，并且可能需要额外的记忆以及综合和推理机制，这些机制比我们通常与常识相关联的机制更加深思熟虑和分析。（专业知识并没有取代常识性知识，而是丰富和加深了常识性知识。例如，即使是火箭科学家也需要知道与他们一起工作的人需要空气来呼吸。）

Expert knowledge: Most people learn some kind of specialty for their work or learn in school about subjects outside everyday experience. What we might call expert knowledge, gained through some combination of being taught explicitly and by hands-on experience, is an essential ingredient in the creation of new technology, solving of complex problems, and indeed progress of society. This kind of knowledge generally builds on a deeper understanding of how things work and why things are the way they are than we see with common sense, which tends to be more experiential, and less inclined to underlying causes and principles. The way expert knowledge is communicated and learned is different from that of common sense, and likely calls on additional memory as well as synthesis and inference mechanisms that are more deliberate and analytic than those we normally associate with common sense. (Expert knowledge does not so much supplant commonsense knowledge as enrich and deepen it. Even rocket scientists need to know that the people they work with will need air to breathe, for instance.)

拼图模式：没有广泛的数学或解决问题训练的人仍然能够解决不平凡的问题。我们都学会从无法直接处理的问题中退后一步，并尝试通过我们的方式找到解决方案，可能使用铅笔和纸，或与他人协商。这可能适用于像数独游戏和杂志上看到的逻辑谜题这样的娱乐性谜题，或者明显不那么娱乐性的活动，例如填写所得税表格或将姓名列表按字母顺序排序。它还可以用于更广泛的专家级任务，例如计算桥梁上的负载或求解线性方程组。一旦我们开始将我们面临的问题视为可以通过特定方法处理的问题我们知道（来自代数、逻辑、流体动力学或任何地方），我们不在常识范围内。如果需要纸笔来解决，或者需要一些复杂的程序来解开谜团，那么它就不是真正的常识。（当然，当我们遵循一个程序时，常识并没有消失。正如我们所提到的，处理我们决定采用的任何方法的每个步骤仍然需要常识。）

Puzzle mode: Humans without extensive mathematical or problem-solving training are still able to solve nontrivial problems. We all learn to step back from problems that cannot be handled directly and try to work our way through to a solution, possibly using pencil and paper, or in consultation with others. This might be for recreational puzzles like sudokus and the logic puzzles seen in magazines, or decidedly less recreational activities such as filling out income tax forms or sorting a list of names into alphabetical order. It can also be for a broad range of more expert-level tasks like calculating the load on a bridge or solving a system of linear equations. Once we start thinking of a problem we are facing as something that can be dealt with by a specific method we know about (coming from algebra, logic, fluid dynamics, or wherever), we are outside the domain of common sense. If it takes pencil and paper to solve, or some complex procedure to puzzle through, then it is not really commonsensical. (Of course common sense does not go away when we are following a procedure. As we’ve mentioned, it is still needed to deal with each of the steps of any method we decide to pursue.)

识别模式：我们从事的思维模式与知识、常识或其他方式完全无关。看着这对字母序列：“wxyz”和“wyzx”。现在看看这对：“rbv”和“rvb”。这是另一对：“喊”和“南”。现在是这个：“gccewt”和“gcewtc”。看到图案了吗？看到这些对的第一个和第二个元素之间的联系所发生的心理过程与任何类型的知识或培训无关。这个过程也不是视觉的：这里使用了印刷字符，但你可以用一系列的声音或轻拍你的身体来重复这个练习。有趣的是，这种模式也不是真正意义上的。如果一对中的第一个元素是星期日、星期一、星期二等到星期六的序列，那么该对中的第二个元素是什么？识别序列中的这些模式或更复杂的结构排列的能力是我们人类擅长的，却与常识大相径庭。（可以说，它融入了常识；我们开始认识到医院和教堂等常识类别之间的类比和部分对应关系。稍后会详细介绍。）

Recognizing patterns: There are modes of thinking we engage in that have nothing to do with knowledge at all, commonsense or otherwise. Look at this pair of letter sequences: “wxyz” and “wyzx.” Now look at this pair: “rbv” and “rvb.” Here’s another pair: “shout” and “south.” And now this one: “gccewt” and “gcewtc.” See the pattern? The mental process that took place to see the connection between the first and second elements of these pairs had nothing to do with any kind of knowledge or training. Nor is the process visual: typographic characters were used here, but you can repeat the exercise with sequences of sounds or taps on your body. Interestingly, the pattern is not really perceptual either. If the first element of a pair is the sequence of days Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, and so on to Saturday, what is the second element of that pair? The ability to recognize patterns like these in sequences or more complex structural arrangements is something we humans are good at, but is quite different from common sense. (Arguably, it feeds into common sense; we come to recognize analogies and part-by-part correspondences between commonsense categories such as hospitals and churches. More on this later.)

原始冲动：很明显，人类采取各种行动更多地是受情绪、冲动和冲动的引导，而不是常识或明确表达的目标。不太清楚的是这些冲动如何以及何时对相关人类真正有益。例如，对陌生人的警惕在某种程度上无疑是有帮助的，但很容易引起适得其反的仇外心理。厌恶的情绪可以阻止人们将不健康的东西放入口中，但它也可以退化为过于宽泛的执念。在最坏的情况下，像这样的冲动会将人类推向与常识截然相反的方向，并被认为是心理障碍。上面地铁轨道上手机的例子是某种原始冲动阻止了犹豫的常识性命令的一个例子。（在常识和其他相互冲突的冲动之间的角力比赛中，哪一方会真正获胜从来都不是很清楚。）

Primitive impulses: It is clear that humans take all sorts of actions that are steered more by emotions, urges, and compulsions than by anything like common sense or expressly articulated goals. What is less clear is how and when these impulses are actually beneficial to the human in question. Wariness of strangers, for example, is no doubt helpful to a point, but easily gives rise to a xenophobia that is counterproductive. The emotion of disgust can block people from putting unhealthy things into their mouths, but it too can degenerate into overly broad obsessions. At their worst, impulses like these push humans in directions that are diametrically opposed to common sense and considered to be psychological malfunctions. The example above of the cell phone on the subway tracks is one instance of some kind of primitive urge blocking out a commonsensical imperative to hesitate. (It is never really clear which side will actually win in a wrestling match between common sense and other conflicting impulses.)

似是而非的信念：社会学家 Duncan Watts 在他的著作Everything Is Obvious* (*Once You Know the Answer)中雄辩地概述了他对什么是常识和什么不是常识的看法，他提出的主要特征之一是常识与“日常生活的直接此时此地。” 他认为，常识在那个领域之外就会崩溃——也就是说，当“在时间或空间上与我们相距遥远的情况下，预测或管理大量人的行为时”。虽然我们不确定“距离”方面，但 Watts 无疑是准确的评估和说明常识性信念可能会出错的情况。作为一名社会学家，他专注于政治冲突、医疗保健经济学和营销活动等社会现象，但他也讨论了关于物理世界的常识性直觉会在哪些方面使我们误入歧途。这是他举的一个例子：哪颗子弹会先击中地面，一颗是从枪中水平发射的，还是一颗只是从同一高度掉落的？即使从高中物理中知道它们将同时撞击地面，也很难摆脱发射子弹会以某种方式使它在空中停留更长时间的感觉。我们的一些表面上似是而非的信念并不能很好地为我们服务。（Watts 书的副标题是常识如何让我们失望，这表明他关注常识的不足。虽然在某些情况下常识显然会让我们失望，但我们坚信它是人类认知的重要组成部分，并且在很多时候确实取得了成功——很大程度上是未被预知的。）
