Specious beliefs: Sociologist Duncan Watts has eloquently outlined his view of what is and is not common sense in his book Everything Is Obvious* (*Once You Know the Answer), and among the key features he posits is the relevance of common sense to “the immediate here and now of everyday life.” He suggests that common sense breaks down outside that realm—that is, when “anticipating or managing the behavior of large numbers of people, in situations that are distant from us in time or space.” While we are not sure of the “distance” aspect, Watts is no doubt accurate in his assessment and illustration of situations where commonsense beliefs can be mistaken. As a sociologist, he focuses on social phenomena like political conflicts, health care economics, and marketing campaigns, but he also discusses where commonsense intuitions about the physical world can lead us astray. Here is an example he cites: which bullet will hit the ground first, one fired horizontally from a gun, or one merely dropped from the same height? Even knowing from high school physics that they will strike the ground at the same time, it’s hard to shake the feeling that firing a bullet will somehow keep it in the air longer. Some of our superficially plausible beliefs don’t serve us well. (The subtitle of Watts’s book is How Common Sense Fails Us, which is indicative of his focus on the inadequacy of common sense. While there are clearly situations where common sense fails us, we strongly believe that it is a critical component of human cognition and does succeed—largely unheralded—a great deal of the time.)

认知偏差：心理学家 Daniel Kahneman 和 Amos Tversky 以及其他人令人信服地展示了常识失效的许多地方，特别是考虑到各种人类认知偏差（“偏离规范或判断理性的系统模式”，如维基百科所说）它）。人类快速、经验驱动、简化的思维模式使我们容易犯许多错误：一厢情愿、确认偏见、涉及成本和收益的谬误、过于乐观的思维捷径，以及许多其他可能导致麻烦的偏见和幻想。

Cognitive biases: Psychologists Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky along with others have convincingly shown many places where common sense breaks down, especially in light of a variety of human cognitive biases (“systematic patterns of deviation from norm or rationality in judgment,” as Wikipedia puts it). Fast, experientially driven, simplified thought patterns in humans leave us vulnerable to a host of mistakes: wishful thinking, confirmation bias, fallacies involving costs and benefits, overly optimistic mental shortcuts, and a host of other biases and illusions that can cause trouble.

例如，考虑所谓的代表性启发式. 这是人们在考虑对象类别时走的一条思维捷径，只考虑典型或有代表性的案例。有一个著名的 Kahneman 和 Tversky 实验，受试者被告知 Linda，一个虚构的学生活动家，深入参与社会正义、学生示威等问题。然后要求受试者对琳达各种职业成果的可能性进行评级。其中一个选项是“女权主义银行出纳员”，另一个是“银行出纳员”。受试者总是最终认为前者比后者更有可能——这在逻辑上是不可能的！错误似乎在于仅根据其典型属性来考虑像“银行出纳员”这样的不合格类别。换句话说，

Consider, for instance, what is called the representative heuristic. This is a mental shortcut that people take when thinking about categories of objects, where only typical or representative cases are considered. There is a famous Kahneman and Tversky experiment where subjects are told about Linda, a fictional student activist, deeply involved in issues of social justice, student demonstrations, and so on. Subjects are then asked to rate the likelihood of various career outcomes for Linda. One of the options is “feminist bank teller,” and another is “bank teller.” Subjects invariably end up rating the former more likely than the latter—a logical impossibility! The mistake, it appears, is to think of an unqualified category like “bank teller” only in terms of its typical properties. In other words, subjects seem to be comparing the “feminist bank teller” outcome to something more like a “stereotypical bank teller” outcome, and then having made this mistake, quite reasonably judge the former to be more likely for Linda than the latter.

在描述人类这些偏见背后的原因时，卡尼曼提出了对刺激的快速、反射式反应（由他所谓的“系统 1”执行）与更深思熟虑的问题解决式反应（为活动调用）之间的区别需要注意的——归因于同样中性命名的“系统 2”。常识在此框架中的位置尚不清楚。虽然常识推理也快速且直观，但它们并不完全符合系统 1，系统 1 似乎更接近我们在上面所说的“反身行动”或“直觉”。卡尼曼认为系统 1 能够对“2+2=?”做出反应。并在空旷的道路上行驶，但它是否能够解析上述句子中的代词，如“it”，“因为它是钢制的，所以大球撞穿了桌子”？系统 2 处理需要注意的活动，但似乎更符合我们上面讨论的分析组件。需要更多的分析来理解卡尼曼和他的同事们将如何在他们的框架中解释常识。

In describing what is behind biases like these in humans, Kahneman posits a difference between a quick, reflexive kind of response to stimuli—executed by what he calls “System 1”—and a more thoughtful problem-solving-style response, invoked for activities that require attention—attributed to the equally neutrally named “System 2.” The place for common sense in this framework is unclear. While commonsense inferences are also quick and intuitive, they don’t align completely with System 1, which appears closer to what we were calling “reflexive action” or “intuition” above. Kahneman suggests that System 1 is capable of responding to “2+2=?” and driving on an empty road, but is it capable of resolving pronouns like the word “it” in the aforementioned sentence, “The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of steel”? System 2 handles activity that requires attention, but seems more aligned with the analytic component we discussed above. More analysis is needed to understand how Kahneman and his colleagues would account for common sense in their framework.

无论社会学家和心理学家所描述的常识的失败和局限性的根源是什么，考虑到常识和专家知识之间的区别，以及常识和更多以谜题为导向的思维之间的区别，很明显，常识虽然对生活至关重要，并不是我们需要的唯一一种心智能力。如果您的工作是运营一座核电站或驾驶一架复杂的客机，那么您不能仅依靠常识来完成任务。

Whatever is at the root of the failures and limitations of common sense described by sociologists and psychologists, given the difference between commonsense and expert knowledge, and between commonsense and more puzzle-oriented thinking, it is quite apparent that common sense, while critical to life, is not the only kind of mental capacity we need. If your job is to run a nuclear power plant or fly a complex passenger aircraft, you cannot rely on common sense alone in your task.

当我们最终尝试规定机器如何获得和使用常识时，我们应该意识到这些限制并努力帮助机器识别它们，无论是在它们试图解决问题之前，还是事后看来，当常识似乎还不够。当我们在接下来的章节中将注意力转向 AI 系统时，这将产生重要的影响。

When we eventually try to prescribe how a machine might gain and use common sense, we should be aware of these sorts of limitations and work to help machines recognize them too, either before they attempt to solve a problem, or in hindsight, when common sense seems to have fallen short. This will have important implications as we turn our attention to AI systems in the chapters to follow.

3个

3

人工智能系统专业知识

Expertise in AI Systems

一个人应该能够换尿布、计划入侵、杀猪、驾驶船只、设计建筑、写十四行诗、平衡账目、筑墙、接骨、安抚临终者、接受命令、给予命令、合作、单独行动、解方程、分析新问题、撒肥料、编程电脑、做一顿可口的饭菜、高效地战斗、英勇地死去。

A human being should be able to change a diaper, plan an invasion, butcher a hog, conn a ship, design a building, write a sonnet, balance accounts, build a wall, set a bone, comfort the dying, take orders, give orders, cooperate, act alone, solve equations, analyze a new problem, pitch manure, program a computer, cook a tasty meal, fight efficiently, die gallantly.

专业是昆虫。

Specialization is for insects.

——罗伯特·海因莱因，爱的时间足够

—Robert Heinlein, Time Enough for Love

本书讲述了如何构建以智能方式运行的机器。这当然不是一个新想法，从最近关于 AI 的头条新闻来看，有人可能会觉得我们现在必须非常接近这个目标，也许在某个隐藏在某个地方的资金充足的研究实验室，就像我们在电影。

This book is about what it takes to build machines that behave in an intelligent way. This is certainly not a new idea, and judging by recent headlines about AI, one might be excused for feeling that we must be pretty close to this goal by now, maybe in some well-funded research lab hidden somewhere, like we see in the movies.

但在我们看来，情况并非如此。迄今为止的所有努力都产生了功能强大但高度专业化的 AI 系统，而且似乎很难脱离这个轨道。为了弄清楚所有这些，值得花一些时间来了解我们今天在 AI 方面所处的位置以及我们是如何走到这一步的。我们在本章中想要做的是突出该领域在过去 60 年中取得的一些主要成就，以说明已经取得的巨大进步，即使 AI 还没有建立起人类所见的多才多艺、强大的智能。然后，我们将退后一步，考虑为前进的道路吸取的教训。

But in our view, this is not the case. All the efforts to date have resulted in AI systems that are capable but highly specialized, and there appears to be some difficulty in getting off this track. To be clear about all of this, it is worth taking some time to understand where we are with AI today and how we got here. What we want to do in this chapter is highlight some of the field’s major accomplishments over the last sixty years to illustrate the great strides that have been made, even as AI falls short of building a versatile, robust intelligence of the sort seen in humans. We will then step back and consider the lessons to be learned for the road ahead.

构建人工智能

Building an AI

几个世纪以来，人们一直在考虑可以说是智能行为的设备和机制。但大多数人会认为，真正的进步只是在 20 世纪 50 年代通用电子计算机出现后才开始的。一个关键的转折点是 1956 年在达特茅斯学院举行的一次会议，会议讨论了一个名为人工智能的新研究领域由约翰麦卡锡。作为一个研究领域，人工智能在 1960 年代初在许多大学实验室扎根，由来自达特茅斯会议的计算机和认知科学家发起，如麦卡锡、马文明斯基、艾伦纽厄尔、赫伯西蒙等。虽然对于智能到底意味着什么还没有明确的共识，但对计算机进行编程以使其以智能方式运行的探索成为过去 60 年来最激动人心的追求之一。最近的增长更为显着；投入 AI 的资金数量和现在熟悉“人工智能”一词的人数令人震惊。

Devices and mechanisms that could be said to behave intelligently have been contemplated for centuries. But most would consider serious progress to have begun only with the advent of general-purpose electronic computers in the 1950s. A critical turning point was a conference at Dartmouth College in 1956 about a new field of study dubbed artificial intelligence by John McCarthy. As a field of study, AI took root in many university labs in the early 1960s, launched by computer and cognitive scientists from the Dartmouth conference like McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Allen Newell, Herb Simon, and others. While there was no clear common understanding of what intelligence actually amounted to, the quest to program computers to behave in intelligent ways became one of the most exciting pursuits of the last sixty years. Recent growth has been even more dramatic; the amount of money that has been poured into AI and the number of people now familiar with the phrase “artificial intelligence” are stunning.

今天对 AI 的大部分关注和投资都指向一种构建 AI 系统的方法，称为深度学习（下文解释）。关于它的文章太多了，以至于许多人认为 AI 是深度学习的同义词。它的成功有很多值得钦佩和兴奋的地方。然而，我们认为，从更广泛的角度来看，可以更好地理解人工智能的优势和局限性。AI 领域经历了多次思考浪潮，对于如何构建 AI 系统有着截然不同的想法。每一次，这波浪潮都被认为是游戏规则的改变者——它将取代所有其他浪潮。深度学习只是最新的。

Much of the attention and investment in AI today is directed toward one way of building AI systems called deep learning (explained below). So much has been written about it that many people think of AI as synonymous with deep learning. And there is much to admire and be thrilled about with its success. In our opinion, however, the strengths and limitations of AI are best understood by taking a somewhat broader perspective. The field of AI has gone through a number of waves of thinking with quite different ideas about how to build AI systems. Each time, the wave was thought to be the game changer—the one that would supplant all the others. Deep learning is only the most recent.

在本章中，我们将探讨五个有些重叠的主题，它们将 AI 推向了有用且有趣的方向。他们从该领域的不同角落开始，强调智能行为的不同方面，每一个都跨越数十年。每一个都取得了显着的成功，但每一个都揭示了其人工智能方法的主要缺点。

In this chapter, we will look at five somewhat overlapping themes that have driven AI in useful and interesting directions. They started in different corners of the field, emphasizing different aspects of intelligent behavior, and each spans multiple decades. Each has resulted in notable successes, but each has also revealed key shortcomings in its approach to synthetic intelligence.

在我们开始之前，请注意：我们并不想在这里涵盖该领域的全部历史，甚至不会在我们谈论的五个领域内进行全面介绍。其他人对 AI 的历史写得很好，我们不会试图与他们竞争。我们的重点是该领域最初的宏伟愿景，即创建一个可以自行管理的自主人工智能系统通过我们生活的世界，实现它的目标，并在飞行中适应不断变化的条件。我们将提及一些更为知名的 AI 成果，但始终着眼于它们对具有常识的强大通用 AI 的影响。

Before we begin, a caveat: we are not attempting to cover the entire history of the field here or even be comprehensive within the five areas we talk about. Others have written well about the history of AI, and we will not try to compete with them. Our focus is on the original grand vision of the field to create an autonomous AI system that can manage its way through the world we live in, accomplish its goals, and adapt on the fly to changing conditions. We will mention some of the better-known AI efforts, but always with an eye toward their implications for a robust, general AI endowed with common sense.

主题 1：游戏启发搜索

Theme 1: Game-Inspired Search

自 1950 年代人工智能出现初期以来，让计算机玩国际象棋（或西洋跳棋、围棋、扑克等）等策略游戏一直是人们关注的焦点。这主要有三个原因。首先，这种领域的成功很容易评估：计算机程序要么可以在游戏中击败顶级人类玩家，要么不能。其次，国际象棋和围棋等游戏被认为是主要的智力挑战。不是每个人都能打好球，国际冠军就像体育英雄一样被人们尊崇。第三个原因更实际：利用数学家克劳德·香农和计算先驱艾伦·图灵的思想，玩游戏的计算机程序似乎可以相对容易地构建和部署。

Since the earliest days of AI in the 1950s, getting a computer to play games of strategy such as chess (or checkers, Go, poker, and so on) has been a major preoccupation. There are three main reasons for this. First, success in this kind of domain is easy to evaluate: either the computer program can beat top human players at the game or it cannot. Second, games like chess and Go are considered to be major intellectual challenges. Not everyone can play well, and international champions are revered like sports heroes. The third reason is more practical: using ideas from mathematician Claude Shannon and computing pioneer Alan Turing, it appeared that game-playing computer programs could be built and deployed relatively easily.

粗略地说，香农-图灵的想法是这样的：要像专家一样玩国际象棋这样的游戏，没有必要对国际象棋专家在书本上写的所有棘手的国际象棋知识进行编码。相反，使用计算机的速度在游戏规则中隐含的可能移动、反移动、反反移动等树状空间中进行搜索就足够了。在游戏的任何时候，计算机程序都可以通过展望未来并考虑游戏在该步之后的结果如何来确定最好的一步，即使对手玩得很好。一个诱人的前景是一个国际象棋程序，它有足够的远见，甚至可以比它的程序员玩出更好的游戏。

The Shannon-Turing idea, roughly speaking, was this: to play a game like chess as well as an expert, it was not necessary to encode all the tricky chess knowledge that chess experts write about in books. Instead, it was sufficient to use the speed of a computer to search through the treelike space of possible moves, countermoves, countercountermoves, and so on, implicit in the rules of the game. At any point in the game, a computer program could determine the best move to make by looking ahead and considering how the game could be made to turn out after that move, even if the opponent played well. The tantalizing prospect was that of a chess program that would see far enough ahead to play a much better game than even its programmer.

这个想法的主要障碍是需要考虑的天文数字的董事会职位。1950 年代的早期计算机远没有今天的强大，因此第一个玩游戏的程序适用于跳棋和 6x6 国际象棋等小得多的游戏。计算机科学家亚瑟·塞缪尔 (Arthur Samuel) 开发的著名跳棋程序在 50 年代取得了早期成功，但直到 1990 年代后期，计算机科学家乔纳森·谢弗 (Jonathan Schaeffer) 的程序才最终成为世界冠军。在国际象棋中，直到 1997 年，IBM 的深蓝程序才击败国际象棋世界冠军加里卡斯帕罗夫。时间。深蓝是按照香农-图灵方案构建的，但配备了每秒能够查看两亿个国际象棋棋局的专用硬件。

The major stumbling block to this idea was the astronomical number of board positions that would need to be considered. Early computers in the 1950s were far from the powerhouses they are today, and so the first game-playing programs worked on much smaller games like checkers and 6x6 chess. A prominent checker-playing program by computer scientist Arthur Samuel was an early success in the 1950s, but it was only much later in the 1990s that a program by computer scientist Jonathan Schaeffer eventually became a world champion. In chess, it took until 1997 for the program Deep Blue from IBM to defeat Garry Kasparov, the world champion at the time. Deep Blue was built along the lines of the Shannon-Turing scheme, but with specialized hardware capable of looking at two hundred million chess positions per second.

深蓝是人工智能史上的一个重要里程碑。在这里，我们有一个 AI 程序在每个人都认为需要人类智能的领域取得成功。因此，国际象棋从一开始就是该领域的圣杯。早在 1957 年，诺贝尔奖获得者 Herb Simon 就挑出了国际象棋，并预测到 1967 年机器将击败世界冠军。这里成功的关键因素不是任何深厚的知识或战略能力，而是管理和修剪国际象棋的技术。巨大的搜索空间。需要额外的扩展和改进来培养具有机会元素的游戏的世界冠军，例如西洋双陆棋（如计算机科学家 Hans Berliner 及其同事在 1979 年所证明的那样）和不完整的信息，例如扑克（如计算机科学家 Tuomas Sandholm 及其同事在 2017 年所证明的那样） ).

Deep Blue was a major milestone in the history of AI. Here we had an AI program achieving success in a realm that everyone agreed required intelligence in humans. As such, chess had been a kind of holy grail for the field since its beginning. As far back as 1957, Nobel laureate Herb Simon had singled out chess and predicted that a machine would beat the world champion by 1967. The crucial ingredient of success here was not any deep knowledge or strategic competence, but rather techniques to manage and prune the enormous search space. Additional extensions and refinements were needed to develop world champions in games with elements of chance such as backgammon (as demonstrated by computer scientist Hans Berliner and colleagues in 1979) and incomplete information such as poker (as shown by computer scientist Tuomas Sandholm and colleagues in 2017). Interestingly, games like Go were still too big for any of these techniques and had to wait for more powerful ideas from machine learning, as described below.

Newell 和 Simon 可能是有效搜索巨大可能性空间作为智能行为核心要素的想法的创始人。除了游戏之外，类似的搜索还出现在解决诸如 15 谜题之类的谜题中（玩家试图将 15 个编号的方块滑入 4×4 的网格中的数字顺序）。这种类型的搜索甚至出现在诸如证明数学定理之类的事情中。在这种情况下，“移动”涉及根据某些逻辑规则向正在进行的证明中添加句子，目的是得出要证明的最终定理。

Newell and Simon were probably the originators of the idea of effectively searching an enormous space of possibilities as a core element of intelligent behavior. Apart from games, a similar kind of search showed up in solving puzzles like the 15 puzzle (where a player tries to slide fifteen numbered tiles into numerical order on a four-by-four grid). This type of search even showed up in doing things like proving theorems in mathematics. In this case, the “moves” involve adding sentences to an ongoing proof according to certain logical rules, with the goal of arriving at the final theorem to be proved.

然而，虽然人工智能工具箱中的一个重要工具，但这种基于搜索的人工智能视图有其明显的局限性，即使对于游戏也是如此。要了解这一点，请考虑名为“外交”的棋盘游戏，维基百科上的描述如下：

And yet while an important tool in the AI toolbox, this search-based view of AI has its clear limitations, even for games. To see this, consider the board game called Diplomacy, described as follows on Wikipedia:

外交由七名玩家扮演，每名玩家控制着一个欧洲大国的武装部队。每个玩家的目标是移动他或她的少数起始单位并击败其他人，以赢得地图上标记为“补给中心”的大部分战略城市和省份的占有；这些供应中心允许控制它们的玩家生产更多单位。在每一轮玩家协商之后，当与攻击省份相邻的省份数量达到下达命令（书面下来并提前宣布）支持攻击省份​​的数量超过了与被攻击省份相邻的被命令支持被攻击省份的省份数量。

Diplomacy is played by seven players, each controlling the armed forces of a major European power. Each player aims to move his or her few starting units and defeat those of others to win possession of a majority of strategic cities and provinces marked as “supply centers” on the map; these supply centers allow players who control them to produce more units. Following each round of player negotiations, each player can issue attack orders and take control of a neighboring province when the number of provinces adjacent to the attacking province that are given orders (written down and declared in advance) to support the attacking province exceeds the number of provinces adjacent to the province under attack that are given orders to support the province under attack.

从 AI 的角度来看，让这款游戏特别有趣的是，在所有玩家同步的棋盘移动之间，为玩家分配了时间来相互协商。联盟对于玩家加强军事努力并避免不得不不断地保卫各方边界至关重要。试图单打独斗的玩家不会坚持太久。但是，这些谈判应该如何进行，这些规则是开放的。球员们选择私下或公开对彼此说什么，完全取决于他们自己。特别是，他们宣布下一轮将做的事情与他们的私人书面命令实际包含的内容可能大不相同。当然，被发现太不值得信任的玩家可能很难找到盟友——不仅在当前游戏中，而且在后续游戏中！

What makes this game especially intriguing from an AI point of view is that between the board moves, which are synchronized for all players, time is allotted for players to negotiate with each other. Alliances are essential for players to bolster their military efforts and avoid having to constantly defend borders on all sides. Players who attempt to go it alone do not last long. But how these negotiations should proceed is left open by the rules. What the players choose to say to each other, privately or publicly, is totally up to them. In particular, what they may announce they will do in the next round and what their private written orders actually contain can be quite different. Of course, players who are found to be too untrustworthy may have a hard time finding allies—not only in the current game, but in subsequent ones!

在这里，我们可以清楚地看到，在预定的可能走法空间中搜索的想法只是故事的一部分。在欧洲地图上移动军队确实就像在国际象棋或围棋中移动棋子一样。但是一旦考虑到谈判，类比就失效了。目前还不清楚玩家在谈判阶段选择的是什么“动作”。“从北海进攻约克郡”是一回事，“与俄罗斯达成协议，假装支持法国”是另一回事。

Here we can see clearly how the idea of searching through a predetermined space of possible moves is only one part of the story. Moving an army on a map of Europe is indeed like moving a piece in chess or Go. But once negotiations are taken into account, the analogy breaks down. It is far from clear what “moves” players are selecting from during a negotiation phase. “Attacking Yorkshire from the North Sea” is one thing, but “making a deal with Russia that involves pretending to show support for France” is different.

换句话说，我们已经认识到，AI 程序在国际象棋、围棋、扑克等游戏中的成功取决于这些程序在可以限定的世界中运行，在这些游戏中可以移动。被预先枚举和表征（可能是概率性的，当涉及机会时）。外交中的动作，与现实生活中的动作相似，并非如此。

What we have come to realize, in other words, is that the success of AI programs in games such as chess, Go, poker, and the like has depended on the fact that these programs operate in worlds that can be circumscribed, where moves can be enumerated and characterized in advance (perhaps probabilistically, when chance is involved). The moves in Diplomacy, similar to those in real life, are not like this.

主题 2：自然语言理解

Theme 2: Natural Language Understanding

关于如何确定机器是否会思考的最早想法之一来自图灵。图灵提出了另一种游戏，但类型有所不同，其中一台计算机和一个人，在人类法官面前隐藏起来，各自与法官进行对话。如果法官不能自信地认为机器是智能的区分它和人类。（这有点过于简单化；所谓的图灵测试有不同的变体。）这个测试具有明显的直观吸引力：人们普遍认为，如果没有真正的智能支持，就无法在对话中达到人类水平的能力。与其他游戏一样，该测试巧妙地确定了智力真正包含的内容或它在人类身上的实际运作方式。计算机必须在这场“模仿游戏”中获胜。

One of the earliest ideas about how to ascertain whether machines could think came from Turing. Turing proposed yet another game, but of a somewhat different sort, wherein a computer and a human, hidden from a human judge, would each engage in a dialogue with the judge. The machine would be considered to be intelligent if the judge could not confidently distinguish between it and the human. (This is a bit of an oversimplification; the so-called Turing test has different variants.) This test had clear intuitive appeal: people generally believe that human-level competence in a conversation could not be achieved without being backed up by true intelligence. And as with other games, the test finessed having to take a position on what intelligence really comprised or how it actually worked in humans. The computer just had to win at this “imitation game.”

自然语言 (NL) 似乎也很适合计算机编程。我们在学校学习语法，感觉动词变位和句子结构的规律性应该使计算机实现语言理解的算法方法自然而然。语言学家诺姆·乔姆斯基 (Noam Chomsky) 和其他人在结构化形式语法方面的工作提供了最初的灵感。机器 NL 理解的潜在实际影响也很明显。与其使用神秘的人工计算机语言来提问和向计算机发出命令，不如使用更像英语的语言呢？

Natural language (NL) also seemed quite amenable to computer programming. We learn grammar in school, and it feels like the regularities of verb conjugation and sentence structure should make an algorithmic approach to language understanding a natural for computer implementation. Work by linguist Noam Chomsky and others on structured formal grammars provided initial inspiration. The potential practical impact of machine NL understanding was clear too. Instead of having to use arcane artificial computer languages to ask questions and give commands to computers, why not use something more like English?

NL 处理的工作早在 AI 的历史上就开始了——甚至在它成为一个领域之前——因为 1950 年代的科学家们试图解决语言之间的自动翻译问题。（我们将在下面的学习部分详细介绍机器翻译。）最令人印象深刻的早期人工智能项目之一是麻省理工学院的一个名为 SHRDLU 的系统，它由计算机科学家 Terry Winograd 在 1970 年左右开发。在桌子上模拟积木世界，并允许用户用英语发出命令，让系统使用虚拟机械臂在桌子上移动积木。一个典型的命令可能是这样的：

Work in NL processing started early in the history of AI—even before it was a field—as scientists in the 1950s tried to tackle automatic translation between languages. (We will have more to say about machine translation in the learning section below.) One of the most impressive early AI projects was a system at MIT called SHRDLU, developed by computer scientist Terry Winograd around 1970. SHRDLU was designed to work in a small world of simulated toy blocks on a table and allowed a user to issue commands in English to get the system to move the blocks around the table using a virtual robotic arm. A typical command might be something like this:

找一个比你拿着的那个高的方块，把它放在盒子里。

Find a block that is taller than the one you are holding and put it in the box.

从研究的角度来看，这种系统的一大优势在于，通常很明显英语命令或问题是否被正确理解。不利之处在于，所讨论的英国人受制于其创建者事先预期的那种对象和属性（具有大小、形状、颜色和位置的块）。

From a research point of view, a big advantage of a system of this sort is that it was usually apparent whether the English command or question was being properly understood. The disadvantage was that the English in question was a slave to the kind of objects and properties (blocks with sizes, shapes, colors, and locations) anticipated in advance by its creators.

像 SHRDLU 这样的系统在某种程度上是通用的，因为不必为新的应用程序域重新编程基本语法和执行机制。但是需要大量的人工劳动来扩大它们的范围。通常，系统只关注语言的输入端，只有最粗糙的方案产生输出。即使他们对受限制的问题和命令做出了合理的回应，他们也无法在自然的对话中坚持自己的立场。

Systems like SHRDLU were general purpose in a way, in that the basic grammars and execution mechanisms did not have to be reprogrammed for new application domains. But a huge amount of human manual labor was required to increase their scope. And typically, the systems focused only on the input side of language, with only the crudest schemes for producing output. Even if they did a reasonable job of responding to restricted questions and commands, they could not hold their own in a natural conversation.

自 1970 年代以来，以文本为中心的 NL 处理工作一直在稳步进行，并进行了一些适度的商业尝试——例如，将 NL 前端用于商业数据库。不过，最终，更重要的影响来自于为处理口头语言而不是打字文本而构建的系统。

Work on text-centric NL processing has continued steadily since the 1970s, and has had some modest commercial forays—for example, with NL front ends to commercial databases. In the end, though, more significant impact came from systems built to process spoken language rather than typed text.

很长一段时间以来，人类语音的处理都有自己的重点。四十年来，美国国防高级研究计划局 (DARPA) 的持续关注在一定程度上推动了重大进展。（DARPA 支持广泛的研究，包括一些远远超出国防应用的基本长期主题。）早期的工作，如基于文本的处理，往往由基于语法和结构的方法驱动。但随着大型语言语料库增强的统计方法接管了该领域，并且机器学习带来了更显着的进步，80 年代后期开始了重大发展。

The processing of human speech has had its own focus for quite some time. Major advances were in part driven by consistent attention from the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) over a span of forty years. (DARPA supports a broad spectrum of research, including some basic long-term topics that go well beyond defense applications.) Early work, like that of text-based processing, tended to be driven by grammar- and structure-based approaches. But a significant evolution started in the late 1980s as statistical approaches augmented by large language corpora took over the field and even more dramatic advances came from machine learning.

语音识别是人工智能历史上最伟大的成功案例之一。像 Siri、Google Home、Alexa 和 Nuance 的 Dragon 这样的系统，无论它们有什么其他的限制，都能够在普通的嘈杂环境中处理普通的口头语言，并以惊人的准确性转录话语。当然，他们确实在转换过程中犯了错误，但更重要的是他们的整体工作情况。即使在 20 年前，对于专家来说，如此强大的语音技术似乎还是遥不可及的希望。

Speech recognition is one of the great success stories in the history of AI. Systems like Siri, Google Home, Alexa, and Nuance’s Dragon, whatever their other limitations, are able to deal with ordinary spoken language in ordinary noisy environments, and transcribe utterances with astounding accuracy. They do make mistakes in the conversion, of course, but much more significant is just how well they work overall. A speech technology this robust seemed a distant hope to experts even twenty years ago.

但遗憾的是，即使在 60 多年之后，让机器以类似人类的方式更广泛地处理语言仍然是一个难以实现的目标。问题是语言通常是用来谈论某事的，而这个主题，就像任何事情一样，是绊脚石。正如 Winograd 所说，“我们假设计算机无法合理地处理语言，除非它能够理解它正在讨论的主题。” 虽然像 Siri 和 Alexa 这样的系统是惊人的杰作，在 20 年前几乎无法想象，但现在却在数以百万计的口袋和家庭中，它们让我们感到沮丧，因为它们无法回答其创造者没有预料到的主题的问题——其中一些问题如此简单，以至于一个六岁的孩子都能回答他们。

But alas, even after more than sixty years, getting machines to deal with language more broadly in a humanlike way remains an elusive goal. The problem is that language is generally used to talk about something, and it is this subject matter, as much as anything, that is the stumbling block. As stated by Winograd, “We assume that a computer cannot deal reasonably with language unless it can understand the subject it is discussing.” While systems like Siri and Alexa are amazing tours de force, barely imaginable two decades ago but now in millions of pockets and homes, they frustrate us with their inability to answer questions whose subject matter wasn’t anticipated by their creators—some of these questions so drop-dead easy that a six-year-old could answer them.

为了避免人们认为缺乏理解只会出现关于深奥主题的复杂句子，一组研究人员（我们中的一个，HJL，included) 提供了比图灵的模仿游戏更有针对性的智力测试——并且表明也许核心挑战不仅仅是语言本身甚至对话，而是理解世界本身。

Lest it be thought that a lack of understanding only arises for complex sentences about esoteric subjects, a set of researchers (one of us, HJL, included) has offered up a more focused test of intelligence than Turing’s imitation game—and one showing that perhaps the central challenge is not just the language per se or even dialogue but instead understanding the world itself.

这是最初由 Winograd 提出的想法：简单的两句模式显示了如何只有对世界有一定的了解才能成功处理 NL 话语。一个现在经典的例子是这样的：

Here’s the idea, originally suggested by Winograd: simple two-sentence schemas show how NL utterances can only be processed successfully with some understanding of the world. A now-classic example is this:

市议员拒绝给示威者许可证，因为他们害怕暴力。

The city councillors refused to grant the demonstrators a permit because they feared violence.

市议员拒绝向示威者发放许可证，因为他们鼓吹暴力。

The city councillors refused to grant the demonstrators a permit because they advocated violence.

挑战在于确定每个句子中的代词“他们”是指市议员还是示威者。这两个句子之间的唯一区别是一个动词，但要成功回答这个问题似乎需要了解市议员和示威者的行为。事实上，这只是上一章中使用代词“它”看到的模式的另一个实例：

The challenge is to determine whether the pronoun “they” refers to the city councillors or demonstrators in each sentence. The only difference between the two sentences is a single verb, yet success at answering the question seems to require knowledge about what city councillors and demonstrators do. In fact, this is just another instance of the pattern seen in the previous chapter with the pronoun “it”:

大球撞穿了桌子，因为它是钢制的。

The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of steel.

那个大球从桌子上掉了下来，因为它是硬纸板做的。

The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of cardboard.

像这样的例子，现在被称为Winograd 模式，表明理解即使是简单的句子也可能依赖于大量现实世界的物理知识、社会互动，坦率地说，几乎任何其他知识。（稍后会详细介绍。）

Examples like these, now called Winograd schemas, show that understanding even simple sentences can depend on substantial real-world knowledge of physics, social interactions, and frankly, almost anything else. (Much more on this later.)

最后，如果不提及 IBM 的 Watson 系统，突出 NL 系统的部分将是不完整的。2011 年，经过巨大的编程和知识获取努力，Watson 参加了电视节目Jeopardy!的三场比赛。对抗它的两个最杰出的人类冠军。在国家电视台上，沃森击败了它的人类对手。事实上，它可以在事先不知道线索领域的情况下实时做到这一点，这一点非常了不起。Watson 使用了多种 NL 处理方法，并接受了来自许多来源的大量世界知识的训练，包括来自所有先前 Jeopardy 的类别、线索和正确答案的庞大档案。游戏。

Finally, a section highlighting NL systems would not be complete without a mention of the Watson system from IBM. In 2011, after an enormous programming and knowledge acquisition effort, Watson played in a three-game head-to-head contest on the TV show Jeopardy! against two of its most prominent human champions. On national television, Watson overwhelmed its human opponents. The fact that it could do this in real time without any idea in advance of the domains of the clues was remarkable. Watson used a variety of NL processing methods and was trained on a massive amount of world knowledge from many sources, including a huge archive of categories, clues, and correct answers from all prior Jeopardy! games.

沃森成为大众媒体的祝酒词，前冠军和失败的选手肯詹宁斯在他最后的回答中承认，“我欢迎我们的新计算机霸主。” IBM 随后开始将其核心系统商业化并将其应用于许多领域，包括医疗保健和医学，尽管结果好坏参半且有些令人失望。但 Watson 在 Jeopardy! 上的一些答案已经出现了问题！例如回答“什么是多伦多？” 美国城市类别的问题。虽然 Watson 表现出了前所未有的多才多艺，并在广播电视上向公众展示了这一点，但它的失态也揭示了处理 NL 仍未解决的挑战：了解世界并使用常识来谈论它。

Watson became the toast of the popular media, with former champion and defeated contestant Ken Jennings acknowledging in his final answer, “I for one welcome our new computer overlords.” IBM subsequently moved to commercialize its core system and apply it to many domains, including health care and medicine, albeit with mixed and somewhat disappointing results. But Watson already had issues with a few of its answers on Jeopardy! such as answering “What is Toronto?” to a question in the US cities category. While Watson showed unprecedented versatility and did so in full view of the public on broadcast TV, its gaffes also revealed the still-unmet challenge of dealing with NL: understanding the world and using common sense to talk about it.

主题 3：基于规则的问题解决

Theme 3: Rule-Based Problem-Solving

与 NL 理解工作所面临的一些相同挑战一样，AI 研究的一个重要线索围绕着需要像人类一样解决问题的任务。这个主题最早的焦点之一是在麻省理工学院，在 1960 年代明斯基指导研究人员应对各种人类认知挑战，例如解决代数和演绎问题（计算机科学家 Daniel Bobrow 和 Bertram Raphael），进行几何类比（数学家 Thomas Evans），以及寻找概念之间的关联（认知科学家 Ross Quillian；在卡内基梅隆大学完成的工作）。

Sharing some of the same challenges that underlie work in NL understanding, an important thread in AI research revolved around tasks requiring humanlike problem-solving. One of the earliest focal points of this theme was at MIT, where in the 1960s Minsky guided researchers on a variety of human cognitive challenges, such as solving algebra and deduction word problems (computer scientists Daniel Bobrow and Bertram Raphael), making geometric analogies (mathematician Thomas Evans), and finding associations between concepts (cognitive scientist Ross Quillian; work done at Carnegie Mellon).

来自人类思维的灵感是卡内基梅隆大学早期人工智能工作的前沿和中心。一种更基于心理学的观点在那里扎根，人工智能程序的编写前提是观察被要求在解决问题时大声思考的人类受试者。Newell 和 Simon 假设，解决问题可以理解为对由 IF/THEN 规则（参见下面的示例）组成的较为稳定的长期记忆和用于中间结果的更不稳定的短期记忆的操作。解决问题的过程本身非常通用：根据当前短期记忆中的内容，反复查找被判断为适用的规则，并使用它们来确定如何在循环的下一轮中更改该记忆。正在解决的问题的所有细节都编码在规则本身中。

Inspiration from human thinking was very much front and center in early AI work at Carnegie Mellon. A more psychologically based point of view had taken root there, and AI programs were being written premised on observing human subjects asked to think aloud while solving problems. Newell and Simon postulated that problem-solving could be understood in terms of operations over a somewhat stable long-term memory made up of IF/THEN rules (see below for an example) and a more volatile short-term memory for intermediate results. The problem-solving process itself was quite generic: repeatedly find rules that were judged applicable given what was in the current short-term memory, and use them to determine how to change that memory for the next round in the cycle. All the specifics of the problem being solved were encoded in the rules themselves.

以这种方式使用规则的想法对整个领域产生了显着影响，并引发了人们对人工智能的热情爆发，并首次产生了许多对商业世界产生明显影响的系统。基于这个想法的 1970 年代的努力集群通常被称为专家系统，因为它们专注于使用在访谈中从人类专家那里获得的规则来模拟人类专家解决问题的过程。

The idea of using rules in this way had a remarkable impact on the field as a whole, and led to an explosion of excitement about AI and, for the first time, generated a number of systems with clear impact in the commercial world. The cluster of efforts in the 1970s based on this idea generally became known as expert systems since they focused on emulating the problem-solving of human experts using rules obtained from them in interviews.

这个方向的许多开创性工作都来自斯坦福大学，第一个专家系统就是在那里创建的。计算机科学家 Ted Shortliffe 的 MYCIN 系统展示了基于规则的系统在医学诊断和治疗（例如开具针对疾病的药物处方）中的强大功能。到 70 年代后期，MYCIN 能够在传染病治疗建议方面表现出与人类医生不相上下的能力——这是一项了不起的成就。典型 MYCIN 规则的解释如图 3.1 所示。

Much of the seminal work in this direction came out of Stanford, where the first expert systems were created. The MYCIN system from computer scientist Ted Shortliffe demonstrated the power of rule-based systems in medical diagnosis and therapy such as prescribing disease-specific drugs. By the late 1970s, MYCIN was able to show competency in infectious disease therapy recommendations on a par with human doctors—a remarkable accomplishment. A gloss of a typical MYCIN rule appears in figure 3.1.

Prospector 和 XCON 是最早的重要工业专家系统。Prospector 由计算机科学家 Richard Duda 和 Peter Hart 以及 SRI International 的同事开发，是一个预测矿床的系统，它模拟了有限数量的地质学家所拥有的特定专业知识。Prospector 在其分配的任务中非常成功，包括预测华盛顿州以前未知的钼矿床。XCON 来自卡内基梅隆大学的计算机科学家 John McDermott，用于配置 Digital Equipment Corporation 的计算机。它于 1980 年投入使用，到 1986 年估计已处理了 8 万份订单并为其母公司节省了 2500 万美元。这是当时最复杂的专家系统，大约有 2500 条规则。

Among the earliest important industrial expert systems were Prospector and XCON. Prospector, from computer scientists Richard Duda and Peter Hart and colleagues at SRI International, was a system for predicting mineral deposits that emulated the specific expertise held by a limited number of geologists. Prospector was quite successful in its assigned task, including predicting a previously unknown molybdenum deposit in Washington State. XCON, from computer scientist John McDermott at Carnegie Mellon, was used to configure computers at the Digital Equipment Corporation. It entered use in 1980, and by 1986 was estimated to have processed eighty thousand orders and saved its parent company $25 million. This was the most complex expert system at the time, with about twenty-five hundred rules.

一旦这些早期的开拓性努力证明了商业可行性，专家系统领域就出现了爆炸式增长。对人工智能公司的投资急剧增长，数以千计的此类专业系统部署在众多行业中。这是国际认可人工智能作为具有商业意义的领域的第一波浪潮。

Once commercial viability was demonstrated by these early trailblazing efforts, the field of expert systems exploded. Investment in AI companies grew dramatically, and thousands of such specialized systems were deployed across a large number of industries. This was the first great wave of international recognition of AI as a commercially significant field.

专家系统的成功以及所有专业知识都被编码在一系列规则中这一事实催生了人工智能保险杠贴纸的口号，“知识就是力量”。（该短语的最初使用通常归因于弗朗西斯培根爵士，但可以追溯到十世纪。）当谈到专家级的问题解决时，聪明的算法不是问题；知识——还有很多——是关键。但没有说明的是，这里的“知识”实际上意味着“以 IF/THEN 规则形式出现的专业知识”。这暗示了范式中的两个重大弱点。首先，存在所谓的知识获取瓶颈：从人类专家那里手动收集足够的规则是一个巨大的负担。其次，虽然这些系统确实允许在专业领域模拟特定问题的解决，他们强烈限于那些狭窄的专业知识。当被问及超出他们严格能力范围的问题时，他们惨遭失败。计算机科学家 Melanie Mitchell 是这样说的：

The success of expert systems and the fact that all the expertise was encoded in a collection of rules gave rise to an AI bumper sticker slogan, “knowledge is power.” (The original use of the phrase is often attributed to Sir Francis Bacon, but is traceable back to the tenth century.) When it came to expert-level problem-solving, clever algorithms were not the issue; knowledge—and lots of it—was the key. But left unsaid was that “knowledge” here really meant “expert knowledge in the form of IF/THEN rules.” This implied two significant weaknesses in the paradigm. First, there is what became known as the knowledge acquisition bottleneck: the manual collection of an adequate supply of rules from human experts was an enormous burden. And second, while the systems indeed allowed the emulation of specific problem-solving in specialized areas, they were strongly limited to those narrow types of expertise. When asked questions beyond their strict competence, they failed miserably. Computer scientist Melanie Mitchell puts it this way:

专家系统……越来越多地暴露出自身的脆弱性，即容易出错，并且在遇到新情况时往往无法概括或适应。在分析这些系统的局限性时，研究人员发现编写规则的人类专家实际上在多大程度上依赖于潜意识知识——你可以称之为常识——以便采取明智的行动。

Expert systems … were increasingly revealing themselves to be brittle, that is, error-prone and often unable to generalize or adapt when presented with new situations. In analyzing the limitations of these systems, researchers were discovering how much the human experts writing the rules actually rely on subconscious knowledge—what you might call common sense—in order to act intelligently.

在下一章中，我们将对此进行更多讨论。

We will have more to say on this in the next chapter.

主题 4：自主集成系统

Theme 4: Autonomous Integrated Systems

随着 AI 技术在专业领域取得成功，趋势很明显：要使 AI 软件在工业级水平上运行并提供能够满足真实付费客户的性能，工作必须深入，但也可能范围狭窄。稍微小心点，上面提到的脆弱性并没有妨碍成功的应用程序。

As AI technology was succeeding well in specialized areas, the trend was clear: to make AI software work at an industrial-grade level and provide performance that would satisfy real, paying customers, the work had to be deep, but it could be narrow. With a bit of care, the brittleness mentioned above did not get in the way of successful applications.

但从一开始，人工智能的野心总是比这更广泛。人们设想自主机器人能够自己决定做什么，然后根据结果采取行动计划。让机器人自己松动意味着它必须准备好处理不可预见的情况。

But AI ambitions from the beginning were always broader than that. People envisioned autonomous robots that would be able to decide for themselves what to do and then carry out actions based on the resulting plans. And letting a robot loose on its own meant that it had to be prepared to handle unforeseen situations.

SRI International 的 Shakey 项目是 1960 年代后期的一项 AI 项目，目的是制造一个可以在室内空间滚动的机器人，并制定和执行相当复杂的计划，从一个房间移动到另一个房间，并四处移动物体。（该机器人之所以被称为 Shakey，是因为它在停止时会摇晃。）这是将（某种程度上）自主移动系统置于（某种）不可预测的世界中并使其感知周围环境、计划其行动、观察这些行动的影响，并调整其计划和下一步行动。例如，它可以确定，为了将一个箱子推离高架平台，它应该卷起一个斜坡并移开其他东西以到达箱子。

The Shakey project at SRI International was an AI effort in the late 1960s to build a robot that could roll around an indoor space, and make and execute fairly complex plans to move from one room to another as well as move objects around. (The robot was called Shakey because it shook when it stopped.) It was one of the earliest efforts to put a (somewhat) autonomous mobile system into the (somewhat) unpredictable world and have it perceive its surroundings, plan its actions, observe the effects of those actions, and adapt its plans and next actions. It could, for example, determine that in order to push a box off an elevated platform, it should roll up a ramp and move something else out of the way to get to the box.

在 Shakey 之后，机器人逐渐走出实验室，走向外面的世界。1998 年，计算机科学家塞巴斯蒂安·特伦 (Sebastian Thrun) 及其同事开发了一种名为 Minerva 的交互式移动机器人，该机器人无需人工干预即可在两周内引导游客参观史密森尼国家美国历史博物馆。博物馆里经常挤满了人，使安全导航变得相当复杂，而 Minerva 专为在这种不可预测和动态的环境中安全导航而设计。（有精彩的视频显示孩子们挡住它的路，试图分散它的注意力或爬上去兜风。）

After Shakey, robots gradually moved out of the lab and into the outside world. In 1998, computer scientist Sebastian Thrun and colleagues developed an interactive mobile robot called Minerva that worked without human intervention to guide visitors through the Smithsonian’s National Museum of American History over a period of two weeks. Museums are often filled with people, making safe navigation quite complex, and Minerva was specifically designed for safe navigation in this unpredictable and dynamic environment. (There are wonderful videos of children blocking its way, trying to distract it or climb on for a ride.)

也许最需要能够适应的自主 AI 系统的环境是像深空这样的环境，在这些环境中，人类离得足够远，无法进行远程操作或实时通信。正因为如此，美国国家航空航天局及其喷气推进实验室一直是自主系统前沿思想的源泉。1997 年部署在火星表面的旅居者漫游者是他们的第一个自主机器人系统之一。在 1999深空 1任务中，一个 AI 软件系统被允许在距离地球超过 6000 万英里的机载计算机系统上运行两天。这个 AI 系统出现了几个模拟的航天器故障（一个有故障的电子单元、提供错误信息的传感器和卡住的姿态控制推进器），据报道，每个故障都处理得很好。

Perhaps the environments most clearly in need of autonomous AI systems that can adapt are those like deep space where humans are far enough away to make teleoperation or real-time communication impossible. Because of this, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration along with its Jet Propulsion Laboratory have always been a source of leading-edge thinking about autonomous systems. The Sojourner rover deployed on the surface of Mars in 1997 was one of their first autonomous robotic systems. In the 1999 Deep Space 1 mission, an AI software system was allowed to run the onboard computer system for two days, more than sixty million miles from Earth. This AI system was presented with several simulated spacecraft failures (a faulty electronics unit, sensor providing false information, and stuck attitude control thruster) and reportedly handled each well.

在继续研究单个机器人系统的同时，一个有趣的发展将研究转向了机器人团队。部分基于计算机科学家 Alan Mackworth 在 1992 年的建议，日本和美国的研究人员为 AI 提出了一项重大挑战：打败人类世界到 2050 年，拥有一支自主机器人团队的杯赛冠军足球队。与其他现实世界的嵌入式机器人一样，足球世界的开放性，包括与对手比赛，挑战了核心 AI 算法，并要求实时感知与实时决策。RoboCup 足球挑战赛诞生了。从那时起，来自世界各地的团队一直在通过模拟以及各种尺寸的轮式或腿式机器人来创建和显着改进机器人足球队。

While work continued on individual robotic systems, an interesting development moved research toward teams of robots. Based in part on a suggestion by computer scientist Alan Mackworth in 1992, Japanese and US researchers posited a grand challenge for AI: to beat the human World Cup championship soccer team with a team of autonomous robots by the year 2050. As with other real-world-embedded robots, the openness of the soccer world, including playing against an adversary, challenged core AI algorithms and demanded real-time perception coordinated with real-time decision-making. The RoboCup soccer challenge was born. Since that time, teams from all over the world have been creating and dramatically improving robot soccer teams in simulation as well as with wheeled or legged robots of various sizes.

我们目前看到一个重要领域，自主集成系统正在慢慢进入日常使用：自动驾驶汽车。这一领域的重大推动始于 DARPA 提出的一项重大挑战，要求车辆自行驾驶穿越加利福尼亚州和内华达州之间沙漠的 132 英里的苛刻路线。第一届比赛于 2004 年举行，最好的车辆只进入了赛道 7 英里，此时它在转弯后挂在了护堤上。但在 2005 年的第二场比赛中，23 辆入围车辆中有 5 辆完成了比赛，来自斯坦福的 Thrun 和他的团队名为 Stanley 的汽车获得了第一名。这一成功直接导致 Google 首先在自动驾驶汽车方面开展工作，并最终在许多汽车制造商中开展工作。当然，迄今为止，这项工作所产生的商用车辆仍远未达到自动驾驶。它们擅长自动车道跟随和反应速度控制，甚至是平行停车，但根本无法对道路上前所未见的物品以及人类在驾驶时做出意想不到、深不可测的事情的无限创造力做出适当的反应。

We are currently seeing one important area where autonomous integrated systems are slowly emerging into routine use: self-driving cars. A major push in this area began with a grand challenge from DARPA for a vehicle to drive by itself over a demanding 132-mile course through the desert between California and Nevada. The first competition was held in 2004, and the best vehicle only got 7 miles into the course, at which point it got hung up on a berm after making a switchback turn. But in the second competition in 2005, five of the twenty-three finalist vehicles completed the course, with the car called Stanley from Thrun and his team from Stanford coming in first. This success led directly to work on self-driving cars first at Google and eventually at a number of car manufacturers. Of course, the commercial vehicles that have come out of this work to date are still far from autonomous. They are good at automatic lane following and reactive speed control, and even parallel parking, but simply cannot yet react appropriately to never-before-seen items on the road and the boundless creativity of humans to do unanticipated, unfathomable things while driving.

并非所有对集成自主系统的 AI 兴趣都集中在机器人或其他移动系统上。该领域的研究一直围绕着可以结合感知、学习和推理的软件系统展开。例如，DARPA“学习的个性化助手”项目（由我们中的一个人 RJB 构思和发起）直接导致了 Siri——然后是 Google Home 和 Alexa——旨在创建一个集成但没有实体的系统来模拟人类办公室助理。在这项工作之前，对集成知识系统的多年研究产生了一系列认知架构，这些架构提出了可以从受人类认知和感知启发的元素构建完整人工智能系统的方法。Soar 架构是沿着这些思路进行的一项更雄心勃勃和长期存在的努力，起源于 Newell 和 Simon 的工作。它试图描述智能体的全部能力agent，包括检查自己解决问题的能力，并将多种形式的记忆（情景记忆、语义记忆和程序记忆）置于一个单一的集成框架中。

Not all AI interest in integrated autonomous systems has been focused on robots or other mobile systems. Research in the field has continued around software systems that can combine perception, learning, and reasoning. For example, the DARPA “Personalized Assistant That Learns” project (conceived and initiated by one of us, RJB), which led directly to Siri—and then Google Home and Alexa—was intended to create an integrated but disembodied system to emulate a human office assistant. And prior to that work, many years’ worth of research on integrated knowledgeable systems led to a series of cognitive architectures suggesting ways in which a complete AI system could be constructed from elements inspired by human cognition and perception. One of the more ambitious and long-lived efforts along these lines is the Soar architecture, originating in the work of Newell and Simon. It attempted to characterize the full range of capabilities of an intelligent agent, including an ability to examine its own problem-solving, and posited multiple forms of memory (episodic, semantic, and procedural) in a single integrated framework.

集成自治系统领域可能是该领域的一个主线，它最终专注于创始人通常认为的人工智能。但即便如此，这些系统最终还是相当有限，或者只是使用统计数据或指标来试图避免它们完成任务的能力受到限制。没有人真正认真地求助于人类认为对度过日常生活至关重要的常识。

The area of integrated autonomous systems is perhaps the one thread of the field that has ended up focusing on what the founders generally thought of as AI. But even then, the systems ended up being fairly limited, or just used statistics or metrics to try to avoid limitations in their abilities to get things done. None has really resorted in a serious way to the kind of common sense that humans find so critical to getting through their everyday lives.

主题 5：数据驱动学习

Theme 5: Data-Driven Learning

在 AI 的早期，Minsky、数学家 Seymour Papert 等研究人员认为，AI 的合理灵感应该是天然的有机大脑。借鉴诺贝尔奖获得者戴维·休贝尔和托斯滕·威塞尔等神经科学工作，以及神经生理学家沃伦·麦卡洛和逻辑学家沃尔特·皮茨在他们所谓的“人工神经网络”方面的早期工作，这些科学家实施和研究了人类神经元模型，并设计了计算设备基于它们的触发机制和连接性。

In the earliest days of AI, researchers like Minsky, mathematician Seymour Papert, and others felt that a reasonable inspiration for an AI would be a natural organic brain. Borrowing from neuroscience work like that of Nobel Laureates David Hubel and Torsten Wiesel, and earlier work by neurophysiologist Warren McCullough and logician Walter Pitts on what they called “artificial neural networks,” these scientists implemented and studied models of human neurons, and devised computational devices based on their triggering mechanisms and connectivity.

Minsky 和 ​​Papert 在 1969 年展示了这些网络的简单形式的计算能力的一些显着局限性，促使该领域的普遍热情减弱。但是，一群敬业的科学家继续在更复​​杂的多层神经网络上开展工作。20 世纪 80 年代中期出现了一项重要的发展，其形式是一种称为反向传播的神经网络学习算法。反向传播是一种在错误分类后对神经元之间的权重进行小幅调整的方法，从输出层一直返回到网络的内部，即所谓的隐藏层。这允许网络随着时间的推移提高其性能，而不会对任何单个训练示例反应过度。同样在80年代，计算机科学家 Yann LeCun 提出了一种非常适合图像处理的网络模型，称为卷积神经网络（或 CNN）。它们从一个输入层开始，该输入层覆盖重叠网格中的输入图像，后续层是前面层的卷积（矩阵乘法）。AT&T 贝尔实验室的 LeCun 小组创建了允许机器阅读和分类手写体的网络信封上的邮政编码技术最终在 1990 年代在美国邮政服务中得到普遍使用，可以说是 AI 神经网络的第一个现实世界应用。

Minsky and Papert showed some significant limitations on the computational power of simple forms of these networks in 1969, prompting general enthusiasm in the area to wane. But work by a dedicated core of scientists continued on more complex multilayer neural networks. An important development came in the mid-1980s in the form of a learning algorithm for neural networks called backpropagation. Backpropagation is a way of making small adjustments to the weights between neurons after an incorrect classification, from the output layer all the way back through the inner, so-called hidden layers of a network. This allows the network to improve its performance over time without overreacting to any single training example. Also in the 1980s, computer scientist Yann LeCun proposed a network model well suited to image processing called convolutional neural nets (or CNNs). These start with an input layer that covers the input image in overlapping grids, and where subsequent layers are convolutions—matrix multiplications—of earlier layers. LeCun’s group at AT&T Bell Laboratories created networks that allowed machines to read and classify handwritten zip codes on envelopes—technology that eventually found its way into common use in the US Postal Service in the 1990s as arguably the first real-world application of AI neural nets.

尽管数字识别取得了成功，但早期的 CNN 并没有很好地扩展，并且在 1990 年代中期人们的兴趣再次消退。但是，在大量标记示例数据集上训练 AI 系统的想法仍然很诱人。最终在 2012 年，随着计算机科学家 Geoff Hinton 和学生（尤其是 Ilya Sutskever 和 Alex Krizhevsky）的发展，多层网络可以有效地处理海量图像训练数据。基于这项工作的名为 AlexNet 的系统在名为 ImageNet 大规模视觉识别挑战赛的第三次公开比赛中击败了竞争对手。（ImageNet 是普林斯顿大学和斯坦福大学创建的价值数百万的图像存储库。）具有超过一层隐藏单元的网络最终开始被称为深度网络，这些网络上的训练被称为深度学习。

Despite the digit-recognition success, early CNNs did not scale well, and interest ebbed again in the mid-1990s. But the idea of an AI system trained on a large data set of labeled examples remained enticing. Eventually in 2012, with developments from computer scientist Geoff Hinton and students (especially Ilya Sutskever and Alex Krizhevsky), massive amounts of image training data could be processed effectively by multilayer networks. A system based on this work called AlexNet trounced its competition in a public third running of a contest called the ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge. (ImageNet was a multimillion image repository created at Princeton and Stanford.) Networks with more than one layer of hidden units eventually began to be called deep networks, and the training on these networks became known as deep learning.

ImageNet CNN 的成功巩固了深度学习非常适用于感知任务（如图像中的对象识别）的观点。Twitter、Facebook、微软和谷歌等公司积极加入深度学习的行列，使用 CNN 让用户找到相似的图像、对照片中的情绪进行分类、标记图像中的人物和物体，并普遍改进各种图像-相关服务。

The ImageNet CNN success solidified the view that deep learning was significantly applicable to perceptual tasks like object recognition in images. Companies like Twitter, Facebook, Microsoft, and Google jumped energetically on the deep-learning bandwagon, using CNNs to allow users to find similar images, classify emotions in photographs, label people and tag objects in images, and generally improve a wide variety of image-related services.

从那时起，深度学习浪潮席卷了整个领域，并以有效的方式用于上述四个主题中的每一个。例如，机器学习一直是自动驾驶汽车技术的关键要素。大约在深度学习彻底改变图像处理的同时，语音识别也以惊人的速度和意想不到的方式被征服。根据谷歌的 Jeff Dean 的说法，深度神经网络的应用提供了“20 年语音研究中最大的单一改进”。这是 Siri、Alexa 和相关产品如此成功的关键原因。

Since then, the deep learning wave has swept the field and been used in effective ways on each of the four themes discussed above. Machine learning has been a key element in self-driving car technology, for instance. Around the same time that image processing was being revolutionized by deep learning, speech recognition was also conquered in a surprisingly fast and unexpected way. According to Jeff Dean at Google, the application of deep neural networks provided the “biggest single improvement in 20 years of speech research.” This is a pivotal reason why Siri, Alexa, and related products have been so successful.

其他应用程序也纷纷效仿。各种产品建议服务，从 Amazon 到 Netflix 再到 YouTube，都使用深度学习来提高推荐引擎的性能。雅虎、谷歌、Facebook 等大型广告平台使用机器学习对用户会话中收集的数据进行广告服务器训练，从而可以提供极其相关的广告推荐。（值得注意的是，最惊人的成果最初来自谷歌、IBM 和微软等公司，它们可以访问海量数据。）2017 年，天文学家在 20 多年前发现了一个由八颗行星组成的太阳系。五百光年之外，通过应用一个神经网络，该神经网络在通过开普勒望远镜四年收集的大量数据集上进行训练。Nest 家用恒温器使用机器学习来调节温度，方法是在安装后的前几周学习用户的手动更改，然后推断人们的日程安排和温度偏好。到 2015 年，战斗口号从“知识就是力量”变为“数据为王”。

Other applications followed suit. Product advice services of various sorts, from Amazon to Netflix to YouTube, use deep learning to improve the performance of their recommendation engines. Large-scale advertising platforms, like Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and others, trained their ad servers using machine learning on the data collected over user sessions, allowing uncannily relevant advertisement recommendations to be made. (It is worth noting that the achievement of the most stunning gains came initially from companies like Google, IBM, and Microsoft, which had access to enormous amounts of data.) In 2017, astronomers discovered an eight-planet solar system more than twenty-five hundred light-years away by applying a neural network trained on a huge data set collected through the Kepler telescope over four years. The Nest home thermostat uses machine learning to regulate temperature by learning from manual changes by users over the first few weeks after installation, and then inferring people’s schedules and temperature preferences. By 2015, the battle cry had changed from “knowledge is power” to “data is king.”

现代机器学习最令人印象深刻的成就之一是谷歌翻译。几乎从一开始，人类语言之间的机器翻译就一直是 AI 的愿望，而谷歌翻译使用数据驱动、基于统计模型的方法，在 2006 年推出时是一个很有前途的新进入者。但谷歌的突破2016 年深度学习的应用彻底改变了游戏规则。使用计算机科学家 Yoshua Bengio 和其他人对单词和单词序列的新颖表示，一个特殊的网络在数量惊人（估计超过三千万）的人工翻译句子对上进行了训练。其中许多来自政府的多种语言来源，例如加拿大议会的记录。转向谷歌的神经机器翻译从根本上提高了其能力的质量和范围。正如任何人都可以在网上确认的那样，谷歌翻译是一项非凡的成就，目前支持超过一百种语言，并且随着时间的推移不断改进。另一方面，像许多这样的翻译系统一样，它在段落长度的文本上表现不佳，并且很容易混淆相同单词的不同含义。（许多作者，包括马库斯、戴维斯和米切尔，都对谷歌翻译和其他深度学习系统的失败进行了分类。）它在段落长度的文本上表现不佳，并且很容易与相同单词的不同含义混淆。（许多作者，包括马库斯、戴维斯和米切尔，都对谷歌翻译和其他深度学习系统的失败进行了分类。）它在段落长度的文本上表现不佳，并且很容易与相同单词的不同含义混淆。（许多作者，包括马库斯、戴维斯和米切尔，都对谷歌翻译和其他深度学习系统的失败进行了分类。）

One of the more impressive achievements of modern machine learning is Google Translate. Machine translation between human languages had been an aspiration for AI since almost its beginning, and Google Translate, using a data-driven, statistical-model-based approach, was a promising new entrant when it was introduced in 2006. But a breakthrough by Google in the application of deep learning in 2016 changed the game completely. Using a novel representation of words and word sequences from computer scientist Yoshua Bengio and others, a special network was trained on a staggering number (estimated to be more than thirty million) of human-translated pairs of sentences. Many of these came from government sources in multiple languages, like the records of the Canadian Parliament. The switch to Google’s neural machine translation radically improved the quality and scope of its abilities. As anyone can confirm online, Google Translate is an extraordinary achievement that currently supports more than a hundred languages, and one that keeps improving over time. On the other hand, like many such translation systems, it doesn’t do well on paragraph-length texts and can get easily mixed up with different senses of the same words. (Many authors, including Marcus, Davis, and Mitchell, have cataloged failures in Google Translate and other deep learning systems.)

NL 领域的另一个深度学习技术的最新产品是来自 OpenAI 研究实验室的名为 Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) 的系统。粗略地说，GPT 所做的是猜测它所提供的任何输入的完成情况——通常是一些文本片段。用户可能会输入

Another recent product of deep learning technology in the area of NL is a system called Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) from the OpenAI research lab. What GPT does, roughly speaking, is to guess at a completion of any input it is given—typically some fragment of text. A user might type in

我在雅典长大。我说得很流利 ……

I grew up in Athens. I speak fluent …

GPT回应

and GPT responds with

……希腊语。我从小学就开始写希腊文了。

… Greek. I’ve been writing Greek since elementary school.

它是如何做到这一点的？它使用了一个巨大的网络（最新版本中有 1750 亿个参数）训练了惊人数量的文本——数千亿个单词。整个维基百科——所有 600 万篇文章——据说不到其训练集的 1%。《纽约时报》称其为“有史以来最强大的‘语言模型’”。结果确实令人印象深刻，并促成了一波新的应用，包括基于问题的搜索引擎、代码生成引擎，甚至是允许您与历史人物“交谈”的聊天机器人。

How does it manage to do this? It uses a gigantic network (175 billion parameters in the latest version) trained on staggering amounts of text—hundreds of billions of words. The entire Wikipedia—all 6 million articles—is said to be less than 1 percent of its training set. The New York Times called it “the most powerful ‘language model’ ever created.” The results can indeed be impressive and have facilitated a wave of new applications, including question-based search engines, code generation engines, and even chatbots that allow you to “talk” to historical figures.

它的效果如何？最新版本（截至撰写本文时）称为 GPT-3，但早期版本 GPT-2 可在线免费使用和测试。出现的是：有时它产生的答案是完美的；有时它产生的答案是完美的。有时答案很古怪，出乎您的意料，但仍然相关且发人深省；有时答案只是胡言乱语。这是一个例子：

And how well does it work? The latest version (as of the time of this writing) is called GPT-3, but an earlier version, GPT-2, is available online for free use and testing. What emerges is this: sometimes the answers it produces are perfect; sometimes the answers are quirky and not what you might have expected, but still relevant and thought-provoking; and sometimes the answers are just plain gibberish. Here’s one example:

我想要一些生日蛋糕。我应该 ……

I want some birthday cake. I should …

……去更危险的地方被捕。

… go to a more dangerous place and get arrested.

对于非正式用途，GPT 非常有趣。但当答案很重要时，就很难认真对待它产生的结果。这不仅仅是因为它偶尔会犯错误；就是毫不犹豫地，它以一种人类从未有过的方式失败。并且没有关于什么会引发它的押韵或理由。（我们将在第 11 章使用 AlexNet 再次看到这个问题。）虽然 GPT 产生的输出总是流畅的并且主要是主题，但它并没有反映对世界的任何真正理解。就像谷歌翻译一样，它不知道自己在说什么。

For informal use, GPT is great fun. But when the answers matter, it is tough to take what it produces seriously. It’s not just that it makes occasional mistakes; it’s that with no hesitation at all, it flubs in a way no human ever would. And there’s no rhyme or reason as to what will set it off. (We will see this issue again with AlexNet in chapter 11.) While the output GPT produces is invariably fluent and mostly on topic, it does not reflect any real understanding of the world. Like Google Translate, it has no idea what it’s talking about.

最后，关于机器学习技术最近取得的成功，无不提到谷歌的 DeepMind 团队在玩游戏方面取得的惊人成功。在 2013 年的一次会议上展示街机视频游戏能力后，DeepMind 于 2014 年被谷歌收购，并将其目标定得更高：学习下围棋，它被认为比国际象棋复杂得多。在通过与自己对抗数百万次来提高其能力（借用塞缪尔多年前在他的跳棋程序中发明的技术）之后，DeepMind 的 AlphaGo 程序在 2016 年击败了世界顶级围棋选手之一李世石，震惊了世界. 显然，至少有两亿人观看了比赛的一部分——令人震惊的观众，比观看次数最多的超级碗的全球观众还要多。随后，AlphaGo 在 2017 年击败了世界顶级棋手柯洁。

Finally, no account of the recent success of machine learning technology can fail to mention the stunning success of Google’s DeepMind group in game playing. Following a sparkling display of competence in arcade video games at a conference in 2013, DeepMind was acquired by Google in 2014 and set its sights substantially higher: learning to play the ancient Chinese game of Go, taken to be much more complex than chess. After improving its ability by playing against itself millions of times (borrowing a technique originated by Samuel with his checkers-playing program years before), the AlphaGo program from DeepMind shocked the world in 2016 by defeating one of the world’s premier Go players, Lee Sedol. Apparently some two hundred million people watched at least part of the match—an astounding audience, bigger than the worldwide audience for the most-watched Super Bowl. AlphaGo then went on to defeat the world’s top player, Ke Jie, in 2017.

鉴于其在公众认可度和商业知名度方面的显着提升，深度学习对人工智能领域产生了惊人的影响。在各种各样的任务中都取得了令人印象深刻的、在某些情况下超人的表现。在大众眼里，人工智能就是深度学习。但仅依赖训练数据也带来了一个重大缺陷：如果训练集与预期的使用环境不匹配，系统就没有其他可以依赖的东西。换句话说，将数据作为大规模学习的主要燃料既是一种祝福——消除了专家系统手动知识获取的挑战——也是一种诅咒，因为成功完全取决于用于训练的数据。正如研究员 François Chollet 所说，“虽然我们能够设计出在特定任务上表现非常出色的系统，

Given its dramatic rise to public recognition and commercial prominence, deep learning has had an astonishing impact on the field of AI. Impressive and in some cases superhuman performance has been achieved on a wide variety of tasks. In the public eye, AI means deep learning. But the reliance on training data alone also entails a major deficiency: if the training sets don’t match the expected context of use, the systems have nothing else to fall back on. In other words, having data as the primary fuel for massive learning is both a blessing—eliminating the manual knowledge acquisition challenge of expert systems—and a curse, in that success is totally dependent on that data used for training. As researcher François Chollet puts it, “Although we are able to engineer systems that perform extremely well on specific tasks, they have still stark limitations, being brittle, data-hungry, unable to make sense of situations that deviate slightly from their training data or the assumptions of their creators, and unable to repurpose themselves to deal with novel tasks without significant involvement from human researchers.”

数据可能已经成为国王，但它只统治着自己有限的领域，在其明确划定的边界之外没有主权。

Data may have become king, but it rules over only its own limited domain with no sovereignty beyond its sharply delineated borders.

人工智能系统的教训

The Lesson from AI Systems

我们可以从上述示例中了解 AI 系统的优势和局限性吗？从表面上看，它们似乎没有什么共同点——不同领域的不同应用程序以完全不同的方式实现。我们看到的一个共同点是，成功通常取决于巨大的计算资源所支持的蛮力。对于 Deep Blue，这是蛮力搜索；对于谷歌翻译，这是蛮力数据。

What can we learn about the strengths and limitations of AI systems from the examples presented above? On the surface, they seem to have little in common—different applications in different domains realized in quite different ways. One common thread we saw is that success often depends on brute force enabled by immense computational resources. For Deep Blue, it was brute-force search; for Google Translate, it was brute-force data.

但是如果我们进一步思考这些例子，我们可以看到它们确实具有以下两个属性：

But if we reflect further on the examples, we can see that they do share the following two properties:

  1. 1. 人工智能系统在某些专业领域表现出高水平的表现。它可能用于识别猫的照片、诊断血液感染或玩街机视频游戏。在许多情况下，性能超出了人类的能力。
  2. 1. The AI system exhibits a high level of performance in some area of expertise. It might be in recognizing photos of cats, diagnosing blood infections, or playing arcade video games. In many cases, the performance exceeds what humans are capable of.
  3. 2. 人工智能系统在其专业领域之外表现极差。假设它可以用尚未明确设计来处理的输入来呈现，它甚至无法达到最低水平的能力。该系统在其应对能力方面体现了一种脆弱性。
  4. 2. The AI system performs extremely poorly outside its area of expertise. Assuming it can be presented with input it has not been explicitly designed to handle, it fails to achieve even a minimal level of competence. The system exemplifies a kind of brittleness in its ability to cope.

由于这两个特性，很难将这些系统的行为直接与我们对人类的了解联系起来。在试图描述他们的整体表现时，支持者有时会说他们的系统表现出“智能”，但这个词通常并不适用于人。

Because of these two properties, it is difficult to relate the behavior of these systems directly to what we know of humans. In attempting to characterize their overall performance, proponents sometimes say that their systems exhibit “intelligence,” but not as the term is normally applied to people.

事实上，有一个适用于人类的术语确实非常接近地匹配这两个属性。“白痴学者”是一个有严重精神或学习障碍的人，但在执行某些专门的智力壮举方面却具有超凡的天赋。一个著名的例子是达斯汀霍夫曼在电影雨人中扮演的角色。上述性质（1）是“学者”部分，而（2）是“白痴”部分。

There is in fact a term applied to humans that does match the two properties fairly closely. An “idiot savant” is a person with a severe mental or learning disability that is nonetheless superbly gifted in performing certain specialized mental feats. A well-known illustration is the character played by Dustin Hoffman in the movie Rain Man. Property (1) above is the “savant” part, while (2) is the “idiot” part.

当我们说一个系统在其专业领域之外表现不佳时，所缺少的并不是第二或第三领域的高级专业知识。这并不是说我们期望血液诊断应用程序可以下象棋或语言翻译系统来证明数学中的定理。我们更期待的是某种通用能力，即使是非专业人士也拥有：常识。人工智能系统之所以难以用人类的术语来描述，是因为它们以某种方式设法获得了令人印象深刻的专业知识水平，而无需首先获得甚至是基本的常识。这是人工智能的一大讽刺：它实际上与人类完全相反。几乎所有人都具有常识，很少有人在具有挑战性的领域拥有深厚的专业知识，例如医学诊断、矿物勘探或围棋，

When we say that a system performs poorly outside its area of expertise, what is missing is not high-level expertise in a second or third area. It’s not that we expect a blood diagnosis application to play grandmaster-level chess or a language translation system to prove theorems in mathematics. It’s more that we expect some sort of general-purpose ability that even nonexpert humans have: common sense. What makes AI systems so hard to characterize in human terms is that they somehow manage to acquire an impressive level of specialized expertise without having first acquired even rudimentary common sense. This is the great irony of AI: it’s been virtually the exact opposite of people. Almost all humans exhibit common sense, and only rarely possess deep expertise in challenging areas like medical diagnosis, mineral prospecting, or Go, yet AI systems have most commonly achieved excellence in such limited special domains, and none of them have common sense.

但是，具有专业知识的 AI 系统甚至需要常识来做什么？答案是常识会允许它以合理的方式处理超出其直接专业领域的事情，以便至少像我们在第 2 章中讨论的那样避免明显的错误，就像我们在第 2 章中讨论的那样。遭遇是棋盘，它所需要担心的只是赢得比赛，常识真的不会增加任何东西。常识将发挥作用的地方是我们跳出棋盘，将国际象棋游戏视为发生在现实世界中的活动。

But what would an AI system with expertise even need common sense for? The answer is that common sense would allow it to deal in a reasonable way with things beyond its immediate area of expertise so as to at least avoid obvious blunders the way a nonexpert human would, as we discussed in chapter 2. If all a system ever encounters are chessboards, and all it ever has to worry about is winning the game, common sense really adds nothing to the mix. Where common sense will have a role to play is when we venture beyond the chessboard and think of a chess game as an activity that takes place in the real world.

开放和封闭系统

Open and Closed Systems

要了解现实世界中像国际象棋这样的游戏可能意味着什么，请考虑父母在与孩子玩竞技游戏时必须处理的问题，尤其是当他们希望孩子从游戏中获得积极体验时。

To get a sense of what a game like chess in the real world might mean, consider what parents have to deal with when playing competitive games with their children, especially when they want their children to come away with a positive experience of the game.

“国际象棋家长”当然必须能够相当好地下国际象棋。只有最小的孩子喜欢轻易获胜。但打得好远不是故事的全部。父母必须清楚地区分赢得比赛和击败对手。没有孩子愿意在单方面的竞争中受到羞辱。因此，国际象棋父母要么必须输掉一些比赛，要么接近足够让孩子保持兴趣和动力。尽管如此，家长也绝不能被视为故意扔掉游戏。没有人喜欢被屈尊。因此，国际象棋家长需要遵循输赢之间的复杂界限。（类似的考虑适用于国际象棋俱乐部的“国际象棋专家”或网球俱乐部的“网球专家”。）

A “chess parent” of course has to be able to play chess reasonably well. Only the youngest of children enjoy winning too easily. But playing well is far from the whole story. A parent has to clearly distinguish between winning a game and trouncing the opponent. No child will want to be humiliated in one-sided contests. So a chess parent will either have to lose some games, or come close enough to keep the child interested and motivated. Still, the parent must never be seen to be deliberately throwing the game either. Nobody likes being condescended to. So there is a complex line between winning and losing that a chess parent needs to follow. (Similar considerations apply to a “chess pro” in a chess club or “tennis pro” in a tennis club.)

在现有的人工智能国际象棋程序中，当前的棋盘（或者可能是导致它的移动列表）实际上是决定如何移动的全部考虑因素。然而，对于国际象棋家长或国际象棋专家来说，在决定如何移动时需要考虑更多，特别是何时更加努力以及何时放松。孩子今天玩得怎么样？该游戏是作为休闲娱乐还是更剧烈的锻炼？孩子是否对游戏感到沮丧，或者他们是否急于接受更苛刻的挑战？在这种情况下，国际象棋的走法更像是拳击中的格斗走法，应该对对手当前的需求和能力做出反应。每一步都传达了这样的信息：“这一步可能不是我在这个棋盘上能下的最好的一步，但它是一个很好的一步，让我们看看你对此的反应。” 被对手视为过强或过弱的举动会破坏目的。

In existing AI chess programs, the current chessboard (or maybe a list of the moves that led to it) is really all that is taken into account in deciding how to move. For a chess parent or chess pro, though, there is more to consider in deciding how to move, and in particular, when to try harder and when to ease up somewhat. How well is the child playing today? Is the game intended as light recreation or a more strenuous workout? Is the child feeling frustrated by the game or are they anxious to take on more demanding challenges? A chess move in this context is more like a sparring move in boxing, and ought to be responsive to the current needs and abilities of the opponent. Each move communicates something like this: “This move is maybe not the best one I could make on this chessboard, but it is a good one, and let’s see your response to it.” Moves that are seen by the opponent as overly strong or overly weak defeat the purpose.

当然，国际象棋家长所做的不仅仅是做出合法的国际象棋动作。棘手的部分是描述棋盘之外的因素，这些因素可能与决定下一步做什么有关。例如，考虑一下可能会迫使国际象棋家长停止或推迟正在进行的比赛的原因。一些这些都是普通的事情——狗把棋盘打翻了，棋局打得太久了，快到吃饭时间了，或者孩子脾气暴躁——但有些情况会更罕见——孩子受伤了一颗棋子，房子着火，远方失散多年的堂兄来访，或者龙卷风席卷整个社区。所以有些因素与国际象棋有关，有些与细心的父母有关，有些只是常识。

Of course, a chess parent does more than make legal chess moves. The tricky part is characterizing the factors beyond the chessboard that might be relevant in deciding what to do next. Consider, for example, what might compel a chess parent to stop or postpone a game in progress. Some of these will be ordinary things—the dog has knocked over the chessboard, the game has gone on for too long, it’s getting close to mealtime, or the child is getting cranky—but some of them will be much rarer—the child is injured by a chess piece, the house catches on fire, a long-lost cousin from a distant country arrives for a visit, or a tornado sweeps through the neighborhood. So some of the factors will be chess related, some will involve being an attentive parent, and some will be just common sense.

在谈论现在和未来的 AI 系统时，考虑系统的行为如何反映其工作环境是很有用的。能够用于决定如何表现。因此，例如，当前的国际象棋系统是封闭的：它们的行为仅是对当前棋盘的响应。他们生活在一个虚构的世界里，那里只有棋盘和棋子。一个更复杂的国际象棋系统也考虑了对手的技能水平（根据该水平有能力下得更好或更差）仍然是封闭的。在这种情况下，一旦指定了棋盘和关卡，其他的都不重要了。

In talking about present and future AI systems, it is useful to consider how the behavior of the system reflects the environment it is working in. Let us call a system closed if we can enumerate in advance all the parameters in the environment that the system will be able to use in deciding how to behave. So for example, current chess systems are closed: their behavior is solely in response to the current chessboard. They live in an imaginary world where chessboards and pieces are all that exists. A more elaborate chess system that also takes into account the skill level of its opponent (with the ability to play better or worse according to that level) would still be closed. In this case, once the chessboard and level are specified, nothing else matters.

系统之所以开放，是因为我们无法提前预测在决定如何行动时可能需要考虑世界的哪些特征。因此，虽然当前的国际象棋系统是封闭的，但国际象棋的父母需要开放。我们不能期望提前列出国际象棋家长在决定何时中断比赛时可能需要考虑的所有事项。清单会提到龙卷风吗？失散多年的堂兄弟？

What makes a system open is that we cannot predict in advance what features of the world might need to be considered in deciding how to behave. So while current chess systems are closed, a chess parent needs to be open. We cannot expect to make a list in advance of all the things a chess parent might need to take into account in deciding when to interrupt a game. Would the list mention tornadoes? Long-lost cousins?

当然，没有人考虑构建人工智能系统来充当国际象棋的家长。这只是为了说明一点。但这里提出的问题出现在现在正在开发的更现实的系统中——其中许多将对人类生活产生深远影响，例如自动驾驶汽车。（我们将在第 11 章回到它们和开放系统。）

Of course, nobody is contemplating building AI systems to serve as chess parents. This was just to illustrate a point. But the issues raised here arise in more realistic systems that are being developed now—many of which will have profound impacts on human lives such as self-driving cars. (We will return to them and open systems in chapter 11.)

总而言之，我们可以看到，当前的人工智能系统——无论是经过深度学习训练的系统、专家系统还是游戏玩家——都具有以下相似之处：在由它们设计处理的参数决定的封闭环境中，它们可以表现出色，有时表现出色；在这些限制之外，他们表现不佳。他们没有常识，人们必须应对现实生活中发生的许多不可预知的事情，比如龙卷风和失散多年的表亲。当我们看到他们误入歧途时，我们甚至无法引导他们。

In sum, then, we can see that current AI systems—whether deep learning trained, expert systems, or game players—are similar in the following way: within the closed environment determined by the parameters they have been designed to deal with, they can perform well, and sometimes amazingly well; outside those limits, they perform poorly. They have nothing like the common sense that people have to deal with the many unpredictable things that happen outside the box in real life, like tornadoes and long-lost cousins. And we can’t even steer them when we see them going astray.

超越专业知识

Beyond Expertise

在我们卷起袖子深入了解常识的细节以及我们想象它如何在 AI 系统中工作之前，值得简要考虑一下我们是否可以走一条更简单的道路并避免所有的并发症。可能有人会问，为什么我们不会像现在这样继续构建 AI 系统，而是拥有越来越大的专业领域，直到这些系统广泛到足以成为他们将看到的几乎所有事物的专家？然后常识就可以自发地出现，而无需我们对此做任何特别的事情。

Before we roll up our sleeves to get into the details of common sense and how we imagine it could work in an AI system, it is worth briefly considering whether we could take an easier path and avoid all the complications. Why, it might be asked, would we not continue to build AI systems as we currently do, but with ever-larger domains of expertise, until those systems are broad enough to be experts on virtually everything they will get to see? Common sense could then emerge spontaneously, without us having to do anything special about it.

这种涌现现象的想法听起来有点像魔术，但在大量微观事件导致宏观影响的领域，这一点很明显。经济学中的一个例子是，自由市场中自利的买卖双方如何自动达成合适的价格——至少在理论上是这样。在生物学中，这个概念最常应用于由微小动物的个体行为产生的大型结构，例如白蚁丘。

This idea of emergent phenomena may sound a bit like magic, but it is evident in areas where macroscopic effects result from a large number of microscopic events. An example in economics is how appropriate prices are arrived at automatically by the to-and-fro of self-interested buyers and sellers in a free market—in theory anyway. In biology, the concept is most often applied to the large-scale structures that result from the individual actions of tiny animals such as termite mounds.

例如，考虑一个基于深度学习的人工智能系统。这个想法是为系统提供足够的数据（当然是在很长一段时间内），以便其培训最终足以涵盖系统可能需要处理的任何事情。最常见的事物类型会在训练中频繁出现，但如果数据真的足够大，最终也会看到更罕见的事物（甚至可能是龙卷风或失散多年的亲人的意外来访）。随着越来越多的数据可以依赖，系统将开始犯越来越少的错误。肯定还会有一些极其罕见的东西，系统不会接受训练，然后可能不会做得很好，但如果它们真的那么罕见，我们为什么要担心它们呢？由此产生的系统可能不是绝对完美的，但正如我们已经看到的，人类也不是。完美不是善的敌人吗？

Think, for instance, of an AI system based on deep learning. The idea would be to provide the system with enough data (over a long period of time, of course) so that its training would eventually be sufficient to cover anything the system might need to deal with. The most common types of things would be seen frequently in the training, yet if the data is truly massive enough, much rarer things (maybe even tornadoes or unexpected visits from long-lost relatives) would eventually be seen as well. With more and more data to lean on, the system would start making fewer and fewer blunders. There certainly would still be some extremely rare things that the system would not get trained on, and might then not do too well on, although if they really are that rare, why should we worry about them? The resulting system might not be absolutely perfect, but as we saw already, neither are humans. Isn’t the perfect the enemy of the good?

重要的是要理解为什么这个论点是错误的。实际上有两个问题需要考虑：现实世界中发生的事件的范围，以及有时称为事件分布的长尾。

It is important to understand why this argument is wrong. There are really two issues to consider: the scope of the events that occur in the real world, and what is sometimes called the long tail of their distribution.

第一，范围。或许我们可以寄希望于这样一个事实，即虽然数量庞大，但系统需要处理的宇宙中的对象数量是可管理的。但这救不了我们。当我们想到世界上的事件时，我们将它们理解为涉及对象的集合，但集合以某种方式排列。仅仅说发生了狗和人的咬伤事件是不够的；我们需要知道是狗咬人还是人咬狗。我们都见过闹钟、救生衣、购物车和小熊，但可以肯定地说，没有人见过穿着救生衣的小熊推着装满闹钟的购物车。这些对象可能都很熟悉，但构成事件的是对象的排列，并且排列可能是新的并且相当陌生。

First, the scope. Perhaps we can rest our hope on the fact that while a huge number, there are only a manageable number of objects in the universe that a system would need to deal with. But that won’t save us. When we think of events in the world, we understand them as involving collections of objects, but collections arranged in a certain way. It’s not enough to say that there was a biting event involving a dog and person; we need to know if the dog bit the person or the person bit the dog. We’ve all seen alarm clocks, life jackets, grocery carts, and bear cubs, yet it is safe to say that nobody has ever witnessed a bear cub wearing a life jacket pushing a grocery cart loaded with alarm clocks. The objects might all be familiar, but it’s the arrangement of the objects that makes up the event, and the arrangement can be new and quite unfamiliar.

即使是少量的物体也可以以天文数字的方式排列。我们可以用文字最清楚地看到这一点。同样，重要的不是单个单词；这是他们在短语和句子中的安排——“dog bites person”和“person bites dog”之间的区别——是压倒性的。例如，考虑四个单词的英语句子。即使每个点只有一千个单词，仍然会有一万亿不同的四字句。八个字的句子，万亿万亿。这就解释了为什么我们阅读的新文本——包括短文本——仍然如此新鲜和原创。我们甚至可以用词对来观察这个现象。想想威廉布莱克的诗“老虎”中的“可怕的对称”。这两个词本身并不起眼；正是他们在那首诗中的组合如此引人注目和令人难忘。

Even a small number of objects can be arranged in an astronomical number of ways. We can see this most clearly with words. Again, it’s not the individual words that matter; it’s their arrangement in phrases and sentences—the difference between “dog bites person” and “person bites dog”—that is overwhelming. Consider, for example, four-word English sentences. Even if there were only one thousand words to use at each point, there would still be a trillion different four-word sentences. With eight-word sentences, it’s a trillion trillion. This explains why new pieces of text we read—including short ones—continue to be so fresh and original. We can even see the phenomenon with pairs of words. Consider “fearful symmetry” in the poem “The Tyger” by William Blake. The two words themselves are unremarkable; it’s their combination in that poem that is so striking and memorable.

更令人望而生畏的是，即使我们阅读了所有小说的第一句话，我们仍然只能对可能性的范围有轻微的暗示。下一部小说的第一句话可能会完全不同和出乎意料。它可能会这样说：

More dauntingly, even if we were to read the first sentence of every novel ever written, we would still only get a slight hint at the range of possibilities. The first sentence of the very next novel might be totally different and unexpected. It might say this:

昨天，当我所有的烦恼都离我远去时，马勒第七交响曲的七个音符——1986 年从另一颗星星传来的著名号角声——从大厅另一头的无线电飘进了我的房间，日内瓦告别立刻又回到了我的脑海。

Yesterday, when all my troubles were somewhat farther away, seven notes of Mahler’s seventh symphony—the famous horn call that arrived from another star in 1986—drifted into my room from a wireless down the hall and Geneva Farewell was instantly restored to me.

谁能预料到这一点？我们是否可以通过对所有其他小说的第一句的分析来预测像这样的小说？这些词当然很熟悉，但安排是独一无二的，与之前的任何安排都截然不同。

Who could have predicted this? Could we have used an analysis of the first sentences of all the other novels to come to anticipate something like this one? The words are certainly familiar, but the arrangement is unique and quite unlike any that preceded it.

现在考虑事件的分布。这是简化形式的想法：想象一张有一亿张彩票的彩票。挑选任何给定门票的机会都微乎其微——也就是说，只有一亿分之一。现在假设每天的每一分钟都随机选择一张彩票（然后更换）。因为彩票太大了，即使过了一个世纪，看到一张特定彩票的机会仍然不到五五十。尽管如此，每分钟都会抽出一张票，这意味着在这个世界上，每分钟都会发生一件极其罕见的事情。

Now consider the distribution of events. Here is the idea in simplified form: imagine a lottery with a hundred million tickets. The chance of picking any given ticket will be miniscule—that is, one in a hundred million. Now suppose that every minute of every day a lottery ticket is chosen at random (and then replaced). Because the lottery is so big, the chance of seeing a particular ticket even after a century is still less than fifty-fifty. Nonetheless, some ticket is drawn every minute, meaning that in this world, an extremely rare event happens every minute.

现实世界有点像这种彩票。任何时候都可能发生许多不同寻常的事情，以至于极其罕见的事情一直都在发生。当然，很难从数学上证实这一说法——我们需要计算可能发生的事情的数量——但我们可以在一个涉及单词的真实世界示例中非常清楚地看到这种所谓的长尾现象。

The real world is somewhat like this lottery. There are so many different exceptional things that can happen at any time that extremely rare ones happen all the time. Of course it would be tough to confirm this claim mathematically—we would need a count of how many things can happen—but we can see this so-called long-tail phenomenon quite clearly in an actual real-world example involving words once again.

British National Corpus 是一个巨大的英语文本数据库，包含来自各种来源的英语文本。它总共有大约1亿个单词。大多数单词都很常见并且经常出现。“the”这个词是最常见的，出现了 600 万次。“时间”一词是最常见的名词，出现了 183,000 次。然而，有些罕见的词在整个语料库中只出现一次。英国形容词“niffy”，意思是“臭”，就是这样一个例子。所以从语料库中随机选出其中一个词的几率是亿分之一，就像上面的彩票一样。然而，语料库中这些单次出现的词太多了，它们大约占总数的 0.5%。一个简单的计算表明，如果我们要从这个庞大的语料库中随机抽取 140 个词——比本段中的词更少——从这些罕见的单次出现词中挑选一个的几率将高于 550 个。极其罕见的词很常见！

The British National Corpus is a gigantic database of English text drawn from a variety of sources. It has about 100 million words in total. Most of the words are common and occur often. The word “the” is the most common, occurring 6 million times. The word “time” is the most common noun, occurring 183,000 times.
