Yet there are some rare words that show up only once in the entire corpus. The British adjective “niffy,” meaning “stinky,” is one such case. So the chance of selecting one of these words at random from the corpus is one in a hundred million, just like a lottery ticket above. There are so many of these single-occurrence words in the corpus, however, that they make up roughly 0.5 percent of the total overall. An easy calculation shows that if we were to draw 140 words at random from this massive corpus—fewer words than in this paragraph—the odds of picking one of those rare single-occurrence ones would be better than fifty-fifty. Extremely rare words are quite common!

我们可以从这些考虑中得出什么结论？世界是由一系列从天文大小的池中提取的事件组成的。虽然这些事件中的大多数都是熟悉和意料之中的，但其中许多事件——比如那些每天都登上报纸的事件——是极不可能发生的。一个人工智能系统已经获得了一种专业知识，可以考虑除最不可能发生的事件之外的所有事件，但仍然会错过一直发生的事件。换句话说，如果我们希望 AI 系统能够以合理的方式处理现实世界中经常发生的事情，我们需要的不仅仅是从抽样中获得的专业知识已经发生的事情。考虑到压倒性的大数字，仅仅基于看到和内化过去发生的事情来预测未来是行不通的，无论蛮力多么残酷。我们需要常识。

What conclusion can we draw from these considerations? The world is made up of a sequence of events drawn from a pool of astronomical size. While most of these events are familiar and expected, many of them—like those that make it into newspapers every day—are extremely unlikely. An AI system that has acquired a form of expertise that takes into account all but the most extremely unlikely events will still miss out on events that occur all the time. In other words, if we want AI systems to be able to deal in a reasonable way with things that happen in the real world quite commonly, we need something beyond an expertise that derives from sampling what has already occurred. Given the overwhelmingly large numbers, predicting the future based simply on seeing and internalizing what has taken place in the past won’t cut it, no matter how brutish the brute force. We need common sense.

在结束本章时，我们并不是说人工智能完全回避了常识这个话题。尽管 AI 的总体重点显然是开发具有各种专业知识的系统，但我们将在下一章中看到，AI 有史以来最大的单一项目实际上直接针对常识。

In concluding this chapter, we do not mean to suggest that AI has completely avoided the topic of common sense. Although the overall emphasis in AI has clearly been on developing systems with specialized expertise of various kinds, we will see in the next chapter that the single-largest project ever undertaken in AI was in fact aimed squarely at common sense.

4个

4

知识及其表示

Knowledge and Its Representation

在你把它写下来之前，这不是一个想法。

It’s not an idea until you write it down.

—Ivan Sutherland，在Dan Ryan 的History of Computer Graphics中报道

—Ivan Sutherland, reported in History of Computer Graphics, by Dan Ryan

常识应该如何发挥作用，使人类能够有效地应对他们遇到的新的和未预料到的情况，这一点远非显而易见。回想一下，我们将常识定义为为此目的利用日常知识的能力。但这究竟意味着什么？一个人如何“利用”像想法这样抽象的东西？这只是一种修辞手法，比如控制住自己或失控吗？这是只有人才能做的事情，还是我们认为机器有一天也能做到？要回答这些问题，我们需要更仔细地审视知识的概念。

It is far from obvious how common sense is supposed to work to allow humans to deal effectively with the new and unanticipated situations they experience. Recall that we defined common sense as the ability to make use of everyday knowledge for this purpose. But what does this really mean? Just how does one “make use” of something abstract like an idea? Is this just a figure of speech, like getting ahold of yourself or flying off the handle? Is it something that only people can do, or do we think machines might be able to do it someday too? To answer these questions, we need to look at the notion of knowledge more carefully.

表达知识

Expressing Knowledge

当我们第一次想到知识时，当我们学习某事时我们会获得什么，我们倾向于把它想象成对世界的某种一般印象。例如，你对你的家乡了解多少？它看起来更像是一种巨大的、渗透的感觉，而不是一些小的、个人的想法的集合。比起一堆单独的配料，更像是一道炖菜。

When we first think about knowledge, what it is we acquire when we learn something, we have the tendency to imagine it as some sort of general impression about the world. What do you know about your hometown, for instance? It seems more like a big, permeating feeling than a collection of small, individual thoughts. More like a stew, say, than a bunch of individual ingredients.

根据萨瑟兰的说法，部分问题在于我们所知道的很多东西很难用语言表达，也很难真正写下来。当我们谈论所谓的程序性知识时，这一点最为明显，例如如何控制溜溜球或揉面团。但是很多我们对具体事物的了解，人或地方感觉相似。我们可能会被问到，“1969 年在伍德斯托克感觉如何？” 或者“土星五号火箭的声音是什么？” 我们可能会举手回答，“你必须在那里！” 不知所措的情况经常发生，以至于我们可能会认为我们所知道的最重要的事情无法用语言来表达。

Part of the problem is that so much of what we know is hard to put into words, to actually write down, as per Sutherland. This is most obvious when we talk about what is called procedural knowledge such as how to control a yo-yo or knead dough. But a lot of what we know about specific things, people, or places feels similar. We might be asked, “What was it like to be at Woodstock in 1969?” or “What is the sound of a Saturn V rocket?” and we might throw up our hands and answer, “You had to be there!” Being at a loss for words happens so often that we may be tempted to think that the most important things we know cannot be expressed in words.

但这太简单了。总的来说，当我们说语言无法表达某事时，我们真正的意思是这并不容易。虽然我们可能不习惯将某些事情用语言表达出来，但只要付出一点脑力，我们就可以做到，而且比我们最初想象的更频繁。当我们这样做的时候，我们开始意识到我们所知道的很多东西并不是真正的某种无差别的炖菜。它可以被阐明——逐段描述。

But this is too simplistic. In the main, what we really mean when we say that words cannot express something is that it would not be easy. While we might not be accustomed to putting certain things into words, with a bit of mental effort, we can do it, and more frequently than we might first suppose. And when we do, we come to realize that much of what we know is not really some sort of undifferentiated stew. It can be articulated—described piece by piece.

当我们需要使用我们所知道的来实际做某事时，我们可以最清楚地看到这一点。例如，考虑回答如下问题：

We can see this most clearly when we need to use what we know to actually do something. Consider, for example, answering questions like the following:

鳄鱼能跑障碍赛吗？

Could a crocodile run a steeplechase?

石榴能装进洗衣篮吗？

Would a pomegranate fit inside a laundry basket?

生日蛋糕吃之前要洗吗？

Should you wash a birthday cake before eating it?

你能从安大略省的萨德伯里开车到特拉华州的威尔明顿吗？

Can you drive from Sudbury, Ontario, to Wilmington, Delaware?

这四个问题的共同点是，没有什么是你曾经经历过的，也没有什么是你曾被告知的，可以直接给你答案。换句话说，回答每个问题不仅仅是利用你的记忆力和回忆答案是什么。这些词是古老而熟悉的，但问题是新的。

What these four questions have in common is that there is nothing you have ever experienced and nothing you have ever been told that gives you the answer directly. In other words, there is more to answering each question than just using your memory and recalling what the answer is. The words are old and familiar, but the questions are new.

以第一个为例。这几乎肯定是你第一次考虑整个鳄鱼和障碍赛马问题（除非你已经阅读了我们之前的一些工作，因为我们之前使用过这个例子）。事实上，你对如何回答这个问题有预感是因为你已经有了一些鳄鱼知识（独立于障碍赛）和一些障碍赛知识（独立于鳄鱼）。如果你错过了一个或另一个——例如，如果你不知道障碍赛是什么——你就会被困住。然后，尽管您很可能没有意识到这样做，但您必须将这两种知识结合起来才能回答问题。

Take the first one, for instance. This is almost certainly the first time you have ever considered this whole crocodile and steeplechase issue (unless you have read some of our previous work since we have used the example before). The fact that you have a hunch about how to answer the question at all is because you already have some crocodile knowledge (independent of steeplechases) and some steeplechase knowledge (independent of crocodiles). If you were missing one or the other—for example, if you had no idea what a steeplechase was—you would be stuck. Then, although you were most likely not aware of doing so, you had to bring those two pieces of knowledge together to answer the question.

这正是我们一直在谈论的那种常识性推理。您遇到的是一个新的、未预料到的事件——在本例中，一个单词的排列方式与您所见过的任何其他方式都不同——而且您能够以常识的方式处理它。

This is precisely the sort of commonsense reasoning we have been talking about. What you have is a new, unanticipated event—in this case, an arrangement of words different from any other you have ever seen—and you were able to deal with it in a commonsense way.

那么这样做需要什么？至少，你必须能够运用你所拥有的知识片段，并以某种方式将它们组合在一起以获得你想要的响应。首次以某种方式将有关鳄鱼的知识与有关参加障碍赛的知识结合起来，产生了鳄鱼不能参加障碍赛的新想法。

So what is required to do this? At a minimum, you have to be able to bring to bear pieces of knowledge you have and somehow put them together to get the response you want. Knowledge about crocodiles is somehow combined for the first time with knowledge about running steeplechases to produce the new idea that crocodiles cannot run steeplechases.

但是你脑子里到底发生了什么？将两条知识（一条关于鳄鱼，一条关于障碍赛马）结合起来，并以某种方式产生新的第三条关于鳄鱼不能参加障碍赛马的知识，这意味着什么？这是理解常识需要解决的关键理论问题。我们无法在物理学、生物学、神经科学甚至心理学等其他科学领域找到答案。答案——或者至少是我们将在本书中考虑的答案——实际上来自一个不太可能的来源：德国哲学家戈特弗里德莱布尼茨，他在三百多年前（1646-1716 年）生活和工作过。

But what exactly took place in your head? What does it mean to combine two pieces of knowledge, one about crocodiles and the other about steeplechases, and somehow produce a new third item about crocodiles being unable to run steeplechases? This is the key theoretical question that needs to be resolved to make sense of common sense. It is not something we can find an answer to in other areas of science like physics, biology, neuroscience, or even psychology. The answer—or at least the answer we will be considering in this book—actually comes from an unlikely source: the German philosopher Gottfried Leibniz, who lived and worked more than three hundred years ago (1646–1716).

符号表示

Symbolic Representations

简而言之，莱布尼茨回答这个理论问题的建议是，我们应该像考虑使用数字一样考虑使用知识。

In a nutshell, the Leibniz proposal for answering this theoretical question is that we should think of using knowledge the same way we think of using numbers.

所以暂时考虑一下数字。尽管它们纯粹是抽象的想法，但我们仍然与它们一起工作并以各种方式使用它们。例如，给定两个数字，我们可以生成第三个数字，即它们的和。我们实际这样做的方法是使用符号表示：我们将每个数字表示为十进制数字序列，我们对这两个序列进行运算以产生第三个数字序列（带有进位数字等，我们在小学），我们要的数字就是第三个序列所代表的数字。最后，我们不必解决如何利用数字等抽象概念这一棘手问题；我们只需要解决如何用符号表示它们，以及如何正确地操纵这些符号表示。这当然就是我们所说的算术。

So consider numbers for a moment. Although they are purely abstract ideas, we still work with them and put them to use in a variety of ways. For example, given two numbers, we are able to produce a third number that is their sum. The way we actually do this is by using symbolic representations: we represent each number as a sequence of decimal digits, we operate on these two sequences to produce a third sequence of digits (with carry digits and so on, the way we were taught in elementary school), and the number we are after is the one represented by that third sequence. In the end, we do not have to resolve the thorny question of how to make use of abstract ideas like numbers; we only have to resolve how to represent them symbolically, and how to properly manipulate those symbolic representations. This of course is what we call arithmetic.

莱布尼茨的建议是，我们应该以类似的方式来考虑使用知识：我们以某种符号形式表示这两种思想；我们的确是对这些符号结构进行某种算术以产生第三个符号结构；我们追求的最终想法将是这个新的符号结构所代表的想法。这是莱布尼茨自己在 17 世纪的话的翻译：

Leibniz’s proposal is that we should think of using knowledge in a similar way: we represent the two thoughts in some symbolic form; we do some sort of arithmetic over these symbolic structures to produce a third symbolic structure; and the final thought we are after will be the one represented by this new symbolic structure. Here it is in a translation of Leibniz’s own seventeenth-century words:

很明显，如果我们能找到适合表达我们所有思想的字符或符号，就像算术表达数字或几何表达线条一样清晰准确，我们就可以在所有需要推理的事情上做我们在推理中所能做的一切。算术和几何。因为所有依赖于推理的研究都将通过调换这些特征和一种微积分来进行。

It is obvious that if we could find characters or signs suited for expressing all our thoughts as clearly and as exactly as arithmetic expresses numbers or geometry expresses lines, we could do in all matters insofar as they are subject to reasoning all that we can do in arithmetic and geometry. For all investigations which depend on reasoning would be carried out by transposing these characters and by a species of calculus.

同样，我们不必解决如何利用抽象知识的棘手问题；我们只需要解决如何用符号表示它们（他称之为“找到适合表达”它们的字符或符号），以及如何正确地操纵这些符号表示（在他称之为“微积分的种类”中）。

Again we will not have to resolve the thorny question of how to make use of abstract items of knowledge; we only have to resolve how to represent them symbolically (what he calls “find[ing] characters or signs suited for expressing” them), and how to properly manipulate these symbolic representations (in what he calls a “species of calculus”).

所以莱布尼茨的提议有两个强烈的要求：

So the Leibniz proposal has two strong requirements:

  1. 1. 我们必须能够获取我们感兴趣的任何一点知识，并用符号表示它（换句话说，得到数字序列的模拟）。
  2. 1. We have to be able to take any bit of knowledge we are interested in dealing with, and represent it symbolically (to get the analogue of a sequence of digits, in other words).
  3. 2. 我们必须弄清楚如何正确地对这些符号表示进行操作，以产生我们正在寻找的新想法的表示（进行算术模拟）。
  4. 2. We have to figure out how to properly operate on those symbolic representations to produce a representation of the new idea we are looking for (to do the analogue of arithmetic).

让我们从第一个要求开始。除其他外，它意味着我们不仅要拥有知识，还必须能够表达它：以符号形式将其写下来。如果我们关心的所有知识都如此深刻和全面，以至于无法分解和表达，那么莱布尼茨的建议将行不通。

Let us begin with the first requirement. Among other things, it implies that more than merely having knowledge, we have to be able to express it: write it down in symbolic form. If all the knowledge we care about is so deep and holistic that it cannot be broken into parts and expressed, the Leibniz proposal will not work.

提出合适的符号表示的一个很好的起点是尝试用英语等语言表达知识。我们希望能够用英语表达我们对鳄鱼的了解（可能相关）以及我们对障碍赛马的了解（可能相关）。很可能确实有各种各样的事情我们知道我们永远无法表达。但是，如果我们能够将它们清晰地表达出来，那么我们很有可能能够以类似句子的形式表达出来。换句话说，如果我们不能用句子来表达我们所知道的东西，我们就根本不可能表达它。（有些符号表示不是句子式的，我们将在下面讨论它们。）

A good starting point in coming up with a suitable symbolic representation is to try to express knowledge in a language like English. We want to be able to say in English what it is we know about crocodiles (that might be relevant) and what it is we know about steeplechases (that might be relevant). It may well be true that there are all kinds of things we know that we can never articulate. But if we can articulate them at all, there is a good chance we will be able to do so in sentence-like form. In other words, if we cannot express something we know as sentences, it is unlikely we will be able to represent it at all. (There are symbolic representations that are not sentence-like, and we will discuss them below.)

以符号方式表示数字问题要小得多。我们已经习惯了这样做，以至于我们甚至很少区分数字和它们的表示——也就是说，区分数字和数字。当我们想为不同的目的以不同的方式表示数字时，就会出现区别。一个数字，十四，可以用14十进制、1110二进制或XIV罗马系统中的数字表示。符号表示的重要部分是它使用固定字母表中的字符排列将数字分成小块。这个字母表不必由数字组成；在罗马数字中，字母I, V, X, L, C, D, 和M被使用。

Representing numbers symbolically is much less of a problem. We are so used to doing this that we seldom even distinguish between numbers and their representations—that is, between numbers and numerals. Where the distinction does arise is when we want to think of representing numbers in different ways for different purposes. The one number, fourteen, might be represented by numerals like 14 in the decimal system, or 1110 in binary, or XIV in the Roman system. The important part about the symbolic representation is that it breaks the number into small pieces using an arrangement of characters from a fixed alphabet. This alphabet does not have to be made up of digits; in Roman numerals, the letters I, V, X, L, C, D, and M are used.

当然，还有其他一些对算术用处不大的数字符号表示。例如，数字十四也可以用字母和空格的字符串表示，例如“ fourteen”、“ ” catorce、“ the sum of eight and six”，甚至可以这样：

Of course, there are other symbolic representations of numbers that are less useful for arithmetic. For example, the number fourteen can also be represented by strings of letters and spaces such as “fourteen,” “catorce,” “the sum of eight and six,” and even this:

the predecessor of the product of the two smallest odd primes.

the predecessor of the product of the two smallest odd primes.

十四的任何这些表示都没有错；它们对我们关心的各种算术运算用处不大。

There is nothing wrong with any of these representations of fourteen; they are just less useful for the sorts of arithmetic operations we care about.

这与上面的第二个要求有关。我们期望对知识的符号表示进行什么样的操作？就数字而言，基本运算很明确：算术。莱布尼茨是第一个研究数字与基数之间精确关系的人。每一个数字都告诉我们要包含多少次幂的底数。例如，14在十进制（十进制）表示系统中表示（从右开始向左移动）包括四个10 0和一个10 1；1110在二进制（基数为二）系统中表示包括 2 0的零、2 1之一、2 2之一和 2 3之一. 莱布尼茨的分析之所以如此重要，是因为它清楚地表明了我们关心的运算（和、乘积、商、最小公倍数、质因数等）如何可以纯粹地象征性地执行。计算的神奇之处在于，我们可以以某种方式对两个数字序列进行运算，并最终得到第三个数字序列，然后保证它代表前两个数字序列所代表的数字之和。对符号结构的操作捕获它们所代表的纯抽象思想之间的关键关系。这就是使机器能够进行有意义的计算的原因。机器可以准确地进行算术运算，因为它们操纵的符号对应于我们关心的数字抽象和符号操作对应于加法和乘法等操作。（有些人可能不愿意说机器实际上可以“做”算术，但它们肯定会进行某种与算术完全一致的符号处理。）

This ties into the second requirement above. What sorts of operations on symbolic representations of knowledge are we expecting to need? In the case of numbers, the basic operations were clear: arithmetic. Leibniz was the first to work on the precise relationships between numbers and numerals in terms of bases. Each piece of a numeral tells us how many powers of the base to include. For instance, 14 in the decimal (base ten) representation system means (starting from the right and moving leftward) including four of 100 and one of 101; 1110 in the binary (base two) system means including zero of 20, one of 21, one of 22, and one of 23. The reason Leibniz’s analysis was so significant is that it made crystal clear how the operations we cared about (sums, products, quotients, least common multiples, prime factors, and so on) could be carried out purely symbolically. The magic of computation is that we can operate on two sequences of digits in a certain way and end up with a third sequence of digits that is then guaranteed to represent the sum of the numbers represented by the first two sequences. Operations on symbolic structures capture key relationships among the purely abstract ideas they represent. This is what makes it possible for machines to do meaningful computation. Machines can do arithmetic exactly because the symbols that they manipulate correspond to the numerical abstractions we care about, and the symbolic manipulations correspond to operations like addition and multiplication. (Some might be reluctant to say that machines can actually “do” arithmetic, but they surely do some sort of symbolic processing that lines up exactly with arithmetic.)

然而，不太明显的是如何在知识的情况下完成所有这些。仅仅找到任何旧的知识符号表示是不够的；我们需要一个能够执行“微积分种类”的平台，这是莱布尼茨心目中的算术模拟，我们将一个代表鳄鱼知识的符号结构与另一个代表障碍赛知识的符号结构结合在一起，对这些表示进行一些计算，并以代表所需结论的新符号结构结束。

What is much less apparent, however, is how all of this can be done in the case of knowledge. It will not be enough to find any old symbolic representation of knowledge; we need one where we will be able to perform a “species of calculus,” the analogue of arithmetic that Leibniz had in mind, where we bring together one symbolic structure representing crocodile knowledge with another representing steeplechase knowledge, perform some computation over those representations, and end up with a new symbolic structure representing the desired conclusion.

在莱布尼茨考虑这些想法的时候，确实没有好的符号表示系统可用于此。可追溯至亚里士多德的逻辑学工作展示了如何使称为三段论的某些组合起作用。你从“所有人都会死”和“苏格拉底是一个人”开始，最后以“苏格拉底会死”结束。但亚里士多德感兴趣的是合理论证的结构，而不是常识性知识。所考虑的推理类型受到高度限制。直到很久以后，在 20 世纪（也许从更早一点的 Gottlob Frege 开始，在 1879 年），现在被称为符号逻辑的提议才开始在这方面显示出明确的希望。最后，我们有了符号表示系统，它们既具有一定的普遍性，又具有算术的精确性。然而，当时的逻辑学家担心数学的基础，并且主要对表示数学真理感兴趣，比如等式关系是传递的事实，而不是常识真理，比如鳄鱼有短而粗的腿。常识知识必须等到二十世纪中叶。

At the time Leibniz was thinking about these ideas, there were really no good systems of symbolic representations to use for this. The work on logic dating back to Aristotle showed how certain combinations called syllogisms could be made to work. You started with “All men are mortal” and “Socrates is a man,” and ended up with “Socrates is mortal.” But Aristotle was interested in the structure of sound argumentation, not in commonsense knowledge. And the kind of reasoning being considered was highly restricted. It was only much later, in the twentieth century (starting perhaps with Gottlob Frege a little earlier, in 1879), that proposals for what is now called symbolic logic started to show clear promise in this regard. Finally we had systems of symbolic representations that had both a certain level of generality and the precision of arithmetic. Logicians at the time, however, were worried about the foundations of mathematics and interested primarily in representing mathematical truth, like the fact that the equality relation is transitive, but not commonsense truth, like the fact that crocodiles have short, stubby legs. Commonsense knowledge had to wait until the mid-twentieth century.

顺便说一句，如上所述，有一些符号表示不是句子式的，例如数字图片或图表。它们的问题恰恰在于，没有关于如何将它们组合起来以产生新思想的表现形式的可​​信故事。想想鳄鱼和障碍赛。即使我们试图用某种图片（也许是那些短而粗的腿）来表示所需的鳄鱼知识，并用另一张马跳得足够高以越过障碍的图片（或电影）来表示障碍赛知识，也没有人有关于对这两种表示进行何种操作会产生所需的显示鳄鱼无法参加障碍赛的任何想法。但这提出了一个更根本的问题：有些简单的想法似乎没有清晰的图形表示。例如，想想否定。哪张图片应该代表约翰不走路的想法？如果图片显示他只是站在那里，为什么这不会被误认为是约翰没有躺下的不同想法？或者乔治华盛顿不在场？或者甚至是约翰穿着裤子——假设他在照片中穿的就是这条裤子？虽然图片可能胜过千言万语，但它们本身似乎不适合表达某些易于用文字表达的想法。

Incidentally, as noted above, there are symbolic representations that are not sentence-like, such as digital pictures or diagrams. The problem with them is precisely that there are no plausible stories about how they would be combined to produce representations of new ideas. Think of the crocodile and steeplechase. Even if we tried to represent the required crocodile knowledge using a picture of some sort (maybe one showing those short, stubby legs) and the steeplechase knowledge using another picture (or movie) of horses jumping high enough to clear the hurdles, nobody has any idea at all about what kind of operation on those two representations would produce the desired one showing crocodiles unable to run steeplechases. But this raises an even more fundamental problem: there are simple ideas for which there appear to be no clear pictorial representations. Think of negations, for instance. What picture should represent the idea of John not walking? If the picture shows him just standing there, why would this not be mistaken as a representation for the different idea of John not lying down? Or of George Washington not being there? Or even of John wearing pants—assuming that is what he is wearing in the picture? Although pictures may be worth thousands of words, by themselves they seem to be ill suited for representing certain ideas easily expressible in words.

知识表示假设

The Knowledge Representation Hypothesis

以符号形式表示常识性知识，然后以计算方式从中得出结论的举措真正始于麦卡锡，他是人工智能领域的创始人之一。1958 年，他写了一篇史无前例的论文，题为“具有常识的程序”，其中他提议开发一种计算机程序，该程序将处理常识知识的符号表示，以此作为决定采取什么行动的一种方式。他为此目的建议的表示方案是最近开发的符号逻辑的一种方言，称为一阶谓词演算，他想到的处理涉及计算这种表示知识的逻辑结果——自从图灵首次阐明计算某物意味着什么以来，这种计算已经研究了二十年。这是麦卡锡所说的：

The move to represent commonsense knowledge in symbolic form and then draw conclusions from it in a computational way really began with McCarthy, one of the founders of the field of AI. In 1958, he wrote a completely unprecedented paper titled “Programs with Common Sense,” where he proposed the development of a computer program that would process symbolic representations of commonsense knowledge as a way of making decisions about what actions to take. The representation scheme he suggested for this purpose was a dialect of the recently developed symbolic logic called the first-order predicate calculus, and the processing he had in mind involved calculating the logical consequences of this represented knowledge—a computation that had been studied for two decades since Turing first made it clear what it meant to compute something. Here is what McCarthy says:

人们将能够假设[拟议的系统]将拥有相当广泛的一类关于它被告知的任何事情及其先前知识的直接逻辑结果。预计此属性与使我们将某些人描述为具有常识的原因有很多共同点。

One will be able to assume that [the proposed system] will have available to it a fairly wide class of immediate logical consequences of anything it is told and its previous knowledge. This property is expected to have much in common with what makes us describe certain humans as having common sense.

这是构建现在所谓的基于知识的计算机系统的第一个建议，即按照以下思路构建的系统：

This was the first proposal for building what is now called a knowledge-based computer system—that is, a system built along the following lines:

  • • 系统需要知道的大部分内容将作为某种符号表达式存储在它的内存中，构成我们称之为知识库的东西。
  • • Much of what the system needs to know will be stored in its memory as symbolic expressions of some sort, making up what we will call its knowledge base.
  • • 系统将使用某种逻辑规则处理知识库，以导出超出明确表示的新符号表示。
  • • The system will process the knowledge base using the rules of some sort of logic to derive new symbolic representations that go beyond what was explicitly represented.
  • • 得出的一些结论将涉及系统下一步应该做什么，然后系统将根据这些结论决定如何行动。
  • • Some of the conclusions derived will concern what the system should do next, and the system will then decide how to act based on those conclusions.

这听起来应该很熟悉。我们之前提到的专家系统的结构正是这样，知识库由从与人类专家的对话中提取的符号表示的规则填充。

This should sound familiar. The structure of the expert systems we mentioned before was exactly this, with the knowledge bases being populated by symbolically represented rules extracted from conversations with human experts.

麦卡锡的主要观点是，如果我们真的对具有人类智能水平的计算机系统感兴趣——也就是说，系统能够做的不仅仅是执行一组预先限定的任务——这些系统就需要以知识为基础感觉。

McCarthy’s main point was that if we were really interested in computer systems with human-level intelligence—that is, systems that are able to do more than perform a set of tasks circumscribed in advance—the systems would need to be knowledge based in just this sense.

麦卡锡的提议有很多值得争论的地方，其中最重要的是它对谓词演算语言的依赖。这是一种非常适合表示数学真理的语言（毕竟它是为此而发明的），但最终不太适合表示常识真理。

There is a lot to quibble with in the McCarthy proposal, not the least of which was its dependence on the language of the predicate calculus. This is a language well suited to representing mathematical truth (for which it was invented, after all), but in the end, not so well suited for commonsense truth.

举个例子，在数学中，我们经常想说“所有P都具有属性Q”，如“所有大于二的偶数都是两个素数之和”或“九个顶点上的所有平面图都有一个非平面补集”。谓词演算对这种量化有特殊的表示法。但在常识性知识中，我们通常不想要这种绝对的、绝对的陈述；相反，我们从正常和例外情况的角度来思考。例如，鸟类会飞是我们常识的一部分（鱼会游泳，蛇会滑行，狗会走会跑），但我们当然不相信每只鸟都会飞。事实上，我们很难以“All birds have property Q”的形式表达我们明确相信的任何事情” （关于这个问题我们稍后会有更多要说的。）正如麦卡锡和其他人很快发现的那样，谓词演算的逻辑需要彻底修改以处理常识类别的典型、非典型和边缘案例等问题。

To give one example, in mathematics, we often want to say something of the form “All P’s have property Q,” as in “All even numbers greater than two are the sum of two primes,” or “All planar graphs on nine vertices have a nonplanar complement.” The predicate calculus has special notation for just this sort of quantification. But in commonsense knowledge, we most often do not want such absolute, categorical statements; instead, we think in terms of normal and exceptional cases. It is part of our commonsense knowledge that birds fly, for instance (as opposed to fish, which swim; snakes, which slither; and dogs, which walk and run), but we certainly do not believe that each and every bird flies. In fact, we are hard-pressed to state anything we believe unequivocally in the form “All birds have property Q.” (We will have much more to say about this matter later.) As McCarthy and others soon discovered, the logic of the predicate calculus would need to be radically revised to deal with things like the typical, atypical, and borderline cases of commonsense categories.

但是撇开所有的争论不谈，我们如何真正知道麦卡锡是对的，以及通向常识的最佳途径是基于对常识知识的符号表示的处理？我们如何甚至知道符号表示是看待知识的正确方式吗？答案是，我们没有。这只是一个假设，哲学家 Brian Cantwell Smith称之为知识表示 (KR) 假设。这是他自己的话：

But all quibbles aside, how do we really know that McCarthy was right and that the best route to common sense is one based on the processing of symbolic representations of commonsense knowledge? How do we even know that symbolic representation is the right way to look at knowledge at all? The answer is, we don’t. It’s a hypothesis only, something called the knowledge representation (KR) hypothesis by philosopher Brian Cantwell Smith. Here it is in his own words:

任何机械体现的智能过程都将由以下结构成分组成：a) 我们作为外部观察者自然地代表对整个过程所展示的知识的命题说明，以及 b) 独立于这种外部语义属性，发挥正式但因果关系和在产生表现出该知识的行为中起着至关重要的作用。

Any mechanically embodied intelligent process will be comprised of structural ingredients that a) we as external observers naturally take to represent a propositional account of the knowledge that the overall process exhibits, and b) independent of such external semantic attribution, play a formal but causal and essential role in engendering the behavior that manifests that knowledge.

换句话说，麦卡锡宣言背后的假设是，智能系统的记忆需要包含具有两个重要属性的符号结构：首先，我们（从外部）将能够将它们理解为代表构成部分的命题。系统的知识，其次，由于这些结构在其内存中的存在，系统将以其智能方式运行。

In other words, the hypothesis behind McCarthy’s manifesto is that the memory of an intelligent system will need to contain symbolic structures with two important properties: first, that we (from the outside) will be able to understand them as representing propositions making up part of the knowledge of the system, and second, that the system will act the intelligent way it does because of the presence of these structures in its memory.

请注意，KR 假设并未说明如何这些符号结构应该会产生这种智能行为。（这是我们将在本书中花费大量时间的内容。）它也没有提及所涉及的知识种类。麦卡锡头脑中显然有常识性知识，但从 1970 年代开始的专家系统后续工作仅将这一想法应用于专家级知识。不足为奇的是，正如我们之前看到的那样，由此产生的系统无法证明任何常识。当偏离狭窄的车道时，它们很脆弱并且会以意想不到的方式崩溃。表示有关各种血液感染的复杂医学知识涉及太多工作，例如，不能留出任何时间来学习更世俗的知识，这些知识的实用性要小得多。并且系统的创建者从未预料到平凡明显的一般事实和规则在支持专家推论方面的关键作用；与专家的访谈侧重于特定问题的专门规则，而不是所有人都知道和使用但很少表达的无聊、通用的事实。（平心而论，我们很难说为什么血液感染诊断医生了解短而短的腿的跳跃限制很重要，比如。常识性知识的个别项目并不能保证有用或实用性。）我们很难说为什么血液感染诊断医生了解短粗腿的跳跃限制很重要。常识性知识的个别项目并不能保证有用或实用。）我们很难说为什么血液感染诊断医生了解短粗腿的跳跃限制很重要。常识性知识的个别项目并不能保证有用或实用。）

Note that the KR hypothesis says nothing about how those symbolic structures are supposed to engender this intelligent behavior. (This is something we will be spending a lot of time on in this book.) It also says nothing about the kind of knowledge involved. McCarthy obviously had commonsense knowledge in mind, but subsequent work on expert systems starting in the 1970s applied the idea to expert-level knowledge only. Not too surprisingly, the resulting systems failed to demonstrate anything like common sense, as we saw before; they were brittle and broke down in unexpected ways when straying out of their narrow lanes. There was too much work involved in representing complex medical knowledge about varieties of blood infections, say, to leave any time for more mundane knowledge, whose utility was much less apparent. And the creators of the systems never anticipated the critical role of mundane obvious general facts and rules in supporting even expert inferences; interviews with experts focused on specialized problem-specific rules rather than the boring, generic facts that all humans know and use but rarely articulate. (In all fairness, we would be hard-pressed to say why it would be important for a blood infection diagnostician to know about the jumping limitations of short, stubby legs, say. Individual items of commonsense knowledge do not come with a promise of usefulness or practicality.)

但这并不是说 AI 研究人员没有注意到这些专家系统的局限性。到 1980 年代，很明显这些系统是充其量是白痴专家：也许在某些专业任务上很有能力，但完全缺乏常识的稳健性和多功能性。虽然该领域正朝着更注重专业知识的方向发展，但少数研究人员希望更直接地跟随麦卡锡的领导，专注于常识性知识。

But it’s not as if AI researchers failed to notice the limitations of these expert systems. By the 1980s, it was quite apparent that those systems were at best idiots savants: highly capable on certain specialized tasks maybe, but totally lacking in the robustness and versatility of common sense. While the field was marching in a more expertise-focused direction, a small number of researchers wanted to follow McCarthy’s lead more directly and concentrate on commonsense knowledge.

从广义上讲，有两种不同的方法。一方面，有些研究人员认为他们的工作是尽可能清楚地表达常识代理需要了解其世界的这个或那个方面，以便能够以常识的方式行事。注意力集中在用某种人工语言表达句子，着眼于根据逻辑规则可以从中得出的常识性结论。在某些情况下，像谓词演算那样的语言就足够了；在其他情况下，必须制定更具表现力的逻辑。除了麦卡锡本人之外，帕特里克·海斯、杰里·霍布斯、欧内斯特·戴维斯、雷蒙德·雷特和约瑟夫·哈尔彭等许多思想领袖都大力推行这一议程，以寻求捕捉物理学、时间、

There were two different approaches, broadly speaking. On the one hand, there were researchers who saw their job as expressing as clearly as possible what a commonsense agent would need to know about this or that aspect of its world in order to be able to behave in a commonsense way. The attention was on articulating sentences in some sort of artificial language, with an eye toward the commonsense conclusions that could be drawn from them according to the rules of logic. In some cases, a language like that of the predicate calculus would suffice; in other instances, a more expressive logic had to be worked out. In addition to McCarthy himself, a number of thought leaders like Patrick Hayes, Jerry Hobbs, Ernest Davis, Raymond Reiter, and Joseph Halpern vigorously pursued this agenda in their quest to capture commonsense views of physics, time, space, minds, beliefs, plans, and society.

另一方面，也有研究人员严重质疑逻辑在麦卡锡提案中的作用。正如明斯基后来所说，“'逻辑'推理不够灵活，无法作为思考的基础。” 这些研究人员包括 Roger Schank 和他的学生 Janet Kolodner 等人，他们认为他们的工作不是表达句子，而是构建复杂的符号结构，这些结构可以作为常识主体的记忆。这些名为“框架”、“脚本”和“图式”的结构仍然旨在作为知识的表示（因此受 KR 假设的指导），但更多地强调对过去经验的记忆而不是对过去经验的记忆。关于世界的一般真理。重点不在于从其他事实中得出结论，

On the other hand, there were researchers who seriously questioned the role of logic in the McCarthy proposal. As Minsky later put it, “‘Logical’ reasoning is not flexible enough to serve as a basis for thinking.” These researchers, who included Roger Schank and students of his like Janet Kolodner and others, saw their job not as articulating sentences but rather as building complex symbolic structures that could serve as the memory of a commonsense agent. These structures, with names like “frames,” “scripts,” and “schemata,” were still intended as representations of knowledge (and thus were guided by the KR hypothesis), but with an emphasis more on the memories of past experiences than on general truths about the world. The focus was less on deriving conclusions from other facts, and more on recognizing patterns and drawing analogies between current circumstances and these remembered experiences as a way of solving new problems.

循环计划

The Cyc Project

上面强调的两种方法都提供了关于常识本质的有用见解，以及我们认为在机器中实现常识的关键要素，正如我们将在本书后面看到的那样。但这项工作缺乏与人类常识进行认真比较所需的广度。它倾向于以孤立的例子和有限的知识领域为中心。

Both of the approaches highlighted above offer useful insights on the nature of common sense and, as we will see later in the book, ingredients that we believe to be critical in the realization of common sense in machines. But the work lacks in the breadth needed for a serious comparison with human common sense. It tends to center on isolated examples and limited areas of knowledge.

常识知识范围的挑战是斯坦福大学一位名叫道格拉斯莱纳特的研究人员决定应对的挑战。在 20 世纪 80 年代中期，从德克萨斯州奥斯汀的微电子和计算技术公司开始，Lenat 和他的同事开始了一个名为 Cyc 的多年项目（如“en cyclopedia）开发常识性知识库——一种完全符合 KR 假设的符号结构，即人工智能系统需要知道什么才能展示某种形式的常识并避免专家系统的脆弱性缺陷。Lenat 的假设是专家推理需要以通常未说明的常识性事实为基础，他着手创建一个综合性的存储库来存储这些不为人知的事实。（这就是我们之前描述的陈述性隐性知识。）这是一项艰巨的任务，可能是人工智能领域有史以来最大、最雄心勃勃的项目——当然也是运行时间最长的项目。Cyc 知识库目前声称包含“超过 10,000 个谓词、数百万个集合和概念以及超过 2500 万个断言”——这是一个了不起的成就。

The challenge of the scope of commonsense knowledge was one that a Stanford University researcher named Douglas Lenat decided to tackle. In the mid-1980s, starting at the Microelectronics and Computing Technology Corporation in Austin, Texas, Lenat and his colleagues began a multiyear project called Cyc (as in “encyclopedia”) to develop a commonsense knowledge base—a symbolic structure totally in keeping with the KR hypothesis of what an AI system would need to know to exhibit some form of common sense and escape the brittleness flaw of expert systems. Lenat’s hypothesis was that expert reasoning needed to be undergirded by typically unstated commonsense facts, and he set out to create a comprehensive repository of such under-the-radar facts. (This is what we described earlier as declarative tacit knowledge.) It was a massive undertaking, probably the largest and most ambitious project ever tackled in AI—and certainly the longest-running one. The Cyc knowledge base is currently claimed to contain “more than 10,000 predicates, millions of collections and concepts, and more than 25 million assertions”—an amazing accomplishment.

那么，Cyc 是否真正实现了它的目标？不幸的是，没有明确的答案。大部分工作仍然是专有的，无法进行批判性评估。正如其他人所观察到的那样，在过去十年中几乎没有公开谈论过这项工作，并且在相当长的一段时间内几乎没有关于 Cyc 的同行评审出版物。（类似的缺乏透明度使得 IBM Watson 系统难以评估。）这很不幸。想要在这样的工作中保护知识产权是可以理解的，但这会阻止科学界了解所取得的成就和评估索赔。

So did Cyc actually succeed in what it set out to do? Unfortunately, there is not a clear answer. The bulk of the work has remained proprietary and impossible to evaluate critically. As others have observed, hardly anything has been said about the work publicly for the last decade, and there has been virtually no peer-reviewed publication about Cyc in quite some time. (A similar lack of transparency has made the IBM Watson system hard to assess.) This is unfortunate. It is understandable to want to protect intellectual property in work like this, but it prevents the scientific community from understanding what was achieved and assessing claims.

Lenat 确实在 2019 年的《福布斯》上发表了两篇有趣的观点文章，重申了 Cyc 哲学，并提供了一些例子，说明在理解戏剧《罗密欧与朱丽叶》中的情节点的背景下，它可以得出什么样的结论。这些轶事示例（通过英文描述、一些 Cyc 公式和两个屏幕截图进行了解释）在许多方面都非常引人注目。也有报道称Cyc知识库已经有成功的商业应用。但尽管如此，可以说具有一般常识的人工智能系统并没有因为这项工作而自发地出现在公众视野中。

Lenat did publish two interesting opinion pieces in Forbes in 2019 that reaffirmed the Cyc philosophy and offered some examples of the kind of conclusions it could draw in the context of understanding plot points from the play Romeo and Juliet. The anecdotal examples—explained through English description, a few Cyc formulas, and two screenshots—are compelling in many respects. It has also been reported that there have been successful commercial applications of the Cyc knowledge base. But despite all of this, suffice it to say that AI systems with general common sense have not emerged spontaneously into the public light as a result of this work.

为什么不？常识不应该来自常识性知识吗？从中吸取的一个教训是，虽然常识可能需要知识，但这还不够。最关键的是，人工智能系统仅仅能够访问所有这些内部以某种符号形式表示的知识是不够的；它需要能够以有效的方式将知识用于它正在努力做的事情。

Why not? Isn’t common sense supposed to derive from commonsense knowledge? One lesson to learn from this is that while knowledge may be necessary for common sense, it is not sufficient. Most critically, it is not enough for an AI system to have access to all of this knowledge, represented internally in some symbolic form; it needs to be able to bring the knowledge to bear in an effective way on what it is trying to do.

关于 Cyc 需要注意的一件事是，投入其中的巨大努力中有很大一部分——估计约为一千人年的工作——是关于建立一个巨大的知识库，而不是关于如何处理和部署这些知识. 用以前的术语来说，Cyc项目最重要的是常识性知识，而不是常识性推理. 这不仅仅是一个 Cyc 问题。我们在卡内基梅隆大学的计算机科学家 Tom Mitchell 及其同事的相关项目中看到了它，例如永无止境的语言学习 (NELL)。在这种情况下，NELL 系统不是手工制作大型知识库，而是通过扫描网页上的信息自动构建知识库。自 2010 年 NELL 成立以来，已通过这种方式获得了近 300 万条断言的集合。但与 Cyc 一样，几乎没有研究如何将这些断言组合在一起并进行处理，以及达到什么目的。

One thing to notice about Cyc is that a huge percentage of the enormous effort that went into it—estimated to be around a thousand person-years of work—was about building a gigantic knowledge base, not about how that knowledge should be processed and deployed. In the terminology from before, the Cyc project was foremost about commonsense knowledge, not commonsense reasoning. This is not just a Cyc issue. We see it in related projects like Never-Ending Language Learning (NELL) from computer scientist Tom Mitchell and colleagues at Carnegie Mellon University. In this case, instead of handcrafting a large knowledge base, the NELL system constructs the knowledge base automatically by scanning for information on web pages. Since NELL’s inception in 2010, a collection of almost three million assertions has been obtained in this way. But as with Cyc, there is virtually no study of how those assertions can be brought together and processed, and to what end.

多年来，人工智能对自动推理给予了相当大的关注，但主要是为了解决专家级的问题，比如高等数学和逻辑中的问题。然而，对于对普通常识感兴趣的研究人员来说，迄今为止的主要重点是知识本身，或者麦卡锡所说的系统的认识论充分性。

Over the years, there has been considerable attention in AI to automated reasoning, but mainly for solving expert-level problems like those found in advanced mathematics and logic. For researchers interested in plain common sense, however, the main emphasis to date has been on the knowledge itself, or what McCarthy called the epistemological adequacy of the system.

公平地说，推理在 Cyc 中并没有被忽视。由于其知识结构的数量和复杂性，Cyc 的创建者需要设法使推理足够快以用于应用程序。Cyc 团队认为麦卡锡的认识论充分性的补充——启发式充分性——与“如何搜索可能性空间和如何匹配模式”有关。为了支持计算，Cyc 工程师开始以不同的方式冗余地表示相同的信息，每种方式都有自己特殊的结构和推理过程。根据 Lenat 的说法，“到 1989 年，我们已经确定并实施了大约 20 个这样的特例推理器，每个都有自己的数据结构和算法。今天 [2019] 有超过 1100 个这样的“启发式推理模块”。

To be fair, reasoning was not ignored in Cyc. Because of the number and complexity of its knowledge structures, Cyc’s creators needed to grapple with ways to make inference fast enough for use in applications. The Cyc team considered the complement of McCarthy’s epistemological adequacy—heuristic adequacy—related to “how to search spaces of possibilities and how to match patterns.” To support computation, Cyc engineers started to represent the same information redundantly in different ways, each with its own idiosyncratic structures and reasoning procedures. According to Lenat, “By 1989, we had identified and implemented about 20 such special-case reasoners, each with its own data structures and algorithms. Today [2019] there are over 1100 of these ‘heuristic level reasoning modules.’”

具有大量特殊计算模块的体系结构作为管理专家使用的推理方法池的一种方式可能非常有意义（例如，用于解决电路分析、流体动力学或积分学中问题的专门分析技术） . 但是我们为什么要认为它对常识有任何好处呢？据称，Cyc 推理模块可以像某种“代理社区”一样协同工作。但是他们呢？

An architecture with a large number of special computing modules might make perfect sense as a way of managing a pool of reasoning methods used by experts (for example, specialized analytic techniques for solving problems in electric circuit analysis, fluid dynamics, or the integral calculus). But why should we think it will be any good for common sense? The Cyc reasoning modules are claimed to work together cooperatively like some sort of “community of agents.” But do they?

虽然 Lenat 和他的同事写了大量关于 Cyc 知识库中的知识种类，以及在正确使用这些知识时可以从这些知识中得出什么结论，但他们几乎没有说 Cyc 实际上用所有这些知识为自己做了什么以一种自动的方式获取知识，特别是当不同的知识片段需要第一次汇集在一起​​时。Cyc 中关于推理的大部分讨论都强调工程问题——适合支持工作软件系统，但与更广泛的常识没有真正的关系。事实上，Cyc 中的推理方法并没有真正受到常识可能提供的好处的启发，这些好处可以支持对意外情况的适当反应或避免计划和行动中的失误。

While Lenat and colleagues have written extensively about the kinds of knowledge in the Cyc knowledge base, and what conclusions can be drawn from this knowledge when it is used properly, they have had little to say about what Cyc actually does for itself with all of this knowledge in an automatic way, especially when different pieces of knowledge need to be brought together for the first time. Much of the discussion around reasoning in Cyc emphasizes engineering issues—appropriate in support of a working software system, but with no real bearing on common sense more broadly. In fact, the reasoning approach in Cyc is not really inspired by the benefits that common sense might offer in support of appropriate reactions to unanticipated circumstances or in avoiding blunders in planning and action.

这似乎是 Cyc 的优势，它允许在不同应用程序中如何通过这些推理模块灵活地使用其庞大的知识库。但这真正意味着使用 Cyc 的 AI 系统构建者必须自己解决所有问题。Cyc 只是没有说明普通的日常知识（比如关于鳄鱼和障碍赛马）是如何在没有人为干预的情况下为普通的日常目标服务的，只是说可以涉及许多方法。1100 个推理模块涵盖超过 2500 万个断言，成分可能都在那里，而且数量很多，但仍然缺少最终配方。太多的问题没有得到解答。

It might seem like a strength of Cyc that it allows flexibility in how its massive knowledge base can be put to use by these reasoning modules in different applications. But what it really means is that AI system builders using Cyc have to figure it all out for themselves. Cyc simply fails to spell out how ordinary, everyday knowledge (about crocodiles and steeplechases, say) gets to be exercised without human intervention in service of ordinary, everyday goals, other than to say that many methods can be involved. With eleven hundred reasoning modules ranging over twenty-five million assertions, the ingredients might all be there, and in abundance, but the final recipe is still missing. Too many questions are left unanswered.

例如，假设 AI 系统拥有以符号形式表示的所有知识，那么这些知识片段将如何以自动方式组合在一起以得出全新的结论？寻找有关鳄鱼和障碍赛马的事实，然后将它们放在一起得出所需结论的过程是什么？这个过程如何开始，何时停止？符号逻辑在这方面（或符号概率论，就此而言）将扮演什么角色？在不使用经典逻辑和概率的地方，提出了什么样的微积分（用莱布尼茨的术语）作为选择？随着正在考虑和制定一系列新结论，如何控制这个过程以在实际情况下足够快地发挥作用？换句话说，如何通过拥有大量可用知识来增强人工智能系统的整体行为，而不是被可能证明相关的项目的绝对数量所阻碍？Lenat 提到了“元知识”和“微观理论”作为控制知识处理方式的方法，但是如何限制这些东西的处理？

For example, assuming an AI system has all the knowledge it needs represented in symbolic form, how exactly will those pieces of knowledge come together in an automated way to allow totally new conclusions to be drawn? What is the process that will go looking for facts about crocodiles and steeplechases, and then bring them together to draw the desired conclusion? How does this process get started, and when does it stop? What role will symbolic logic play in this regard (or symbolic probability theory, for that matter)? And where classical logic and probability are not used, just what species of calculus (in Leibniz’s terminology) is being proposed as the alternative? As a range of new conclusions are being considered and developed, how is this process going to be kept in check to work quickly enough in real circumstances? In other words, how will the overall behavior of an AI system be enhanced by having massive amounts of knowledge available and not be stymied by the sheer number of items that might turn out to be relevant? Lenat has mentioned “metaknowledge” and “microtheories” as ways of controlling how the knowledge will be processed, but how will the processing of these things be constrained?

如果没有对这些问题的清晰明确的答案，就很难看出 Cyc 或任何其他推理系统在实践中将如何运作。通过将 Cyc 知识库中的项目串在一起可以得出常识性结论的例子并不能解决这个问题。我们无法知道 Cyc 将能够理所当然地为自己做什么样的穿线而不会迷路或不知所措。

Without clear and definite answers to questions like these, it is hard to see how Cyc or any other reasoning system will work in practice. Seeing example after example of commonsense conclusions that can be drawn by stringing together items from the Cyc knowledge base does not address the concern. We have no way to know what kind of stringing Cyc will be able to do for itself as a matter of course without getting lost or overwhelmed.

检验假设

Putting the Hypothesis to the Test

鉴于对像 Cyc 这样的基于知识的系统的所有这些担忧，我们很可能会问，AI 系统中的常识有什么替代 KR 假设的方法？答案是：到目前为止，没有，真的。如前所述，尽管基于深度学习的人工智能系统取得了令人瞩目的成就——显然不是基于符号表示的系统——但我们有充分的理由相信，仅靠这些想法是无法胜任的。深度学习社区最近的一项尝试——一个名为 COMET 的项目——实际上是借助传统的知识库来训练语言模型。即便如此，重点仍然是常识性知识，而不是我们所谓的常识性推理。

Given all these concerns about knowledge-based systems like Cyc, we might well ask, What alternative to the KR hypothesis is there for common sense in AI systems? The answer: so far, none, really. As explained earlier, despite the impressive achievements of AI systems based on deep learning—systems that are clearly not based on symbolic representations—there are good reasons to believe that those ideas alone will not be up to the job. A recent attempt from the deep learning community—a project called COMET—actually resorts to a conventional knowledge base to train a language model. And even then, the focus remains on commonsense knowledge and not on what we have called commonsense reasoning.

但是，是什么让我们认为基于 KR 假设的系统会变得更好呢？对于许多当前的 AI 研究人员来说，所有这些关于知识和符号的讨论都显得乏味和过时。这就是哲学家 John Haugeland 不久前谈到的“优秀的老式人工智能”(GOFAI)。他们可能会说，“符号人工智能？真的吗？我们在七十年代尝试过，但没有成功！” 不过，这太简单了。毕竟，很长一段时间以来，AI 人员可能会说，“神经网络？真的吗？我们在六十年代尝试过它们，明斯基和帕尔特证明它们没有用！” 正如我们在上一章中看到的，关于这些 AI 努力的真实故事更加微妙和复杂。

But what makes us think that systems based on the KR hypothesis will turn out to be any better? For many current AI researchers, all of this talk of knowledge and symbols seems tired and outdated. It’s that “good old-fashioned AI” (GOFAI) that philosopher John Haugeland talked about a while back. They might say, “Symbolic AI? Really? We tried that in the seventies and it didn’t work!” This is too simplistic, though. After all, for quite some time, AI people might well have said, “Neural nets? Really? We tried them in the sixties, and Minsky and Papert showed they didn’t work!” As we saw in the previous chapter, the real story about these AI efforts is more subtle and involved.

在本书的下一部分，我们要做的不仅仅是就什么行得通或行不通的原则进行争论。我们希望以更具建设性的方式接受 KR 假说，列出我们所认为的所有必要成分：需要的常识知识种类、可能用于表示它们的符号结构，以及种类的计算操作，然后可以以实用和有效的方式处理这些表示。这将在第 5-8 章中完成。（虽然之前的工作可能值得牢记，但我们将从第一原则开始。）然后在第 9 章中，我们将展示这些部分如何组合在一起以支持需要使用常识来处理意外情况的代理情况。

In the next part of the book, we want to do more than argue on principle about what will or will not work. We want to take on the KR hypothesis in a more constructive way by laying out what we see as all the necessary ingredients: the kinds of commonsense knowledge that would be needed, the symbolic structures that might be used to represent them, and also the sorts of computational operations that can then process these representations in a practical and effective manner. This will be done in chapters 5–8. (While prior work may be valuable to keep in mind, we will be doing this from first principles.) In chapter 9, we will then show how those pieces can come together to support an agent needing to use common sense to deal with an unanticipated situation.

显然，这不会解决问题；KR 假设将仍然是一个假设。但我们确实希望我们的分析至少能给它一些可信度，作为一种理解常识的方式。

This will not settle the question, obviously; the KR hypothesis will remain a hypothesis. But we do hope our analysis will at least give it some credence as a way of making sense of common sense.

5个

5

对世界的常识性理解

A Commonsense Understanding of the World

你不能拥有一切。你会把它放在哪里？

You can’t have everything. Where would you put it?

——史蒂文·赖特，引用自杰森·兹诺曼 (Jason Zinoman) 的“站立之河的源头”

—Steven Wright, quoted in “Headwaters for a River of Stand-Up,” by Jason Zinoman

我们正在开发的常识图片是一种特定的能力，即有效利用大量世俗背景知识来决定在普通情况下做什么的能力。但是这种能力的基础是什么？我们在谈论什么样的知识？它将如何使用？什么时候使用有效？

The picture we are developing of common sense is one of a certain ability, namely the ability to make effective use of a large store of mundane background knowledge in deciding what to do in ordinary situations. But what underlies this ability? What kind of knowledge are we talking about? How is it going to be used? And when is this use effective?

在接下来的四章中，我们想对这些问题提出一些答案。这将花费四章的原因是我们想要做的不仅仅是建议如何实现某种常识性幻觉。这不是关于捷径和聪明的技巧，他们可能会愚弄谁，测试用例的百分比或多长时间。我们想概述我们认为机器中的常识如何实际起作用。

In the next four chapters, we want to propose some answers to these questions. The reason this will take four chapters is that we want to do more than suggest how some sort of illusion of common sense might be achieved. This is not about shortcuts and clever tricks, who they might fool, over what percentage of test cases, or for how long. We want to outline how we think common sense in machines can actually work.

请注意，我们的目的只是提供一个大纲。这个故事将以一定的细节缓慢呈现——对于某些读者来说可能过于详细——但对于负责按照这些思路构建计算系统的工程师来说，细节还远远不够。然而，我们相信，虽然许多问题仍有待解决，但它们基本上与我们将详细讨论的问题属于同一类。

Note that our intent is to provide an outline only. The story will be presented slowly and in a certain amount of detail—perhaps in too much detail for some readers—but in nowhere near enough detail for an engineer tasked with building a computational system along these lines. Our belief, however, is that while many issues remain to be resolved, they are fundamentally of the same sort as the issues that we will discuss in detail.

我们这部分旅程的起点是常识性知识，即对普通情况和可以用日常语言表达的事物的信念。请注意，当我们谈论人们对他们的世界了解多少时，我们并不是在寻找科学家或其他人专家们一定会同意。一方面，我们不想将自己局限于那些已经由科学家进行了精确分析的主题。我们根本不期望数值精度在常识性思维中发挥重要作用——比如说，人们对奶酪三明治或换尿布有什么精确的了解？我们也不想用只有专家才会使用的术语来表达我们的故事，例如物理学家的量子或哲学家的感受质。

The starting point for this part of our journey will be commonsense knowledge—that is, beliefs about ordinary situations and things expressible in everyday language. Note that when we talk about what people know about their world, we are not looking for an account that scientists or other experts would necessarily find agreeable. For one thing, we do not want to limit ourselves to the sorts of topics that have been given precise analyses by scientists. We do not expect numerical precision to play a big role in commonsense thinking at all—what do people know with any kind of precision about cheese sandwiches or changing diapers, say? Nor do we want to couch our story in terms that only experts would use, like quanta for physicists, or qualia for philosophers.

当我们谈论人们普遍知道的事情时，我们想到的是谁？这些人几岁了？他们属于什么文化？答案是我们（主要）考虑的是成年人，我们想提供一个适用于广泛背景和文化的故事（主要）。当然，不同的人会知道不同的事情。加拿大人通常对黑冰（铺砌道路上的某些冰）了解很多，但对哈卡舞（某种仪式舞蹈）知之甚少，而新西兰人可能恰恰相反。我们对常识性知识的描述对于它应该涵盖哪些主题是不可知的。每种文化都应该坚持的是，该文化中的成年人希望彼此了解普通的日常知识。

When we talk about what people commonly know, who do we have in mind? How old are these people? What culture do they belong to? The answer is that we have adults in mind (mostly), and we want to give a story that applies to a wide range of backgrounds and cultures (mostly). Different people will know different things, of course. Canadians typically know a lot about black ice (certain ice on paved roads), but not so much about haka (a certain ceremonial dance), while the reverse might be true for New Zealanders. Our account of commonsense knowledge will be agnostic as to what topics it should cover. What should hold for every culture is that there will be ordinary, everyday knowledge that the adults in that culture expect each other to know.

什么构成常识将取决于它所依赖的知识。我们可能想说，当那里发生骚乱时，避免去机场只是常识。然而，如果你不知道骚乱，或者你知道骚乱，但你认为骚乱只是人们在一起玩得很开心，那么去机场并不是没有常识。

What constitutes common sense will depend on the knowledge it leans on. We might want to say that it is just common sense to avoid going to the airport when there is a riot going on there. Yet it is not a failure of common sense to go to the airport if you don’t know about the riot, or if you know about it but you think a riot is just people having a good time together.

我们将在下一章深入探讨常识性知识本身。但首先我们需要做好准备。在本章中，我们将探讨我们可能认为是这种知识的前提的东西——也就是说，在你开始理解关于这个世界的知识之前必须具备的那种理解。与知识本身一样，不需要单一的方法来做到这一点。我们将提出一种方法，但肯定有可能以不同的方式瓜分世界（正如对认知发展感兴趣的心理学家所做的那样）。

We will dive into commonsense knowledge itself in the next chapter. But first we need to set the stage. In this chapter we look into what we might think of as the presuppositions of this knowledge—that is, the kind of understanding that has to be in place before you can even start to make sense of knowledge about the world. As with the knowledge itself, there need not be a single way to do this. We will suggest one way, but it will certainly be possible to carve up the world in different ways (as psychologists interested in cognitive development have done).

事物及其属性

Things and Their Properties

要开始思考知识，特别是可以用普通语言表达的世俗知识，这里有一个思想实验可供考虑。假设您的生活从未听说过足球（或世界大部分地区所谓的“足球”）。想象一下，你要求某人向你解释。以下是他们可能如何开始：

To start thinking about knowledge, and specifically mundane knowledge expressible in ordinary language, here is a thought experiment to consider. Suppose you have lived your life without ever having heard of the game of soccer (or what is called “football” in much of the world). Imagine you ask somebody to explain it to you. Here is how they might begin:

足球是一项有点像曲棍球的运动，除了 ......

Soccer is a sport somewhat like hockey except that …

当然，如果您还不知道曲棍球是什么，这对您没有多大帮助。您可能更喜欢不参考其他运动的解释：

Of course this is not much help if you do not already know what hockey is. You might prefer an explanation that does not make reference to other sports:

足球是一种由两支球队在室外场地上进行的球类运动 ……

Soccer is a game played with a ball by two teams on an outdoor field …

（这是一个有点枯燥的公式，不是你期望在实际对话中听到的东西，但现在忽略它。）要理解这一点，你仍然需要对以下内容有一些了解：什么是游戏，球是什么，玩球是什么意思，团队是什么，两个人在比赛中比赛是什么意思，室外场地是什么，一个人玩是什么意思。例如，如果您不知道足球的用球是什么样的，您可以问，并得到如下信息：

(This is a somewhat dry formulation, not something you would expect to hear in an actual conversation, but ignore that for now.) To make sense of this, you would still need to have some understanding of the following: what a game is, what a ball is, what it means to play with a ball, what a team is, what it means to have two of them competing in a game, what an outdoor field is, and what it means to play on one. If, for example, you have no idea what a ball for soccer might be like, you could ask, and get something like this:

足球是一个中空的球形物体，大小约为 ……

A soccer ball is a hollow spherical thing about the size of …

要理解这一点，您将再次需要对什么是球体、某物是空心的意味着什么等有某种理解，其中任何一个都可能需要进一步澄清。

To make sense of this, you would again need to have some sort of understanding of what a sphere is, what it means for something to be hollow, and so on, any of which might call for even further clarification.

这一切会在哪里结束？似乎它可能永远不会结束；您总是可以问后续问题，例如“啊，是的，但是您的意思是……？” 然而，仔细检查一下，谈话确实必须在某个地方结束；你会到达一个你仍然可以要求解释的地步，但是你得到的回应不会告诉你任何新的东西。

Where would this all end? It seems like it might never end; you can always ask follow-up questions like “Ah yes, but what do you mean by … ?” On closer examination, however, the talk does have to end somewhere; you will get to a point where you can still ask for explanations, but the words you get in response are not going to tell you anything new.

例如，您可能被告知足球是具有特定尺寸的特定物体，但假设您就此打断并询问物体是什么，它具有一定尺寸意味着什么？有人可能会尝试提供解释：

For instance, you may be told that a soccer ball is a certain thing of a certain size, but suppose you interrupt right there and ask what a thing is, and what it means for it to have a size? Someone might try to offer an explanation:

事物可以是任何事物，事物可以具有某些属性 ……

A thing is anything at all, and things can have certain properties …

但这实际上只是另一种说法：

But this is really just another way of saying this:

这些东西称为“事物”，它们可以具有某些称为“属性”的属性。

There are these things called “things,” and they can have certain properties called “properties.”

也就是说，解释根本就不是解释！如果您还不了解事物是什么，那么告诉您它并没有真正的帮助它可以是任何东西。如果您还不了解事物可以具有属性，那么告诉您这是事物的属性也于事无补。当你被告知一个足球有一定的大小，一个足球队有一个守门员，或者一个足球场的两端都有网时，你必须已经明白这些都是东西，它们可以有属性。这是关于您可能需要了解的关于足球或您世界中任何其他事物的任何其他信息的前提。

In other words, the explanation is no explanation at all! If you do not already understand what a thing is, it does not really help to be told that it could be anything. If you do not already understand that things can have properties, it does not help to be told that this is a property of things. When you are told that a soccer ball has a certain size, a soccer team has a goalkeeper, or a soccer field has nets at each end, you have to already understand that these are all things, and that they can have properties. This is a presupposition of whatever else you might need to be told about soccer—or anything else in your world.

万物理论

A Theory of Everything

让我们多谈谈事物及其属性。

Let us say a little more about things and their properties.

有东西，它们有属性。

There are things, and they have properties.

根据它们具有的属性，有不同种类的东西。数字、信仰和故事等一些东西不是物质的。猫头鹰、冰箱和湖泊等一些东西是物理的，因此具有大小和位置等属性。

There are different kinds of things depending on the properties they have. Some things like numbers, beliefs, and stories are not physical. Some things like owls, refrigerators, and lakes are physical, and so have properties like size and location.

事物所具有的某些属性只是诸如活着或每周二被关押之类的品质。其他属性涉及事物与其他事物之间的关系，例如出生在城市或是两个数字的总和。有些属性或多或少地存在，例如沉重或喜欢某事。

Some of the properties that things have are just qualities like being alive or being held every Tuesday. Other properties concern relationships between the thing and other things, such as being born in a city or being the sum of two numbers. Some properties hold to a greater or lesser extent, such as being heavy or being fond of something.

时间点是线性排列的非物理事物，因此具有在其他时间点之前或之后的属性。当我们谈论什么事物存在或它们具有什么性质时，这总是相对于一个时间点而言的。一个事物可能在某个时候不存在，可能在以后的某个时间出现，然后可能在更晚的时候不存在。类似地，一个事物可能在某一时刻拥有某种属性，而在另一时刻却不具备。

Time points are nonphysical things that are ordered linearly, and so have the property of being before or after other time points. When we talk about what things exist or what properties they have, this is always relative to a time point. A thing may not exist at one time, may come to exist at a later time, and then may cease to exist at an even later time. Similarly, a thing may have a property at one time and fail to have it at another.

事件发生是非物质事物，其存在导致变化。存在的事物以及它们具有的属性被认为会随着时间的推移保持不变，除非在某个时间点发生事件来改变它们。有些事件的发生是代理的结果。其他事件是早期事件的结果。有些事件是自发发生的。

Event occurrences are nonphysical things whose existence is responsible for change. What things exist and what properties they have are considered to stay the same over time unless an event takes place at some point to change them. Some events happen as the result of agents. Others occur as the result of earlier events. Some events occur spontaneously.

有些事件只发生在一个单一的时间点，并导致立即发生变化。其他事件，称为过程，发生在多个时间点，并随着时间的推移产生逐渐变化。多个事件可能同时发生。有一个过程称为时间的流逝，它一直在发生并逐渐改变所有物质事物。

Some events happen only at a single time point and result in an immediate change. Other events, called processes, take place across a number of time points and produce a gradual change over time. More than one event may be occurring at the same time. There is a process called the passage of time that is always taking place and gradually changing all physical things.

关于这个小小的“万物理论”，我们能说些什么呢？也许最明显的是它呈现的世界观是我们所信奉的！该语言可能看起来很奇怪，并且有一些晦涩的部分。我们可能不会以这种方式表达自己。还有一些我们甚至可能不同意的要点。也许我们不认为有自发发生的事件。或者，也许我们更愿意说某些事情只是自行改变，比如头发的生长，而不是将其归因于某些正在进行的过程。但总的来说，它描绘的画面让人感觉非常熟悉。我们希望我们遇到的每个人都知道这些事情，在年轻的时候通过经验学会它们，即使从未像上面那样明确表达过。

What can we say about this little “theory of everything”? Maybe the most obvious thing is that the worldview it presents is one we believe in! The language might look strange and there are some obscure parts. We might not express ourselves in this way. And there are some fine points that we might even disagree with. Maybe we don’t think of there being events that occur spontaneously. Or maybe we prefer to say that certain things just change by themselves like the growth of hair, say, without attributing this to some ongoing process. But by and large, the picture it paints is one that feels quite familiar. We would expect everyone we meet to just know these things, to have learned them through experience at a young age, even if never articulated explicitly as above.

第二点值得注意的是，它所呈现的世界观又是一种以常识为前提的世界观。例如，如果我们还不了解事情会随着时间而改变，那么很难想象我们必须知道什么才能在以后了解这种可能性。

The second point worth noting is that the worldview it presents is again one presupposed by commonsense knowledge. For example, if we did not already understand that things could change over time, it is hard to imagine what we would have to know so as to later be informed about this possibility.

这种世界观的一个重要组成部分是有时被称为惯性常识法则的东西：事物将保持不变，除非它们因事件而改变。这就像艾萨克·牛顿爵士的物理学第一定律，只是它不仅仅适用于物理对象的持续运动。每当我们把长凳漆成黄色并期望它第二天呈现那种颜色，或者为一架钢琴调音并期望它第二天发出正确的声音时，我们就是在应用这条定律。

One important part of this worldview is what is sometimes called the commonsense law of inertia: things will stay the same unless they are changed by events. This is like Sir Isaac Newton’s first law in physics except that it is not just for the constant motion of physical objects. Whenever we paint a bench yellow and expect it to have that color the next day, or tune a piano and expect it to sound right the next day, we are applying this law.

要将法律应用于我们关心的事情，我们必须相信不会发生任何事情来改变它。使定律如此有效的是所谓变化的局部性：当我们积累关于世界的常识性知识时，我们开始意识到每个事件只会改变一小部分事物，并且事物的每个属性只能通过以下方式改变事件范围狭窄（尽管远处蝴蝶的翅膀动作）。所以虽然各种各样的事件一直在发生，但世界总体上是稳定的。然而，我们确实认识到，某些灾难性事件（例如天文事件或地震事件）会对我们关心的事物产生广泛影响，即使它们对整个宇宙的影响仍然非常局限。

To apply the law to something we care about, we have to believe that nothing will occur to change it. What makes the law so potent is what might be called the locality of change: as we accumulate commonsense knowledge about the world, we come to realize that each event changes only a narrow range of things, and each property of a thing is changed only by a narrow range of events (the wing action of distant butterflies notwithstanding). So although events of a variety of sorts are taking place all the time, there is an overall steadiness to the world. We do recognize, however, that there are certain cataclysmic events such as the astronomical or seismic ones that can have broad effects on the things we care about, even if their impact on the universe as a whole remains quite localized.

惯性法则和变化的局部性使生活在世界上变得易于管理。在许多事情中，它们使我们能够从经验中学习：当我们第二次遇到某事时，我们可以预期它在很大程度上与第一次相同。这也意味着我们可以一点一点地处理我们关心的事情。在许多情况下，我们可以完成一项任务并继续执行下一项任务，并期望第一个任务保持完成状态。所以我们可以把车停在停车场，去杂货店买东西，然后期待找到我们离开的那辆车。我们也充分认识到，我们不能把车停好，去斐济三年，然后期望回来时在同一个地方找到它。世界有一种稳定，但不是冰川般的稳定。

The law of inertia and the locality of change are what make living in the world as manageable as it is. Among many things, they allow us to learn from experience: the second time we encounter something, we can expect it to be largely as it was the first time. This also means we can work on what we care about piece by piece. In many cases, we can finish one task and move on to the next, expecting the first to remain finished. So we can park the car in the parking lot, do our grocery shopping, and expect to find the car where we left it. We also recognize full well that we cannot park the car, go to Fiji for three years, and expect to find it in the same place on our return. There is a steadiness to the world, but not a glacial steadiness.

顺便说一下，正是这种稳定性也使得所谓的人类语言的位移特性——谈论不在附近的事物的能力——如此有价值。例如，听到某人最近遇到的当前看不见的危险事物可能会很有趣。但是，让这样的报告如此重要的原因是这些危险仍然存在的预期，即使我们不能立即看到它们。

Incidentally, this steadiness is also what makes the so-called displacement property of human languages—the ability to talk about things that are not nearby—so valuable. It might be entertaining to hear about the dangerous things currently out of sight that someone encountered recently, for example. But what can make a report like this so consequential is the expectation that these dangers are still there, even if we can’t immediately see them.

然而，这个小理论是不完整的。它提到物理事物而没有充分说明它们，对于代理人也是如此。接下来我们转向这些。

The little theory, though, is incomplete. It mentions physical things without saying enough about them, and similarly for agents. We turn to these next.

天真的物理学

Naive Physics

在我们所了解的众多事物中，我们几乎所有的注意力都集中在物理事物上。一般而言，我们能对他们说些什么？这是一种尝试：

Among the many things we have knowledge about, almost all of our attention is on physical things. What can we say about them in general? Here is one attempt:

物理世界是由位于空间中的物质构成的。

The physical world is made of matter located in space.

空间中的点是在三个独立维度中线性排列的非物理事物。在空间中连续的点的集合称为区域。区域的边界是区域内与区域外的点相邻的那些点。每个区域都有一定的体积，这是对其包含的空间量的度量。

Points in space are nonphysical things that are ordered linearly in three separate dimensions. A collection of points that are contiguous in space is called a region. The border of a region are those points in the region that are contiguous with points outside the region. Each region has a certain volume, which is a measure of the amount of space it contains.

物质是具有空间存在的事物——也就是说，对于每一点物质，在空间中都有一个点，称为它单独占据的位置。有许多不同种类的物质，例如空气、花岗岩和姜汁汽水，它们具有不同的特征密度。物质的碎片也具有称为能量特性的非空间特性，例如它们的运动、热量、光、声音和电荷。

Bits of matter are things that have a spatial presence—that is, for each bit of matter, there is a point in space called its location that it alone occupies. There are many distinct kinds of matter such as air, granite, and ginger ale, with different characteristic densities. Bits of matter also have nonspatial properties called energy properties, such as their motion, heat, light, sound, and electric charge.

物理对象是由连续的物质组成的。所涉及的物质总量（考虑到密度）称为物体的质量。包围所有物质的最小区域称为物体的形状，总体积称为物体的大小。有时一个对象停止和另一个对象开始的边界不清楚。

A physical object is a thing made of contiguous bits of matter. The total amount of matter involved (taking density into account) is called the mass of the object. The smallest region that encloses all the matter is called the shape of the object, and the total volume is called the size of the object. Sometimes the border where one object stops and another object begins is unclear.

在物理对象的属性中，它在空间中的位置可能是最重要的。这是因为物理对象必须位于附近才能以某种方式作用或使用——例如，弹吉他、吃苹果或拿起梳子。通过将一个物体放入其中或将其牢固地固定到另一个物体上，可以使一个物体靠近另一个物体。

Among the properties of a physical object, its location in space is perhaps foremost. This is because a physical object must be located nearby to be acted on or made use of in some way—for example, to play a guitar, eat an apple, or pick up a comb. One object can be kept in close proximity to another by putting it inside or attaching it securely to the other.

构成物体的物质碎片会随着时间而改变。云和河流等一些物体不断变化，而岩石和塑料袋等其他物体则变化得更慢。物体的形状也会随着时间而改变。一个物体可以处于固态、液态或气态，这取决于它改变形状的容易程度。一些固体物体，如建筑物，往往会保持其形状；像水坑这样的液体物体根据周围的固体物体呈现形状；随着时间的推移，像一股空气这样的气体物体会自发地改变它们的形状。物体也可以由不同状态的部件组成：一杯牛奶作为物体，有一个坚固的外壳，周围环绕着一定量的液体。

The bits of matter that make up an object can change over time. Some objects like clouds and rivers change constantly, while others like rocks and plastic bags change more slowly. The shape of an object can also change over time. An object can be in a solid, liquid, or gaseous state, according to how readily it changes its shape. Some solid objects like buildings tend to keep their shape; liquid objects like puddles take on a shape according to the solid objects around them; gaseous objects like puffs of air change their shapes spontaneously over time. Objects can also be made of component parts in different states: a glass of milk as an object has a solid outer shell surrounding a certain quantity of liquid.

这第二篇论文只是迈向朴素物理学的第一步。（这里的“天真”并不是说错了；我们的意思是不成熟或有先见之明。）与真正的物理学不同，它不深入任何微观细节。胡萝卜是由小块的胡萝卜物质组成的，仅此而已。有对质量和能量等定量属性的引用，但甚至没有关于它们的理论的存根。（我们将在下面单独的部分返回数量。）

This second treatise is only a first step toward a naive physics. (By “naive” here, we do not mean mistaken; we mean something like unsophisticated or prescientific.) Unlike real physics, it does not dig into any of the microlevel details. A carrot is made up of small bits of carrot matter, and that’s that. There is reference to quantitative properties like mass and energy, but not even the stub of a theory about them. (We will return to quantities in a separate section below.)

朴素物理学主要关注既不太大也不太小的物理对象——我们可以称之为中间宏观对象，比如甲虫、洗碗机和药店。这是我们所知道的事物的一个特例，但对我们来说意义重大，因为这是我们通过感官感知并直接采取行动的事物。

Naive physics is concerned primarily with physical objects that are not too big and not too small—what we might call medial macro-objects, like beetles, dishwashers, and drugstores. This is a special case of the things we know about, but one that means a lot to us since this is the kind of thing we perceive through our senses and act on directly.

物理对象概念的一个问题是它们的空间边界。这对于非固体事物最为明显，但对于固体事物也存在问题。这是主要公路或出口坡道的一段特殊路面吗？常识性的回答是：没人在乎。我们认识到这个问题，但不以为意，说像这样的物理对象的精确边界几乎无关紧要。对于某些事件的边界也是如此——例如，法国大革命结束的确切时刻。类似的考虑适用于基于在一定程度上持有的属性的对象分类。在我们将其视为河流之前，小溪必须有多宽？什么时候因为太小而不是石头？同样，零食什么时候变成正餐？熟人什么时候变成朋友？

One problem with the idea of physical objects is that of their spatial boundaries. This is most evident for nonsolid things, but the problem is there for solid ones too. Is this one particular bit of pavement part of the main highway or the exit ramp? The commonsense answer is this: nobody cares. We recognize the issue, but shrug it off and say that the precise boundaries of physical objects like these almost never matter. This is also true for the boundaries of some events—say, the exact moment that was the end of the French Revolution. Similar considerations apply to classifications of objects based on properties that hold to a degree. Just how wide does a creek have to be before we consider it to be a river? When is something not a rock because it is too small? And similarly, when does a snack become a meal? When does an acquaintance become a friend?

将物理对象视为离散事物的另一个困难是它们的存在如何随时间展开。房子可以在火灾中被摧毁；一个细胞可以分裂并被两个新细胞取代；水坑会蒸发；并且可以通过在侧柱中安装一块木头来创建门。但是尽管有这些复杂性，我们仍然倾向于考虑物理世界足够稳定，可以在人类时间尺度上工作，而不是像量子力学所建议的那种不稳定的炖菜。这里没有矛盾。即使潜在的微观属性剧烈波动，宏观属性也可以非常稳定。

Another difficulty with thinking about physical objects as discrete things is how their existence unfolds over time. A house can be destroyed in a fire; a cell can divide and be replaced by two new ones; a puddle can evaporate; and a door can be created by installing a piece of wood in a jamb. But despite complexities like these, we still do tend to think of the objects of the physical world as steady enough to work with on a human timescale, not as the sort of volatile stew suggested by quantum mechanics. There is no contradiction here. Macroproperties can be quite stable even when the underlying microproperties fluctuate wildly.

隐含在上述说明中的是我们所谓的搭配常识法则：如果一个对象包含在另一个对象中或附加到另一个对象，则更改后者的位置也会更改前者的位置。这可以被认为是惯性常识法则的一个明确例外。通常，像护照这样的东西的位置不会受到涉及其他物体的事件的影响，比如弹吉他、吃苹果或拿起梳子。但是，如果护照在汽车后备箱中的手提箱中，那么将汽车开到蒙特利尔会改变护照的位置，以后可能会需要它。关于这个世界的一个具有挑战性的事实是，正如史蒂文赖特提醒我们的那样，你不仅无法拥有一切，而且你甚至无法在附近拥有你需要的一切，因此必须采取适当的措施。

Implicit in the above account is what we might call the commonsense law of collocation: if an object is contained in or attached to another, then changing the location of the latter also changes the location of the former. This can be thought of as an explicit exception to the commonsense law of inertia. Normally, the location of something like a passport would not be affected by events involving other objects, like playing a guitar, eating an apple, or picking up a comb. But if the passport is in a suitcase that is in the trunk of a car, then driving the car to Montreal changes the location of the passport where it might later be needed. One challenging truth about the world is that not only can you not have everything, as Steven Wright reminds us, but you also cannot even have everything you need nearby, and appropriate measures have to be taken.

朴素心理学

Naive Psychology

上述一切理论的最后一个主要主题是代理。在所有物理对象中，我们可能花费大部分时间试图弄清楚代理人在做什么以及为什么。当然，特别值得关注的是那些像我们一样的人。

The final major topic in the theory of everything above is that of agents. Among all the physical objects, we spend perhaps most of our time trying to make sense of what agents are up to and why. Of special concern, of course, are those that are like us.

代理是可以主动使某些事件发生的物理事物。这种情况下的事件称为动作，代理被称为执行动作。有意的代理人是根据由命题组成的心理状态执行动作的代理人。

Agents are physical things that can actively make certain events take place. The events in this case are called actions, and the agent is said to perform the action. Intentional agents are ones that perform actions in accordance with a mental state, made up of propositions.

命题是非物质的事物，具有要么为真要么为假的属性。原子命题是那些其真实性取决于某物是否具有某种性质或某物是否存在的命题。复杂命题的真实性取决于其他命题集合的真实性，例如某个房间里的每个人是否都出生在费城。

Propositions are nonphysical things that have the property of being either true or false. Atomic propositions are those whose truth depends on whether something has a certain property or a certain thing exists. Complex propositions are those whose truth depends on the truth of a collection of other propositions, such as whether every person in a certain room was born in Philadelphia.

在任何时候，都会有某些命题被有意的代理人认为是真的（与这些命题是否真的真的无关）和它希望使之成为真的其他命题；后者我们称之为代理人的目标。尽管有意的代理人可能会在不知不觉中执行某个动作，但签名案例是当代理人执行该动作时的目标是当时这样做，并且相信这样做会带来它所期望的变化。

At any point, there will be certain propositions that an intentional agent believes to be true (quite apart from whether those propositions really are true) and others that it desires to make true; the latter we refer to as the agent’s goals. Although an intentional agent may perform an action unwittingly, the signature case is when the agent performs the action with the goal of doing so at that point, and the belief that doing so will bring about a change that it desires.

一个有意向的代理人在尽可能最好地利用其信念来实现其目标并获得其想要的东西的范围内表现得很聪明。然而，在实践中，即使按照代理人自己的标准，也无法保证代理人会选择正确的行为来执行。除其他外，代理人可能无法理解其自身信念和愿望的所有后果。

An intentional agent is behaving intelligently to the extent that it is making the best possible use of its beliefs to achieve its goals and get what it desires. In practice, however, there is no guarantee that an agent will choose the right action to perform, even by its own standards. Among other things, an agent may fail to appreciate all the consequences of its own beliefs and desires.

代理人通常会有他们认为可以通过其他代理人的行为实现的目标。当然，那些其他代理人将按照自己的信念和愿望行事。然而，两个代理之间的一个强大联系是相互信任：两个代理相互相信一个命题，当他们都相信它并且都相信他们相互相信它时。当一个代理人相信与另一个代理人相互相信另一个代理人希望由第一个代理人完成（甚至可能愿意稍后回报）时，代理人有时会选择采取行动。为了达到这样的状态，代理人将执行通知和请求等交际行为，其目的是改变另一个代理人对他们相互信任的信念。

Agents will often have goals that they believe can be realized by the actions of other agents. Of course, those other agents will be acting on their own beliefs and desires. Yet one strong link between two agents is that of a mutual belief: two agents mutually believe a proposition when they both believe it and both believe that they mutually believe it. An agent will sometimes choose to do an action when it believes that it is mutually believed with another agent that the other agent wants it done by the first agent (and may even be willing to reciprocate later). To get to such a state, agents will perform communicative actions like informing and requesting, whose purpose is to change the beliefs of another agent about what they mutually believe.

因此，虽然代理人被认为是使事件发生的东西（例如，包括烤面包机），但重点是有意的代理人：那些根据信念、一般愿望和特定目标选择行动的人。关于这些代理人的一个更简单的故事是，他们根据世界的方式选择做什么。例如，我们可能会说，当预报有雨时，代理人会带雨伞。这个更简单的帐户与经验非常吻合。因此，这个故事是错误的，这是对世界的微妙但至关重要的洞察力，这是信念重要的代理人；如果代理人错误地认为天气预报是晴天，他们就不会在预报有雨时带雨伞。众所周知，幼儿直到大约四岁时才获得这种洞察力，那时他们首先构建了一种心理理论，允许其他代理人可能拥有错误的信念并按照错误的信念行事。

So while agents are considered to be the things that make events occur (including toasters, say), the emphasis is on intentional agents: those that choose actions in accordance with beliefs, general desires, and specific goals. A much simpler story about these agents is that they choose what to do according to the way the world is. For example, we might have said that agents take their umbrellas when the forecast is for rain. This simpler account aligns quite well with experience. So it is a subtle but crucial insight about the world that this story is wrong, that it is the beliefs of the agents that matter; the agents would not take their umbrellas when the forecast was for rain if they mistakenly believed the forecast was for sun. Famously, young children do not get this insight until about the age of four, when they first construct a theory of mind, allowing that other agents could have and be acting on false beliefs.

也许关于有意代理人的关键事实是所谓的代理人的常识倾向：代理人会选择他们认为会推进他们目标的行动，并避免他们认为会阻碍他们的行动。不过，这是一种趋势，而不是严格的规律。一方面，代理人有时会随意做出选择，甚至不考虑重要的目标。一个非常在意金钱价值的人最终仍然可能会不明智地花钱——这种选择可能无法解释，除非是某种原始冲动，或者可能是纯粹自由意志的练习（“我这样做是因为我可以！ ”）。另一方面，代理人有时会陷入可能导致他们误入歧途的错误推理模式。所以很难对代理人在特定情况下实际会做什么产生任何信心，并且几乎不可能确定他们的行为。期望他们像某种理想的逻辑/理性机器一样行动，总是充分利用他们所知道的来获得他们想要的东西，这是对有意的代理人的一种过于简单化的看法。事实证明，即使是粗略的近似，这种关于人们行为方式的观点也没有多大帮助（正如已经讨论过的）。

Perhaps the key fact about intentional agents is what might be called the commonsense tendency of agents: agents will choose actions they believe will advance their goals, and avoid actions they believe will hinder them. This is a tendency, though, and not a strict law. For one thing, agents will sometimes make choices willy-nilly without taking even important goals into account. A person who cares deeply about the value of money can still end up spending injudiciously—a choice that may be inexplicable except as some sort of primitive impulse, or perhaps as an exercise in sheer free will (“I am doing it because I can!”). For another, agents will sometimes fall prey to faulty modes of reasoning that may lead them astray. So it is hard to develop any confidence about what agents will actually do in particular situations, and virtually impossible to have certainty about their behavior. It is an oversimplified view of intentional agents to expect them to act like some sort of ideal logical/rational machines, always making the best use of what they know to get what they want. It turns out that even as a rough approximation, this view of how people behave is not that helpful (as already discussed).

上面的最后一段是交际行为（或所谓的言语行为）理论的存根。一旦一个代理人将另一个代理人识别为有意代理人，它就会在如何实现某些目标方面开辟一个全新的维度。代理人可以走过去打开一扇窗户，或者在适当的情况下，留在原地，只是说：“这里很闷，不是吗？” 和窗口的整体效果可以是一样的。同样，一群代理人可以共同完成个人无法完成的事情。为了获得完整的画面，重要的是要考虑更广泛的社会习俗以及群体之间的互动，或者我们称之为天真的社会学。

The final paragraph above is the stub of a theory of communicative actions (or speech acts, as they are called). Once one agent recognizes another as an intentional agent, it opens up a whole new dimension in how to achieve certain goals. An agent can either walk over and open a window, or in the right circumstances, stay put and just say the words, “It’s stuffy in here, isn’t it?” and the overall effect on the window can be the same. Similarly, groups of agents can achieve things together that individuals cannot. For a complete picture, it would be important to take into account broader social conventions as well as interactions between groups, or what we might call naive sociology.

数量和限制

Quantities and Limits

虽然常识性思维可能不会求助于科学和数学中所见的那种精确的数字计算，但它肯定会处理数量，例如事物更重或更轻、更亮或更暗、或更老或更年轻。成年大象放不下汽车是常识。那么如何表征尺寸等数量呢？这是一种方法：

While commonsense thinking might not resort to the sort of precise numerical reckoning seen in science and mathematics, it certainly deals with quantities, such as things being heavier or lighter, brighter or darker, or older or younger. It is commonsensical that an adult elephant will not fit into a car. How then to characterize quantities like size? Here is one way:

自然数是线性排列的抽象事物。如果一个数字在排序中出现得较晚/较早，则它比另一个数字大/小。有一个最小的数叫做零。数字的后继是顺序中下一个最大的数字。除零之外的每个数字都有一个前导数，它是排序中的下一个最小数字。

Natural numbers are abstract things that are linearly ordered. A number is larger/smaller than another if it occurs later/earlier in the ordering. There is a smallest number called zero. The successor of a number is the next largest number in the ordering. Every number other than zero has a predecessor, which is the next smallest number in the ordering.

事物可以具有数字属性。其中一些数字属性仅用于识别——也就是说，不同的事物将与不同的数字相关联（例如电话线和公民纳税人）。但是有一些称为数量（或数量）的抽象事物具有特殊的数值属性，可以将它们分类为大或小。数量的例子有面积、重量、电压、成本和持续时间。此处的数值属性以某些标准化单位衡量数量的大小。例如，给定一个特定的长度，我们可以要求以米、足球场或光年为单位进行测量，在每种情况下得到不同（但相关）的数字。

Things can have numerical properties. Some of those numerical properties are for identification only—that is, different things will be associated with different numbers (like phone lines and citizen taxpayers). But there are abstract things called quantities (or amounts) that have special numerical properties that categorize them as big or small. Examples of quantities are things like areas, weights, voltages, costs, and durations. The numerical properties here measure the size of the quantities in certain standardized units.
