Given a specific length, for instance, we can ask for its measure in meters, football fields, or light-years, getting different (but related) numbers in each case.

数量通常作为其他事物的属性引入：地毯的面积、人的体重、电池电压、自行车的成本或用餐时间。两个事物可能与相同的数量相关联，例如两个年龄相同的人。数量也可以代表不止一件事，比如两个城市之间的距离。

Quantities are typically introduced as properties of other things: the area of a rug, weight of a person, voltage of a battery, cost of a bicycle, or duration of a meal. Two things might be associated with the same quantity, like two people having the same age. Quantities can also be for more than one thing, like the distance between two cities.

当某物发生变化时，它可能会作为属性与不同的数量相关联。例如，一个人可以增加或减轻体重。我们说当某事物发生变化时，该数量会增加，因此它与一个新数量相关联，该新数量的度量（在某些固定单位中）比旧数量更大。同样，当涉及的新度量值较小时，数量会减少。像这样的数量变化的一个关键特征是，如果一个数量反复递减，它最终将以零的度量结束。

When something changes, it can come to be associated with a different quantity as a property. A person can gain or lose weight, for example. We say that a quantity is incremented for something when that thing is changed so that it is associated with a new quantity whose measure (in some fixed units) is a bigger number than the old. Similarly, a quantity is decremented when the new measure involved is a smaller number. One key feature about a change in quantity like this is that if a quantity is repeatedly decremented, it will eventually end up with a measure of zero.

一个基本情况是事物的（有限）集合，其中所讨论的数量是集合中项目数量的计数。在这种情况下，从集合中移除一些东西会减少计数，因此重复这样做最终会导致集合的计数为零——空集合。

A basic case of this is a (finite) collection of things, where the quantity in question is a count of the number of items in the collection. In this case, removing something from the collection decrements the count so that repeatedly doing so will eventually result in a collection with a count of zero—the empty collection.

这部关于数量的论文从对自然数的描述开始，没有太多使用标准算术术语（除了名称“零”）。这种排序的主要动机是能够谈论一个数量多于或少于另一个数量，并比较差异。

This treatise on quantities begins with a description of the natural numbers, without much by way of standard arithmetic terminology (except for the name “zero”). The main motivation for this ordering is to be able to talk about one quantity being more or less than another, and compare differences.

接近尾声的一个重要特征是所谓的常识极限法则：反复减少的数量最终将减少到零。就像上面讨论的惯性定律一样，这是一个强大的原则，它使我们能够思考范围广泛的问题，否则这些问题可能会让人不知所措。

An important feature noted near the end is what might be called the commonsense law of limits: a quantity that is repeatedly reduced will eventually be reduced to zero. Like the law of inertia discussed above, this is a powerful principle that allows us to think about a wide range of problems that might otherwise be overwhelming.

例如，假设我们要将一堆砖块放到卡车后部。有了这个定律，常识告诉我们，我们可以通过反复从堆中捡起一块砖并将其放在卡车上来做到这一点。我们每次选择移动的砖块并不重要。具体来说，为了对结果有信心，我们不必先想出一个计划来确定何时捡起哪块砖。（我们确实必须确信总是有可能转移一些砖块。）每当我们有一堆东西要以统一的方式处理时，就像阅读所有的邮件或剥所有的土豆一样，类似的考虑也适用。

Suppose, for example, that we want to get a pile of bricks onto the back of a truck. With this law, common sense tells us that we can do this by repeatedly picking a brick up from the pile and putting it on the truck. The brick we choose to move each time is not important. Specifically, to be confident of the outcome, we do not have to first come up with a plan that determines which brick to pick up when. (We do have to be confident that it will always be possible to transfer some brick.) Similar considerations apply whenever we have a collection of things to deal with in a uniform way, like reading all the mail or peeling all the potatoes.

假设我们可以确定所涉及的数量，这种极限法则还使我们无需求助于数学就可以轻松得出某些结论。例如，我们可以看到棋盘上的国王可以到达棋盘上的任何其他方格，一旦我们意识到它总是可以移动减少到那个广场的距离。对于一千乘一千板来说，这个结论并不难得出。（顺便说一句，马也可以到达八乘八棋盘上的任何一个方格，但在那种情况下，每一步减少的数量远非显而易见。）

This law of limits also allows us to easily draw certain conclusions without having to resort to mathematics, assuming we can identify the quantities involved. For example, we can see that a king on a chessboard can get to any other square on the board once we realize that it can always move to reduce the distance to that square. That conclusion is no harder to get to for a thousand-by-thousand board. (Incidentally, a knight can get to any square on an eight-by-eight chessboard too, but in that case, the quantity being reduced by each move is far from obvious.)

量论只讲自然数。我们假设数量是以小到足以避免分数的单位来衡量的，但这并不重要。不过，需要注意分数。例如，我们希望能够得出这样的结论：当两个物体靠得越来越近时，它们最终会发生接触。但是，如果距离以小数单位测量，并且我们允许距离有任意小的变化，则需要进行更复杂的分析。

The treatise on quantities only talks about natural numbers. We are assuming that quantities are measured in units small enough to avoid fractions, but this is not crucial. Some care with fractions is needed, though. For instance, we want to be able to conclude that when two objects are moving closer and closer together, they will eventually come into contact. But if distances are measured in fractional units, and we allow arbitrarily small changes in distance, a much more complex analysis is needed.

在谈论像自由女神像大小这样的话题时，我们最终会谈论三个不同的事物：雕像（物理对象）、它的高度（与该雕像相关的抽象量）和数字九十三（a以米为单位测量该数量）。然而，出于许多目的，我们可以绕过数量并谈论两件事：雕像及其以米为单位的高度——数字九十三。（我们将在后面的章节中看到这种简化形式。）

In talking about subjects like the size of the Statue of Liberty, we end up talking about three distinct things: the statue (the physical object), its height (an abstract quantity related to that statue), and the number ninety-three (a measure of that quantity in meters). For many purposes, however, we can bypass the quantity and talk about two things: the statue and its height in meters—the number ninety-three. (We will see this simplified form in later chapters.)

反事实和世界之道

Counterfactuals and the Ways of the World

在谈论事物的现状以及它们如何因事件而发生变化时，我们允许事物可能与当前的方式不同。类似地，在谈论代理人的信念和目标时，我们至少在考虑事物与过去或将来不同的可能性。

In talking about the way things are and how they change as the result of events, we are allowing that things can be different from the way they currently are. Similarly, in talking about the beliefs and goals of agents, we are at least contemplating the possibility of things being different from how they have ever been or will ever be.

从其他“世界”的角度来谈论这些问题可能是一种不幸的倾向。例如，我们可以说某人正在想象另一个世界，那里有一些理想的条件。不幸的是，它表明存在比世界更广阔的东西，它由许多这样的世界组成。（物理学家和漫画作家有时会谈论“多元宇宙”。）比如说，我们碰巧生活在一个这样的世界上，但可以想象使用某种神奇的望远镜观察另一个世界，甚至旅行到另一个世界，有点像参观一个遥远的星球。我们可能会去探索，调查那里的相同点和不同点，也许会追踪我们在那个世界的对应物，等等。

There is a perhaps unfortunate tendency to talk about these matters in terms of other “worlds.” For instance, we might say that someone is imagining another world where some desirable condition holds. This is unfortunate in that it suggests that there is something broader than the world, something made up of many such worlds. (Physicists—and comic book writers—sometimes talk about a “multiverse.”) We happen to live on one such world, say, but could imagine observing another one using some sort of magic telescope or even traveling to another world, somewhat like visiting a distant planet. We might go exploring, investigating what is the same and different there, perhaps tracking down our counterpart in that world, and so on.

但这种类型的故事，如果它能被连贯起来，就不是我们对过去事物的看法。事情可能会有所不同，但我们并不认为过去是另一个世界，例如，我们的对方生活在那里；我们是住在那里的人。这是常识性理解的一部分，即昨天的我并不是一个截然不同的人，一个二重身；只有我。同样，假设我没有死，明天又会是我，而不是像我一样的东西。

But this type of story, if it can be made coherent at all, is not really how we think about the way things were in the past. Things might have been different, but we do not think of the past as some other world where, for example, our counterpart lives; we’re the ones who lived there. It is part of a commonsense understanding that the person I was yesterday is not someone distinct from me, a doppelgänger; it’s just me. Similarly, assuming I don’t die, it will be me again tomorrow, not something that resembles me.

与其谈论其他世界，常识性的理解更像是下面这样，它同样适用于过去和未来以及代理人想象的更极端的可能性：

Rather than talking about other worlds, the commonsense understanding is more like the following, which applies equally well to the past and future as well as the more extreme possibilities imagined by agents:

世界只有一个，但世界可以有多种不同的方式，我们称之为世界状态。状态完全由存在的事物及其具有的属性决定。所以在任何给定的时间点，世界都处于一种状态，称为当前状态，事件可以将世界从一种状态改变为另一种状态。

There is one and only one world, but there are many different ways that world can be, which we call states of the world. A state is completely determined by the things that exist and the properties they have. So at any given point in time, the world is in one state, called the current state, and events can change the world from one state to another.

任何不同于当前状态的世界状态都称为反事实。代理人的信念和愿望处理反事实，因为他们认为是真实的或想要真实的命题可能仅在当前状态以外的状态下为真。

Any state of the world distinct from the current one is called a counterfactual. The beliefs and desires of agents deal with counterfactuals in that the propositions they believe to be true, or want to be true, may only be true in states other than the current one.

特别令人感兴趣的是一种几乎与另一种状态相似的状态：其中的事物几乎相同，并且它们的属性也几乎相同。在思考世界和他们可以采取的行动时，代理人会考虑反事实，其中事物几乎与他们想象的世界相同，只是他们想象的会因行动而改变。

Of special interest is a state that is almost like another: the things in it are almost the same, and their properties are almost the same. In thinking about the world and the actions at their disposal, agents consider counterfactuals where things are almost the same as they imagine the world to be, except for what they imagine to be changed by the action.

虽然我们谈论世界的当前状态、五分钟前的世界状态和五分钟后的世界状态，但这些状态实际上是什么对代理来说是不可知的。除了错误的信念之外，总会有代理人由于各种原因而无法知道的事情。对于任何代理人来说，世界似乎总是有许多不同的方式，可能是，或者可能是。这里的部分困难是实际的；代理只能观察、测量和验证这么多，并且这些仅适用于当前状态。但也存在概念上的问题。例如，对于物理对象或事件的构成缺乏精确的界限，可能导致对世界真实状况的合理分歧。

Although we talk about the current state of the world, the state of the world five minutes ago, and the state of the world five minutes from now, what these states actually are will be unknowable to agents. Quite apart from false beliefs, there will be always be matters that agents fail to know for a variety of reasons. To any agent, it will always seem like there are many different ways the world could be, could have been, or could turn out to be. Part of the difficulty here is practical; agents can only observe, measure, and verify so much, and these apply to the current state only. But there are conceptual problems as well. The lack of precise boundaries on what constitutes a physical object or event, say, can result in legitimate disagreements about the true state of the world. This is quite apart from the various subjective opinions agents have, such as whether or not a movie was boring, where there are really no objective facts about the world under consideration.

在考虑反事实时，我们最终可能会谈论我们认为目前不存在的事物。例如，在谈论未来时，我们可能会讨论乔治正在建造的房子。只要我们清楚我们心目中的世界状态，这就不是问题。例如，我们可能会坚持认为这所房子有五间卧室，尽管严格来说，没有房子可谈。类似的考虑也适用于谈论夏洛克·福尔摩斯的伦敦街道地址或圣诞老人靴子的颜色等话题。

In thinking about counterfactuals, we can end up talking about things that we do not believe currently exist. For example, in talking about the future, we might discuss the house that George is having built. This is not a problem as long as we are clear about what state of the world we have in mind. We might insist, for instance, that the house has five bedrooms, even though, strictly speaking, there is no house to be talking about. Similar considerations apply in talking about topics like the London street address of Sherlock Holmes or the color of Santa Claus’s boots.

因果关系和其他高级主题

Causality and Other Advanced Topics

本章的前提是某些主题属于常识性理解的一部分，可能难以通过语言获得。（我们在这里用语言来过一遍，只是为了提醒读者注意它们，而不是从头开始介绍。）在某些情况下，我们提到了主题，但只是暗示了细节。对于物理对象，我们讨论了质量和能量，但忽略了重力等力。对于代理人，我们讨论了信念和目标，但忽略了情感，例如代理人感到兴奋、害怕或感到羞耻的东西，以及这些如何影响他们做出的选择。遗漏只是为了保持讨论的合理长度，不应被视为暗示未提及的项目不重要。

The premise of this chapter is that there are certain topics that are part of a commonsense understanding that might be difficult to acquire through language. (We used language here to go through them, but only to remind the reader about them, not to introduce them from scratch.) In some cases, we mentioned topics but only hinted at the details. For physical objects, we talked about mass and energy, but left out forces such as gravity. For agents, we talked about beliefs and goals, but left out emotions, such as what agents find exciting, are afraid of, or are shamed by, and how these might contribute to the choices they make. The omissions were simply to keep the discussion of reasonable length and should not be taken to imply that the unmentioned items are not important.

我们可能已经讨论过许多其他主题，并且最终可能需要将其作为智能机器常识性知识的基础。在这个阶段，很难判断其中哪一个在其他主题方面最容易理解。对于代理人，我们会想了解道德的概念，例如代理人如何根据某些规则将某些选择视为善或恶。在圣经中，这个特定的主题最终成为所谓的知识之树的原始主题。（当然，理解某些代理人认为什么是善或恶，以及为什么，与实际将某些事情视为善或恶是不同的。两者都是必需的。）存在控制、自由、以及值得捕捉的责任——关于代理人可以自由行动或受到他人胁迫的假设，这在日常情况下可能很有用。人们了解物理对象的外观、它们如何随时间变化以及它们与这些对象的潜在属性有何关系物体以及外部覆盖物。还有因果关系的概念——一个值得在这里更详细研究的主题。

There are many additional topics we might have discussed, and which ultimately are likely to be needed as foundations of the commonsense knowledge of an intelligent machine. At this stage, it is hard to tell which of them might best be understood in terms of other topics. For agents, we will want to understand the idea of morality, such as how agents view some choices as good or evil according to certain precepts. In the Bible, this particular topic ends up being the primal subject of what is called the Tree of Knowledge. (Of course, understanding what some agents take as being good or evil, and why, is different from actually taking some things to be good or evil. Both are required.) There are issues of control, freedom, and responsibility that would be worth capturing—assumptions about agents’ freedom to act or coercion by others that can be useful in everyday circumstances. People understand appearances of physical objects, how they can change over time, and how they relate to underlying properties of those objects as well as to external coverings. And there is also the notion of causality—a subject worth looking at here in more detail.

我们对广泛学科领域的世界的大部分看法都是用因果关系来表达的。我们想知道是什么导致了什么，因为我们想知道当事情发生时谁或什么负责，或者什么行动可以带来我们想要发生的事情。We might believe that Jane was late for the meeting because she slept through her alarm, Jimmy was not allowed on the waterslide because he was too short, or Trump was elected because of Russian meddling. 在更一般的层面上，我们可能认为吸烟导致癌症或碳排放导致全球变暖。

Much of what we believe about the world across a wide variety of subject areas is expressed in terms of causality. We want to know what causes what because we want to know who or what is responsible when things happen, or what action can bring about something we want to happen. We might believe that Jane was late for the meeting because she slept through her alarm, Jimmy was not allowed on the waterslide because he was too short, or Trump was elected because of Russian meddling. On a more generic level, we might believe that smoking causes cancer or carbon emissions cause global warming.

这些不是关于世界的简单事实，而是涉及反事实的复杂事实。不仅仅是有两个事件，其中一个发生在另一个之前：Jane 睡了，然后 Jane 迟到了。这就是律师们称之为事后因果推论的谬论。因果关系意味着如果您想象第一个事件没有发生（或某些属性不成立）的世界状态，那么在所有其他条件相同的情况下，第二个事件将不再发生。所以我们可能知道的是：如果简没有睡懒觉，她会准时到达；如果吉米再高一点，他就会被允许上那个滑水道；或者如果俄罗斯人不干预，特朗普就不会赢。

These are not simple facts about the world but rather complex ones involving counterfactuals. It’s not just that there are two events, where one happens before the other: Jane sleeps in and then Jane is late. This is the fallacy that lawyers call post hoc ergo propter hoc. Causality means that if you imagine a state of the world where the first event does not take place (or where some property does not hold), then all other things being equal, the second event no longer takes place. So what we might know is this: had Jane not slept in, she would have arrived on time; had Jimmy been taller, he would have been allowed on that waterslide; or had the Russians not meddled, Trump would not have won.

然而，反事实的故事本身并不完全正确。这既不必要也不充分。考虑一下：我们可能碰巧知道简乘坐的公共汽车在她睡觉的那天堵车了，但我们仍然想说她迟到了是因为她睡了，即使她无论如何都会迟到。或者考虑一下：如果 Tommy 把 Timmy 推下楼梯，我们想说 Timmy 摔倒是因为 Tommy 推了他（否则他不会摔倒），但我们不想说 Timmy 摔倒是因为他在楼梯上（尽管如果他不在场他肯定不会倒下）。如果一个事件涉及不止一个人，他们不一定都是原因。这很重要，因为这意味着所涉及的各方不必同样受到指责。

Nevertheless, the counterfactual story by itself is not quite right; it is neither necessary nor sufficient. Consider this: we might happen to know that the bus Jane takes was stuck in traffic on the day she slept in, but we still want to say that she was late because she slept in, even though she would have arrived late anyway. Or consider this: if Tommy pushes Timmy down the stairs, we want to say that Timmy fell because Tommy pushed him (since he would not have fallen otherwise), but we do not want to say that Timmy fell because he was on the stairs (even though he certainly would not have fallen had he not been there). If an event involves more than one person, they need not all be causes. This is important since it means that the parties involved need not be equally to blame.

这些是因果关系的微妙特征，很难精确描述。然而，正如我们已经提到的，因果关系有两个基本方面将成为我们项目的核心，并且我们将在本书中反复处理：

These are subtle features of causality that are hard to be precise about. As we have already alluded to, however, there are two fundamental aspects of causality that will be central to our project, and that we will be dealing with repeatedly in this book:

  1. 1.事件可以引起世界的变化；阵雨会使草地湿润，生日派对可能会在客厅里留下一团糟，购买可能会改变汽车的所有权，或者开车去蒙特利尔可能会改变护照的位置。
  2. 1. Events can cause the world to change; a rain shower can make the grass wet, a birthday party can leave a mess in the living room, a purchase can change the ownership of a car, or a drive to Montreal can change the location of a passport.
  3. 2. 在适当的情况下，代理可以导致某些事件发生；代理人可以拿起一块砖头、吃一个苹果、唱歌或开车去蒙特利尔。
  4. 2. Under the right circumstances, agents can cause certain events to take place; an agent can pick up a brick, eat an apple, sing a song, or drive to Montreal.

但最终，如何以尊重我们对该术语的常识用法的更全面的方式最好地理解因果关系，即使是专家也尚未达成一致意见。

But in the end, how best to make sense of causality in the more full-bodied way that respects our commonsense usage of the term is something that even the experts have yet to come to an agreement on.

作为最后的想法，我们可能想知道我们是不是错过了一些重要的主题，而是包含了太多的主题。本章是关于常识性知识的前提，或者在你理解你对这个世界的了解之前需要具备的条件。但我们是不是预设得太多了？这里呈现的那种话题真的不是整个游戏吗？梳理出一种常识性的世界观可能更像是智能的最终目标，而不是它的起点。或者正如 Brian Cantwell Smith 所说，“本体论是智慧的成就，而不是预设。” 我们唯一的辩护是说这是一个视角问题。我们确实预设了很多，但正如我们将在下一章中看到的那样，这一切都只是为一场更大的游戏做准备。

As a final thought, we might wonder if instead of having missed some important topics, we have included too many of them. This chapter was about the presuppositions of commonsense knowledge, or what needs to be in place before you can make sense of what you find out about the world. But are we presupposing too much? Aren’t the kind of topics presented here really the whole game? Sorting out a commonsense worldview may feel more like the ultimate goal of intelligence rather than its starting point. Or as Brian Cantwell Smith puts it, “Ontology is an achievement of intelligence, not a presupposition.” Our only defense is to say that this is a question of perspective. We are indeed presupposing a lot, but as we will see in the next chapter, this is all just preparation for a much larger game that remains to be played.

6个

6

常识性知识

Commonsense Knowledge

海象说，是时候谈论很多事情了：

The time has come, the walrus said, to talk of many things:

鞋——和船——和密封蜡——卷心菜——和国王。

of shoes—and ships—and sealing-wax—of cabbages—and kings.

——刘易斯·卡罗尔，《海象与木匠》

—Lewis Carroll, “The Walrus and the Carpenter”

既然我们已经了解了常识是如何瓜分世界的，那么是时候谈谈常识知识本身了。那么一般来说，这些知识是关于什么的呢？答案很简单：它是关于我们周围的日常事物——出租车司机、电梯门、摩天轮、前院草坪、汽车贷款、悬疑小说、苹果派、法庭判决，是的，甚至还有卷心菜和国王。如前一章所述，它还涉及市议会会议、游戏表演、交通堵塞、餐厅用餐、森林火灾、出国旅行以及每天发生的所有可能导致其他事物的属性发生变化的事件时间。

Now that we’ve seen how common sense carves up the world, it is time to talk about commonsense knowledge itself. So what is this knowledge about in general? The answer is easy: it’s about the everyday things around us—taxi drivers, elevator doors, Ferris wheels, front-yard lawns, car loans, mystery novels, apple pies, court verdicts, and yes, even cabbages and kings. As suggested in the previous chapter, it’s also about events like city council meetings, game shows, traffic jams, restaurant meals, forest fires, trips abroad, and all the things that happen every day that can cause the properties of other things to change over time.

回想一下，我们将常识定义为一种能够有效利用普通的、日常的、经验性的知识来决定做什么的能力。在本章中，我们考虑了阐明这些知识所涉及的一些问题——关于普通事物、它们的属性以及它们如何变化的知识。

Recall that we defined common sense as an ability to make effective use of ordinary, everyday, experiential knowledge in deciding what to do. In this chapter, we consider some of the issues involved in articulating this knowledge—knowledge of commonplace things, their properties, and how they change.

为了明确我们的方法和最终目标，我们最终想考虑如何让计算机拥有和使用常识性知识。为此，我们必须找到以计算设备可以操纵和操作的方式来表示知识的方法。如前所述，这将采用某种计算机可处理的符号形式。但是，我们需要先花一些时间更好地了解我们将要做的事情，而不是直接投入其中想代表。正如我们将看到的，这其中有一些有趣的细微差别和复杂性。因此，我们将使用以英语等自然语言表达事物的能力作为临时替代品，以计算机可以操作的形式来表示它们，我们将在下一章进行介绍。

Just to be clear about our approach and end goal, ultimately we want to consider what it would take to get computers to have and make use of commonsense knowledge. To do that, we’ll have to find ways to represent the knowledge in a manner that a computational device could manipulate and operate on. As discussed before, that will be in some sort of computer-processable, symbolic form. But rather than jump right into that, we need to first spend some time getting a better sense of the sorts of things we will want to represent. And as we will see, there are some interesting nuances and complexities in this. So we will use the ability to state things in a natural language like English as a temporary surrogate for representing them in a form that a computer could operate on, which we will get to in the next chapter.

整体组织

The Overall Organization

我们对世界的大部分了解似乎都是关于具体的、个别的事情——我们遇到的事情、我们接触过的人以及我们的经历。正如我们所见，我们可以将这些视为构成世界的一种状态。此外，我们考虑到现在不存在但可能存在或我们期望将来存在的世界状态。人们善于回忆世界以前的状态，并至少以有限的方式想象行动和事件可能产生的结果，也善于为想象中的未来制定计划。当我们想到这些场景时，它们通常看起来或多或少与我们所处的实际情况相似；他们有个人、地点等，就像我们现在的世界一样。

Most of what we know about the world seems to be about specific, individual things—the things we’ve encountered, the people we’ve interacted with, and the experiences we’ve had. As we saw, we can think of these as making up a state of the world. In addition, we allow for states of the world that do not exist right now, but that could exist or we expect to exist in the future. People are good at recalling previous states of the world, and imagining, at least in a limited way, what the outcomes of actions and events might be, and also at making plans for imagined futures. When we think of those scenarios, they generally look more or less like the actual situations we are in; they have individual people, places, and so on, the same way our current world does.

那么我们对所有这些单独的事物了解多少呢？很明显，人类会组织他们所知道的，例如与他们的家庭和工作、地理和时间有关的东西，甚至与思想有关的东西。将世界上某些种类的事物视为在概念上接近和/或结构相似的事物将很有用。我们倾向于认为事物是按类型或类别聚集的。

So what do we know about all these individual things? It is pretty clear that humans organize what they know, such as related to their families and jobs, geography and time, and even with respect to ideas. It will be useful to think of certain kinds of things in the world as being conceptually close and/or structured similarly to one another. We tend to think of things as clustered in types or categories.

所以在谈论常识时，我们需要超越个体事物本身，考虑我们将称之为概念结构的东西。这不仅仅是因为我们知道医院和生日派对之类的事情；而是我们将它们视为医院和生日聚会。因此，与个体本身不同，存在这些称为概念（如医院的概念）的通用概念，用于组织我们对个体的看法。

So in talking about common sense, we need to go beyond the individual things themselves and consider what we will be calling a conceptual structure. It’s not just that we know about things like hospitals and birthday parties; it’s that we think of them as hospitals and birthday parties. So separate from the individuals themselves, there are these generic ideas called concepts (like the concept of a hospital) that serve to organize how we think about the individuals.

想象一下在户外的田野上看一些人。一个人可能会看到一场棒球比赛，一个人扮演投手的角色，另一个人扮演接球手的角色。另一个人可能会看到同一场景只是一堆人扔球和接球、用棍子击球、跑步等等。两个人可能在什么事情上完全一致在场上，他们拥有的属性，以及发生的可观察到的事件。他们不同意（或者可能只是无法沟通）的地方在于，其中一个具有涉及棒球比赛的概念结构，而另一个则没有。

Imagine looking at some people on a field outdoors. One person might see a game of baseball, with one person playing the role of pitcher and another the catcher. Another person might see the same scene as just a collection of people throwing and catching a ball, hitting it with a stick, running, and so on. The two people might agree completely on what things are on the field, the properties they have, and the observable events taking place. Where they disagree (or maybe just fail to communicate) is that one of them has a conceptual structure involving the game of baseball, and the other does not.

因此，概念结构涉及我们想象存在的事物种类以及我们想象它们具有的属性种类。比方说，在我们知道约翰出生在波士顿之前，我们需要将约翰视为具有出生在某个地方的特性的事物。也就是说，我们要有一个人的概念，一个人就是那种会有出生地的东西。同样，我们可以有棒球队的概念，每个人在球队中担任一个位置，比如游击手；我们可以有医院的概念以及它有手术室和病人的想法；我们可以有生日派对的概念，以及会有客人和生日蛋糕的想法；等等。

So a conceptual structure concerns the kinds of things we imagine there to be and the kinds of properties we imagine them to have. Before we can know that John was born in Boston, say, we need to see John as the kind of thing that can have the property of being born somewhere. In other words, we need to have the concept of a person and the idea that a person is the kind of thing that will have a birthplace. Similarly, we can have the concept of a baseball team and the idea that each person will play a position on the team, such as shortstop; we can have the concept of a hospital along with the idea that it will have operating rooms and patients; we can have the concept of birthday party along with the idea that there will be guests and a birthday cake; and so on. A conceptual structure like this gives us huge leverage for thinking about the world by allowing generalizations and analogies to be made between individual things, and allowing us to understand things much more richly than as disconnected, individual items.

在其最基本的形式中，这样的概念结构可以用动词“to have”和“to be”用英语句子来表达：

In its most elemental form, a conceptual structure like this can be expressed in English sentences using the verbs “to have” and “to be”:

医院是一座建筑物，有病人和手术室，手术室有明亮的灯光。

A hospital is a building, and has patients who are people and operating rooms that have bright lights.

“待定”部分归纳出泛化层次结构或分类法。医院是建筑物。建筑物是物理外壳。房子是建筑物。度假屋和湖屋都是房子。“拥有”部分也产生了等级制度。城市有医院。医院有病人。患者受伤或生病。受伤有治疗方法。根据这些层次结构进行思考——例如，将某些概念视为比其他概念更普遍或更专业——是一种有效地处理大量概念的有效方法。词典和百科全书条目通常围绕这样的想法构建：从一般类别开始，然后指定手头的术语与该类别有何不同和更具体。

The “to be” portion induces a generalization hierarchy, or taxonomy. Hospitals are buildings. Buildings are physical enclosures. Houses are buildings. Vacation houses and lake houses are houses. The “to have” portion also induces a hierarchy. Cities have hospitals. Hospitals have patients. Patients have injuries or illnesses. Injuries have treatments. Thinking in terms of these hierarchies—for example, thinking of certain concepts as being more general or more specialized than others—is a powerful way of dealing with large numbers of them manageably. Dictionaries and encyclopedia entries are often built around the idea of starting with a general category, and then specifying how a term at hand is different and more specific than that category.

正如我们稍后将看到的，概念之间还有其他重要的关系，这些关系本质上更具因果关系或时间关系。在其他情况下，概念之间的关系涉及位置和结构，例如手与手臂有关。然而，要点是这些想法都是通用的，与世界上任何特定的个人无关。由于多种原因，这种通用知识对于认知至关重要，当然也是常识的重要组成部分。

As we will see later, there are other important relationships between concepts that are more causal or temporal in nature. In other cases, the relationships between concepts involve location and structure, like how a hand relates to an arm. The main point, however, is that these ideas are all generic and not about any particular individual in the world. This generic knowledge is critical to cognition for many reasons and certainly is a significant part of common sense.

所以最后，当我们谈论表达常识性知识时，我们感兴趣的不仅仅是个体事物及其属性；我们也对帮助我们理解这些事情的概念感兴趣。常识需要利用概念结构。例如，面对新的和未预料到的事情，我们会问自己，这是什么东西，在此基础上，我还可能知道（或猜测）到什么，这表明我下一步该做什么？这种双管齐下的知识组织——对世界上个别事物的信念，在概念结构中形成——是常识性知识的基础。

So in the end, when we talk about expressing commonsense knowledge, we are interested in more than individual things and their properties; we are also interested in the concepts that help us make sense of these things. Common sense will need to make use of a conceptual structure. For example, faced with something new and unanticipated, we ask ourselves, What kind of thing is this, and on that basis, what else might I know (or guess) about it, and what does that suggest I do next? This double-barreled organization of knowledge—beliefs about individual things in the world, framed within a conceptual structure—is the fundamental basis for commonsense knowledge.

什么是概念？

What’s in a Concept?

概念结构由以各种方式相互关联的概念集合构成。但是我们能对每一个说些什么呢？例如，我们对医院的概念是什么？当我们想到医院时，我们会想到什么？尝试用文字表达这一点是否有意义？

A conceptual structure is made of a collection of concepts interrelated in various ways. But what can we say about each one? Just what is our concept of a hospital, for instance? When we think of a hospital, what idea do we have in mind? And does it even make sense to try to express this in words?

这里有两个观察开始。首先，我们想要的不仅仅是相关词的定义。以下是Merriam-Webster词典的内容：

Here are two observations to begin. First of all, we want more than a definition of the word in question. Here is what Merriam-Webster’s dictionary says:

医院是为病人或受伤者提供医疗服务的机构。

A hospital is an institution where the sick or injured are given medical care.

另一本面向儿童的字典是这样说的：

Another dictionary, geared to children, says this:

医院是照顾病人的地方。

A hospital is a place where people who are ill are looked after.

尽管这些定义就目前而言还不错，但它们显然达不到我们期望反映对医院的常识性理解的程度。他们并没有告诉我们很多我们在考虑、四处走动或决定在医院做什么时需要知道的事情。在描述我们对医院的想法时，还有很多要谈的。还有建筑物本身：紧急入口、手术室、重症监护病房、病房和护士站。然后是那里的人：病人和他们的来访者、医生、护士、勤务兵、礼物店员等人员。那里提供医疗服务：检查、手术、药物管理和绷带的应用。我们可能会谈论医院科室：重症监护、妇产科、冠状动脉科、肿瘤科和计费科。我们可能会谈到家具：病床、药车、轮床和手术台。我们可能还想谈谈其他服务：药店、自助餐厅、礼品店和长期停车场。预计字典条目不会涵盖这些中的任何一个。百科全书可能，除了百科全书倾向于关注那些不像医院那样经常遇到的事情。

While these definitions are fine as far as they go, they clearly fall short of what we’d expect to reflect a commonsense understanding of hospitals. They don’t tell us many things we’d need to know when thinking about, getting around, or making decisions about what to do in a hospital. In characterizing our idea of a hospital, there is a lot more to talk about. There is the building itself: emergency entrances, operating rooms, intensive care units, patient wards, and nurses’ stations. Then there are the people there: patients and their visitors, doctors, nurses, orderlies, gift shop clerks, and other personnel. There are the medical services that take place there: examinations, surgery, the administration of medicine, and the application of bandages. We might talk about hospital departments: intensive care, maternity, coronary, oncology, and billing. We might speak of the furniture: patient beds, medicine carts, gurneys, and operating tables. We might also want to talk about other services: pharmacies, cafeterias, gift shops, and long-term parking. A dictionary entry would not be expected to cover any of these. An encyclopedia might, except for the fact that encyclopedias tend to focus on things that are not encountered as routinely as hospitals.

其次，当我们谈到表达我们对医院的概念时，我们的意思是表达我们所谓的医院的基本属性，而不是可以从中得出的许多结论。例如，这是关于医院的常识告诉我们的一些事情：

Second, when we talk about expressing our concept of a hospital, we mean expressing what we might call a hospital’s basic properties, not the many conclusions that can be drawn from them. For example, here is something that common sense tells us about hospitals:

医院比冰淇淋车大。

A hospital is bigger than an ice cream truck.

虽然这是常识，但冰淇淋车的想法并不是我们医院想法的一部分。确实有很多东西我们想象的比医院更大，但我们希望它们可以从涉及的规模的更基本的东西中推导出来。举一个更极端的例子，考虑这种形式的句子：

While this is commonsensical, the idea of an ice cream truck is not really part of our idea of a hospital. There are indeed an enormous number of things we imagine a hospital to be bigger than, but we expect them to be derivable from something more basic about the sizes involved. To take a more extreme illustration, consider sentences of this form:

医院是一栋少于 N 层的建筑物。

A hospital is a building with fewer than N floors.

医院建筑的楼层少于 279 层当然是常识。事实上，我们知道有无数这样的句子是真实的。但同样，我们希望它们可以从有关医院楼层数的更基本属性中推导出来。（医院不是摩天大楼；迄今为止最高的医院在香港，只有 38 层。）

It is certainly commonsensical that a hospital building has fewer than, say, 279 floors. Indeed, there are an infinite number of sentences like this that we know to be true. But again, we expect them to be derivable from more basic properties about the number of floors in a hospital. (Hospitals are not skyscrapers; the tallest one so far is in Hong Kong and only has 38 floors.)

总而言之，我们在医院概念中所追求的不仅仅是字典定义，而是我们可能了解的关于医院的所有事实。总的来说，有两个主要的事情需要关注：首先，医院的概念如何适应我们的其他概念结构——也就是说，它如何专门化或概括我们所知道的其他概念（如建筑物或医疗机构的概念） ) 就其所具有的性质而言；其次，医院以外的事物（如病人、候诊室和轮床）如何发挥作用。如上所述，这通常可以仅使用英语动词“to be”和“to have”来表达。然而，在许多情况下，events 会涉及到，用其他英语动词来表示会更自然。例如，与其说些尴尬的话，不如说，

In sum, what we are after in our concept of a hospital is something more than a dictionary definition, but less than all the facts we might know about hospitals. Overall, there are two main things to focus on: first, how the concept of a hospital fits within the rest of our conceptual structure—that is, how it specializes or generalizes other concepts we know about (like that of a building or medical institution) in terms of the properties it has; and second, how things other than hospitals (like patients, waiting rooms, and gurneys) have a role to play. As noted above, this can often be expressed using just the English verbs “to be” and “to have.” In many cases, however, events will be involved, and it will be more natural to use other English verbs for them. For example, instead of saying something awkward like,

医院是一个建筑物，它有医疗服务事件，这些事件在该建筑物中有一个位置，接受者是病人。

A hospital is a building that has medical service events that have a location in that building and recipients who are patients.

我们更愿意说，

we prefer to say,

医院是病人接受医疗服务的建筑物。

A hospital is a building where patients receive medical services.

除了医院，我们现在将医疗服务想象为具有位置和接受者（以及其他属性，例如提供者，即医务人员）的事件。

where quite apart from hospitals, we are now imagining medical services as events that have locations and recipients (and other properties, such as providers—that is, the medical personnel).

注释一般性

Annotating Generalities

在试图用语言表达我们对医院的概念时，不可避免地会发生以下情况：我们开始谈论一般的医院，但就在结束之前，我们意识到我们要说的并不完全正确。几乎不可能完成像“Every hospital has ......”或“All hospitals are ......”这样的句子，因为变化太大了。一旦你开始说某事，你就会想纠正自己并以某种方式对其进行修饰。我们觉得有必要详细说明、讨论特殊情况，并且不可避免地对冲几乎所有事情。

In trying to put into words our concept of a hospital, here is what inevitably happens: we start saying something about hospitals in general, and just before finishing, we realize that what we were going to say is not quite right. It is almost impossible to complete a sentence like “Every hospital has …” or “All hospitals are …” because there is so much variation. No sooner do you begin to say something than you want to correct yourself and qualify it in one way or another. We feel a need to elaborate, discuss special cases, and inevitably, hedge almost everything.

那如何开始呢？一种可能性是：我们对我们所说的一切都持保留态度。我们对一般医院做出直率、无保留的陈述，使用诸如“医院是……”或“医院有……”之类的表达方式，并理解这些是初步的，稍后会有注释。简单的陈述可能是孩子知识的全部。但是随着我们了解得更多，这个概念将会演变；我们将要对声明进行注释，添加改进和细微之处，并修改原始的无条件声明。我们学得越多，注释就越多。

How then to get started? One possibility is this: we take everything we say with a grain of salt. We make blunt, unqualified statements about hospitals in general, using expressions such as “A hospital is …” or “A hospital has … ,” with the understanding that these are preliminary and subject to annotations to come later. The simple statement might be all there is for the knowledge of a child. But as we come to learn more, the concept will evolve; we will want to annotate the statement, adding refinements and subtleties, and revising the original unqualified claim. The more we learn, the more we annotate.

如图 6.1 所示，在文本中可视化此注释的一种方法是使用脚注。像这样用注释写的每一行本身都需要进一步注释。总的来说，像英语句子这样的线性单词串可能不适合这份工作。

One way to visualize this annotation in text is in terms of footnotes, as suggested in figure 6.1. Each line written in annotations like these is itself subject to further annotation. Overall, a linear string of words like an English sentence can feel ill-suited for the job.

在 1974 年的一篇文章中，明斯基建议我们对诸如医院之类的事物的了解根本不应该用线性词串来表示，而是取而代之的是实体和关系的复杂结构，他称之为框架。明斯基对这些概念结构有一些有用的想法，我们在这里包含了他所说的一些内容（来自他的论文“A Framework for Representing Knowledge”）。请注意，他在这里谈论的是符号表示（节点和关系网络）；暂时忽略这方面，只是了解他对这种概念框架的看法：

In a 1974 piece, Minsky suggested that what we know about things like hospitals should be represented not by a linear string of words at all but instead by a complex structure of entities and relationships he called a frame. Minsky has some useful thoughts on these kinds of conceptual structures, and we include here some of what he said (from his paper “A Framework for Representing Knowledge”). Note that he is talking about symbolic representations (networks of nodes and relations) here; ignore that aspect for now, and just get a sense of his view about this kind of conceptual framework:

当一个人遇到新情况（或对当前问题的看法发生重大变化）时，他会从记忆中选择一个称为框架的结构。这是一个被记住的框架，可以通过根据需要更改细节来适应现实。

框架是一种数据结构，用于表示刻板印象的情况，例如在某种起居室中，或者去参加孩子的生日聚会。每个框架都附有几种信息。其中一些信息是关于如何使用框架的。有些是关于人们可以预期接下来会发生什么。有些是关于如果这些期望没有得到证实该怎么办。

我们可以将框架视为节点和关系的网络。一个框架的“顶层”是固定的，并且代表关于假设的事情总是正确的情况。较低层有许多终端，即必须由特定实例或数据填充的“插槽”。每个终端都可以指定其分配必须满足的条件。（分配本身通常是较小的“子框架”。）简单条件由标记指定，这些标记可能需要终端分配是一个人、一个具有足够价值的对象或指向某种类型的子框架的指针。更复杂的条件可以指定分配给多个终端的事物之间的关系。

相关框架的集合链接在一起形成框架系统。系统框架之间的转换反映了重要行动的影响。这些用于使某些类型的计算变得经济，代表重点和注意力的变化，并说明“意象”的有效性。

对于视觉场景分析，系统的不同帧从不同的视点描述场景，一帧与另一帧之间的转换表示从一个地方移动到另一个地方的效果。对于非视觉类型的框架，系统框架之间的差异可以表示动作、因果关系或概念观点的变化。一个系统的不同框架共享相同的终端；这是使协调从不同观点收集的信息成为可能的关键点。

该理论的许多现象学力量取决于包含预期和其他类型的假设。框架的终端通常已经填充了“默认”分配。因此，一个框架可能包含许多细节，这些细节的假设并没有得到具体情况的保证。这些在表示一般信息、最可能的情况、绕过“逻辑”的技术以及进行有用概括的方法方面有很多用途。

默认分配松散地附加到它们的终端，因此它们可以很容易地被更适合当前情况的新项目取代。因此，它们也可以作为“变量”或作为“实例推理”的特例，或作为“教科书案例”，并且通常不需要使用逻辑量词。

框架系统又通过信息检索网络链接起来。当建议的框架无法适应现实时——当我们找不到与其终端标记条件相匹配的终端分配时——该网络提供了一个替换框架。这些帧间结构使其他方式成为可能，以表示有关事实、类比和其他有助于理解的信息的知识。

一旦提出一个框架来表示一种情况，匹配过程就会尝试为每个框架的终端分配值，与每个位置的标记一致。匹配过程部分由与框架相关的信息（包括有关如何处理意外的信息）控制，部分由有关系统当前目标的知识控制。当匹配过程失败时获得的信息有重要用途。

When one encounters a new situation (or makes a substantial change in one’s view of the present problem) one selects from memory a structure called a Frame. This is a remembered framework to be adapted to fit reality by changing details as necessary.

A frame is a data-structure for representing a stereotyped situation, like being in a certain kind of living room, or going to a child’s birthday party. Attached to each frame are several kinds of information. Some of this information is about how to use the frame. Some is about what one can expect to happen next. Some is about what to do if these expectations are not confirmed.

We can think of a frame as a network of nodes and relations. The “top levels” of a frame are fixed, and represent things that are always true about the supposed situation. The lower levels have many terminals, “slots” that must be filled by specific instances or data. Each terminal can specify conditions its assignments must meet. (The assignments themselves are usually smaller “sub-frames.”) Simple conditions are specified by markers that might require a terminal assignment to be a person, an object of sufficient value, or a pointer to a sub-frame of a certain type. More complex conditions can specify relations among the things assigned to several terminals.

Collections of related frames are linked together into frame-systems. The effects of important actions are mirrored by transformations between the frames of a system. These are used to make certain kinds of calculations economical, to represent changes of emphasis and attention, and to account for the effectiveness of “imagery.”

For visual scene analysis, the different frames of a system describe the scene from different viewpoints, and the transformations between one frame and another represent the effects of moving from place to place. For non-visual kinds of frames, the differences between the frames of a system can represent actions, cause-effect relations, or changes in conceptual viewpoint. Different frames of a system share the same terminals; this is the critical point that makes it possible to coordinate information gathered from different viewpoints.

Much of the phenomenological power of the theory hinges on the inclusion of expectations and other kinds of presumptions. A frame’s terminals are normally already filled with “default” assignments. Thus, a frame may contain a great many details whose supposition is not specifically warranted by the situation. These have many uses in representing general information, most likely cases, techniques for bypassing “logic,” and ways to make useful generalizations.

The default assignments are attached loosely to their terminals, so that they can be easily displaced by new items that fit better the current situation. They thus can serve also as “variables” or as special cases for “reasoning by example,” or as “textbook cases,” and often make the use of logical quantifiers unnecessary.

The frame-systems are linked, in turn, by an information retrieval network. When a proposed frame cannot be made to fit reality—when we cannot find terminal assignments that suitably match its terminal marker conditions—this network provides a replacement frame. These inter-frame structures make possible other ways to represent knowledge about facts, analogies, and other information useful in understanding.

Once a frame is proposed to represent a situation, a matching process tries to assign values to each frame’s terminals, consistent with the markers at each place. The matching process is partly controlled by information associated with the frame (which includes information about how to deal with surprises) and partly by knowledge about the system’s current goals. There are important uses for the information, obtained when a matching process fails.

我们当然可以将框架系统的内容分解成一系列英语句子，但重要的是要记住这些句子并不是孤立存在的。他们将被其他人评论句子，提出相关的想法，阐述，澄清，对冲，有时甚至通过提出变体和例外情况来反驳它们。

We can of course unpack the content of a frame system into a sequence of English sentences, but it will be important to remember that those sentences do not live in isolation. They will be commented on by other sentences, suggesting related ideas, elaborating, clarifying, hedging, and sometimes even contradicting them by bringing up variations as well as exceptional cases.

考虑一下，例如：

Consider this, for example:

医院有六层 ……

A hospital has six floors …

这是医院建筑大小的合理默认值（也就是说，医院往往比摩天大楼矮但比平房高），但我们知道我们可能期望看到的楼层数有相当大的自由度。六层楼以外的医院很常见。

This is a reasonable default for the size of a hospital building (that is, hospitals do tend to be shorter than skyscrapers yet taller than bungalows), but we know that there is considerable latitude in how many floors we might expect to see. Hospitals with other than six floors are common.

这个纬度的想法是关键。考虑一下：

This idea of latitude is key. Consider this:

鸟是一种人手大小的动物。

A bird is an animal about the size of a human hand.

虽然我们可以接受这种关于鸟类大小的粗略陈述，或者作为关于某种原型鸟类的陈述，但在这里我们允许有很大的自由度。一只全尺寸的皇家信天翁远没有手那么大，小蜂鸟也没有。但我们认识到这些是极端情况。昆虫比鸟小，鸟又比狗小，这是常识的一部分，尽管我们很清楚也有例外。我们不能对如何使用我们所相信的东西过于严格或绝对。

While we may accept this rough statement about the size of birds, or as a statement about some sort of prototypical bird, here we allow for great latitude. A full-size royal albatross is nowhere near the size of a hand, nor is a young bee hummingbird. But we recognize that these are extreme cases. It is part of commonsense knowledge that insects are smaller than birds, which are smaller than dogs, even though we well know there are exceptions. We cannot afford to be overly strict or categorical in how we make use of what we believe.

纬度的概念也与那些仅在一定程度上适用的模糊属性有关。将绿色X想象成只是一个颜色为绿色的X可能是有意义的，但我们不能以这种方式思考高X。形容词“高”的意思取决于所讨论的X，更像是“对于X的事物而言，高度处于较高范围内”” 一座高大的医院可能有二十层楼，但一所高大的高中预计会少一些，而一座高大的市中心酒店可能会多得多。这表明一个概念可能不仅包括默认值，还包括默认的高值和低值，并且可能默认非常高和非常低的值。（更进一步，我们甚至可以想象默认值的完整分布，从最常见的到各种不太可能的。）

The idea of latitude also connects to those vague properties that hold only to a degree. It might make sense to think of a green X as no more than an X whose color is green, but we cannot think of a tall X in this way. What the adjective “tall” means depends on the X in question and is something more like “having height that is in the high range for things that are X.” A tall hospital might have twenty floors, but a tall high school would be expected to have fewer, while a tall downtown hotel would probably have considerably more. This suggests that a concept might include not only a default value but default high and low values too, and maybe default very high and very low values. (Going further, we can even imagine a full distribution of default values, from the most common one to various less likely ones.)

考虑医院高度或理发持续时间等典型数量的一种有趣方式是按照数量级。较小的N可能意味着在某些合适的单位中取值介于 10 N和 10 (N+1)之间。例如，我们可能有一个默认的数量级精装书的成本（美元）为 1，空调为 2，订婚戒指为 3，汽车为 4，房子为 5（这些物品的豪华版可能高一个数字，低最终预算版本少一个）。这些小数字完成了定性排序的工作，我们倾向于使用英语中的副词，如“非常”、“非常”、“有点”、“勉强”等。它们使我们无需知道所涉及的确切数量就可以轻松得出结论，在旅馆过夜比吃汉堡包更贵。

One interesting way to think about typical quantities like the height of a hospital or duration of a haircut is in terms of orders of magnitude. A small number N might mean a value taken to be between 10N and 10(N+1) in some suitable units. For example, we might have a default order of magnitude cost (in US dollars) of a hardcover book as 1, an air conditioner as 2, an engagement ring as 3, a car as 4, and a house as 5 (with luxury versions of these items perhaps one number higher, and low-end budget versions one number less). These small numbers do the job of qualitative orderings for which we tend to use adverbs in English like “extremely,” “very,” “somewhat,” “barely,” and so on. They allow us to easily conclude that a night in a hotel is more expensive than a hamburger without having to know the exact quantities involved.

因此，当我们想到我们对某事的了解并尝试写一个句子来表达它时，我们应该按照明斯基的框架系统来思考。这些句子会告诉我们在正常、典型的情况下会发生什么，要寻找什么，以及要问什么问题。但句子要有丰富的注解，不能孤立地看。特别有趣的是，框架系统可用于“鉴别诊断”，针对正在考虑的事物提出当前最佳猜测的替代方案。

So when we think of what we know about something and try to write a sentence to express it, we should be thinking along the lines of Minsky’s frame systems. The sentences will tell us what to expect under normal, typical circumstances, what to look for, and what questions to ask. But the sentences need to be richly annotated and cannot be taken in isolation. Of special interest is that a frame system may be used for “differential diagnosis,” proposing alternatives to the current best guess as to the kind of thing under consideration.

同样，我们不应该草率​​地驳回我们认为是错误的句子。考虑这样的语句：

Similarly, we should not be too hasty about dismissing a sentence that we think is wrong. Consider a statement like this:

狗是棕色哺乳动物。

A dog is a brown mammal.

这里的问题不在于我们是否认为该陈述在现实中是对还是错（下一节将对此进行更多讨论）；这是我们准备坚持它所说的内容的强烈程度。例如，我们根本不应该对一只黑狗感到惊讶，但我们应该对一只绿色的狗感到惊讶得多。（进一步注释：在卡通中描绘狗时，它们受到的约束要少得多，例如哈克贝利猎犬，一种会说话和唱歌的蓝狗（无论如何都是一首可怕的歌），以及克利福德，一种车库大小的红狗。）另一方面，当狗是哺乳动物时，自由度要小得多。我们承认有没有活着的机器狗和玩具狗，但我们确实觉得那些活着的应该是哺乳动物。很难想象一只狗有干燥、有鳞的皮肤并会下蛋。

The issue here is not so much whether we take the statement to be true or false in reality (but more on this in the next section); it is how strongly we are prepared to hang onto what it says. We should not be surprised at all by a black dog, for instance, but we should be much more surprised by a green one. (Further annotation: dogs are considerably less constrained when depicted in cartoons, such as Huckleberry Hound, the blue dog that can talk and sing (one horrendous song, anyway), and Clifford, the red dog that is the size of a garage.) On the other hand, there is much less latitude when it comes to a dog being a mammal. We recognize that there are robot dogs and toy dogs that are not alive, but we do feel that those that are alive should be mammals. It would be quite unusual to imagine a dog that had a dry, scaly skin and laid eggs. We might want to say that that was something other than a dog.

明斯基框架的想法捕捉了一些关于刻板情境的常识性知识的重要高级想法。值得注意的是，这个想法还涵盖了有关事件序列的知识。像 Schank 这样的 AI 科学家的其他早期工作专注于刻板印象序列基于日常经验的行为，通常被称为“脚本”。一个经典示例捕捉了与在餐厅用餐相关的典型事件序列，其中“场景”与进入、点餐、就餐、支付和退出相关。可以将上述相同类型的注释、情境匹配和期望驱动的识别设备应用于这些事件序列。请注意，时间和因果关系的常识性概念将是支持这种机制的基本要素。

The Minsky idea of a frame captures some important high-level ideas about commonsense knowledge of stereotyped situations. It is worth noting that this idea also covers knowledge about sequences of events. Other early work by AI scientists like Schank focused on stereotypical sequences of actions based on everyday experiences, which were often referred to as “scripts.” A classic example captures the typical sequence of events related to eating at a restaurant, with “scenes” related to entering, ordering, eating, paying, and exiting. The same kind of annotation, situation-matching, and expectation-driven recognition apparatus described above can be applied to these sequences of events. Note that commonsensical notions of time and causality would be essential ingredients to support such a mechanism.

获得正确的概念

Getting a Concept Right

毫不奇怪，我们很难写出“每家医院都有……”这种形式的任何明确形式的东西。是我们世界的一部分。例如，哲学家路德维希·维特根斯坦 (Ludwig Wittgenstein) 问道，考虑到极端的变化范围，我们如何描述游戏的常识概念？

It is not too surprising that we should have a hard time writing anything categorical of the form “Every hospital has …” Philosophers of language have long made the case that we cannot expect to find satisfactory characterizations in language for many of the kinds of things that are part of our world. For example, how do we characterize something like our commonsense notion of a game, philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein asked, given the extreme range of variations?

问题的很大一部分与边界条件有关。构成医院的概念边界（就像构成小溪的边界一样，来自上一章）不需要明确界定。对于范围更有限的机构（只有一些医生办公室和一些医疗服务），我们可能更愿意使用诸如“医学艺术大楼”之类的术语，而对于范围更小的机构（包括收容所和长期精神病房等机构），但我们不希望在这种分类中有确切的界限。

A big part of the problem has to do with boundary conditions. The conceptual boundaries of what constitutes a hospital (like the boundaries of what constitutes a creek, from the previous chapter) need not be clear-cut. We might prefer to use a term like “medical arts building” for institutions that are more limited in scope (only some doctors’ offices and a few medical services) and something like “health care facility” for institutions that are less limited in scope (institutions that include things like hospices and long-term psychiatric wards), but we do not expect exact boundaries in this classification.

然而，一旦我们承认在形成常识性概念时，我们无需确定对所有且仅适用于此类事物的事实，任务就会大大简化。重复一遍，我们可以从这个想法的直率和不合格的版本开始，也许适合作为对孩子的第一个解释。这个版本可能会让一个成年人畏缩，就像一个成年人在阅读四年级课本中民主概念的表现时可能会畏缩一样。它忽略了如此多的问题、特殊情况、变化和微妙之处。为了弥补这一点，我们允许注释在必要时改进描述的可能性。

Once we accept that in formulating commonsense concepts, however, we need not pin down the facts that are true of all and only things of that kind, the task is eased considerably. To repeat, we can start with a blunt and unqualified version of the idea, perhaps one that is suitable as a first explanation to a child. This version might make an adult cringe in the same way an adult might cringe at reading how the concept of democracy is presented in a fourth grade school text. It ignores so many issues, special cases, variations, and subtleties. To compensate for this, we allow for the possibility of annotations to refine the description as necessary.

要实际看到这一点，请考虑儿童生日派对的概念，在任何类型的注释之前，如下所示：

To see this in action, consider the concept of a children’s birthday party, prior to annotation of any sort, as in the following:

儿童生日派对是孩子的父母在家里举办的庆祝孩子出生周年的活动。聚会在临近孩子出生日期的周末举行，约有六个其他孩子参加，通常是之前受邀的朋友或亲戚。预计每位出席的客人都会带上一份包装好的礼物送给过生日的孩子。

A children’s birthday party is an event put on by the parents of a child in their home to celebrate the anniversary of the birth of that child. The party takes place on a weekend close to the date of the birth of the child, and is attended by about six other children, usually friends or relatives, who have been previously invited. Each attending guest is expected to bring a wrapped gift to give to the birthday child.

以下事件按顺序发生：

The following events take place in sequence:

1. 晚会以家长为孩子们组织的派对游戏开始，例如给驴子别尾巴。

1. The party begins with party games for the children, organized by the parents, such as pin the tail on the donkey.

2. 然后孩子们坐在一张桌子旁吃点心。

2. The children are then seated at a table for a light snack.

3. 点心结束时，灯光变暗，端出顶部点缀着小蜡烛的蛋糕；蜡烛的数量与生日孩子的年龄相匹配。

3. At the end of the snack, the lights are dimmed and a cake decorated with small, lit candles on the top is brought out; the number of candles matches the age of the birthday child in years.

4、嘉宾合唱歌曲《生日快乐！而蛋糕则放在过生日孩子面前的桌子上。

4. The guests sing the song “Happy Birthday!” while the cake is placed on the table in front of the birthday child.

5、歌曲结束，让生日小朋友许个愿，小朋友吹灭所有蜡烛，然后来宾鼓掌。

5. At the end of the song, the birthday child is told to make a wish, and the child blows out all the candles, after which the guests clap.

6. 蛋糕由家长切块，作为点心甜点分发给大家食用。

6. The cake is then cut into pieces by the parents and distributed for everyone to eat as the snack dessert.

7. 过生日的孩子收到生日客人带来的礼物。

7. After this, the birthday child is presented with the gifts brought by the birthday guests.

8. 大家看着过生日的孩子依次拆开礼物，感谢送礼物的客人。

8. Everyone watches as the birthday child unwraps each gift in turn, thanking the guest who brought it.

9. 所有的礼物都打开后，孩子们可以玩一会儿，聚会就结束了。

9. Once all the gifts have been unwrapped, the children may play for a while, and the party then comes to a close.

剧本当然是大家耳熟能详的：指定生日的孩子、嘉宾、礼物、蛋糕、蜡烛，还有很多场景，其中最关键的是唱生日歌和吹蜡烛。但该描述并没有试图对所有孩子的生日聚会都是真实的；事情说得太直白了。它说活动在孩子父母的家里举行，但没有提到像许多派对那样使用附近的餐馆或工艺品店的可能性。它说该活动在周末举行，没有考虑到没有学校的工作日。它甚至不区分两岁孩子的聚会和十岁孩子的聚会。同样，每个子事件的当事人以某种固定的顺序明确指定，几乎没有或没有变化的余地。所有这些都需要在注释中处理。

The script, of course, is quite familiar: the designated birthday child, guests, gifts, cake, candles, and a number of scenes, including most crucially, the singing of the birthday song and blowing out of the candles. But the description does not make any attempt to be true of all children’s birthday parties; things are stated too bluntly. It says the event takes place at the home of the parents of the child, without mentioning the possibility of using a nearby restaurant or craft shop, as many parties do. It says that the event takes place on a weekend, without allowing for weekdays when there is no school. It does not even distinguish between a party for a two-year-old and one for a ten-year-old. Similarly, each of the subevents of the party are specified categorically, in a certain fixed order, with little or no room for variation. All of these would need to be dealt with in annotations.

因此，为了能够完全表达常识性知识，我们提倡对孩子们的生日聚会进行简单描述，我们承认这并非对所有孩子都如此。事实上，如果描述的足够详细，我们可能会知道其中的大多数情况并非如此。但这随后提出了一个令人不安的问题：如果我们似乎不关心准确性或真实性的概念，那么任何描述都可以吗？有没有办法弄错一个？

So with the aim of being able to express commonsense knowledge at all, we are advocating for a simple description of children’s birthday parties that we admit is not true of all of them. In fact, if the description is detailed enough, we may know that it is not true of the majority of them. But this then raises a troubling question: If we are seemingly unconcerned with notions of accuracy or truth, will any description do? Is there no way to get one wrong?

有一个老笑话/谜语是这样的：

There’s an old joke/riddle that goes like this:

问：什么东西又大又灰，有树干，住在树上？

Q: What’s big and gray, has a trunk, and lives in a tree?

答：一头大象。我对那棵树撒了谎。

A: An elephant. I lied about the tree.

这个谜语的归谬法版本是这样的：

The reductio ad absurdum version of this riddle is this:

问：什么东西又大又灰，有树干，住在树上？

Q: What’s big and gray, has a trunk, and lives in a tree?

答：七号。我对一切都撒了谎。

A: The number seven. I lied about everything.

这提出了这样一种前景，即我们可以用任意幻想的术语来描述常识性概念，并认为可以叠加注释以消除任何失误。例如，我们可能提出了一个大象的概念，

What this raises is the prospect that we could characterize commonsense concepts in arbitrarily fanciful terms, with the idea that annotations could be superimposed to cancel any missteps. We might, for example, have proposed a concept of an elephant that goes,

大象是一种大型的树栖动物。 ……

An elephant is a big, arboreal creature. …

带有注释以对冲“树栖”部分。这不是问题吗？

with annotations to hedge the “arboreal” part. Is this not a problem?

这是。描述中麻烦地包含了“树栖”一词，我们知道（也就是说，我们的常识告诉我们）使用“陆地”等不同的词会好得多。大型树栖生物的概念很好，但作为我们认为的大象的描述，这是错误的。

It is. The description goes to the trouble of including the word “arboreal,” where we know (that is, our commonsense knowledge tells us) that it would have been much better to use something different like “terrestrial.” The concept of a big, arboreal creature is fine, but as a characterization of what we think of as an elephant, it’s just wrong.

更一般地说，如果我们知道在更准确的相同细节层次上对某个概念（如大象、医院或生日派对的描述）的描述是错误的。这可能在编辑方面最容易可视化：如果您可以在描述的某些部分画一条红线并用您知道会更好的相同细节级别的内容替换它，则描述是错误的。相反，如果您发现任何部分令人反感或令人畏惧（包括您正在考虑的任何注释中），则描述并没有错，您将被迫在页边空白处写更详细的更正（也就是说，你将被迫写一个注释）。所以回到生日派对，可以说它是在父母家里举行的，因为更准确的描述需要额外的细节和讨论。

More generally, we say that a description of a concept (like that of an elephant, hospital, or birthday party) is wrong if we know a change to it at the same level of detail that would be more accurate. This might be easiest to visualize in terms of editing: a description is wrong if you can put a red line though some part of it and replace it by something at that same level of detail that you know would be better. Conversely, the description is not wrong if for any part you find objectionable or cringeworthy (including within any of the annotations you are considering), you would be forced to write a more detailed correction somewhere in the margin (that is, you would be forced to write an annotation). So going back to the birthday party, it’s fine to say that it takes place at the home of the parents since a more accurate account would need additional detail and discussion.

顺便说一句，描述像陈规定型的生日聚会这样的事件的想法有助于解释如何处理一些很难找到其他地方的一般经验知识。例如，考虑一下人们（倾向于）在生日聚会上吃蛋糕这一事实。这似乎不是我们所指的人或蛋糕的一部分。但它确实符合我们的生日派对概念，尤其是在该活动中扮演特定角色的人，如上所述。人们在曲棍球比赛中欢呼、饭后洗碗以及在冬天穿暖和的衣服时也可以说类似的话。

Incidentally, the idea of describing events like stereotypical birthday parties helps to explain how to handle some general experiential knowledge that is tough to find a place for otherwise. Consider, for instance, the fact that people (tend to) eat cake at birthday parties. This doesn’t seem to be part of what we mean either by a person or cake. But it does fit well within our concept of a birthday party and in particular the people playing a certain role in that event, as described above. Similar things could be said about people cheering at hockey games, washing dishes after a meal, and wearing warm clothing in the winter months.

原型和范例

Prototypes and Exemplars

虽然上面的大部分内容都是建立在诸如刻板印象之类的想法之上的，但让我们花点时间更仔细地研究一下。在本章和上一章中，我们一直强调简化的、常识性的世界观，而不是严格的字典定义、精心制作的百科全书条目或专家知识。我们甚至使用“朴素物理学”一词来与训练有素的物理学家持有的观点形成对比。普通人的世界观包括诸如“不受支撑的物体坠落”之类的简单想法，而不是诸如扭曲的时空或引力波之类的概念。

While much of the above is built on ideas like stereotyped situations, let us take a moment to examine this a little more closely. Throughout this chapter and the previous one, we have emphasized simplified, commonsensical views of the world rather than strict dictionary definitions, carefully crafted encyclopedia entries, or expert knowledge. We even used the term “naive physics” to contrast with the perspectives held by trained physicists. The worldview of the average person includes simplistic ideas like “unsupported objects fall” instead of notions like distorted space-time or gravitational waves.

这是因为常识性知识来源于日常生活中人们对日常生活的经验。我们在童年时期通过观察（偶尔接受父母和老师的指导）发展我们对世界的理论，因此我们对世界如何运作、人们为什么做事以及事件如何导致变化的中心观点往往是直觉和肤浅的。甚至在我们能够理解语言之前（当然在我们能够阅读书籍之前），我们就会体验到周围世界中物体和人的互动。我们开发本地化视图。因此，生日派对在生日孩子的父母家中举行或狗是棕色动物的想法是很自然地产生的，并且在我们遇到例外之前很容易变得强烈。通过阅读和学校教育了解更多关于宇宙的复杂和隐藏的规则。但我们世俗知识的核心来自个人经验。

This is because commonsense knowledge is derived from experiences by everyday people of everyday situations. We develop our theories of the world in childhood by observation (with occasional instruction from parents and teachers), and so our central views of how the world works, why people do things, and how events cause change tend to be intuitive and shallow. Even before we can understand language (and certainly well before we can read books), we experience objects and people interacting in the world around us. We develop a localized view. So the ideas that a birthday party is thrown at the house of the parents of the birthday child or a dog is an animal that is brown are arrived at quite naturally, and can easily become strongly lodged before we ever experience exceptions to them. We eventually learn about things different than those we’ve experienced, and come to understand more complex and hidden rules about the universe through reading and schooling. But the core of our mundane knowledge comes from personal experience.

虽然我们对世界的了解最初是由我们具体的、个人的经验驱动的，但我们也有一种自然的趋向于概括的动力。我们注意到，我们遇到的第二只、第三只和第五只狗似乎与我们之前见过的那些有一些明显的特征：尾巴、黑鼻子、四条腿等等。当然会有差异，比如颜色、鼻子的形状，或者我们是否听到它们的吠声。然而，在看到他们中的一些人开始相信他们所有人都有潜在的共性之后，这是一种不可避免的趋势。这种概括的冲动具有很大的价值，因为它让我们知道当我们看到我们认为是同一类实例的其他事物时会发生什么：我们遇到的第一批狗摇着尾巴舔我们的脸，所以很自然地假设接下来的人也会这样做。

While our knowledge of the world is initially driven by our specific, individual experiences, we also have a natural drive toward generalization. We notice that the second, third, and fifth dogs we encounter seem to share some obvious characteristics with the ones we’ve seen before: tails, black noses, four legs, and so on. Of course there will be differences, like color, shape of the snout, or whether we hear them bark. Yet it’s an inevitable tendency after seeing a few of them to come to believe that there is an underlying commonality in all of them. This urge to generalize has great value since it allows us to know what to expect when we see other things that we believe to be instances of the same class: the first dogs we encountered wagged their tails and licked our faces so it’s natural to assume that the next ones will do the same.

人们可以想象有不同的方法来保留我们对第一次经验及其概括的知识。当谈到人类时，认知科学中的一些工作倾向于支持所谓的原型或类别的理想表示，建立在一个人对某事的第一次体验之上。如果孩子与狗的第一次接触恰好是牧羊犬，那么孩子对狗的原型就会具有该牧羊犬最显着的特征。随着遇到更多的狗并注意到新的特征，这种表示会被抽象和提炼。我们在这里所涵盖的内容直接承认了这样一个事实，即常识性知识似乎是建立在由一些个人经验驱动的概念之上，然后进行概括；它允许表达概括并保留默认值。我们的机制还允许需要通过注释逐步添加的不可避免的异常和细微差别。

There are different methods one can imagine for retaining our knowledge of first experiences and their generalizations. When it comes to humans, some work in cognitive science tends to favor what are called prototypes or ideal representations for categories, built on a person’s first experience with something. If a child’s first experience with a dog happens to be a collie, the child’s prototype for dogs takes on the most salient features of that collie. This representation then gets abstracted as well as refined as more dogs are encountered and new features are noticed. What we’ve covered here directly acknowledges the fact that commonsense knowledge seems to be built on concepts driven by a few personal experiences and then generalized; it allows generalizations to be expressed and default values to be retained. Our mechanism also allows for the inevitable exceptions and nuances that need to be added incrementally via annotations.

关于如何通过给定类的范例而不是抽象的原型来保留日常知识并将其应用于新情况，还有另一种观点。在那种情况下，新项目将与我们遇到的特定个体的知识进行比较（比如电影中的流浪狗，我们在院子里第一次看到的那只特定的狗，我们现在的宠物 Fido，等等）而不是代表该类别的虚构代表。一些心理学家发现，人们既可以使用原型来对类别进行中心表征，也可以使用原型周围的范例。

There is an alternate view of how to retain everyday knowledge and apply it to new situations via exemplars of a given class rather than abstracted prototypes. In that case, new items would be compared to knowledge of specific individuals we’d encountered (like the dog Tramp in the movies, that specific dog we first saw in our yard, our current pet Fido, and so on) as opposed to a made-up representative that exemplifies the category. Some psychologists have found that people may use both prototypes for the central characterization of categories and also exemplars surrounding the prototypes.

虽然我们在此类问题上没有强硬立场，但任何建立人工常识认知的人都可能需要得出一种或另一种观点。重要的是我们一直在谈论的那种概念工具应该足以处理这些方法中的任何一种。（但请参阅下面本章的最后一节，以更激进地看待这个问题。）

While we have no strong stance on matters like these, anyone building an artificial commonsense cognition will probably need to arrive at one view or the other. The important thing is that the kind of conceptual apparatus we have been talking about should be adequate to handle any of these approaches. (But see the last section of this chapter below for a more radical take on the issue.)

变化：事件、行动及其影响

Change: Events, Actions, and Their Effects

生日派对和其他活动一样，改变了世界：蜡烛被点燃并吹灭，蛋糕被吃掉，每份礼物的所有权从客人转移到生日孩子。了解生日聚会引起的变化涉及查看发生的各种子事件。但有些事件还有另外一个方面。除了子事件之外，我们还认为它们是代理人故意执行的行为，作为实现他们关心的目标的一种方式。

Birthday parties, like other events, change the world: candles are lit and blown out, a cake is eaten, and the ownership of each gift is transferred from the guest to the birthday child. Understanding the changes caused by a birthday party involves looking at the various subevents that take place. But some events have an additional aspect. Alongside having subevents, we think of them as actions that agents perform deliberately as a way of working toward goals they care about.

例如，考虑打开一扇门。关于门，我们可能知道很多事情（包括它们的材料、安装、把手、铰链和锁），但从常识的角度来看，关于它们的主要内容是它们的位置以及它们可以打开和关闭的事实。关闭。我们为什么要关心？如前所述，我们关心靠近某些物体以便能够对它们采取行动，而这样做通常涉及进入物体所在的房间，而这反过来可能需要穿过一扇门。如果门没开？代理可以执行一些特定的操作来改变门的状态。我们可以将这门知识表达如下：

Consider opening a door, for example. There may be many things we know about doors (including their material, installation, handles, hinges, and locks), but from a commonsense point of view, the main thing about them is their location along with the fact that they can be opened and closed. Why do we care? As already noted, we care about getting close to certain objects to be able to act on them, and to do so often involves going into a room where the objects are located, and this in turn may require going through a door. And if the door is not open? There are specific actions that agents can do to cause the state of a door to change. We can express this door knowledge as in the following:

门的状态为打开、关闭 + 锁定或关闭 + 解锁。

A door has a state that is open, closed + locked, or closed + unlocked.

代理可以关闭附近的门，前提是它的状态是打开的，效果是将其状态更改为关闭 + 解锁。

An agent can close a nearby door provided its state is open, and the effect is to change its state to closed + unlocked.

代理可以打开附近的门，前提是其状态为关闭 + 解锁，效果是将其状态更改为打开。

An agent can open a nearby door provided its state is closed + unlocked, and the effect is to change its state to open.

代理可以锁定附近的门，前提是其状态为关闭 + 解锁并且代理持有门的钥匙，效果是将其状态更改为关闭 + 锁定。

An agent can lock a nearby door provided its state is closed + unlocked and the agent is holding a key for the door, and the effect is to change its state to closed + locked.

代理可以解锁附近的门，前提是其状态为关闭 + 锁定并且代理持有门的钥匙，效果是将其状态更改为关闭 + 解锁。

An agent can unlock a nearby door provided its state is closed + locked and the agent is holding a key for the door, and the effect is to change its state to closed + unlocked.

这描述了 agent 可以执行的四个动作，每个动作都有一个前后故事：在 agent 能够成功执行该动作之前必须是什么（通过纯粹的意志力），以及哪些变化是由代理成功执行操作。前者称为动作的先决条件；后者，它的影响。在这种情况下，未指定在操作过程中实际发生的具体情况。对于大多数用途，门事件可能被认为根本没有子事件。例如，密钥的实际使用只能在补充注释中进行描述。

This describes four actions that agents can perform using a before-and-after story for each one: what has to be true before an agent is able to successfully perform the action (by sheer force of will), and what changes are caused by the agent successfully performing the action. The former are called the prerequisites of the action; the latter, its effects. In this case, what specifically actually happens during the action is left unspecified. For most purposes, door events might be thought of as having no subevents at all. For example, the actual use of a key is something that would be described only in a supplementary annotation.

这里的模式很熟悉。正如门状态受打开、关闭和锁定事件的影响一样，婚姻状况受婚礼、离婚和死亡的影响。同样，对象的所有权会受到销售、捐赠和收回等事件的影响。无生命物体的位置会受到运输事件的影响，并因搭配的常识性规律而变得复杂。代理执行的某些操作具有启动或终止其他长期事件的效果。因此，在装满水的浴缸中拔下塞子会立即启动排水事件。桶中的水量是随时间推移受此排水事件影响的量。同样，头发的长度是一个随时间缓慢增加的量，除非它突然受到剪发事件的影响。

The pattern here is familiar. Just as door states are affected by opening, closing, and locking events, marital status is affected by weddings, divorces, and deaths. Likewise, the ownership of an object is affected by events like sales, donations, and repossessions. The location of an inanimate object is affected by transportation events, complicated by the commonsense law of collocation. Certain actions performed by agents have the effect of initiating or terminating other longer-term events. So pulling the plug in a bathtub filled with water immediately starts a water-draining event. The amount of water in the tub is a quantity that is then affected over time by this draining event. Similarly, length of hair is a quantity that slowly increases over time unless it is suddenly affected by a haircutting event.

像上面那些事前事后的故事专门用于决定执行什么行动，尤其是常识行为所必需的手段-目的分析（即分析如何实现目标以及通过什么手段）。这是常识的一部分，如果你想从某个房间拿一本书，你可能需要从完全相反的方向开始，尽管一开始看起来很荒谬。为什么？因为你可能知道房间的门是锁着的，你首先需要拿到钥匙开锁，然后才能开门，进入房间，拿到书。

Before-and-after stories like those above are geared specifically to deciding what actions to perform, and in particular, the means-ends analysis (that is, the analysis of how to achieve goals and by what means) necessary for commonsense behavior. It is part of common sense that if you want to get a book from a certain room, you may need to start by going in a completely opposite direction, as preposterous as this might seem at first. Why? Because you may know that the door to the room is locked, and you first need to get the key to unlock it, which will then allow you to open the door, enter the room, and get the book.

虽然尝试将行动串在一起以实现目标当然是常识的一部分，但另一部分是知道何时某些行动不合适，因为这种努力没有必要或可能会失败，或者因为这些行动可能有不受欢迎的一面效果。例如，如果您不知道门的钥匙在哪里，仍然可以通过其他方式进入房间：将门从铰链上取下，请锁匠取下锁，在门上开一个洞墙，在附近引爆一颗小炸弹门等等。虽然可能存在牵强附会的情况，其中每项行动都是合理的选择，但常识的一部分涉及了解与执行某项行动相关的典型工作（或不便、成本或风险），并使用该知识排除不适合相关目标的行动方案。

While attempting to string actions together to achieve a goal is certainly part of common sense, another part is knowing when certain actions would not be suitable, either because the effort is not warranted or is likely to fail, or because the actions might have undesirable side effects. For example, if you don’t know where the key to the door is, it is still possible to get into the room in other ways: taking the door off the hinges, getting a locksmith to remove the lock, cutting a hole in the wall, exploding a small bomb near the door, and so on. While there might be far-fetched cases where each of these actions would be a reasonable choice, part of common sense involves knowing the typical effort (or inconvenience, cost, or risk) associated with performing an action, and using that knowledge to rule out courses of action that are inappropriate for the goals in question.

当然，在不知道共享密钥位置的情况下获取共享密钥的一种方法是询问知道的人。使用其他代理人作为达到目的的手段是人们和其他社会动物使用的一种熟悉的策略。这需要认识到其他代理人不仅参与事件，而且还可以导致事件发生。如前所述，如果可以让代理人分享你的目标，这可能足以让代理人为实现该目标而做它需要做的事情。因此，传达您的需求可能是完成任务的有效方式，包括找出钥匙的位置，甚至可能实现更高层次的目标，例如实际从上锁的房间里拿到书。

Of course, one way of getting a shared key when its location is not known is to ask somebody who does know. Using other agents as a means to achieve an end is a familiar strategy used by people and other social animals. This requires recognizing that other agents are not only involved in events but can also cause them to take place. As noted before, if an agent can be made to share a goal you have, this may be sufficient to have the agent do what it takes to achieve that goal. So communicating what you want can be a powerful way of getting things done, including finding out where a key is and possibly even achieving higher-level goals like actually getting the book from the locked room.

但同样重要的是要记住让其他代理人参与进来可能需要付出的努力——以及那里的副作用。如果你需要知道现在几点了，问问别人，即使是一个完全陌生的人也很有意义。然而，如果你周末需要一辆车，试图说服一个完全陌生的人把他们的车借给你是徒劳的。（如果那个陌生人恰好有汽车租赁业务，那就另当别论了。）这是常识的一部分，代理人会很容易地接受某些目标，有时只是被问到，但不会在没有具体说明的情况下接受其他目标可能难以应对的原因。

But it is also important to keep in mind the effort it might take to get other agents involved—and the side effects there as well. If you need to know what time it is, it makes perfect sense to ask someone, even a complete stranger. If you need a car for the weekend, however, trying to convince a complete stranger to lend you their vehicle is a fool’s errand. (If that stranger happens to have a car rental business, then that’s a different story.) It is part of common sense that an agent will take on certain goals quite readily, sometimes just by being asked, but will not take on others without specific reasons that might be difficult to contend with.

最后，某些事件的发生是代理人努力的结果，尽管在这样的特定情况下，最好不要将它们视为行动，而更像是自然发生的事件，如雷暴或交通堵塞。例如，我们可能不会将生日派对视为由代理人针对其实现的每一种效果而执行的动作。尽管我们可能非常有信心参加生日派对的客人会得到蛋糕吃，但我们绝不会想通过邀请生日派对来获得蛋糕。相比之下，一个复杂的事件，比如在面包店买蛋糕，将被理解为可以仅仅为了这种效果而做的事情，即使许多变化是由它的子事件引起的（比如门打开、服务号码被选择、陈列柜打开、

In the end, there are certain events that take place as the result of the efforts of agents, although under such specific circumstances that they might best be thought of not as actions but rather more as naturally occurring events like thunderstorms or traffic jams. For example, we might not think of a birthday party as an action that is performed by an agent for every effect it achieves. Even though we may be quite confident that the guests at a birthday party will be given cake to eat, it would never occur to us to try to get cake by finding a birthday party to get invited to. In contrast, a complex event like buying cake at a bakery will be understood as something that can be done just for this effect, even though many of the changes caused by its subevents (like doors opened, service numbers picked, display cases opened, and cash registers used) will be considered to be side effects only.

有关个人的事实信息

Factual Information about Individuals

正如本章开头所指出的，我们对世界的了解大多与具体的个体事物有关。的确，我们随身携带了大量的概念来描述这些东西。但是我们至少知道一件独特事物的个体事物的数量要大得多。举一个简单的例子，我们知道数字 7,503，而且只有 7,503，有 7,502 作为它的直接前身。

As noted at the start of this chapter, much of what we know about the world is about specific individual things. It is true that we carry around a large number of concepts to describe these things. But the number of individual things we know at least one distinctive thing about is much larger. To take a trivial example, we know that the number 7,503, and 7,503 alone, has 7,502 as its direct predecessor.

我们对个人的大多数常识性知识读起来都像一张资料单：住在隔壁的约翰出生在波士顿，是一名理发师，有一个叫苏的母亲；星期六晚上的扑克比赛在约翰的地下室举行，有五名选手参加，一直持续到凌晨三点。但正如在第一节中指出的那样，关于个人的知识与概念结构之间存在着密切的联系：要相信一个事物具有某种属性，它必须被认为是可以具有这种属性的事物。换句话说，概念结构决定了事实说明书的范围——关于世界上个别事物的已知范围。

Most of our commonsense knowledge of individuals reads like a fact sheet: John, the person who lives next door, was born in Boston, works as a barber, and has a mother called Sue; the Saturday night poker game took place in John’s basement, had five players, and lasted until three in the morning. But as noted in the first section, there is a strong connection between knowledge about individuals and conceptual structures: to believe that a thing has a certain property, it must be thought of as the kind of thing that can have such a property. The conceptual structure, in other words, determines the scope of the fact sheet—the range of what can be known about the individual things in the world.

用英语表达关于个人的知识的一个棘手问题涉及使用名词短语来指定世界上的事物。我们所说的“约翰”、“约翰的地下室”或“波士顿”指的是谁或什么？当约翰没有地下室时，我们应该如何理解包含短语“约翰的地下室”的句子？或者有两个？

One thorny issue in expressing knowledge about individuals in English involves the use of noun phrases designating things in the world. Who or what do we mean by “John,” “John’s basement,” or “Boston”? How should we understand sentences containing the phrase “John’s basement” when John does not have a basement? Or has two of them?

哲学家伯特兰·罗素 (Bertrand Russell) 对于在英语中使用像这样的名词短语（包括名字）有一个有用的建议。每当我们写类似的东西时，

The philosopher Bertrand Russell had a useful suggestion regarding the use of noun phrases like this in English, including names. Whenever we write something like,

约翰出生于波士顿。

John was born in Boston.

我们应该把它解释为更像是在说什么，

we should interpret it as saying something more like,

有一个人的名字叫“约翰”，他出生在一个叫“波士顿”的城市。

There is a person whose name is “John,” and that person was born in a city whose name is “Boston.”

换句话说，我们应该做的是澄清什么东西被声称存在以及它们被声称具有什么属性。所以当我们说，

What we should do, to put it another way, is clarify just what things are claimed to exist and what properties they are claimed to have. So when we say,

一场比赛在约翰的地下室举行。

A game took place in John’s basement.

我们应该将其解释为，

we should interpret this as,

有一个地下室，是一个叫“约翰”的人唯一拥有的地下室，在那里举行了一场比赛。

There is a basement that is the only one owned by a person called “John,” and a game took place there.

换句话说，建议是将所有描述个体的名词短语（引号和数字内的字符串除外）替换为存在具有各种属性的各种事物的主张，并且在某些情况下（例如对于使用定冠词“the”的名词短语，也可能有唯一性声明。

In other words, the suggestion is to replace all noun phrases describing individuals (except maybe for strings of characters within quotation marks and numerals) by claims of the existence of things of various kinds with various properties, and where, in some cases (such as for noun phrases that use the definite article “the”), there may also be claims of uniqueness.

当涉及到关于个别事物的知识时，上面提到的基础知识和派生知识的问题再次发挥作用。例如，假设我们知道以下内容：

When it comes to knowledge about individual things, the issue of basic and derived knowledge noted above again comes into play. Suppose, for example, that we know the following:

1. 玛丽拿着手电筒在约翰的地下室里。

1. Mary is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

我们可能希望知道这些中的每一个：

We might expect to then know each of these:

2. 约翰的地下室里有人拿着手电筒。

2. There is a person in John’s basement with a flashlight.

3. Joe 以外的其他人拿着手电筒在 John 的地下室。

3. Someone other than Joe is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

4. 爱丽丝或玛丽拿着手电筒在约翰的地下室里。

4. Either Alice or Mary is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

这些中的每一个都可以很容易地从（1）中推导出来。不同之处在于 (1) 将所讨论的个人标识为 Mary，而 (2)、(3) 和 (4) 将该身份保留为开放状态。

Each of these would be easily derivable from (1). The difference is that (1) identifies the individual in question as Mary, while (2), (3), and (4) leave that identity open.

然而，有趣的可能性是拥有像 (2) 这样的东西作为基础知识，而不知道像 (1) 这样的东西。例如，我们可能会通过一个又小又脏的窗户看到地下室里的某个人，但无法确定是谁。与 (3) 类似，我们可能会看到足够多的信息，知道地下室里的人不可能是乔（比方说，他比乔高得多），但仅此而已。对于 (4)，我们可能能够分辨出它是 Alice 或 Mary（因为他们看起来很像，比如说），而无法进一步缩小范围。

The interesting possibility, however, is having something like (2) as basic knowledge, without knowing anything like (1). For example, we might spot somebody in the basement through a small, dirty window without being able to identify who it is. Similarly for (3), we might see enough to know that the person in the basement cannot possibly be Joe (who is much taller, say), but no more. For (4), we might be able to tell that it is either Alice or Mary (because they look alike, say), without being able to narrow it further.

在谈论知识时，哲学家有时会区分知道那个和知道谁。我们可以知道有人拿着手电筒在地下室，但不知道是谁。我们可以知道一张扑克牌是从一副牌中抽出的，但不知道那张牌是什么。这是有时被称为不完整知识的一个例子：我们知道有一个形式的句子

In talking about knowledge, philosophers sometimes distinguish between knowing that and knowing who. We can know that somebody is in the basement with a flashlight without knowing who it is. We can know that a playing card has been drawn from a deck without knowing what that card is. This is an instance of what is sometimes called incomplete knowledge: we know that there is a sentence of the form

X在约翰的地下室里拿着手电筒。

X is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

这是真的，但我们还不能说这是哪句话。对于（2），X可以是任何人；对于 (3)，必须是 Joe 以外的其他人；对于（4），它必须成为爱丽丝或玛丽。我们还使用像“all”这样的全称量词得到了类似的不完整知识：

that is true, but we cannot yet say what sentence it is. For (2), the X could be any person; for (3), it must be someone other than Joe; for (4), it must be Alice or Mary. We also get a similar sort of incomplete knowledge using a universal quantifier like “all”:

约翰地下室里所有的油漆罐都布满了灰尘。

All the paint cans in John’s basement are covered in dust.

在这种情况下，我们是在说一群人拥有某种财产，但没有确定这些人是谁或他们是什么。（我们将在下面详细说明识别个人的含义。）

In this case, we are saying that a group of individuals have a certain property without identifying who or what those individuals are. (We will have more to say about what it means to identify an individual below.)

为什么我们要以这种方式关心不完整的知识？主要是因为当我们了解世界时，无论是通过语言还是经验，我们经常以零碎的方式获取信息，有时只需要使用我们拥有的信息。我们可能会在 John 的地下室发现某人，并且需要在我们确定该人是 Mary 之前决定要做什么。

Why do we care about knowledge that is incomplete in this way? Primarily because when we learn about the world, whether through language or experience, we frequently acquire information in a piecemeal fashion and sometimes will need to make do with just the information we have. We may spot somebody in John’s basement and need to decide what to do before we have identified the person in question as Mary.

这种不完整的知识会导致机器和人在推理时出现严重的并发症。简而言之，我们被迫从直接表示事物及其属性转向表示有关事物及其属性的信息。将这些信息放在一起得出结论就像使用线索来解决某种难题一样。

This type of incomplete knowledge leads to serious complications when it comes to reasoning, for both machines and people. In a nutshell, we are forced to move away from a direct representation of things and their properties toward a representation of information about things and their properties. Putting these pieces of information together to draw conclusions can be like using clues to solve some sort of puzzle.
