要更具体地了解这一点，请考虑图 6.2 中关于三对夫妇参加舞会的示例。在这种情况下，所有相关人员及其财产都已确定。如果这是我们被告知的，那么我们会立即看到 Gina 将与 Bob 一起去参加舞会。常识还告诉我们，她不会和比尔一起去。

To see this more concretely, consider the example about three couples going to the prom presented in figure 6.2. In this case, all the relevant people and their properties are identified. If this is what we are told, then we see immediately that Gina is going to the prom with Bob. Common sense also tells us that she will not be going with Bill.

但现在考虑图 6.3 中呈现的变体（以有时称为逻辑谜题的形式）。这次我们不会自动看到谁将和 Gina 一起去参加舞会。（为了记录，必须再次是 Bob。请参阅下面的下一段。）使用给定的三个来确定 Gina 的日期线索显然仍然是一种思维方式，只是一种特殊的思维方式：它需要一定的努力，可能需要笔和纸，而且不是每个人都擅长。吉娜不会和比尔一起去的结论虽然仍然正确，但超出了常识。解释常识运作的一个更微妙的挑战是解释这两种情况之间的差异。（这是我们将在本书末尾的附加章节中详细讨论的内容。）

But now consider the variant presented in figure 6.3 (in the form of what is sometimes called a logic puzzle). This time we do not automatically see who is going to the prom with Gina. (For the record, it has to be Bob again. See the next paragraph below.) Identifying Gina’s date using the three given clues is obviously still a form of thinking, but thinking of a specialized sort: it requires a certain amount of effort, it may require pencil and paper, and not everyone is good at doing it. The conclusion that Gina is not going with Bill, while still true, is beyond the reach of mere common sense. One of the more subtle challenges in explaining the workings of common sense is accounting for the difference between these two cases. (This is something we will take up in detail in the bonus chapter at the end of this book.)

关于舞会难题，这是推理。我们从第一个线索看出 Gail 没有和 Bob 一起去，第二个线索表明她也没有和 Brad 一起去。所以盖尔一定会和比尔一起去。根据第三条线索，Gabby 将与 Brad 或 Bill 一起去，但由于 Gail 将与 Bill 一起去，Gabby 必须与 Brad 一起去。这使得吉娜和鲍勃成为最后一对。因此，是鲍勃要和吉娜一起去参加舞会。顺便说一句，逻辑谜题通常会利用其他一些常识来使谜题更有趣。在第一条线索中，与其说“与 Gail 以外的人”，不如说“与 Gail 的姐姐”。在第二条线索中，与其说是“与 Brad 以外的人”，不如说是“与 Brad 最好的朋友”。这不会改变上面的推理：鲍勃仍然和吉娜在一起。

Regarding the prom puzzle, here’s the reasoning. We see by the first clue that Gail is not going with Bob and by the second that she is not going with Brad either. So Gail must be going with Bill. By the third clue, Gabby is going with Brad or Bill, but since Gail is going with Bill, Gabby must be going with Brad. This leaves Gina and Bob as the final couple. Hence it is Bob who is going to the prom with Gina. Incidentally, logic puzzles typically make use of other bits of commonsense knowledge to make the puzzle more interesting. Instead of saying “with someone other than Gail” in the first clue, it might say something like “with Gail’s sister.” Rather than “with someone other than Brad” in the second clue, it might say “with Brad’s best friend.” This would not change the reasoning above: Bob is still going with Gina.

这就留下了一个有趣的问题，即常识实际上应该如何处理这类不完整的信息——也就是说，在尝试任何解谜之前。可以说，鉴于上面的 (4)，我们应该能够确定 Alice、Mary 或 Jill 在 John 的地下室，而不必首先确定那个人是谁。（更多内容在奖励章节中。）

This leaves open the interesting question as to what common sense should actually do with incomplete information of this sort—that is, before any puzzle solving is even attempted. Arguably, given something like (4) above, we ought to be able to determine that Alice, Mary, or Jill is in John’s basement, without having to first identify who that individual is. (More on this in the bonus chapter.)

在考虑关于个别事物的知识时，确定一个事物一般意味着什么？在上面的舞会谜题中，这意味着能够为与 Gina 一起参加舞会的人附加一个名字：Bob，布拉德，或比尔。但不仅如此。我们在上面建议我们应该理解像 (1) 这样的句子，就好像它的意思是这样的：

In considering knowledge about individual things, what does it mean in general to have identified one? In the prom puzzle above, it meant being able to attach a name to the individual going with Gina to the prom: Bob, Brad, or Bill. But there is more to it than this. We suggested above that we should understand a sentence such as (1) as if it meant something like this:

一个名叫“玛丽”的人拿着手电筒在约翰的地下室里。

Someone whose name is “Mary” is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

这与这样说没什么不同：

This is not so different from saying something like this:

一个棕色头发的人拿着手电筒在约翰的地下室里。

Someone whose hair is brown is in John’s basement with a flashlight.

为什么我们应该认为第一句话已经确定了所讨论的个人而不是第二句话？如果我们想象一个世界上很多人都有相同的名字，那么知道这个名字并不足以识别其中一个人。也没有必要；如果我们读了一个神秘的谋杀案，最后揭示是管家干的，我们会说我们终于知道凶手是谁，即使我们可能不知道管家的名字。

Why should we think of the first sentence as having identified the individual in question but not the second? If we were imagining a world where many people had the same name, knowing the name would not be sufficient to identify one of them. Nor is it necessary; if we read a murder mystery, and it reveals at the end that it was the butler who did it, we would say that we finally know who the murderer is, even though we might not know the butler’s name.

这些例子中似乎涉及的是这样的事情：有 N 个个体在考虑中，以某种方式呈现，描述为d 1 、 d 2 、  … d N，每个被认为指的是一个不同的事物。然后我们说，如果我们能识别出哪个d i，我们就知道新描述指的是谁指的是同一件事。对于舞会示例，这些人表示为 Bob、Brad 和 Bill，因此我们需要通过名字来识别 Gina 的舞会日期。对于谋杀之谜，这些人可能表现为管家、分居的妻子和客座教授，因此将凶手与这些描述之一联系起来可能就足够了。

What does seem to be involved in these examples is something like this: there are a number N of individuals under consideration, presented in some way, with descriptions d1, d2, … dN, each considered to refer to a distinct thing. We then say that we know who a new description refers to if we can identify which di refers to the same thing. For the prom example, the individuals were presented as Bob, Brad, and Bill, so we needed to identify Gina’s prom date by name. For the murder mystery, the individuals might be presented as the butler, the estranged wife, and the visiting professor, and so it might be sufficient to associate the murderer with one of those descriptions.

一个常见的情况是，正在考虑的一组人以索引方式呈现——也就是说，通过使用提及此时此地的短语：“从现在开始五秒钟”、“从这里向前直走两个街区”、“我戴的手表”或“我左边门上的标志” ” 这是因为涉及其他事物的代理执行的操作取决于代理知道这些事物相对于它们当前坐标的位置，而不是它们在更全局、绝对意义上的位置。如果你需要在某个精确的位置，如果你不知道你在哪里，仅仅找出那个位置在全局意义上是什么是不够的；知道如何使该位置成为您所在的位置（例如，向前走两个街区）既是必要的也是充分的。同样，如果你需要在某个精确的时间做某事，时间; 同样，您需要知道的是现在的时间（例如，等待五秒钟）。

A common case is when the group of individuals under consideration are presented indexically—that is, by using phrases that make reference to the here and now: “five seconds from now,” “two blocks straight ahead from here,” “the watch I am wearing,” or “the sign on the door to my left.” This is because actions performed by agents involving other things depend on the agents knowing where those things are relative to their current coordinates rather than where they are in some more global, absolute sense. If you need to be at a certain precise location, it is not enough to find out what that location is in a global sense if you don’t know where you are; it is both necessary and sufficient for you to know how to make that location become where you are (for instance, by walking ahead two blocks). Similarly, if you need to do something at a certain precise time, it is not enough to find out what that time is in a global sense if you don’t know the current time; again, what you need to know is when that time is now (say, by waiting five seconds).

这种索引性的想法也适用于名称。例如，假设您想与房间里最富有的人握手。找出形式的东西

This indexical idea carries over to names. Suppose, for example, that you would like to shake hands with the richest person in the room. Finding out something of the form

房间里最富有的人是瑟斯顿豪厄尔三世。

The richest person in the room is Thurston Howell III.

可能根本没有帮助。你仍然想知道房间里哪个人有这个名字。另一方面，如果你开始了解一些更具索引性的东西，比如

may be of no help at all. You are still left wondering which person in the room has that name. On the other hand, if you come to know something more indexical like

房间里最富有的人是你右边的人。

The richest person in the room is the person to your immediate right.

然后你就可以和那个人握手了。

you will then be in a position to shake that person’s hand.

关于种类的事实信息

Factual Information about Kinds

我们关心的大部分事实信息显然是关于个别事物及其拥有的属性。当我们问“那里有多少个P？”这样的问题时 或“是否存在具有属性Q的P？” 我们在问一个事实问题。有多少人参加了婚礼？星期二有棒球比赛吗？二十四和二十八之间有素数吗？答案取决于我们相信存在的事物及其具有的属性。

Much of the factual information we care about is clearly about individual things and the properties they have. When we ask something of the form “How many P’s are there?” or “Is there a P that has property Q?” we are asking a factual question. How many people attended the wedding? Is there a baseball game on Tuesday? Are there any prime numbers between twenty-four and twenty-eight? The answers depend on the things we believe there to be and the properties they have.

然而，有时我们似乎不是在寻找关于事物的事实信息，而是在寻找关于各种事物的事实信息。我们可能会问，

Sometimes, however, we seem to be looking for factual information not about things but instead about kinds of things. We might ask,

狗有多少种？

How many kinds of dogs are there?

在一读中，这个问题有点奇怪。如果我们把它看作是关于我们的概念结构，我们可能会期待这样的答案：

In one reading, this question is somewhat odd. If we take it to be about our conceptual structure, we might expect answers like this:

按照我对世界的看法，有看门狗、赛狗、卡通狗、哈巴狗、杂种狗、咆哮狗 ……

According to the way I think of the world, there are guard dogs, racing dogs, cartoon dogs, lap dogs, mongrels, snarly dogs …

这几乎肯定不是预期的。但是这里潜伏着一个更明智的问题——一个不是关于概念而是关于世界的问题：

This is almost certainly not what was intended. But there is a more sensible question lurking here—one not about concepts but rather about the world:

有多少种狗？

How many breeds of dog are there?

现在这是一个事实问题，与询问有多少人参加了婚礼没有太大区别。事实证明，世界犬类组织目前的犬种数量为 339 种（在撰写本文时），包括比熊犬和西部高地白梗等犬种，分为十大类。

This is now a factual question, not so different from asking how many people attended a wedding. As it turns out, the World Canine Organization has the number of dog breeds currently at 339 (at the time of this writing), including ones like Bichon Frise and West Highland White Terrier, divided into ten major groups.

与狗本身和狗的各种概念（比如护卫犬）截然不同的是，世界上有些东西被称为狗品种，具有起源、历史、相关品种等属性。一个看似关于狗的种类的事实问题实际上是一个完全不同的抽象事物的问题。类似的考虑适用于有关福特汽车的种类、通用磨坊生产的谷物以及杂货店的玉米种类的问题。

So distinct from the dogs themselves and the various concepts of dogs (like guard dogs, say), there are things in the world called dog breeds with properties such as origin, history, related breeds, and so on. A factual question that seems to be about the kinds of dogs is actually a question about a different sort of abstract thing altogether. Similar considerations apply to questions about the kinds of cars made by Ford, cereals produced by General Mills, and corn at the grocery store.

一旦我们承认品种等事物的存在，很自然地会将它们视为狗的属性。就像狗可以有特定的颜色一样，它们也可以有特定的品种。（许多狗是混种，但我们在这里忽略了这种复杂情况。）正如我们可以谈论颜色为棕色的狗一样，我们可以谈论品种为 Pug（339 之一）的狗。然而，这两个属性之间存在差异。我们对棕色狗的了解是，它是狗并且具有特定的颜色，并且它就此止步。但是我们对哈巴狗的了解不仅仅是它是一只狗并且有特定的品种；我们还知道它有独特的皱纹、凸出的眼睛和卷曲的尾巴。（或者更准确地说，了解狗的人都知道这一点。） 这些知识从何而来？

Once we admit the existence of things like breeds, it is natural to think of them as properties of dogs. Just as dogs can have a certain color, they can have a certain breed. (Many dogs are of mixed breed, but we ignore that complication here.) Just as we can talk about dogs whose color is brown, we can talk about dogs whose breed is Pug (one of the 339). Yet there is a difference between the two properties. What we know about a brown dog is that it is a dog and has a certain color, and it stops there. But what we know about a pug is more than that it is a dog and has a certain breed; we also know that it has distinctive wrinkles, bulging eyes, and a curly tail. (Or to be more precise, people who know dogs know this.) Where does this knowledge come from?

首先，请注意卷尾巴和其他是狗的特性，而不是品种的特性。此外，这些狗有卷曲的尾巴这一事实并不是它们碰巧拥有的一些特性，就像上一节提到的约翰地下室的油漆罐上的灰尘一样。我们可以想象说这样的话

First of all, note that curly tails and the rest are properties of dogs, not of breeds. Furthermore, the fact that these dogs have curly tails is not some property they just happen to have like the dustiness of the paint cans in John’s basement mentioned in the previous section. We might imagine saying something like

所有品种为 Pug 的狗都有卷尾巴。

All the dogs whose breed is Pug have curly tails.

就像我们说的一样

the same way we might say

狗展上所有的狗都戴着红色的狗项圈。

All the dogs at the dog show were wearing red dog collars.

但重点是错误的。卷曲的尾巴在某种程度上是该品种固有的。（关于特别收藏的信息，比如地下室的油漆罐或狗展上的狗，本身就很有趣。更多信息请参见附加章节。）这表明我们想到的更像是概念一只哈巴狗。正如生日派对有生日蛋糕一样，哈巴狗也有卷曲的尾巴：

but the emphasis is wrong. The curly tails are somehow inherent in the breed. (Information about ad hoc collections, like the paint cans in the basement or dogs at the dog show, is interesting in its own right. See the bonus chapter for more.) This suggests that what we have in mind is something more like the concept of a pug. Just as birthday parties have birthday cakes, pugs have curly tails:

哈巴狗是一种有皱纹、凸出的眼睛、卷曲的尾巴……的狗。 

A pug is a dog that has wrinkles, bulging eyes, a curly tail, … 

描述会继续提到它的扁鼻子、短发、体型等等。据推测，我们也想谈谈它的品种：

The description would go on to mention its flat nose, short hair, size, and so on. Presumably, we would want to say something about its breed too:

哈巴狗是一种狗，其品种是哈巴狗。

A pug is a dog whose breed is Pug.

这是正确的，但忽略了一个事实，即如果您有一只狗并且它的品种是哈巴狗，那么它就足以成为一只哈巴狗，而不管它可能拥有或不拥有任何其他属性。此属性的充分性可以使用“任何”一词来表达，如下所示：

This is correct, but misses the fact that if you have a dog and its breed is Pug then that is enough for it to be a pug, regardless of any other property it may or may not have. The sufficiency of this property is something that might be expressed using the word “any” as follows:

哈巴狗是任何品种为哈巴狗的狗。它有皱纹、凸出的眼睛、卷曲的尾巴…… 

A pug is any dog whose breed is Pug. It has wrinkles, bulging eyes, a curly tail, … 

这类似于我们如何呈现具有充分条件的其他概念，例如

This is similar to how we might present other concepts with a sufficiency condition, such as

四足动物是任何有四条腿的动物。

A quadruped is any animal that has four legs.

而不是

as opposed to

马是一种有四只脚的动物。

A horse is an animal that has four legs.

回顾一下：关于各种事物的事实问题最好理解为关于某些抽象事物的问题，例如狗的品种、谷物品牌、汽车模型和玉米品种。这些抽象的东西（称之为类型）本身可以具有属性，例如它们首次引入时的属性。底层事物（即狗、谷物、汽车和玉米穗）的属性然后以通常的方式表示为概念结构的一部分，并根据相应类型额外规定充分条件。

So to recap: factual questions about kinds of things are best understood as questions about certain abstract things like breeds of dogs, brands of cereals, models of cars, and varieties of corn. These abstract things (call them types) can have properties in their own right, such as when they were first introduced. Properties of the underlying things (that is, the dogs, cereals, cars, and ears of corn) are then expressed in the usual way as part of a conceptual structure, with the extra stipulation of a sufficiency condition in terms of the corresponding type.

对概念结构的挑战

A Challenge to Conceptual Structures

在结束本章时，我们并不意味着我们已经穷尽了出现的各种问题。在许多主题中，即使是最简单的常识知识形式也很难用语言表达。在结束本章时，我们想最后一次考虑这个挑战，但从一个稍微不同的角度。

In bringing this chapter to a close, we do not mean to suggest that we have exhausted the sorts of issues that arise. There are many topics where even the simplest forms of commonsense knowledge are quite challenging to put into words. To conclude this chapter, we want to consider this challenge one last time, but from a slightly different perspective.

在思考有关世界的事实知识时，很容易想到这样的陈述

In thinking about factual knowledge concerning the world, it is tempting to think of a statement like

1. 湖上有一艘红船。

1. There is a red boat on the lake.

类似于这样的陈述

as being similar to a statement like

2. 二十四和二十八之间有一个质数。

2. There is a prime number between twenty-four and twenty-eight.

他们都谈论那里有什么东西以及它们有什么属性。但对 (1) 之类事物的信念必须考虑我们所说的“红色”、“船”和“湖”的含义。这些术语含糊不清，而且如前所述，人们可以合理地对它们的界限提出异议。无论如何，我们所说的“红色”这个词到底是什么意思？红酒真的是红色的吗？具有某种颜色意味着什么？物体的整个表面都必须是那种颜色，还是只是其中的很大一部分？多少？“船”是什么意思？我们包括玩具船吗？木筏上有某种座位安排？最后，“在湖上”是什么意思？我们可以相信 (1) 是错误的，同时相信有一艘红色的船系在岸边的码头上吗？

They both talk about what things there are and what properties they have. But a belief in something like (1) has to take into account what we mean by “red,” “boat,” and “lake.” These terms are vague, and as already noted, people can legitimately disagree on their boundaries. Just what do we mean by the word “red” anyway? Is red wine really red? And what does it mean to be of a certain color? Does the entire surface of the object have to be of that color, or just a good part of it? How much? And what do we mean by “boat”? Are we including toy boats? Rafts with some sort of seating arrangement on them? Finally, what do we mean by “on the lake”? Can we believe that (1) is false while believing there is a red boat tied to a dock near the shore?

这种吹毛求疵的言论可能看起来很可笑，只有像律师这样试图在技术细节上赢得争论的人才会感兴趣。（这让人想起著名的比尔克林顿台词，“这取决于‘是’这个词的含义。”）但在它的背后是对常识性知识的整个概念的严重挑战。

This kind of hairsplitting might seem laughable, only of interest to somebody like a lawyer trying to win an argument on a technicality. (It brings to mind the famous Bill Clinton line, “It depends on what the meaning of the word ‘is’ is.”) But behind it there is a serious challenge to the whole idea of commonsense knowledge.

挑战在于：也许我们认为的常识性知识终究是无法用语言表达的。当我们使用“red”、“boat”和“lake”等普通英语单词时，也许我们是在自欺欺人。也许我们所拥有的是一系列与一系列实际体验相关的想法，其方式根本不会将世界划分为离散的可命名类别，如“红色”、“船”和“湖泊”。Brian Cantwell Smith 是这样说的：

The challenge is this: perhaps what we think of as commonsense knowledge is something that cannot be expressed in words after all. Maybe we are fooling ourselves when we use ordinary English words like “red,” “boat,” and “lake.” Perhaps what we have is a collection of ideas connected to a range of actual experiences in a way that does not carve the world into discrete nameable categories like “red,” “boat,” and “lake” at all. Brian Cantwell Smith puts it this way:

是的，我们可以说世界在本体论上是离散的；是的，我们也可能相信我们是这样想的。然而，这种直觉似乎越来越有可能反映语言和发音的离散、组合性质，而不是任何潜在的本体论事实，也比我们的发音所依赖的默会和直觉思维模式更多。

Yes, we may talk as if the world were ontologically discrete; and yes, too, we may believe that we think that way. It seems increasingly likely, however, that such intuitions reflect the discrete, combinatorial nature of language and articulation more than any underlying ontological facts, and also more than the patterns of tacit and intuitive thinking on which our articulations depends.

因此，以“红色”、“船”和“湖”等词为例的类别可能更多地是关于我们如何说话，而不是世界是怎样的，也不是我们如何思考它。

So categories exemplified by words like “red,” “boat,” and “lake” might be more about how we talk, not how the world is, nor how we think about it.

如果这是真的，那么在这个涉及红船的案例中，我们究竟会相信什么？这是一种表达方式。想象一下说类似的话(3) 指着附近的一些船、一些色板和一个湖在下方：

If this were true, then what would we actually believe in this case involving the red boat? Here is one way to put it. Imagine saying something like (3) below while pointing to some nearby boats, some color swatches, and a lake:

3. 有类似这些东西的东西，有这样或那样的颜色，位于与这里类似的区域的表面上。

3. There is something like these things, having a color like this or this, located on the surface of a region similar to this one here.

当然，我们仍在使用 (3) 中的词，但没有假设涉及红色、船和湖泊的基本概念结构。

We are still using words in (3), of course, but without assuming an underlying conceptual structure involving the color red, boats, and lakes.

这种思考常识性知识的方式有一个很好的优势，那就是可以与过去的经验建立直接联系。我们不是将某物视为“红色”，而是将其视为（在某种程度上）与之前感知到的可能有或没有标签的色调的集合相似。没有原型；只有一堆未分化的感知范例。（这可能会对构建执行低级感知学习并仍然表现出常识的人工智能系统产生重要影响。）

This way of thinking about commonsense knowledge has the nice advantage of making a direct connection to past experiences. Instead of thinking of something as being “red,” we think of it as being similar (in some way) to a collection of previously perceived hues that may or may not have a label. No prototypes; only a raft of undifferentiated perceptual exemplars. (This could have important ramifications in building AI systems that perform low-level perceptual learning and still exhibit common sense.)

但是，挑战本身是否正确？毫无疑问，我们拥有我们从未期望能够用语言表达的知识：如何骑自行车；吉米在哪些方面看起来像他的堂兄萨米？酸橙的味道不同于柠檬。但是，当我们确实设法将事情用语言表达出来时，例如 (1)，我们是否只是在自欺欺人地认为我们就是这样想的呢？

Is the challenge itself correct, though? It is no doubt true that we have knowledge we never expect to be able to put into words: how to ride a bicycle; in what way Jimmy looks like his cousin Sammy; the taste of lime as distinct from lemon. But when we do manage to put things into words, such as (1), are we just fooling ourselves in thinking this is how we think about it?

正如我们在这里试图争论的那样，我们的观点是，概念结构确实不仅仅是一种谈论世界的方式。它直接关系到智能代理在决定做什么时使用什么。

As we have tried to argue here, our view is that a conceptual structure is indeed much more than a way of talking about the world. It has a direct bearing on what an intelligent agent uses in deciding what to do.

回到本章开头的例子：棒球。我们真的要声称双重比赛只是谈论棒球的一种方式，而不是一种思考方式吗？当一个游击手决定把球扔到二垒而不是一垒时，这个决定中是否没有涉及棒球概念，比如局内有多少人出局，而只是人们跑来跑去的过去经验的集合，扔球和挥棒？同样，当我们决定说“生日快乐！” 对于房间里的一个特定孩子，但对其他孩子都没有，该决定是否没有涉及生日概念，而只是过去在一群戴着派对帽的活泼孩子中的经历？与史密斯所说的相反，这一切似乎都不太可能。

Go back to the example at the start of this chapter: baseball. Do we really want to claim that a double play is just a way of talking about baseball, not a way of thinking about it? When a shortstop makes a decision to throw the ball to second base rather than to first base, are there no baseball concepts involved in that decision, like how many are out in the inning, but only a collection of past experiences of people running around, throwing balls, and swinging bats? Similarly, when we decide to say “Happy Birthday!” to one particular child in the room yet to none of the others, are there no birthday concepts involved in that decision, but only past experiences of being among groups of animated children wearing party hats? This all seems highly unlikely, contrary to what Smith says.

并不是要贬低感性学习在棒球之类的比赛中的重要性，而是要了解游击手最终将球投向一垒，而在绝大多数情况下，这种学习既不存在也不存在。重要的是以这种或那种方式行事的原因，在我们看来，这些都涉及棒球概念。在棒球比赛中，有一些重要的考虑因素，例如球员应该知道并考虑到多少出局，但不是由比赛的直接感知场决定或无法从中恢复。AI 科学家 Rodney Brooks 的反表征格言，“世界是它自己最好的模型”（粗略地说，“如果你需要找到一些东西，看看世界本身，而不是它的模型”），可能至少对于像这样的活动是合理的足球和围棋（或至少其中的一部分），但显然不是棒球，也不是生日聚会，我们认为，我们发现自己所处的许多常识性情况也不是。

Not to minimize the importance of perceptual learning in a game like baseball, but learning that a shortstop ends up throwing to first base the vast majority of the time is neither here nor there. What matters are the reasons to act one way or another, and these, it seems to us, involve baseball concepts. In baseball, there are some crucial considerations such as how many are out that players are expected to know and take into account, but are not determined by or recoverable from the immediate perceptual field of play. AI scientist Rodney Brooks’s antirepresentation maxim, “the world is its own best model” (roughly, “if you need to find out something, look to the world itself, not to models of it”), may be at least plausible for activities like soccer and Go (or for some part of them, anyway), but clearly not for baseball, nor for birthday parties, nor, we submit, for many of the commonsense situations we find ourselves in.

最后，最好将挑战视为一个经验问题。史密斯认为，符号人工智能未能产生智能行为的系统，部分原因是它们被束缚于对世界过于简单化的分解——即分解为可命名的事物和属性。我们的感觉不同：他们之所以失败，是因为他们没有给予常识性知识和常识性推理应有的应有。时间会证明一切。

In the end, the challenge might best be thought of as an empirical issue. Smith feels that symbolic AI failed to produce systems that behaved intelligently in part because they were shackled to an overly simplistic breakdown of the world—that is, into nameable things and properties. Our sense is different: they failed because they did not give commonsense knowledge and commonsense reasoning their proper due. Time will tell.

7

7

表示与推理，第一部分

Representation and Reasoning, Part I

所有知识都与所有其他知识相关联。

All knowledge is connected to all other knowledge.

乐趣在于建立联系。

The fun is in making the connections.

——亚瑟·奥夫德海德，引自凯文·克拉吉克的《木乃伊医生》

—Arthur Aufderheide, quoted in “The Mummy Doctor,” by Kevin Krajick

在上两章详细阐述了常识性知识的概念之后，现在是时候看看将这些知识实际应用到机器中可能意味着什么了。这开始了我们从用非正式英语术语讨论知识到如何在机器中捕获和处理这些知识的转变。（我们不会试图涵盖前面章节中提出的所有内容，而只会涵盖一些主要思想。）

Having spent the last two chapters elaborating on the idea of commonsense knowledge, it is time to look at what it might mean to actually put such knowledge to use in a machine. This begins our transition from discussing knowledge in informal English terms to how that knowledge can be captured in a machine and processed. (We are not going to try to cover everything raised in previous chapters, but only some of the main ideas.)

如前所述，KR 假设意味着我们需要在接下来的两章中讲述的故事将是一个象征性的故事：代理将以符号形式表示其一些常识性知识，然后对这些符号结构执行计算操作以达到相关目的它可能需要采取的行动。在本章中，我们将概述常识性知识如何在我们称为模型的连接符号结构中表示，以及对这些模型的一些基本处理。在下一章中，我们将讨论如何以符号形式表示命题以及如何以更复杂的方式使用模型进行推理。

As already noted, the KR hypothesis implies that the story we need to tell in the next two chapters will be a symbolic one: an agent will represent some of its commonsense knowledge in symbolic form and then perform computational operations over those symbolic structures for purposes related to the actions it might need to take. In this chapter, we sketch how commonsense knowledge might be represented in connected symbolic structures we call models and some of the basic processing over those models. In the next chapter, we discuss how to represent propositions in symbolic form and how to reason with models in a more complex way.

在本章和下一章中，我们将根据我们在这一研究领域的经验，提出各种可用于常识表示和推理的符号结构。但是有很多方法可以做到这一点，其他人工智能研究人员已经使用了完全不同的符号表示和推理形式。对于本书，我们使符号结构看起来很像英语表达，以便于阅读，但值得记住的是，它们是仍然是供机器使用的符号。重要的不是我们人类阅读和解释它们的难易程度，而是机器将能够用它们做什么。

In this chapter and the next, we will be proposing a variety of symbolic structures that can be used for commonsense representation and reasoning, based on our own experience in this area of research. But there are many ways of doing this, and other AI researchers have worked with quite different forms of symbolic representation and reasoning. For this book, we have made the symbolic structures look a lot like English expressions to make them somewhat easier to read, yet it is worth remembering that they are nonetheless symbols intended for machine consumption. What matters is not really how easily we humans can read and interpret them but rather what machines will be able to do with them.

为了理解常识如何建立在符号和符号处理的基础上，有必要剥开熟悉的常识外壳，仔细观察下面机器的工作原理。我们认为这是通向常识之路的关键路段，但它也是一条要求更高的路段：主题更枯燥、更不直观，而且诚然，更不符合常识。一旦我们读到第 9 章，这条路会再次变得更容易，因为我们会看到我们已经研究过的符号机制可以在哪些地方用于做出更熟悉的关于如何行为的常识性决定。

In trying to understand how common sense can be built on a foundation of symbols and symbol processing, it will be necessary to peel back the familiar outer shell of common sense and look closely at the workings of the machinery underneath. We believe this to be a critical stretch of the road to common sense, but it is also a more demanding one: the topics are drier, less intuitive, and, admittedly, less commonsensical. Once we make it to chapter 9, the road will be easier going again, as we see where the symbolic machinery we have examined can be put to use in making more familiar commonsense decisions about how to behave.

世界模特

World Models

在考虑如何表示常识性知识时，将需要表示的内容分成两个不同的领域是很有用的。正如上一章所建议的，需要考虑两种不同类型的知识：

In considering how to represent commonsense knowledge, it is useful to separate what needs to be represented into two distinct realms. As suggested in the previous chapter, two different types of knowledge need to be accounted for:

  • • 世界上个别事物的知识（如“John”和“Boston”）及其属性，它们构成了世界状态；
  • • knowledge of individual things in the world (like “John” and “Boston”) and their properties, which make up a state of the world;
  • • 概念结构中概念的知识（如“医院”和“生日聚会”），这些概念是关于事物可能存在的种类和它们可能具有的属性种类的一般概念。
  • • knowledge of the concepts in a conceptual structure (like “hospital” and “birthday party”), which are general ideas about the kinds of things there can be and the kinds of properties they can have.

相应地，常识知识的表示将分为两部分：表示世界状态的世界模型和表示概念结构的概念模型——可用于对世界中的项目进行分类的概括框架。

Correspondingly, a representation of commonsense knowledge will have two parts: a world model to represent a state of the world, and a conceptual model to represent a conceptual structure—a framework of generalizations that can be used to classify items in the world.

用最简单的术语来说，世界模型是一种符号结构，旨在以直接方式反映所考虑的某些世界状态的片段。因为我们正在想象一个由具有属性的事物组成的世界，所以世界模型将由代表这些事物的符号和代表这些事物属性的符号组成，所有符号都以某种方式连接在一起。

In the simplest possible terms, a world model is a symbolic structure intended to reflect in a direct way a fragment of some world state under consideration. Because we are imagining a world made up of things with properties, the world model will be made up of symbols standing for those things and symbols standing for properties of those things, all connected in a certain way.

举个例子很容易看出这一点。假设我们正在考虑一个有两个人的世界，John 和 Sue，其中 Sue 是 John 的生母。这个世界的代表将是一个代表约翰的符号——我们John现在将使用——和一个代表约翰的符号苏——我们将使用Sue. （一般来说，我们会用它this font来表示世界或概念模型中的符号。）接下来，我们需要一个符号来代表一个人的概念person——以及一个代表生母关系的符号birthMother——在 John 和 Sue 之间的关系. 最后，我们需要一种方法来对这些符号进行分组以表示它们之间的联系。最简单的此类分组是符号序列：

This is easily seen with an example. Suppose we are considering a world with two people, John and Sue, where Sue is John’s birth mother. A representation of this world would be one where there would be a symbol standing for John—we’ll use John for now—and a symbol standing for Sue—we’ll use Sue. (In general, we’ll use this font to show symbols in a world or conceptual model.) Next, we will need a symbol representing the concept of a person—person—and a symbol representing the birth mother relationship—birthMother—that holds between John and Sue. Finally, we need a way of grouping these symbols to represent the connections among them. The simplest such grouping is as a sequence of symbols:

John is a person.

John is a person.

Sue is a person.

Sue is a person.

John has Sue as a birthMother.

John has Sue as a birthMother.

这就是世界模型的全部内容：它是与这三个句子具有相同形式的表达式的集合。内容符号—— the John, Sue, person, and birthMother——会随着句子的不同而变化；其他符号—— is、a（或an）、has和as——将始终相同。事实上，我们本可以将它们排除在外并使用更像

This is really all there is to a world model: it is a collection of expressions of the same form as these three sentences. The content symbols—the John, Sue, person, and birthMother—will change from sentence to sentence; the other symbols—the is, a (or an), has, and as—will always be the same. In fact, we could have left those out and used something more like

(John person)

(John person)

(Sue person)

(Sue person)

(John Sue birthMother)

(John Sue birthMother)

达到类似的效果，但符号结构对人们来说更难阅读。（为了进一步帮助阅读，我们将个别事物的名称大写，同时让属性名称以小写字母开头。）

to similar effect, but the symbolic structures would have been harder for people to read. (To further help in the reading, we are capitalizing the names of individual things, while leaving the names of properties to start with lowercase letters.)

然而，在继续之前，有必要对上面的三个句子做一些修改。首先，我们最好不要直接在世界模型中使用像John和这样的名称，因为许多实体可以具有相同的名称。相反，我们将使用其中带有Sue特殊“ ”字符的编号符号来表示世界上的个别事物，并使用单独的属性将它们连接到标识字符串（在引号内）或数字。#所以对于 John 和 Sue，我们可能会有这样的事情：

Before moving on, however, it is worth making a few changes to the three sentences above. First, we are better off not using names like John and Sue directly in the world model, since many entities can have the same names. Instead we will use numbered symbols with a special “#” character in them to represent individual things in the world, with separate properties connecting them to identifying strings (within quotation marks) or numbers. So for John and Sue, we might have something like this:

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#16 is a person.

Person#16 is a person.

Person#16 has “Sue” as a firstName.

Person#16 has “Sue” as a firstName.

其次，与其直接将 John 表示为 Sue 作为他的母亲，我们可能想进一步分析这个属性，并说这个属性实际上源自一个涉及他们两人的潜在事件：John 出生的事件。除了间接代表关系在 John 和 Sue 之间，这使我们能够考虑事件本身的其他属性，例如发生的地点和时间。

Second, instead of directly representing John as having Sue as his mother, we might want to analyze this property further and say that the property actually derives from an underlying event involving both of them: the event of John’s birth. Besides indirectly representing the relationship between John and Sue, this allows us to consider additional properties of the event itself, such as where and when it took place.

使用这个想法，以下将替换birthMother上面的句子。首先，代表波士顿市City#18：

Using this idea, the following would replace the birthMother sentence above. First, a representation for the city of Boston, City#18:

City#18 is a city.

City#18 is a city.

City#18 has “Boston” as an englishName.

City#18 has “Boston” as an englishName.

接下来，表示波士顿某处的空间点SpacePt#25：

Next, a representation for a spatial point somewhere in Boston, SpacePt#25:

SpacePt#25 is a pointInSpace.

SpacePt#25 is a pointInSpace.

SpacePt#25 has City#18 as an enclosingCity.

SpacePt#25 has City#18 as an enclosingCity.

然后，1979 年某个时间点的表示TimePt#24：

Then, a representation for a time point in 1979, TimePt#24:

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

最后，对所讨论的特定事件的表示，Event#23约翰于 1979 年某个时候在波士顿的某个地方生下苏：

And finally, a representation for the specific event in question, Event#23, John’s birth to Sue somewhere in Boston sometime in 1979:

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 has Person#17 as a baby.

Event#23 has Person#17 as a baby.

Event#23 has Person#16 as a mother.

Event#23 has Person#16 as a mother.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

因此，与其将 John 表示为直接以 Sue 作为生母的事物，我们将他表示为（人类）出生事件的一部分，其中 Sue 是涉及的母亲。有了这些符号结构，我们就不再使用birthMother符号本身了。在下一章中，我们将看到如何重新引入该符号来表示派生属性：当存在具有正确属性的相关出生事件时，一个人将被视为另一个人的生母。（在更深层次的细节上，我们可能想进一步分析出生事件本身，一方面将其视为一系列复杂的子事件，其中包括护士和助产士等其他个人，另一方面，将其视为生殖过程的高潮，还有其他人参与，例如父亲，可能还有捐赠者和代理人。）

So rather than representing John as something that has Sue as a birth mother directly, we represent him as being part of a (human) birth event where Sue is the mother involved. With these symbolic structures, we no longer use the birthMother symbol itself. In the next chapter, we will see how to reintroduce that symbol to represent a derived property: a person will be considered to be a birth mother of another precisely when there is an associated birth event with the right properties. (At a deeper level of detail, we might want to further analyze the birth event itself, casting it, on the one hand, as a complex series of subevents with other individuals involved like nurses and midwives, and on the other hand, as the culmination of a reproductive process, with still other individuals involved such as the father, and possibly donors and surrogates.)

图 7.1 的第一项总结了世界模型的基本结构。（图中剩下的两项，概念模型和推导子句，后面会讲到。）

The basic structure of a world model is summarized in the first item of figure 7.1. (The remaining two items of the figure, the conceptual model and derivation clauses, will be discussed later.)

虽然在世界模型中使用像上面那样的短句足以进行后续计算，但随着模型变得越来越大，人类读者越来越难以洞察正在发生的事情。出于这个原因，世界模型通常显示为带有节点和边的图形，这样人们更容易查看和吸收，如图 7.2 所示。（为了给自己定位，请注意最左边的圆圈代表苏，最右边的圆圈代表波士顿。）

While using short sentences like those above in a world model is quite sufficient for the computations to follow, as the models get larger, it becomes increasingly difficult for a human reader to get insight into what is going on. For this reason, a world model is often displayed as a graph with nodes and edges that can be much easier for people to look at and absorb, as in figure 7.2. (To orient yourself, notice that the leftmost circle represents Sue and the rightmost one represents Boston.)

那么世界模型中的这些句子到底是什么意思呢？具有上述模型的计算系统会如何看待它的世界？我们还没有完全准备好回答这个问题，因为我们还没有讨论命题，而且正如已经指出的那样，命题是被相信的事物。下一章会详细回答这个问题，这里可以做一个粗略的总结。使用世界模型来表示世界状态的智能体认为，在该状态下，一定数量的事物存在，并具有一定数量的属性。（如前所述，代理人也可以使用世界模型来表示世界的反事实状态，例如过去或未来的状态、其他代理人相信的状态以及其他想象的状态。）像和这样的Person#17名字SpacePt#25只要将它们彼此区分开来，结果将无关紧要。person另一方面，诸如和之类的名称enclosingCity实际上指的是智能体概念模型的元素，智能体用来思考世界的类别，我们稍后会谈到。

So what do these sentences in a world model mean exactly? What would a computational system having a model like the one above believe about its world? We are not fully ready to answer that question since we have not yet discussed propositions, and as already noted, propositions are the things that are believed. The question will be answered in detail in the next chapter, but we can give a rough summary here. An agent using a world model to represent a state of the world believes that in that state, a certain number of things exist with a certain number of properties. (As discussed before, an agent can also use a world model to represent counterfactual states of the world, such as ones that are in the past or future, ones that other agents believe in, and other imagined ones.) The names like Person#17 and SpacePt#25 will turn out not to matter at all as long as they are kept distinct from each other. Names like person and enclosingCity, on the other hand, actually refer to elements of the agent’s conceptual model, the categories the agent uses to think about the world, which we will get to in a moment.

在世界模型上执行的推理操作是什么？主要的问题将在下一章讨论，因为它们也涉及命题。尽管如此，我们已经可以想象一些有趣的操作，它们不直接涉及命题，而是涉及个体之间的联系，如下所示：

And what are the reasoning operations to perform on a world model? The main ones will be discussed in the next chapter since they too involve propositions. Still, we can already imagine some interesting operations that do not involve propositions directly, but rather connections among individuals, as in the following:

约翰和苏有什么关系？

In what way is John connected to Sue?

他有一个出生事件，苏是母亲。

He has a birth event where Sue is the mother.

约翰以何种方式与芬威公园相连？

In what way is John connected to Fenway Park?

他出生在一个拥有芬威球场作为当地棒球场的城市。

He was born in a city that has Fenway Park as a local baseball stadium.

约翰与宾夕法尼亚有什么联系？

In what way is John connected to Pennsylvania?

他出生在宾夕法尼亚州首府哈里斯堡（“三哩岛”）附近发生重大核事故的那一年。

He was born in the year when there was a major nuclear accident near Harrisburg (“Three Mile Island”), which is the capital of Pennsylvania.

为了确定这些联系，我们可以想象一个计算操作 ，FIND-PATH它将代表世界上个人的两个符号作为其参数（即作为其输入参数）。例如，我们可能会调用FIND-PATH代表 John 和 Sue 的符号。FIND-PATH将使用世界模型来计算连接两者的路径。这样的路径将是代表关系和其他个人的一系列符号。（有关如何定义此操作的信息，请参阅本书的附录。）我们在这里对这个推理操作没有什么可说的，只是要注意类似的东西对于有时称为联想思维的东西很有用，例如寻找个人被其他人想到。

To determine these connections, we can imagine a computational operation, FIND-PATH, that would take as its arguments (that is, as its input parameters) two symbols representing individuals in the world. For example, we might invoke FIND-PATH with the symbols representing John and Sue. FIND-PATH would use the world model to compute a path connecting the two. Such a path would be a sequence of symbols representing relationships and other individuals. (See the appendix of the book for how this operation might be defined.) We will have nothing further to say about this reasoning operation here except to note that something like it would be useful for what is sometimes called associative thinking, such as finding individuals brought to mind by other individuals.

概念模型

Conceptual Models

现在让我们转向概念模型。我们可以把上一章的概念结构想象成一个世界。然而，这不是一个事物和属性的世界，就像在上一节中那样；这是一个世界想法：事物的一般概念，它们的组成部分，以及它们与其他想法的关系。这些可以用类似于世界模型——概念模型——的符号结构来表示。

Let us now turn to conceptual models. We can think of a conceptual structure from the previous chapter as something like a world. It’s not a world of things and properties, however, as in the previous section; it’s a world of ideas: general concepts of things, their parts, and their relationships with other ideas. These can be represented in a symbolic structure similar to a world model—a conceptual model.

出于我们的目的，我们可以将概念视为具有三种部分：角色、限制和注解。角色是与概念相关的属性和本质关系，限制是对与概念相关的角色的填充的约束，注释是关于如何解释概念的其他各个部分。（见图 7.1 的第二部分。）

For our purposes, we can think of concepts as having three kinds of parts: roles, restrictions, and annotations. Roles are the properties and essential relationships associated with the concept, restrictions are constraints on the fillers of the roles associated with the concept, and annotations concern how to interpret various other parts of the concept. (See the second part of figure 7.1.)

让我们看一些例子。考虑上一节中使用的出生事件和母亲关系的概念。概念模型可能包含以下内容：

Let us look at some examples. Consider the concept of a birth event and the mother relationship, as used in the previous section. A conceptual model might contain the following:

A birthEvent is a kind of thing.

A birthEvent is a kind of thing.

Having a mother is a property of a birthEvent.

Having a mother is a property of a birthEvent.

所以对于概念和角色，我们在概念模型中有像上面两句话这样的表达。这些句子中的内容符号是birthEvent, thing, 和mother; 所有其他符号都只是为了使可读的句子表达内容符号之间的基本联系。person和 等其他概念city以及baby和 等其他角色enclosingYear将以类似方式处理。（从现在开始，为了措辞方便，我们有时会使用代表概念的符号来指代概念本身。所以当我们说“其他概念，如和”时，我们真正的意思是“person其他city概念就像符号person和符号所代表的那样city。”）

So for concepts and roles, we have expressions in the conceptual model like the two sentences above. The content symbols in these sentences are birthEvent, thing, and mother; all the other symbols are just there to make readable sentences expressing the essential connections among the content symbols. Other concepts like person and city, and other roles like baby and enclosingYear, would be handled in an analogous way. (From now on, for ease of wording, we will sometimes use a symbol representing a concept as a way of referring to the concept itself. So when we say, “Other concepts like person and city,” what we really mean is, “Other concepts like the ones represented by the symbol person and the symbol city.”)

现在让我们谈谈限制。值限制用于限制可以作为角色填充物的事物的种类。这是一个例子：

Let us now turn to restrictions. A value restriction is used to constrain the kind of things that can be fillers of a role. Here is an illustration:

vr#26: A mother of a birthEvent is a woman.

vr#26: A mother of a birthEvent is a woman.

在这种情况下，我们使用符号来表示对概念角色vr#26所期望的填充物种类的限制。（正如概念和角色有名称一样，限制也有名称，以便后面的注释可以直接引用它们。）这里的内容符号是, , , 和。motherbirthEventvr#26motherbirthEventwoman

In this case, we use the symbol vr#26 to represent the restriction on the kind of filler expected for the mother role for the birthEvent concept. (Just as concepts and roles have names, the restrictions have names so that later annotations can refer to them directly.) The content symbols here are vr#26, mother, birthEvent, and woman.

数量限制类似于值限制，用于限制可以作为角色填充物的事物的数量。这是一个例子：

A number restriction is similar to a value restriction and is used to constrain the number of things that can be fillers of a role. Here is an example:

nr#28: A birthEvent has 1 associated mother.

nr#28: A birthEvent has 1 associated mother.

本例中的符号用于表示对概念角色nr#28预期的填充数的限制。内容符号为、、和数字。（如果数字更大，我们希望将符号复数化以提高可读性。）请注意，与概念相关联的角色数量与填充符数量不同；像父母角色这样的单一角色可能有两个填充物，相反，一家公司可能有首席执行官和总裁，但这两个角色可能由同一个人担任。motherbirthEventnr#28motherbirthEvent1mother

The symbol nr#28 in this case is used to represent the restriction on the number of fillers expected for the mother role for the birthEvent concept. The content symbols are nr#28, mother, birthEvent, and the numeral 1. (Had the number been larger, we would have wanted to pluralize the mother symbol for readability.) Note that the number of roles that are associated with a concept is not the same as the number of fillers; a single role like the parent role might have two fillers, and conversely, a company might have a CEO and president, but those two roles might be filled by the same person.

概念模型（或它们的某些部分）通常以类似于世界模型的图形形式显示，如图 7.3 所示。请注意，此图中的链接现在涉及值限制：对于概念birthEvent，mother角色被限制为woman；对于pointInSpace， theenclosingCity被限制为 a city。（下一节将讨论woman和之间的广泛联系。）person

Conceptual models (or some parts of them anyway) are often displayed in a graphical form analogous to that for world models, as seen in figure 7.3. Note that the links in this diagram now involve value restrictions: for the concept birthEvent, the mother role is restricted to be a woman; and for pointInSpace, the enclosingCity is restricted to be a city. (The broad link between woman and person will be discussed in the next section.)

在深入探讨概念模型的其他方面之前，让我们简要回顾一下它们是如何与世界模型联系起来的。我们看到世界上的事物可以具有涉及其他事物的属性。例如，在上一节中，我们有

Before diving into other aspects of conceptual models, let us briefly review how they are connected to world models. We saw that things in the world could have properties involving other things. For instance, in the previous section, we had

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 has Person#16 as a mother.

Event#23 has Person#16 as a mother.

这是一种表示特定出生事件的方式，其中苏是所涉及的母亲。世界模型的这个片段显然与上面概念模型的片段相关：

This was a way of representing a specific birth event where Sue was the mother involved. This fragment of the world model is clearly related to a fragment of the conceptual model above:

A birthEvent is a kind of thing.

A birthEvent is a kind of thing.

Having a mother is a property of a birthEvent.

Having a mother is a property of a birthEvent.

换句话说，Event#23苏是母亲的出生事件的想法取决于更普遍的观念，即出生事件是与母亲相关的事物。如果Event#23是棒球比赛而不是出生，我们不会期望在世界模型中看到这种母亲关系。此外，由于上述数量和价值限制，我们希望母亲（在本例中为 Sue）是一名女性，并且是该角色的唯一填充者。一般来说，世界模型中角色的填充者遵守概念模型中指定的限制。（但我们稍后会看到异常是如何发生的。）

In other words, the idea that Event#23 is a birth event where Sue is the mother is contingent on the more general notion that birth events are the kinds of things that have associated mothers. Had Event#23 been a baseball game instead of a birth, we would not have expected to see this mother relationship in the world model. Furthermore, because of the number and value restrictions above, we expect the mother (in this case, Sue) to be a woman and the sole filler of that role. In general, the fillers of roles in the world model respect the restrictions specified in the conceptual model. (But we will see later how exceptions can occur.)

除了上面看到的数量和价值限制之外，我们还可以想象与概念相关的其他种类的限制。这些将是角色的填充者可能期望共同满足的其他属性，可能使用下一章中提供的公式表示。

We can also imagine other sorts of restrictions associated with concepts beyond the number and value restrictions seen above. These would be other properties that the fillers of the roles might be expected to jointly satisfy, expressed perhaps using the formulas presented in the next chapter.

分类法

Taxonomies

除了具有角色和限制等部分之外，概念之间还可以直接相关。最重要的这种关系是一个概念是另一个概念的子概念，这意味着作为思想，前者包括后者。例如，我们可能有

In addition to having parts like roles and restrictions, concepts can be related directly to each other. The most important such relation is that of one concept being a subconcept of another, meaning that as ideas, the former includes the latter. For example, we might have

A person is a kind of mammal.

A person is a kind of mammal.

这表明一个人是一种哺乳动物，而不仅仅是一种东西。除了识别这两个概念之间的关系外，结果是世界上任何被识别为人的东西也可以被认为是哺乳动物。像这样以图形方式显示子概念/超概念关系会产生如图 7.4 所示的熟悉的分类图。woman图 7.3 中 和之间的广泛联系person就是这种关系的一个例子。

This declares a person to be a kind of mammal rather than just a thing. Besides identifying the relationship between the two concepts, the upshot is that anything in the world identified as a person can be thought of as a mammal too. Displaying subconcept/superconcept relationships like this graphically results in the familiar sort of taxonomic diagram shown in figure 7.4. The broad link in figure 7.3 between woman and person is an instance of this kind of relationship.

birthEvent与上面文本中的示例相关，我们的概念模型可能包含以下内容：

Related to the birthEvent examples in the text above, our conceptual model might contain the following:

A birthEvent is a kind of liveMammalBirth.

A birthEvent is a kind of liveMammalBirth.

A birthEvent is a kind of medicalProcedure.

A birthEvent is a kind of medicalProcedure.

（这当然是针对那些由医务人员处理的出生。）然后，属于liveMammalBirth或medicalProcedure将被视为其中一部分的任何角色、限制和注释birthEvent也是如此。正如我们将在下一节中看到的那样，这些部分被认为是继承的——除非它们被显式注解取消。

(This is of course for those births that are handled by medical personnel.) Then, any roles, restrictions, and annotations that are part of liveMammalBirth or medicalProcedure would be considered to be parts of birthEvent as well. As we will see in the next section, these parts are said to be inherited—unless they are explicitly canceled with an annotation.

如前所述，将概念组织成子概念和超级概念的分类法是一种以模块化方式组织大量概念的有效方法。例如，涉及母亲、婴儿和其他事物的人类诞生的想法实际上是从更普遍的哺乳动物活产（与卵子出生相反）的概念中继承而来的。所以我们想象这个概念liveMammalBirth有母亲和婴儿的角色以及价值和数量限制。然后这个birthEvent概念将继承所有这个结构，只有两个本地限制，确保这两个角色的填充物是人而不仅仅是哺乳动物。（一个概念可以有或继承很多限制属于同一个角色。这些应该被理解为同时应用。）类似地，在第一部分的世界模型中使用的time和location角色birthEvent可能继承自更一般的事件概念。这个medicalProcedure概念也将继承这两个角色，因为它是一种事件，并且可能将位置限制在医院内——这样的限制birthEvent也会继承。

As already noted, organizing concepts into a taxonomy of subconcepts and superconcepts is a powerful way to organize a large collection of them in a modular way. For instance, the idea of a human birth involving a mother, baby, and other things is actually something inherited from the more general notion of a mammalian live birth (as opposed to births from eggs). So we imagine the concept liveMammalBirth having roles for the mother and baby as well as value and number restrictions. The birthEvent concept would then inherit all of this structure, with only two local restrictions of its own, ensuring that the fillers of these two roles are persons and not just mammals. (A concept can have or inherit many restrictions pertaining to the same role. These should be understood as all applying simultaneously.) Similarly, the time and location roles for birthEvent used in the world model of the first section might be inherited from the more general concept of an event. The medicalProcedure concept would also inherit these two roles since it is a kind of event, and perhaps restrict the location to be within a hospital—a restriction that birthEvent would then inherit as well.

继承与注销

Inheritance and Cancellation

虽然能够说一个概念是另一个概念的子概念通常是有用的，但如果我们不得不承诺相信前者的每个实例都必须具有后者的所有属性，那么这种效用将被严重削弱。举一个 AI 中的著名例子，我们可能会认为鸟类是通过飞行四处走动的动物，而企鹅也是鸟类，但我们不想被迫认为企鹅是通过飞行四处走动的。的确，总的来说，鸟类会飞，这当然是鸟类概念的一部分，但也有许多例外，包括企鹅、鸵鸟、猕猴桃等。鸟类也有相当标准的尺寸，但如前所述，蜂鸟和皇家信天翁的尺寸非常特别。

While it is generally useful to be able to say that one concept is a subconcept of another, this utility would be severely diminished if we had to commit to believing that every instance of the former had to have all the properties of the latter. To take a famous example in AI, we might think of birds as animals that get around by flying, and penguins as birds, but we do not want to be forced into thinking that penguins get around by flying. It is true that by and large, birds fly, and that is certainly part of the idea of a bird, yet there are many exceptions, including penguins, ostriches, kiwis, and others. Birds also have a fairly standard size, but as noted before, bee hummingbirds and royal albatrosses have sizes that are exceptional.

这表明，除了角色和限制之外，概念还可以具有之前讨论过的那种注释，以覆盖超概念中不适用的部分。概念模型中的注释将用类似于限制的句子表示。要查看示例，请首先考虑对baby概念角色的数量限制birthEvent：

What this suggests is that in addition to roles and restrictions, concepts can have annotations of the sort discussed before to override the parts of a superconcept that do not apply. Annotations within a conceptual model will be represented with sentences similar to those for restrictions. To see an example, first consider a number restriction on the baby role for the birthEvent concept:

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby.

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby.

这反映了在正常情况下，出生事件只会涉及一个婴儿的预期。由于情况并非总是如此，我们可能在概念模型中有以下内容来解释多胞胎：

This reflects the expectation that under normal circumstances, a birth event will involve only a single baby. Since this is not always the case, we might have the following in a conceptual model to account for multiple births:

A multipleBirth is a kind of birthEvent.

A multipleBirth is a kind of birthEvent.

ann#504: The restriction nr#29 is canceled for a multipleBirth.

ann#504: The restriction nr#29 is canceled for a multipleBirth.

第一句话说多胞胎（双胞胎、三胞胎等）是一种出生事件；第二个说多胞胎，有一个注解（ann#504）取消了对涉及婴儿数量的限制（nr#29）。注释中的实词是ann#504，nr#29, 和multipleBirth. multipleBirth(like )的子概念twinBirth然后可以自由添加自己的新数字限制。可以类似地覆盖值限制和概念的其他部分。

The first sentence says that a multiple birth (for twins, triplets, and so on) is a kind of birth event; the second one says that for a multiple birth, there is an annotation (ann#504) that cancels the restriction on the number of babies involved (nr#29). The content words in the annotation are ann#504, nr#29, and multipleBirth. Subconcepts of multipleBirth (like twinBirth) are then free to add new number restrictions of their own. Value restrictions and other parts of concepts can be overridden analogously.

有了取消的概念，我们现在可以具体说明一个概念以可废除的方式从另一个概念继承一部分意味着什么。我们想象一个GET-PARTS对概念模型中的符号结构进行操作的过程。GET-PARTS将表示概念的符号作为参数，并返回表示概念根据当前概念模型具有或继承的所有角色、限制和注释的符号作为值。这个想法是这样的：一个概念是另一个概念的子概念，如果存在一个（可能是空的）“is a”链接链从一个到另一个（例如，从到到到person，mammal等等animal）livingThing。然后GET-PARTS如果给定的概念是另一个与该部分直接关联的子概念（在概念模型中的数字限制语句内）并且没有继承该概念的注释，则将返回该部分（例如数字限制）取消那部分。当然，要继承此取消注释，它本身不能被未被第三个注释取消的第二个注释取消，依此类推。（具体细节见附件。）

With this notion of cancellation, we can now be specific about what it means for a concept to inherit a part from another concept and in a defeasible way. We imagine a procedure GET-PARTS that operates on the symbolic structures in a conceptual model. GET-PARTS takes as argument a symbol representing a concept, and returns as value the symbols representing all the roles, restrictions, and annotations that the concept has or inherits according to the current conceptual model. The idea is this: one concept is a subconcept of another if there is a (perhaps empty) chain of “is a” links from one to the other (for example, from person to mammal to animal to livingThing, and so on). Then GET-PARTS will return a part (such as a number restriction, say) if the given concept is a subconcept of another that is directly associated with the part (within a number restriction sentence in the conceptual model) and there is no annotation inherited for the concept that cancels that part. Of course, for this cancellation annotation to be inherited, it must itself not be canceled by a second annotation that is not canceled by a third, and so on. (See the appendix for the exact details.)

请注意，虽然我们还没有谈到命题，但我们已经可以看出运算GET-PARTS是推理的一种形式。它将使我们能够得出结论，例如，边境牧羊犬有四条腿，这是狗的一般特性。当我们到达分类法的底部时，概念将从它们所有的超级概念继承丰富的角色、限制和注释结构。此外，GET-PARTS即使在大型概念模型中，也可以很容易地计算操作。我们希望分类法是一种结构，其中每个概念仅在少数更一般的概念之下，即使在非常大的分类法中也可以搜索这些“是一个”链接。（如果这些链接本身可以取消，继承将复杂得多。请参阅下一节。）

Note that although we still have not talked about propositions, we can already see that the GET-PARTS operation is a form of reasoning. It will allow us to conclude, for example, that border collies have four legs from that property of dogs in general. By the time we get to the bottom of the taxonomy, concepts will inherit a rich structure of roles, restrictions, and annotations from all their superconcepts. Moreover, the GET-PARTS operation can be expected to be readily computed even in large conceptual models. We would expect a taxonomy to be a structure where each concept is below only a small number of more general concepts, making it quite feasible to search up these “is a” links even in extremely large taxonomies. (The inheritance would be considerably more complicated if these links could themselves be canceled. See the next section.)

默认值和其他注释

Defaults and Other Annotations

也许最有用的概念注释是角色的默认填充符。例如，考虑一个事件的一般概念的表示，其中可能包括它具有以秒为单位的持续时间的想法。（作为durationInSeconds已经讨论过，我们可能更喜欢将此持续时间更详细地表示为一个数量，该数量映射到不同度量单位的不同数字，但我们在这里采用简化视图。）我们可以通过添加注释为该角色指定默认填充符像这样：

Perhaps the most useful annotation for a concept is that of a default filler for a role. Consider, for example, a representation for the generic concept of an event, which might include the idea that it has a duration in seconds. (As already discussed, we might prefer a more elaborate representation of this duration as a quantity that maps to different numbers for different units of measure, but we are taking the simplified view here.) We can specify a default filler for this durationInSeconds role by adding an annotation like this:

ann#706: A durationInSeconds defaults to 1 for an event.

ann#706: A durationInSeconds defaults to 1 for an event.

这表示对于event概念，有一个注释 ( ann#706) 为角色提供默认填充符 1 durationInSeconds。实际上，它规定的是，如果我们正在寻找角色的填充物并且没有理由更喜欢任何其他值，我们可以使用默认值，理解它可能会被其他考虑因素所取代。因此，如果我们没有理由不相信，我们将假设事件的持续时间为一秒。

This says that for the event concept, there is an annotation (ann#706) that provides a default filler of 1 for the durationInSeconds role. What it stipulates, in effect, is that if we are looking for a filler for the role and have no reason to prefer any other value, we can use the default value, understanding that it may be dislodged by other considerations. So if we have no reason to believe otherwise, we will assume that the duration of an event is one second.

角色的默认值的概念是一个强大的想法，并且在如何使用表示方面产生巨大的差异。

The notion of a default value for a role is a powerful idea and makes an enormous difference in how the representations will be used.

这是一个应用程序。AI 文献中提出了取消子概念/超概念关系的想法，例如，允许penguin成为 的子概念bird，并且bird成为 的子概念flyingAnimal，而不需要penguin成为 的子概念flyingAnimal。如上所述，该提议导致继承定义相当复杂（与GET-PARTS附录中的定义相比），以至于确定一个属性是否被继承最终看起来更像是一个逻辑谜题。但这与我们认为常识性推理应该快速而简单的观点背道而驰。

Here is one application. The idea of canceling subconcept/superconcept relationships has been proposed in the AI literature to allow, for instance, penguin to be a subconcept of bird, and bird to be a subconcept of flyingAnimal, without requiring penguin to be a subconcept of flyingAnimal. As mentioned above, that proposal leads to considerable complications in the definition of inheritance (compared to the GET-PARTS defined in the appendix), so much so that determining if a property is inherited can end up looking more like a logical puzzle. But that flies in the face of our view that commonsense reasoning should be fast and easy.

使用默认值可以避免其中一些复杂情况。我们首先表示具有严格充分条件的类别，例如flyingAnimal不是要进一步专门化的概念，而是派生属性。（我们将在下一章中看到如何做到这一点。）换句话说，当某物是一种运动方式是飞行的动物时，它就被认为是飞行动物——不多也不少。然后，我们不说这bird是 的子概念flyingAnimal，而是说该bird概念具有Flying作为其默认运动模式的概念。然后，该penguin概念可以是birdas desired 的子概念，但可以使用另一个注释取消此默认设置。

Some of these complications can be avoided by using default values. We start by representing categories with strict sufficiency conditions like flyingAnimal not as concepts to be further specialized but rather as derived properties. (We will see how to do this in the next chapter.) In other words, something is considered to be a flying animal precisely when it is an animal whose mode of locomotion is flying—no more, no less. Then instead of saying that bird is a subconcept of flyingAnimal, we say that the bird concept has Flying as its default mode of locomotion. The penguin concept can then be a subconcept of bird as desired, but cancel this default with another annotation.

关于如何使用这些表示，还有最后一个难题需要考虑，那就是角色的重要性以及限制或注释的强度。

There is one final piece of the puzzle left to consider in how these representations will be used, and that is the idea of the importance of a role as well as the strength of a restriction or annotation.

如果我们要在世界模型中明确表示根据概念模型需要存在的一切，每个人都会有一个出生事件，每个出生事件都会涉及一位母亲——一个比婴儿年长的人。那个人又会有涉及母亲等的出生事件。这意味着一个拥有无限多人的世界模型！

If we were to explicitly represent in a world model everything that was required to exist according to the conceptual model, each person would have a birth event, and each birth event would involve a mother—a person older than the baby. That person would in turn have a birth event involving a mother and so on. This implies a world model with an infinite number of people!

但是当代表一个人时，我们可能会选择不明确代表他们的出生，即使我们知道必须有一个。在考虑这个人时，考虑出生可能重要也可能不重要。这种重要性由一个注释确定，该注释表明该角色（先验地）对所讨论的概念有多重要：

But when representing a person, we may choose not to represent explicitly their birth, even though we know there must be one. It may or may not be important to think about the birth when thinking about the person. This importance is determined by an annotation indicating how central the role is (a priori) to the concept in question:

ann#501: A birth has an importance of 0.6 for a person.

ann#501: A birth has an importance of 0.6 for a person.

将这些重要性数字取在 0.0 和 1.0 之间，我们可以认为注释ann#501是说一个人的出生是一个相当重要的 (0.6) 属性，但不要过分担心忽略它。所以并不是说苏没有出生；而是说苏没有出生。这是我们判断该事件不如模型中的其他事物重要。就这一点而言，我们没想到她的出生会成为下一章考虑的那种推理操作的主题。但是，随着我们注意力的变化，我们可能需要扩展模型并考虑她的出生​​；我们将在下一节讨论这个问题。

Taking these importance numbers to be between 0.0 and 1.0, we can think of annotation ann#501 as saying that the birth of a person is a fairly important (0.6) property, but not be overly concerned about ignoring it. So it’s not that Sue did not have a birth; it’s that we judged the event to be less important than other things in the model. To the point, we did not expect her birth to be the subject of the sort of reasoning operations considered in the next chapter. As our attention changes, though, we may need to extend the model and consider her birth; we discuss this in the next section.

限制或注释强度的概念是相似的。再考虑一下birthEvent。虽然我们希望允许多个婴儿出生，但看到多个生母分娩时，我们当然应该更加惊讶（或者更确切地说，震惊）。这表明对a 中填充物数量mother（上图）的限制比对填充物数量（上图）的限制要强得多。我们可以为此引入新的注释，但更容易假设限制和注释可以在句子中有一个额外的部分来指示（先验的）强度。所以上面的两个数字限制可以指定如下：nr#28birthEventbabynr#29

The idea of the strength of a restriction or annotation is similar. Consider birthEvent again. While we want to allow for a birth involving multiple babies, we should certainly be much more surprised (or rather, shocked) to see a birth involving multiple birth mothers. This suggests that the restriction on the number of mother fillers (nr#28 above) in a birthEvent is much stronger than the one on the number of baby fillers (nr#29 above). We could introduce new annotations for this, but it is easier to assume that restrictions and annotations can have an extra part in the sentence indicating an (a priori) strength. So the two number restrictions above might be specified as follows:

nr#28: A birthEvent has 1 associated mother (strength 1.0).

nr#28: A birthEvent has 1 associated mother (strength 1.0).

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby (strength 0.9).

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby (strength 0.9).

在这里，我们断然坚持 (1.0) 母亲的数量是给定的——即一个。但是我们对只有一个婴儿的信念并不那么坚定。类似地，事件的典型持续时间可能由类似

Here we are insisting categorically (1.0) that the number of mothers is as given—that is, one. But our belief about there being exactly one baby is not quite as strong. Similarly, the typical duration of an event might be specified by something like

ann#706: A durationInSeconds defaults to 1 for an event (strength 0.1).

ann#706: A durationInSeconds defaults to 1 for an event (strength 0.1).

这表示默认值非常松散；这是一个弱默认值。eventlike moviePerformanceor的子概念birthdayParty可以取消这个默认持续时间，并提出一个强度更高的不同默认值。

which says that the default is quite loosely attached; it’s a weak default. A subconcept of event like moviePerformance or birthdayParty can cancel this default duration, and propose a different default with a much higher strength.

顺便说一句，使用数量级数字来捕捉强度的广泛等级可能更有意义。对一胎只能生一个婴儿的限制强度可能是 2（比方说，几百个中只有一个，但只有一个生母），它可能更像是 11 个（几百个中只有一个，但没有一个）千亿），允许原则上仍然可以违反限制，例如碰巧是连体双胞胎的母亲。

Incidentally, it might make more sense to use order of magnitude numbers to capture wide gradations in the strengths. The strength of the restriction on there being one baby in a birth might be 2 (all but one birth in a few hundred, say), but on there being one birth mother, it might be more like 11 (all but one birth in a hundred billion), allowing that the restriction could still be violated in principle, such as for mothers who happen to be conjoined twins.

我们可以想象其他种类的注释。这里我们提三个。首先，我们可以使用注释来记录概念之间的相似性。例如，鲸鱼类似于鱼，货车类似于汽车，医院类似于教堂。类比提供了更多的例子：卢瑟福原子就像太阳系，争论就像战争，时间就像金钱。相似性注释会将概念连接到从概念的某些部分到另一个概念的某些部分的映射。除其他事项外，这对于进行之前（和下文）提到的那种鉴别诊断很有用。

We can imagine other varieties of annotations. Here we mention three. First, we might use annotations to record similarities among concepts. For instance, whales are similar to fish, wagons are similar to cars, and hospitals are similar to churches. Analogies offer additional examples: Rutherford atoms are like solar systems, arguments are like war, and time is like money. A similarity annotation would connect a concept to a mapping from some of the parts of the concept to some of the parts of another. Among other things, this would be useful in doing the sort of differential diagnosis mentioned before (and below).

其次，我们可能想要注释世界模型中个体的属性。在第一部分关于约翰出生的模型中，我们有

Second, we might want to annotate the properties of individuals in a world model. In the model about John’s birth in the first section, we had

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

在这里，Event#23代表他的出生，SpacePt#25代表他在波士顿的位置。我们可能想在注释中记录我们是如何相信事件发生在那里的。例如，如果这是默认分配，我们可以记录我们对这种默认使用的强烈感受。如果我们随后从这项任务中得出额外的结论，我们也会想要记录它们的来源。如果我们最终不得不重新考虑约翰的出生地，这些注释将发挥作用。

Here, Event#23 stood for his birth, and SpacePt#25 stood for a location in Boston. We might want to record in an annotation about how we came to believe that the event took place there. If this was a default assignment, say, we can record how strongly we feel about this use of the default. If we then draw additional conclusions from this assignment, we will want to record their sources as well. These annotations will have a role to play if we end up having to reconsider where John was born.

注释的第三种可能应用涉及元级概念和角色。我们可以这样对待概念模型中的数字限制句

A third possible application of annotations concerns metalevel concepts and roles. We can treat a number restriction sentence in a conceptual model like this

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby (strength 0.9).

nr#29: A birthEvent has 1 associated baby (strength 0.9).

就好像它是一组较小句子的缩写，如下所示：

as if it were an abbreviation for a collection of smaller sentences as follows:

birthEvent has nr#29 as a PART.

birthEvent has nr#29 as a PART.

nr#29 is a NUMBER-RESTRICTION.

nr#29 is a NUMBER-RESTRICTION.

nr#29 has baby as a SUBJECT.

nr#29 has baby as a SUBJECT.

nr#29 has 1.0 as an OBJECT.

nr#29 has 1.0 as an OBJECT.

nr#29 has 0.9 as a STRENGTH.

nr#29 has 0.9 as a STRENGTH.

概念模型中的其他句子，对于注解、概念、角色，都可以类推。这些扩展使概念模型看起来与世界模型完全一样，但在元层次上：个体由birthEvent、location和 等符号表示ann#706；NUMBER-RESTRICTION这些概念由和等符号表示ROLE；角色由 和PART等符号表示SUBJECT。birthEvent我们可能会借此机会用和之类的符号替换 和之location类的符号，就像我们对世界模型中代表个人的符号所做的那样，以考虑到不止一个想法可以具有相同的英文名称这一事实。Concept#19Role#58

The other sentences in conceptual models, for annotations, concepts, and roles, can all be expanded analogously. These expansions make a conceptual model look exactly like a world model, but at a metalevel: the individuals are represented by symbols like birthEvent, location, and ann#706; the concepts are represented by symbols like NUMBER-RESTRICTION and ROLE; and the roles are represented by symbols like PART and SUBJECT. We might take this opportunity to replace symbols like birthEvent and location with ones like Concept#19 and Role#58, as we did for the symbols representing individuals in world models, to allow for the fact that more than one idea can have the same English name.

图 7.5 将早期图 7.3 的一部分显示为元级别的世界模型。（为了弄清楚方位，请注意最左上角的个人代表概念person，最右上角的个体代表概念birthEvent。底部中心个体代表价值限制vr#26。）然后可以如上注释元水平个体。例如，OBJECT数字限制的角色可以具有默认值 1，STRENGTH注释的角色可以默认为 0.4。如果找不到其他值，则可以使用这些典型值，并且可以对它们本身进行进一步注释。

Figure 7.5 shows a portion of the earlier figure 7.3 as a world model at the metalevel. (To get one’s bearings, note that the upper-leftmost individual represents the concept person and the upper-rightmost individual represents the concept birthEvent. The bottom-center individual represents the value restriction vr#26.) The metalevel individuals could then be annotated as above. For example, the OBJECT role of a number restriction could have a default value of 1, and the STRENGTH role of an annotation could default to 0.4. These typical values could then be used if no others can be found, and could themselves be further annotated.

添加到世界模型

Adding to a World Model

如上所述，随着我们注意力的转移，我们可能需要扩展我们的世界模型以包含更多的事物和属性。例如，考虑到苏本身就是一个人，而不仅仅是约翰的母亲，我们会想看看我们期望在一个人身上看到的其他属性。为此，我们可以使用GET-PARTS上面提到的过程来找到概念的角色person。在这种情况下，birth角色（可能继承自mammal) 在这一点上可能被认为足够重要，以至于我们希望模型中有一个符号代表它的填充物，就像我们为 John 所做的那样。根据这个角色的一个值限制，filler应该是出生事件。所以模型中需要有一个新的出生事件来表示苏的出生。（可能已经有代表此事件的符号。见下文。）

As remarked above, as our attention shifts, we may need to extend our world model to include additional things and properties. Thinking about Sue as a person in her own right and not just as John’s mother, for example, we would want to look at other properties we expect to see in a person. To do so, we can use the GET-PARTS procedure mentioned above to find the roles for the person concept. In this case, the birth role (perhaps inherited from mammal) might be deemed important enough at this point that we would want a symbol in the model standing for its filler, just as we had for John. According to a value restriction on this role, the filler should be a birth event. So there needs to be a new birth event for the birth of Sue in the model. (It is possible that there is already a symbol standing for this event. See below.)

所以我们需要实例化这个birthEvent概念。我们查看了这个概念的所有角色（GET-PARTS再次通过），并决定哪些角色足够重要，可以代表他们的填充物。例如，我们看到该baby角色应该由一个人来担任。但是，我们也可能会发现，这个概念上有一个相关的限制person：一个人出生的婴儿应该是那个人。（这些类型的限制被称为角色链平等。）因此，新创建的出生事件将 Sue 作为角色的填充物baby。该birthEvent概念还有其他角色，如mother、time，location现在可能没有填补，以及其他更不重要的继承角色（例如持续时间）。

So we would need to instantiate the birthEvent concept. We look at all the roles for this concept (via GET-PARTS again), and decide which ones are important enough to have their fillers represented. We see, for instance, that the baby role should be filled by a person. We may also find, however, that there is a relevant restriction from the person concept: the baby of a birth of a person should be that person. (These sorts of restrictions are known as role-chain equalities.) So the newly minted birth event would have Sue as the filler of the baby role. The birthEvent concept has other roles like mother, time, and location that might be left unfilled for now, and other inherited roles (such as for duration) that are even less important.

迫使我们以这种方式扩展世界模型的条件是什么？最主要的是，出于某种原因，我们希望将注意力从我们之前考虑的事情上转移开。

What are the conditions that would compel us to engage in extending a world model in this way? The main thing is that for one reason or another, we want to shift our focus away from the things we were previously thinking about.

这可能是一种自下而上的推动力。也许我们在我们周围的环境中观察到一些新事物；也许我们被告知提到了一些新事物或属性。但也可能存在自上而下的推动力。也许我们决定执行某种感知动作，例如查看盒子以找出其中包含的新对象。也许我们需要考虑一些新的对象来实现一个感兴趣的目标；也许我们需要烤箱手套来拿起火锅或靴子才能在雪地里出门。

This could be a bottom-up impetus. Perhaps we observed something new in our immediate surroundings; perhaps we were told something that mentions some new things or properties. But there could also be a top-down impetus. Perhaps we decided to perform some sort of perceptual action like looking into a box to find out what new objects it contains. Perhaps we need to consider some new objects to achieve a goal of interest; maybe we need oven gloves to pick up a hot pot or boots to go outside in the snow.

无论出于何种原因，我们都被迫扩展世界模型以包含新事物和属性。我们希望推动力或多或少地具体说明应该包括哪些新事物和属性。如果我们被告知 Sue 的母亲是一个我们之前不认识的人，那么我们将扩展模型以包括她，以及一个新的出生事件，Sue 是婴儿，那个人是母亲。我们还可以包括注释，说明模型的详细说明是我们被告知的结果。

Whatever the reason, we are pushed toward extending the world model to include new things and properties. We would expect the impetus to be more or less specific about what new things and properties ought to be included. If we are told that Sue’s mother is a person whom we did not know about before, then we would extend the model to include her, and a new birth event with Sue as the baby and that person as the mother. We might also include annotations to the effect that this elaboration of the model was the result of something we were told.

但是，如果我们需要在没有其他信息的情况下考虑 John 的母亲和祖母，那么我们就没有太多的事情可以决定所涉及的人是否已经在模型中表示出来。一个合理的猜测是它们是新的，我们会相应地改变模型。类似地，如果一个角色具有足够高的重要性，我们想要代表它的填充物，即使不知道填充物是谁或什么。这是默认值的主要工作：它们是在没有其他信息可用时使用的值。然而，在所有这些情况下，我们都想说明这样一个事实，即正在做出的假设可能需要在以后进行更正。（见本章最后一节。）

But if we need to think about John’s mother and grandmother with no additional information, we would not have much to go on in deciding whether the people involved were already represented in the model. A reasonable guess would be that they are new, and we would change the model accordingly. Similarly, if a role has a high enough importance, we want to represent its filler, even with no definite idea about who or what that filler is. This is the primary job for defaults: they are values to use when no other information is available. In all such cases, however, we would want to annotate the fact that assumptions are being made that might need to be corrected later. (See the last section of this chapter.)

如果我们发现苏的出生城市是凤凰城，过程将大同小异。我们可能会像为 John 所做的那样，希望忽略新位置项的所有属性，而不是它所在的城市。

The process would be much the same if we were to find out that the birth city of Sue was Phoenix. We might expect to leave out all the properties for the new location item other than its enclosing city, as we did for John.

然而，如果我们不知何故得知苏的出生城市是菲尼克斯或图森，但又不知道是哪一个，情况就会复杂得多。我们可能会像上面那样选择使用两个城市之一（随机选择），也许带有一个注释说它是随机选择的，以防后来发现选择错误。或者我们可能更愿意将有关 Sue 出生城市的信息视为稍后要解决的谜题的某种线索，例如第 6 章谜题中 Gabby 的舞会日期。将世界模型表示简单地概括为为这种情况包括一个特殊的新符号，但这并不能真正解决问题。世界模型将不再像以前那样代表封闭的城市，而只是关于该城市的一些信息。无论采用何种符号，这些信息都难以推理。（这在奖励章节中有介绍。）

Yet a much more complex situation arises if we were to learn somehow that Sue’s birth city was either Phoenix or Tucson without finding out which. We might choose to use one of the two cities (chosen at random) as above, perhaps with an annotation saying that it was picked randomly, in case the choice was later found to be wrong. Or we might prefer to treat the information about Sue’s birth city as some sort of clue to a puzzle to be solved later, like Gabby’s date for the prom in the puzzle of chapter 6. It might be tempting to simply generalize the world model representation to include a special new notation for this case, but this does not really resolve the issue. The world model would no longer represent the enclosing city as it did before, but only some information about that city. That information is challenging to reason with, whatever notation is adopted. (This is taken up in the bonus chapter.)

更复杂的方法也是可能的。我们可能会问自己，我们对所讨论的两个给定城市了解多少？我们可以查看我们的概念模型，找到包含这两个城市的最具体的概念。例如，我们可能知道它们都是亚利桑那州的城市。然后我们可以扩展模型以记录封闭状态：enclosingCity我们将使用属性而不是像以前那样使用enclosingState属性。我们这样做会丢失信息——当我们得到两个几乎没有共同点的案例时，例如图森和廷巴克图，我们会丢失很多信息——但有一个明显的优势：我们可以向世界模型添加一些关于位置的相关信息无需解决逻辑难题或做出无根据的猜测。

A more sophisticated approach is also possible. We might ask ourselves, What do we know about the two given cities in question? We can look at our conceptual model and find the most specific concept that includes both cities. We might know, for instance, that they are both cities in the state of Arizona. We can then expand the model to record the enclosing state: instead of using an enclosingCity property as before, we would use an enclosingState property. We lose information in doing this—and a lot of information when we are given two cases that have little in common such as Tucson and Timbuktu—but there is a clear advantage: we get to add some relevant information about the location to the world model without having to solve a logic puzzle or make unwarranted guesses.

添加到概念模型

Adding to a Conceptual Model

我们现在已经引入了足够多的技术机制，可以想象在计算机中构建一个庞大的知识库，其中包含结构丰富的概念，这些概念描述了计算机在其世界中可能遇到的个别事物。在上一章中，我们关注了我们可能想要表示的事物和属性的种类。如果我们回顾我们对人类常识的观察，我们会被提醒，它主要是关于日常事物和事件，记住这些是为了支持快速得出合理的结论。当我们在世界上看到一些感觉是同一类事物的例子时，我们很快就会概括并开始简化我们记住这些事物的方式；我们倾向于形成一个新的概念来捕捉一些更显着的特性。

We’ve now introduced enough technical machinery to imagine building a sizable knowledge base in a computer with richly textured concepts that describe individual things that the computer might encounter in its world. In the previous chapter, we focused on the kinds of things and properties we might want to represent. If we go back to our observations about common sense in humans, we are reminded that it is largely about everyday things and events, remembered in order to support drawing quick, plausible conclusions. When we see a few examples in the world of what feels to be the same kind of thing, we are quick to generalize and start to simplify how we remember those things; we are inclined to form a new concept capturing some of the more salient properties.

想象一下我们第一次遇到汽车。我们可能会看到黑色的、白色的和银色的，然后是许多其他银色的。我们可能会看到一两辆敞篷车，但主要是轿车。当我们注意到它们的许多感知相似性时，我们很可能会自动想象一个新概念，它们都可以说是实例。由于我们观察到的例子的分布，我们可能倾向于建立我们的汽车概念来模仿银色四门轿车的常见情况。正如我们所知，有很多例外，但记住这一点的最简单方法可能就是有我们的汽车概念的颜色默认为银色，但强度较弱。所以看到一辆红色汽车不会引起任何惊愕（正如我们将在下一节中看到的那样），只是放弃了银色作为默认颜色。另一方面，通常我们对有四个轮子和挡风玻璃的汽车的默认值会更强，因为我们几乎从未见过轮子较少或没有挡风玻璃的汽车。

Imagine the first time we encounter cars. We might see a black one, white one, and silver one, and then many other silver ones. We might see a convertible or two, but mainly sedans. As we notice their many perceptual similarities, we are likely to automatically imagine a new concept of which they could all be said to be instances. As a result of the distribution of the examples we observe, we might be inclined to build our concept of a car to mimic the common case of a silver four-door sedan. As we know, there are many exceptions, but the easiest way to remember that might simply be to have the color of our car concept have silver as a default, though with weak strength. So seeing a red car doesn’t cause any consternation (as we will see in the next section), simply the abandonment of silver as the default color. On the other hand, generally our defaults of cars having four wheels and windshields will be much stronger, since we almost never see cars with fewer wheels or without windshields.

这种创造一个反映班级成员最常见特征的概念的想法不仅在构建新概念和记住新事物的容易性方面是有意义的，而且在人类记忆方面也被心理学家普遍观察到。我们记得特定的代表性范例或概念的构造原型，而不是我们遇到的类中每个成员的细节。正如在第 2 章中提到的，像弗雷德里克·巴特利特爵士这样的心理学家观察到，人类的大部分记忆似乎都是基于这样的原型和一种重建形式，而不是对所观察到的细节的精确记忆。除非他们观察到的人（或犯罪）有一些非常不寻常的方面，与我们通常非常通用的记忆原型不符，否则人们通常会成为糟糕的目击者。应该出现以及实际出现的方式。异常越不寻常，就越容易记住。

This notion of creating a concept that reflects the most common characteristics of members of a class not only makes sense in terms of the ease of constructing new concepts and remembering new things but has been commonly observed by psychologists about human memory too. We remember specific representative exemplars or perhaps constructed prototypes of a concept rather than the details about every member of a class we encounter. As mentioned in chapter 2, psychologists like Sir Frederic Bartlett observed that much of human memory appears to be based on such prototypes and a form of reconstruction as opposed to an exact memory of the details observed. People often make poor eyewitnesses unless the person (or crime) they observe has some remarkably unusual aspect that does not match our generally quite-generic remembered prototypes. Bartlett suggested that memory may work by remembering not photographic representations of individual things observed but instead generic versions of what is observed plus salient exceptions—differences between how the item we’ve observed ought to have appeared and how it actually appeared. The more unusual the exceptions, the easier they are to remember.

当涉及到我们对事件或程序序列的记忆时，我们会看到完全相同的现象。AI 中的经典插图涉及诸如去医生办公室、在餐厅用餐或生日聚会之类的事情。一旦遇到其中一些，我们就会构建概念，将普通案例捕获为涉及较小事件序列的脚本，参与者扮演各种通用角色。为了表示这些时间顺序的活动，我们需要比这里介绍的更多的设备，特别是用于表示时间顺序和事件影响的更复杂的机制。我们将在下一章中看到其中的一些内容。

We see exactly the same phenomenon when it comes to our memory for sequences of events or procedures. Classic illustrations in AI involve things like a visit to a doctor’s office, meal in a restaurant, or birthday party. Once we’ve encountered a few of these, we construct concepts that capture the ordinary cases as scripts involving sequences of smaller events, with participants playing various generic roles. In order to represent these temporally sequenced activities, we would need more apparatus than introduced here, particularly more elaborate mechanisms for representing sequencing in time and the effects of events. We’ll see some of that in the next chapter.

稍后我们将详细讨论当我们的原型期望未得到满足时可能发生的情况，但通常我们似乎相处得很好，想起了一般概念，包括我们几乎可以在我们之前谈到的那种自动驾驶仪上遵循的脚本. 这是一个很好的地方来记住我们从 Minsky 介绍的关于框架的内容上一章。上面所有的技术机制都是为了以一种可以指导对新情况的快速、近乎反射性的解释和下一步做什么的决定的方式来表示普通事物。

In a moment we’ll say more about what might happen when our prototypical expectations are not met, but generally we seem to get along quite well calling to mind general concepts including scripts that we can follow almost on the kind of autopilot we talked about earlier. Here is a good place to remember what we introduced from Minsky regarding frames in the previous chapter. All the technical machinery above is in order to represent ordinary things in a way that can guide a rapid, almost-reflexive interpretation of a new situation and a determination of what to do next.

世界模型中的和解

Reconciliation in a World Model

在本章的最后，我们简要说明了当出现问题时可能发生的情况。（回想一下我们之前的观察，当意外发生时，常识通常会发挥作用。）我们可以将本章和下一章中的计算操作视为纯粹的内向过程：我们的注意力仅集中在内部表示上并利用尽我们所能。可能使我们摆脱这种遐想的是意识到存在问题，例如我们想要合并到模型中的新信息与已经存在的信息冲突。

We conclude this chapter with a quick note on what might happen when things go wrong. (Recall our earlier observation about common sense regularly coming into play when something unexpected happens.) We can think of the computational operations in this chapter and the next as purely inward-looking processes: our attention is focused solely on internal representations and making use of them as best we can. What might snap us out of this reverie is the realization that there is a problem, such as that new information we want to incorporate in the model conflicts with something already there.

当然，人们所相信的主要矛盾预计会出现问题，并且可能永远无法完全解决。大人物经常处理对立思想之间的界限。例如，我们可能坚信需要保护言论自由，同样坚信需要禁止仇恨言论。但是，正如我们有时可能会判断某个流动的水体是一条河流，而有时又会判断它太小而不是一条河流（参见第 5 章关于朴素物理学的讨论），我们很可能会在两者之间的边界上出现不一致的情况。言论自由和仇恨言论。以令人满意的方式解决此类冲突是一生的工作，而不是这里的问题。

Of course, major contradictions in what is believed are expected to be problematic and may never be fully resolved. The big ones often deal with the boundaries between antagonistic ideas.
