For example, we may have strong beliefs about the need to protect free speech and equally strong beliefs about the need to prohibit hate speech. But just as we might judge a certain body of flowing water to be a river sometimes and too small to be a river at other times (see the discussion in chapter 5 on naive physics), we may well be inconsistent about cases on the boundary between free speech and hate speech. Sorting out conflicts like these in a satisfactory way is a lifetime job and not what is at issue here.

我们想到的是像这样更温和的矛盾：我们将要访问的医院的世界模型是默认情况下，比如说，有六层楼。然而，当我们接近相关建筑物时，我们发现它只有五层楼，这与模型相矛盾。或者这里是上面提到的另一个例子：我们被告知 Tweety 是一只鸟，并得出它通过飞行四处走动的结论，后来才知道 Tweety 实际上是一只企鹅，不会飞。我们希望像这样的违反预期的行为非常普遍，并且应该在没有任何重大中断的情况下在世界模型中得到调和。

What we have in mind are more modest contradictions like this: the world model we have of the hospital we are about to visit is that it will by default, say, have six floors. As we approach the building in question, however, we observe that it has only five floors, contradicting the model. Or here is another example mentioned above: we are told that Tweety is a bird and draw the conclusion that it gets around by flying, only to learn later that Tweety is in fact a penguin and cannot fly. We would expect violations of expectations like these to be quite common and something that should be reconciled in a world model without any major disruption.

在最简单的情况下，世界模型中的冲突值类似于松散的默认值。我们需要检查注释以查看作业的强度。只要没有附加结论是从默认值绘制的，我们可以移除默认值，适当地更改世界模型，并完成它。

In the easiest case, the conflicting value in the world model is something like a loosely held default value. We would need to examine annotations to see the strength of the assignment. As long as no additional conclusions were drawn from the default value, we can dislodge the default, change the world model appropriately, and be done with it.

然而，并不是所有的和解都这么容易。例如，如果我们进入一座我们认为是医院的建筑物，却发现一个天花板很高的大房间里聚集着一群人，显然在唱歌和祈祷，我们会想重新考虑我们在医院里的前提。这就是上面提到的相似性注释可能有用的地方，让我们看到我们可能正在处理更像教堂的东西。这可能涉及重新解释以前被理解为医院的一部分的事物，并将它们重新分配给教堂的相应部分。作为日常常识推理的一部分，所有这些似乎都是必不可少的。

Yet not all reconciliation will be quite this easy. For instance, if we enter a building we expect to be a hospital only to find a large high-ceilinged room where a crowd of people are gathered, apparently singing and praying, we will want to reconsider the premise that we are in a hospital. This is where the similarity annotations mentioned above might be useful, allowing us to see that we might be dealing with something more like a church. This can involve reinterpreting things that were previously understood as parts of a hospital and reassigning them to the corresponding parts of a church. All of this seems to be essential as part of everyday commonsense reasoning.

8个

8

表示和推理，第二部分

Representation and Reasoning, Part II

阅读只为头脑提供知识材料；正是思考使我们阅读的内容成为我们的内容。

Reading furnishes the mind only with materials of knowledge; it is thinking that makes what we read ours.

——John Locke，引自 Horace Mann 的“手册：警告和建议”，The Common School Journal

—John Locke, quoted in “Hand Book: Caution and Counsels,” The Common School Journal, by Horace Mann

在上一章中，我们将世界模型和概念模型视为常识知识的表示。但就常识实际需要的内容而言，代表性难题的很大一部分仍然缺失。

In the previous chapter, we looked at world models and conceptual models as representations of commonsense knowledge. But in terms of what is actually needed for common sense, a large piece of the representational puzzle is still missing.

要看到这一点，请想象一个具有常识的代理人正在考虑要做什么。例如，它可能认为某扇门是开着的，并且正在考虑是否要关闭它。请注意，为了能够沿着这些思路思考，代理必须能够接受门已关闭的想法，即使它实际上认为它是打开的。像开门或关门这样的想法就是我们在第 5 章中所说的命题。因此我们假设具有常识的代理人能够认为命题为真，而不必相信它们在当前状态下为真。

To see this, imagine an agent with common sense deliberating about what to do. It might believe that a certain door is open, for example, and be thinking about whether or not to close it. Notice that to be able to think along these lines, the agent has to be able to entertain the idea of the door being closed even though it actually believes it to be open. Ideas like that of a door being open or closed are what we called propositions in chapter 5. So we are presuming that an agent with common sense will be able to think about propositions being true without necessarily believing them to be true in the current state.

如果一个计算系统要能够以这种方式处理命题，它将需要它们的符号表示。它对世界的认识可能仍然体现在前一章的世界和概念模型中。用洛克的话来说，这些是知识的材料。但是它出于某种原因想要考虑的命题必须在不同于这些模型的第三个领域中表示。事实上，知识本身就是一个命题问题。代理人可能在世界模型中表示一扇门是开着的，但实际的信念它有将是一个命题：它相信门是开着的，等等。

If a computational system is going to be able to deal with propositions in this way, it will need a symbolic representation of them. Its knowledge of the world might still be represented in the world and conceptual models of the previous chapter. These are the materials of its knowledge, to use Locke’s phrase. But the propositions it will want to think about for one reason or another will have to be represented in a third realm distinct from these models. Indeed knowledge itself is a propositional concern. An agent might represent a door as being open in a world model, but the actual belief it has will be a proposition: it believes that the door is open, among other things.

在本章中，我们将讨论命题的符号表示，并展示认知代理如何将它们与其世界模型一起使用，以处理诸如“现在 P 是否为真？”、“如果我采取行动 P 是否为真”之类的问题A？”和“我可以采取什么行动使P为真？”——所有这些都是常识性思维的重要组成部分。

In this chapter, we will discuss symbolic representations of propositions and show how a cognitive agent can make use of them in concert with its world model to deal with questions like “Is P true now?,” “Would P be true if I took action A?,” and “What actions could I take to make P true?”—all of which are essential components of commonsense thinking.

命题的表示语言

A Representation Language for Propositions

为了用符号表示命题，我们将使用一种称为 L 的人工语言。从技术上讲，L 是所谓的一阶谓词演算（在第 4 章中提到）的类英语变体。与普通英语的主要区别在于它使用称为变量的特殊符号。因此，L 的表达式，称为合式公式（或简称公式），将类似于英语，除了有两种方式来指代个体：和以前一样，符号Person#17，如 ，我们以后将其称为常量，和符号:在其中写有一个特殊字符，例如Person:x，我们将其称为变量. （待会儿我们会看到变量的用法。）L的常量和变量一起称为单数项（或简称项），在英语中起名词短语的作用。

To represent propositions symbolically, we will use an artificial language called L. Technically, L is an English-like variant of what is called the first-order predicate calculus (mentioned in chapter 4). The main difference from ordinary English is that it uses special symbols called variables. So the expressions of L, called well-formed formulas (or formulas for short), will be English-like except that there will be two ways to refer to individuals: as before, symbols like Person#17, which we will henceforth call constants, and symbols written with a special : character in them like Person:x, which we will call variables. (We will see how variables are used in a moment.) The constants and variables of L together are called singular terms (or terms for short), and play the role of noun phrases in English.

在本节中，我们将详细介绍语言 L，然后说明公式的含义——即，哪些旨在表示真命题，哪些表示假命题。（从现在起，为了表述方便，我们将说 L 的公式为真，而不是说它是真命题的符号表示。）

In this section, we lay out the language L in detail and then say what the formulas are supposed to mean—that is, which ones are intended to represent true propositions and which ones represent false propositions. (From now on, for ease of wording, we will say that a formula of L is true instead of saying that it is a symbolic representation of a proposition that is true.)

让我们从公式的结构开始。L 的公式分为三种类型：原子公式、等式和复合公式。L 的原子公式只是出现在世界模型中的符号表达式，但除了常数之外还允许变量。例如，

Let us begin with the structure of formulas. There are three types of formulas of L: atomic formulas, equalities, and composite formulas. The atomic formulas of L are just the symbolic expressions that appear in world models, but allowing for variables in addition to constants. So for example,

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

是一个原子公式，但也是

is an atomic formula, but so is

Person:x has Event#23 as a birth.

Person:x has Event#23 as a birth.

L 的等式是由两个由单词“is”分隔的项组成的公式。例如，

The equalities of L are formulas consisting of two terms separated by the word “is.” So for instance,

Person:x is Person#16.

Person:x is Person#16.

是等式。

is an equality formula.

最后，L的复合公式是那些有其他公式作为部分的公式：通过在两个公式之间加上“和”一词来形成连词；通过在两个公式之间加上“或”一词来进行析取；通过在公式前面加上“it is not the case that”来表示否定；最后，通过在公式前面加上“有一个”、一个变量和“哪里”这个词来进行存在量化。下面是一个复合公式的示例：

Finally, the composite formulas of L are those that have other formulas as parts: a conjunction is made by putting the word “and” between two formulas; a disjunction is made by putting the word “or” between two formulas; a negation is made by putting the words “it is not the case that” in front of a formula; and finally, an existential quantification is made by putting the words “there is a,” a variable, and the word “where” in front of a formula. Here then is an example of a composite formula:

There is a Thing:x where

There is a Thing:x where

Thing:x is a person and

Thing:x is a person and

it is not the case that Thing:x is Person#16.

it is not the case that Thing:x is Person#16.

这是整个语言。图 8.1 总结了这些组件。L 中还有一些与处理数字和序列的世界模型无关的特殊用途的附加功能。这些在附录中有描述，稍后可以查阅。请注意，我们忽略了语言 L 在句法上有歧义的事实：具有多个“and”或“or”单词的公式可以用不同的方式进行分组。我们将在页面上使用缩进来消除歧义。

This is the entire language. The components are summarized in figure 8.1. There are also a few special-purpose extras in L that have nothing to do with world models for dealing with numbers and sequences. These are described in the appendix, which can be consulted later. Note that we are ignoring the fact that the language L is syntactically ambiguous: formulas with multiple “and” or “or” words can be grouped in different ways. We will use indentation on the page to disambiguate as necessary.

我们可以使用一些缩写来使公式更易于阅读。当我们有多个由“and”字词连接的公式时，我们将省略除最后一个“and”之外的所有公式，并使用逗号代替分隔符。类似地，当我们将一个“有”嵌套在另一个“有”中时，我们会将变量组合在一起，并用逗号和最后的“和”分隔它们。例如，

There are a few abbreviations we can use to make the formulas somewhat easier to read. When we have multiple formulas joined by “and” words, we will leave out all but the last “and” and use commas instead as separators. Similarly, when we have a “there is” nested inside another “there is,” we will group the variables together, and separate them with commas and a final “and.” So for example,

There is a Person:x and an Event:y where

There is a Person:x and an Event:y where

Person:x is a person,

Person:x is a person,

Event:y is a birthEvent, and

Event:y is a birthEvent, and

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

是的缩写

is an abbreviation for

There is a Person:x where

There is a Person:x where

there is an Event:y where

there is an Event:y where

Person:x is a person and

Person:x is a person and

Event:y is a birthEvent and

Event:y is a birthEvent and

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

这些缩写没有给语言增加任何实质内容，但它们确实使公式不那么冗长。

These abbreviations add nothing of any substance to the language, but they do make the formulas less wordy.

拥有像 L 这样的符号表示语言的全部意义在于考虑处理符号结构的计算。我们将从下一节开始介绍这些推理操作。但是让我们首先回顾一下公式的含义，从没有变量的公式开始。直觉上，这些公式应该根据世界模型理解为真或假。

The whole point of having a symbolic representation language like L is to consider computations that process the symbolic structures. We will get to those reasoning operations starting in the next section. But let us first go over what the formulas are supposed to mean, beginning with formulas with no variables. Intuitively, these formulas should be understood as true or false according to a world model.

没有变量的原子公式应该像以前一样阅读。与世界模型中完全相同的那些被认为是真实的；所有其他的都被认为是错误的。例如，对于上一章的世界模型，公式

Atomic formulas with no variables should be read as they were before. The ones that appear exactly as is in the world model are considered to be true; all the others are considered to be false. So for instance, for the world model from the previous chapter, the formula

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

被认为是真实的，但公式

is considered to be true, but the formula

Person#17 has “James” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “James” as a firstName.

被认为是假的。当两项是相同的常数时，没有变量的等式公式恰好为真。这意味着公式

is considered to be false. An equality formula with no variables is true exactly when the two terms are the same constant. This means that the formula

Thing#237 is Thing#238.

Thing#237 is Thing#238.

无论世界模型中有什么，都被认为是错误的。对于没有变量的复合公式，规则是通常的：当两个合取都为真时，“与”公式为真，当至少一个析取为真时，“或”公式为真，而“非”公式恰好在否定公式为假时为真。

is considered to be false no matter what there is in the world model. For composite formulas without variables, the rules are the usual: an “and” formula is true exactly when both conjuncts are true, an “or” formula is true exactly when at least one of the disjuncts is true, and a “not” formula is true exactly when the negated formula is false.

提及变量的“存在”公式的真实性稍微复杂一些。当存在一个常数时，它被认为是正确的，这样嵌入在“有”中的公式可以通过替换该常数所涉及的变量来实现。

The truth of a “there is” formula that mentions a variable is slightly more complex. It is considered to be true when there is a constant such that the formula embedded within the “there is” can be made true by replacing the variable involved by that constant.

比方说，我们有一个像上一章那样的世界模型，它只包含以下七项：

Suppose, say, we have a world model like the one in the previous chapter that contains just the following seven items:

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

那么根据这个模型，下面的公式成立：

Then the following formula is true according to this model:

There is a Person:x and an Event:y where

There is a Person:x and an Event:y where

Person:x has “John” as a firstName and

Person:x has “John” as a firstName and

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

Person:x has Event:y as a birth.

这是真的，因为我们可以用Person:x常量替换变量，用嵌入公式中的常量替换Person#17变量，最后得到Event:yEvent#23

This is true because we can replace the variable Person:x by the constant Person#17 and the variable Event:y by the constant Event#23 in the embedded formula, and end up with

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName and

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName and

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

这被认为是真实的。这个公式表示约翰有出生的命题，或者更确切地说，存在两件事，第一件事的名字是“约翰”，第二件事的名字是“约翰”。

which is considered to be true. This formula represents the proposition that John has a birth, or more literally, that there exist two things, where the first thing has “John” as its name and the second thing as its birth.

最后，我们要如何使用像这样的公式

Finally, what are we to make of a formula like

Person:x has “Harry” as a firstName.

Person:x has “Harry” as a firstName.

其中包含一个变量？这是一个既不正确也不错误的公式；它没有真值。它可以读作“它的名字是‘Harry’”——也就是说，作为一个带有代词的句子。只有当公式出现在“有”量词的范围内时，该公式才获得真值，例如

which contains a variable? This is a formula that is neither true nor false; it has no truth value. It can be read as something like “It has ‘Harry’ as a first name”—that is, as a sentence with a pronoun. The formula only gets a truth value when it appears within the scope of a “there is” quantifier such as

There is a Person:x where Person:x has “Harry” as a firstName.

There is a Person:x where Person:x has “Harry” as a firstName.

可以读作“有一个东西，它的名字是‘Harry’”，或者更确切地说，“某物的名字是‘Harry’”，根据上面的模型这是错误的（因为有没有替换变量Person:x以使嵌入的公式为真）。不在“有”量词范围内的变量称为自由变量，只有没有自由变量的L的公式才能得到真值。

which can be read as “There is a thing, and it has ‘Harry’ as a first name,” or better, “Something has ‘Harry’ as a first name,” which is false according to the model above (since there is no substitution for the Person:x variable to make the embedded formula true). A variable that is not within the scope of a “there is” quantifier is called a free variable, and only formulas of L without free variables are intended to get a truth value.

回答事实问题

Answering Factual Questions

现在我们准备谈谈推理。如开头所述，L 的公式的主要用途是表达推理代理可能出于某种目的而考虑的关于世界的问题。的答案问题将在世界模型中找到，但问题本身将表示为一个公式。L 中的问题是关于模型所代表的世界的，但它们不在世界模型中。

Now we are ready to talk about reasoning. As mentioned at the start, the primary use of the formulas of L is to express questions about the world that a reasoning agent might want to consider for some purpose. The answer to the question will be found in the world model, but the question itself will be represented as a formula. Questions in L are about the world that the model represents, but they are not in the world model.

总的来说，有两类事实问题需要考虑。wh -question（例如，“John where was born?”）期望答案是代表世界上某物的符号——在本例中是位置。是非问题（例如，“Sue 的孩子中有没有在多伦多出生的？”）需要二元答案。Wh 问题也可以有多个答案（例如，“谁是出生在波士顿的人？”），在这种情况下，答案将是一组有限的符号。关于有多少事物具有特定属性的问题（例如，“有多少养蜂人是化学家？”）也可以通过计算适当问题的答案数来回答。

Overall, there are two sorts of factual questions to consider. A wh-question (say, “Where was John born?”) expects an answer to be a symbol representing something in the world—in this case, a location. A yes-no question (say, “Were any of Sue’s children born in Toronto?”) expects a binary answer. Wh-questions can also have multiple answers (for instance, “Who are the people born in Boston?”), in which case the answer will be a finite set of symbols. Questions about how many things have a certain property (for example, “How many beekeepers are chemists?”) can also be answered by counting the number of answers to an appropriate wh-question.

我们可以用L的公式来表达这些问题。我们设想对公式进行两种操作：

We can use formulas of L to express these questions. We imagine two operations on formulas:

  • • 对于是-否问题，操作TEST将返回符号之一TRUE或，FALSE具体取决于给定的公式根据当前模型被认为是真还是假。
  • • For yes-no questions, the operation TEST will return one of the symbols TRUE or FALSE depending on whether the given formula is considered to be true or false according to the current model.
  • • 对于wh 问题，该运算FIND-ALL将返回所有常量组合，以便如果其自由变量被这些常量替换，则公式为真。
  • • For wh-questions, the operation FIND-ALL will return all combinations of constants such that the formula would be true if its free variables were replaced by those constants.

请注意，对于TEST操作，参数必须是没有自由变量的公式；否则它将没有真值。因此，例如，TEST将能够计算公式的真值

Note that for the TEST operation, the argument must be a formula with no free variables; otherwise it will not have a truth value. So for example, TEST will be able to compute the truth value of the formula

Person#17 has “Jim” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “Jim” as a firstName.

作为FALSE; 但是公式

as FALSE; but the formula

Person:x has “John” as a firstName.

Person:x has “John” as a firstName.

没有真值。FIND-ALL，另一方面，可以将第二个公式解释为 wh 问题“谁的名字是‘约翰’？” 并将答案计算为Person#17。

has no truth value. FIND-ALL, on the other hand, would be able to interpret this second formula as the wh-question “Who has ‘John’ as a first name?” and compute the answer as Person#17.

和运算的工作原理是将给定的公式分解成多个部分，然后在世界模型中寻找原子公式TEST。FIND-ALL因为语言 L 是递归构造的——公式可以作为其他公式的一部分出现——andTEST过程FIND-ALL同样是递归的。这两个过程的完整定义在附录中给出；确切的细节并不重要。

Both the TEST and FIND-ALL operations work by breaking apart the given formula into its pieces, and then looking for atomic formulas in the world model. Because the language L is constructed recursively—formulas can appear as parts of other formulas—the TEST and FIND-ALL procedures are similarly recursive. The full definitions of the two procedures are given in the appendix; the precise details are not important.

请注意，wh-questions 的答案可能不提供信息。例如，假设我们想知道约翰出生的时间。返回的唯一答案FIND-ALL是TimePt#24，根据上面的世界模型，它确实代表了约翰出生的正确时间点，但没有以任何方式识别它。在某些情况下，我们可能不需要标识——例如，我们可能只想检查两个返回的结果是否相同。但如果我们这样做，我们将希望后续的 wh-question 从一个符号出发TimePt#24到识别字符串或数字。对于某个时间点，我们可能需要年份和月份名称（可能还有更多详细信息）；对于一个人，我们可能需要名字和姓氏，或者电话号码或电子邮件地址，这取决于我们想要做什么。即使在后续操作需要索引标识的情况下（如前所述），我们仍然需要标识字符串和数字：从现在开始还有多少秒？从当前航向顺时针转多少个四分之一圈？正前方的牌子上写的是什么字？

Note that the answers to wh-questions may not be informative. For example, suppose we want to find out when John was born. The single answer returned by FIND-ALL would be TimePt#24, which indeed represents the correct time point for John’s birth according to the world model above, but does not identify it in any way. In some cases, we might not need an identification—for instance, we may just want to check if two returned results are the same. But if we do, we will want a follow-up wh-question to go from a symbol like TimePt#24 to an identifying string or number. For a time point, we might want the year and name of the month (and maybe more details); for a person, we might want a first and last name, or maybe a phone number or email address, depending on what we are trying to do. Even in cases where indexical identification is required for subsequent action (as discussed before), we will still want identifying strings of characters and numbers: How many seconds from now? How many quarter turns clockwise from the current heading? What string is written on the sign directly ahead?

还值得注意的是，TEST和FIND-ALL操作执行一种逻辑推理。（我们在额外章节中详细说明了细节。）然而，重要的是，这样做TEST比处理经典逻辑中的演绎规则集合要容易得多。我们正在使用数据库检索领域的想法，几乎没有逻辑机制。事实上，使用现成的数据库技术，应该可以在具有数十万个符号的巨大世界模型上运行这些推理操作。正是这些操作的计算易处理性使得这种简单的逻辑推理形式非常适合常识。

It is also worth noting that the TEST and FIND-ALL operations perform a kind of logical reasoning. (We spell out the details in the bonus chapter.) Importantly, however, what TEST does is much easier than dealing with a collection of deductive rules as in classical logic. We are using ideas from the field of database retrieval, with little in the way of logical machinery. In fact, using off-the-shelf database technology, it should be possible to run these reasoning operations on gigantic world models having hundreds of thousands of symbols. It is the computational tractability of these operations that makes this simple form of logical reasoning so well suited for common sense.

派生新属性

Deriving New Properties

仅仅因为我们正在使用世界模型来表示知识并不意味着 L 的公式只能用于问题。我们可以将世界模型视为代表世界上事物的基本属性，然后使用 L 的公式作为处理从中导出的附加属性的一种方式。

Just because we are using world models to represent knowledge does not mean that the formulas of L can only be used for questions. We can think of a world model as representing the basic properties of things in the world, and then use formulas of L as a way of dealing with additional properties to be derived from them.

这是想法。考虑上一章中介绍的关于约翰和苏的世界模型。我们可以看到名为 John 的人与一个出生事件相关联，然后该事件与某处的某个位置相关联波士顿。换句话说，我们将约翰描述为以波士顿为他的出生城市。然而，我们不能问一个简单的问题，例如“约翰的出生城市是哪里？” 因为出生城市不是模型中任何地方直接表达的属性。但是，使用 L 的公式，我们可以扩展我们的概念词汇表，将出生城市视为从其他更基本的城市派生而来的人的财产。

Here is the idea. Consider the world model about John and Sue presented in the previous chapter. We can see that the person named John is linked to a birth event, which is then linked to a location somewhere in Boston. In other words, we have represented John as having Boston as his birth city. And yet we cannot ask an easy question like “What is the birth city of John?” since the birth city is not a property expressed anywhere directly in the model. Using formulas of L, though, we can extend our conceptual vocabulary to treat a birth city as a property of people to be derived from other, more basic ones.

为此，我们设想除了世界和概念模型之外，知识库将包含称为推导子句（或简称子句）的符号表达式。（参见上一章图 7.1 的第三部分。）它们由三部分组成：使用一些变量的表达式、“when”一词和 L 的公式。 of the clause 是一个新公式，只要从句末尾的 L 公式为真，就认为该公式为真。扩展TEST（因此FIND-ALL）以允许收集此类派生子句是一件容易的事。（详情载于附件。）

To do this, we imagine that in addition to world and conceptual models, a knowledge base will contain symbolic expressions called derivation clauses (or clauses for short). (See the third part of figure 7.1 in the previous chapter.) These are made up of three parts: an expression that uses some variables, the word “when,” and a formula of L. The idea is that the expression at the start of the clause is a new formula that is considered to be true whenever the formula of L at the end of the clause is true. It is an easy matter to extend TEST (and therefore FIND-ALL) to allow for a collection of derivation clauses of this sort. (The details are in the appendix.)

为了实际看到这一点，我们可以想象将一个人的出生城市描述为该人出生地点的封闭城市：

To see this in action, we might imagine characterizing the birth city of a person as the enclosing city of the location where the person was born:

Person:x has City:c as a birthCity

Person:x has City:c as a birthCity

when

when

there is an Event:e and SpacePt:s where

there is an Event:e and SpacePt:s where

Person:x has Event:e as a birth,

Person:x has Event:e as a birth,

Event:e has SpacePt:s as a location, and

Event:e has SpacePt:s as a location, and

SpacePt:s has City:c as an enclosingCity.

SpacePt:s has City:c as an enclosingCity.

这定义了一个新的派生角色，将人与城市联系起来。如果空间中存在某个事件和点，则该birthCity关系成立，例如 (1) 事件是相关人员的出生，(2) 出生事件的位置是空间中的点，以及 (3) 封闭的空间中那个点的城市就是所讨论的城市。

This defines a new, derived role relating a person to a city. The birthCity relationship holds if there is some event and point in space, such that (1) the event is the birth of the person in question, (2) the location of the birth event is the point in space, and (3) the enclosing city of that point in space is the city in question.

有了这个推导子句，每当类似

With this derivation clause in place, whenever something like

Person:z has City#65 as a birthCity

Person:z has City#65 as a birthCity

出现在公式中，TEST将把它解释为好像使用了上面子句中嵌入的公式来代替。birthMother上一章中提到的属性将进行类似处理。

appears within a formula, TEST will interpret it as if the formula embedded in the clause above had been used instead. The birthMother property mentioned in the previous chapter would be handled analogously.

如果在推理操作之前不明显TEST，那么现在情况就更加明显了。例如，假设世界模型包括以下内容：

If it wasn’t obvious before that TEST was a reasoning operation, the case is much more evident now. For example, assume the world model includes the following:

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

Event#23 has SpacePt#25 as a location.

SpacePt#25 has City#18 as an enclosingCity.

SpacePt#25 has City#18 as an enclosingCity.

然后该TEST操作将得出结论

The TEST operation would then conclude that

Person#17 has City#18 as a birthCity.

Person#17 has City#18 as a birthCity.

也是如此。该操作汇集了四个人的一些基本属性，得出一个将约翰 ( Person#17) 与波士顿 ( City#18) 相关联的新结论，如图 8.2 所示。

is true as well. The operation assembles some basic properties about four individuals to derive a new conclusion relating John (Person#17) to Boston (City#18), as illustrated in figure 8.2.

如上所述使用派生子句允许我们引入具有任意数量参数的派生属性，而不仅仅是派生角色。例如，我们可能想将土生土长的多伦多人视为出生在多伦多的任何人：

The use of derivation clauses as above allows us to introduce derived properties with any number of arguments, not just derived roles. For example, we might want to think of a native Torontonian as any person born in Toronto:

Person:x is a nativeTorontonian

Person:x is a nativeTorontonian

when

when

there is a City:y where

there is a City:y where

Person:x has City:y as a birthCity and

Person:x has City:y as a birthCity and

City:y has “Toronto” as an englishName.

City:y has “Toronto” as an englishName.

请注意，这些推导子句涉及我们之前所说的充分条件。我们要说的是，拥有一个名为“多伦多”的出生城市就足以被视为土生土长的多伦多人。如果我们想要允许更丰富的 Torontonian 概念，我们将需要在我们的概念模型中为它​​添加一个概念和附加部分，如前一章所示。其他涉及充分条件的属性，例如flyingAnimal或quadruped将被类似地处理。（请参阅附录，了解如何将第 6 章末尾的狗品种插图作为派生属性进行处理。）

Note that these derivation clauses involve what we previously called sufficiency conditions. What we are saying is that it is sufficient to have a birth city with the name “Toronto” to be considered a native Torontonian. If we wanted to allow a richer notion of Torontonian, we would need a concept for it in our conceptual model with additional parts, as seen in the previous chapter. Other properties involving sufficiency conditions such as flyingAnimal or quadruped would be handled analogously. (See the appendix for how to handle the dog breed illustration from the end of chapter 6 as a derived property.)

如前一章所述，推导子句为我们提供了一种处理典型属性的好方法，而无需涉及可废止子概念和超概念关系的复杂性。想法是这样的：flyingAnimal只要所讨论的动物具有正确的运动属性，派生属性就会成立。如果默认情况下，个体鸟被实例化为Flying它们的运动模式，那么出于同样的原因，它们将被归类为具有此flyingAnimal属性。因此，默认情况下，鸟类最终会成为飞行动物，而不需要概念模型中 a 的一般概念bird与flyingAnimal属性之间的任何关系。

As mentioned in the previous chapter, derivation clauses give us a nice way to handle typical properties without the complications involving defeasible subconcept and superconcept relationships. Here’s the idea: the derived flyingAnimal property will hold whenever the animal in question has the right locomotion property. If by default, individual birds are instantiated with Flying as their mode of locomotion, then by the same token, they will be classified as having this flyingAnimal property. So birds end up being flying animals by default without requiring any relationship in the conceptual model between the general concept of a bird and the flyingAnimal property.

我们还可以推导出世界模型中看似无关的事物对的属性（例如石榴和洗衣篮）。考虑一个事物的体积比另一个事物大的特性。（为简单起见，我们不将某物的体积视为数量，而是将其视为某些未指定单位的数字，就像我们在上一章中对持续时间所做的那样。）该属性可能编码如下：

We can also derive properties about pairs of things that are seemingly unrelated in the world model (such as pomegranates and laundry baskets, say). Consider the property of one thing being larger in volume than another. (For simplicity, we treat the volume of something not as a quantity but rather as a number in some unspecified units, just like we did for duration in the previous chapter.) The property might be encoded as follows:

Thing:x1 is larger in volume than Thing:x2

Thing:x1 is larger in volume than Thing:x2

when

when

there is a Number:v1 and a Number:v2 where

there is a Number:v1 and a Number:v2 where

Thing:x1 has Number:v1 as a volume,

Thing:x1 has Number:v1 as a volume,

Thing:x2 has Number:v2 as a volume, and

Thing:x2 has Number:v2 as a volume, and

Number:v1 > Number:v2.

Number:v1 > Number:v2.

here>是 L 中表示数字的特殊符号，具有其通常的算术解释。因此，例如，如果TEST操作可以确定

The > here is a special symbol in L for numbers and has its usual arithmetic interpretation. So for example, if the TEST operation can determine that

Thing#656 has 3 as a volume.

Thing#656 has 3 as a volume.

Thing#474 has 7 as a volume.

Thing#474 has 7 as a volume.

都是真的（也许使用其他派生属性），然后它就能够派生出

are both true (perhaps using other derived properties), it would then be able to derive that

Thing#474 is larger in volume than Thing#656.

Thing#474 is larger in volume than Thing#656.

也是真的。可以以类似的方式使用算术来表征具有一定程度的属性（例如富有或喜欢某事）。使用这些想法，我们还可以拥有涉及两个以上事物的属性——一些根本无法在世界模型中表示的事物，例如约翰可能拥有的属性，即年龄与比尔比与苏更接近。

is true too. Properties that hold to a degree (like being rich or fond of something) can be characterized using arithmetic in a similar way. Using these ideas, we can also have properties that involve more than two things—something that cannot be represented in a world model at all, such as the property that John might have of being closer in age to Bill than to Sue.

作为最后的考虑，我们可以允许递归定义的属性。例如，想象一下，我们已经拥有作为父母的（基本或派生的）属性。然后我们可以有这个推导子句：

As a final consideration, we can allow for properties that are recursively defined. Imagine, for instance, that we already have a (basic or derived) property of being a parent. Then we can have this derivation clause:

Person:x has Person:y as an ancestor

Person:x has Person:y as an ancestor

when

when

there is a Person:p where

there is a Person:p where

Person:x has Person:p as a parent and

Person:x has Person:p as a parent and

Person:p is Person:y or Person:p has Person:y as an ancestor.

Person:p is Person:y or Person:p has Person:y as an ancestor.

换句话说，如果第一个人的父母是第二个人或（递归地）以第二个人为祖先，那么一个人就有第二个人的祖先。（在它自己的定义中使用一个项目是使它递归的原因。）然后，如果世界模型中两个个体之间存在父关系链，将正确地得出TEST一个是另一个的祖先的结论。（奖励章节中讨论了一些注意事项。）

In other words, one person has a second as an ancestor if the first person has a parent who either is the second person or (recursively) has the second person as an ancestor. (Using an item within its own definition is what makes this recursive.) Then, if there is a chain of parent relationships between two individuals in a world model, TEST will correctly conclude that one is an ancestor of the other. (There are some caveats discussed in the bonus chapter.)

模拟变化

Simulating Change

使用 L 的公式来表征可导出的属性的想法表明了一种处理变化的自然方式——或者至少是简单形式的变化。回想一下第 5 章，不仅我们的常识世界由具有属性的事物组成，而且这些属性也被假定为随着世界中发生的事件而改变。（事件也可能导致事物开始或停止存在，但我们在这里搁置了这部分故事。）

The idea of using formulas of L to characterize properties that can be derived suggests a natural way of dealing with change—or at least simple forms of change. Recall from chapter 5 that not only is our commonsense world made up of things with properties but these properties also are assumed to change over time as a result of events that occur in the world. (Events can cause things to start or stop existing as well, but we put aside that part of the story here.)

让我们再次考虑门。我们可能期望一个世界模型将门表示为处于某种状态，打开或关闭，也许使用这样的东西：

Let us consider doors again. We might expect a world model to represent a door as being in a certain state, open or closed, perhaps using something like this:

Door#58 is a door.

Door#58 is a door.

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState.

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState.

但我们还需要表示事件发生后事情会有何不同，例如开门或关门。（为简单起见，我们将忽略此处的门锁。）

But we also need to represent how things will be different after events take place, such as the opening or closing of doors. (We will be ignoring the locking of doors here for simplicity.)

为了简化问题，假设我们在世界模型中有可能发生或可能不会发生的事件的表示，这样我们就可以假设地问如果它们发生的话什么是真的。因此，就我们的目的而言，世界模型中的符号Event#427将代表一个事件（例如婚礼、购买自行车或关门），而不假设该事件已经发生或将永远发生（不像Event#23，在上一章中，代表假定发生在 1979 年的事件）。

To simplify matters, it will be convenient to assume that we have representations in the world model for events that may or may not occur so that we can ask hypothetically what would be true if they were to take place. So for our purposes, a symbol like Event#427 in a world model will represent an event (such as a wedding, the purchase of a bicycle, or the closing of a door) without assuming that the event has occurred or will ever happen (unlike Event#23, which in the previous chapter, represented an event assumed to have occurred in 1979).

要讨论如果发生这样的事件会怎样Event#427，我们可以使用语言 L，还有一个附加功能：我们将允许原子公式包含单词“after”，后跟一系列术语。只有当这些术语代表事件时，这才有意义。这个想法是这个扩展的原子公式表明嵌入的公式在给定的事件序列发生后立即为真。事实上，我们会将没有序列项的原子公式视为具有空序列的原子公式的缩写：

To talk about what would be true if an event like Event#427 were to happen, we can use the language L, with one additional feature: we will allow atomic formulas to include the word “after” followed by a sequence of terms at the end. This will only make sense when these terms represent events. The idea is that this extended atomic formula says that the embedded formula is true immediately after the given sequence of events has taken place. In fact, we will treat an atomic formula without a sequence term as an abbreviation for one with the empty sequence:

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState.

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState.

应该理解为的缩写

should be understood as an abbreviation for

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState after [].

Door#58 has “open” as a doorState after [].

（此处的术语[]表示空序列，其中带有 a 的术语|可用于表示非空序列，如附录中所示。）

(The term [] here denotes the empty sequence, and a term with a | in it can be used to represent a nonempty sequence, as presented in the appendix.)

但是，应该如何TEST修改推理来解释这类原子公式呢？答案是我们可以将更改后的门状态视为派生属性。对于使用空序列的原子公式，TEST过程可以像以前一样处理它，寻找没有after []世界模型的公式。这可以被认为是世界模型中表示的门的当前状态。但是对于事件序列不为空的事物，该TEST过程可以寻找描述事件序列之后门状态的推导子句。

But then how should the TEST reasoning be modified to interpret atomic formulas of this sort? The answer is that we can treat a changed door state as a derived property. For an atomic formula that uses the empty sequence, the TEST procedure can handle this exactly as before, looking for the formula without the after [] in the world model. This can be thought of as the current state of the door, as represented in the world model. But for something where the sequence of events is not empty, the TEST procedure can look for a derivation clause characterizing what the door state will be after the sequence of events.

受我们之前关于门的讨论的启发，我们可能想根据图 8.3 中描述的流程图来推断在一系列事件之后门的状态将如何不同，如果它发生变化的话。

Inspired by our discussion of doors from before, we might want to reason about how the state of a door will be different after a sequence of events, if it changes at all, along the lines of the flowchart depicted in figure 8.3.

换句话说，我们可以使用如下方式来描述门的变化状态：

In other words, we can characterize the changing state of a door using something like this:

在任何事件序列之后门的状态如下：

The state of a door immediately after any sequence of events is as follows:

• 如果序列中的最后一个事件是打开那扇门，则门状态将为“打开”（无论之前发生什么）。

• If the last event in the sequence was an opening of that door, then the door state will be “open” (regardless of what came before).

• 如果序列中的最后一个事件是关闭那扇门，则门状态将为“关闭”（无论之前发生什么）。

• If the last event in the sequence was a closing of that door, then the door state will be “closed” (regardless of what came before).

• 否则，门状态不受序列中最后一个事件的影响（无论是否与门相关），并且将是最后一个事件之前的状态。

• Otherwise, the door state is unaffected by the last event in the sequence (door related or not) and will be whatever it was just prior to that last event.

这是现在写成推导子句的同一件事：

Here is the same thing now written as a derivation clause:

Door:d has State:z as a doorState after Seq:s|Event:e

Door:d has State:z as a doorState after Seq:s|Event:e

when

when

if Event:e is a doorOpeningEvent and

if Event:e is a doorOpeningEvent and

Event:e has Door:d as an object

Event:e has Door:d as an object

then State:z is “open”

then State:z is “open”

else if Event:e is a doorClosingEvent and

else if Event:e is a doorClosingEvent and

Event:e has Door:d as an object

Event:e has Door:d as an object

then State:z is “closed”

then State:z is “closed”

else Door:d has State:z as a doorState after Seq:s.

else Door:d has State:z as a doorState after Seq:s.

（这里使用的“if-then-else”是析取的缩写：要么“if”部分为真，“then”部分为真，要么“if”部分为假，“else”部分为真的。）这个有点复杂的递归子句实际上体现了一个相当简单的想法：以前的常识性惯性定律。它说门的状态保持不变，除了某些特殊事件：特定门的打开和关闭。使用此子句，TEST不仅可以从世界模型中读取门的当前状态，还可以在任何给定的事件序列之后读取门的状态。

(The “if-then-else” used here is an abbreviation for a disjunction: either the “if” part is true and the “then” part is true, or the “if” part is false and the “else” part is true.) This somewhat complex recursive clause actually embodies a rather simple idea: the commonsense law of inertia from before. It says that the state of a door remains unchanged except for certain special events: openings and closings of that specific door. Using this clause, TEST can read off from a world model not only the current state of the door but the state of the door after any given sequence of events too.

为了解这是如何工作的，让我们假设我们的世界模型包含一个符号 ，Event#817代表 的结束Door#58。同样，我们不假设此事件已经发生或将要发生。然后，使用上面的推导子句，TEST将确定公式

To see how this works, let us suppose that our world model contains a symbol, Event#817, representing the closing of Door#58. Again, we are not assuming that this event has occurred or will occur. Then, using the derivation clause above, TEST would determine that the formula

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event#817].

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event#817].

为真——也就是说，门将在给定事件后立即关闭。此外，该操作将确定

is true—that is, that the door will be closed immediately after the given event. Furthermore, the operation would determine that

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [ …… ].

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [ … ].

对于任何不涉及的事件序列都是假的Door#58，例如哼着曲子或读书。FIND-ALL（附录中有其他事件序列的示例。）另请注意，我们可以使用with找出哪个事件会使门关闭

is false for any sequence of events that did not involve Door#58, such as humming a tune or reading a book. (The appendix has examples with other sequences of events.) Also note that we can find out what single event will make the door be closed using FIND-ALL with

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event:u].

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event:u].

并接收关门事件Event#817作为响应。虽然我们正在接近使系统能够进行规划，但我们还没有完全做到这一点，因为代理无法知道这是否Event#817可以实现。我们将在下一节中讨论。

and receive the door-closing event Event#817 as an answer. While we are getting close to enabling the system to do planning, we are not quite there yet, since an agent has no way of knowing whether this Event#817 can be made to occur. We will get to that in the next section.

这个处理变化的方案的一个微妙之处在于时间的流逝。由于持续时间看似无关的事件，某些属性可能会发生变化。例如，如果浴缸里装满了水，那么在拔下排水管塞、关灯和关门之后，它会立即保持原样。然而，在拔下塞子、烤蛋糕和关门之后，浴缸就空了。对此的一种理解是，拔下塞子会使浴缸进入排水状态，在这种状态下，水位会根据任何后续事件的持续时间而变化，包括哼着曲子、烤蛋糕或读一本书书。相似的时间考虑因素涉及诸如热物体的冷却或无支撑物体的掉落等事情。

One subtlety in this scheme for dealing with change concerns the passage of time. Some properties can be changed by events that are seemingly unrelated as a result of their duration. For example, if a bathtub is full of water, then it remains so immediately after the sequence of pulling the plug from the drain, turning off the light, and closing the door. The bathtub, however, would be empty after the sequence of pulling the plug, baking a cake, and closing the door. One way to understand this is that pulling the plug causes the bathtub to enter a draining state, and in this state, the water level is changed according to the duration of any subsequent event, including humming a tune, baking a cake, or reading a book. Similar temporal considerations are involved in things like the cooling of hot objects or falling of unsupported ones.

期望我们的知识库将包括像上面那样的推导子句，doorState用于任何可以被事件改变的基本属性（比如婚姻状况、浴缸中的水位、物体的位置等等；这些被称为精通AI 文献）。如果某些基本属性的知识库中不存在这样的子句，则该TEST过程可以简单地假设该属性不会因任何事件的发生而发生变化。另一方面，对于非基本属性，特别是对于以派生子句为特征的属性，TEST可以假设属性随着子句嵌入公式中提到的属性如何变化而变化。

The expectation is that our knowledge base will include derivation clauses like the one for doorState above for any basic property that can be changed by events (like marital status, the water level in a bathtub, the location of objects, and so on; these are called fluents in the AI literature). If a clause like this is not present in the knowledge base for some basic property, the TEST procedure can simply assume that the property is unchanged by any occurrence of events. For a property that is not basic, on the other hand, in particular for one characterized by a derivation clause, TEST can assume that the property changes in accordance with how the properties mentioned in the embedded formula of the clause change.

这种理解变化的方式使我们能够模拟由任何事件序列产生的变化。我们的想法是，我们从一个具有类似这样的东西的世界模型开始

This way of understanding change allows us to simulate the change produced by any sequence of events. The idea is that we start with a world model having something like this

Door#58 has “open” as doorState.

Door#58 has “open” as doorState.

并想象一些事件的发生顺序。现在我们构建一个新的世界模型，其中门状态由上面的推导子句确定doorState。例如，如果门在相关事件发生后确定要关闭，则新世界模型包含

and imagine some sequence of events taking place. Now we construct a new world model where the door state is as determined by the doorState derivation clause above. For example, if the door is determined to be closed after the events in question, then the new world model instead contains

Door#58 has “closed” as doorState.

Door#58 has “closed” as doorState.

现在假设我们以这种方式更新我们关心的每个基本属性，我们最终计算出一个新的世界模型，该模型考虑了每个基本属性如何因该事件序列而发生变化。派生属性将随着底层基本属性的更改而自动更改。如果我们愿意，我们可以将这个新模型视为我们“当前”的世界模型。如果我们想考虑以前的情况，或者如果事件没有发生，事情可能会如何不同，我们只需要回到原始模型。

Now assuming we update every basic property we care about in this way, we end up computing a new world model that takes into account how each basic property changes as a result of that sequence of events. The derived properties will change automatically as underlying basic ones change. We can, if we so desire, think of this new model as our “current” model of the world. We only have to go back to the original model if we want to consider how things were before, or how things might have turned out differently had the events not happened.

变革规划

Planning for Change

正如我们从一开始就强调的那样，常识的一个重要方面是使用推理来有效地利用某些类型的知识来实现​​实际目标，因此确定代理人可以做什么来使世界上的事情成为现实对于常识来说至关重要.

As we have emphasized from the beginning, an essential aspect of common sense is using reasoning to make effective use of certain types of knowledge to achieve practical goals, so determining what an agent can do to make things true in the world is critical for common sense.

在上一节中，我们了解了如何计算事件产生的变化。剩下的就是如何推理代理是否真的可以导致事件发生。典型的说法是，存在代理能够执行的称为动作的这些东西。出于我们的目的，我们将代理执行操作的想法解释为代理以某种方式导致事件发生的一种方式。因此，例如，说一个代理人按下了一个按钮，是一种说代理人使某个按钮按下事件发生的方式。

In the previous section, we saw how to compute the changes produced by an event. All that is left is how to reason about whether an agent can actually cause the event to occur. It is typical to say that there are these things called actions that agents are able to perform. For our purposes, we will interpret the idea of an agent performing an action as a way of saying that the agent is somehow causing an event to occur. So saying that an agent pushed a button, for example, is a way of saying that the agent made a certain button-pushing event take place.

在上一节中，我们看到了关门事件如何导致世界状态发生变化。但这并不意味着代理人总是能够使此类事件发生。例如，不在门附近的代理可能无法将其关闭。如前所述，我们期望代理人执行的操作具有先决条件——即代理人能够导致事件发生的条件必须为真。

In the previous section, we saw how door-closing events cause the state of the world to change. But this does not mean that an agent will always be able to make such an event occur. An agent who is nowhere near the door may be unable to close it, for instance. As discussed before, we expect that actions performed by agents will have prerequisites—that is, conditions that must be true for an agent to be able to cause the event to happen.

对于原始事件——也就是那些没有被认为是更简单的组件事件的事件——我们可以使用我们称之为 的属性来表示它们的先决条件possible。这个派生属性可以用这样的子句来表征：

For primitive events—that is, events that are not thought of in terms of simpler component events—we can represent their prerequisites using a property that we call possible. This derived property can be characterized by clauses like this:

Event:e is possible for Agent:x

Event:e is possible for Agent:x

when

when

Event:e is a doorClosingEvent and

Event:e is a doorClosingEvent and

there is a Door:d where

there is a Door:d where

Event:e has Door:d as an object,

Event:e has Door:d as an object,

Agent:x is near Door:d, and

Agent:x is near Door:d, and

Door:d has “open” as a doorState.

Door:d has “open” as a doorState.

换句话说，如果代理靠近相关门并且门是开着的，则代理可以使关门事件发生。期望我们的知识库将为possible每种类型的原始事件包含一个这样的推导子句。因此，就此子句而言，Event#817如果约翰在附近，他可能会导致发生Door#58那扇门是开着的。这是一个有点粗略的特征，可以进一步限定或注释。例如，如果约翰在门附近但瘫痪、门被撬开或门太大以至于一个人无法移动，他可能无法关门。请注意，这与操作的效果完全不同。这里我们问的是代理人是否可以导致事件发生，代理人是否应该这样选择，而不是事件会改变什么。

In other words, a door-closing event can be made to occur by an agent if the agent is near the door in question and the door is open. The expectation is that our knowledge base will include a possible derivation clause like this for each type of primitive event. So as far as this clause is concerned, John can cause Event#817 to occur if he is near Door#58 and that door is open. This is a somewhat crude characterization that might be further qualified or annotated. For example, John might be unable to close the door if he is near the door but paralyzed, the door has been jimmied open, or the door is too massive for one person to move. Note that this is a completely different consideration from what the effect of the action would be. Here we are asking if the agent can cause the event to take place, should the agent so choose, rather than what the event will change.

对于非原始事件——即由​​其他子事件组成的事件——我们仍然想知道代理是否可以导致它们发生。让我们做一个简单的假设，即此类事件仅被描述为原始事件的序列。在这种情况下，我们需要描述何时可能导致一系列原始事件发生。事实证明，我们称之为 的这个属性possibleSequence可以从possible如下：必须能够执行序列中的第一个动作；那么在执行第一个动作所导致的状态下，必须有可能执行第二个动作；那么在按顺序执行前两个动作所产生的状态下，必须有可能执行第三个动作，依此类推。（具体细节见附件。）

For nonprimitive events—that is, events made up of other subevents—we still would like to know if the agent can cause them to take place. Let us make the simplifying assumption that such events are characterized as sequences of primitive events only. In this case, we would need to characterize when it was possible to cause a sequence of primitive events to occur. As it turns out, this property, which we call possibleSequence, can be defined from possible as follows: it must be possible to perform the first action in the sequence; then in the state that results from having performed that first action, it must be possible to perform the second; then in the state that results from having performed those first two actions in sequence, it must be possible to perform the third, and so on. (See the appendix for the exact details.)

要了解这一切是如何工作的，假设在当前的世界模型中，Door#58是打开的并且Person#17（约翰）不在那扇门附近，但是存在某种运动事件，Event#357约翰可以在当前状态下发生并且会把他放在靠近门的地方。然后该TEST操作可以确定以下两个公式为真：

To see how this would all work, suppose that in the current world model, Door#58 is open and Person#17 (John) is not near that door, but that there is some sort of motion event, Event#357, that John can make happen in the current state and that would put him near the door. The TEST operation can then determine that the following two formulas are true:

[Event#357,Event#817] is a possibleSequence for Person#17.

[Event#357,Event#817] is a possibleSequence for Person#17.

（约翰可以靠近门然后关上它。）

(John can move near the door and then close it.)

Door#58 has “closed” as doorState after [Event#357,Event#817].

Door#58 has “closed” as doorState after [Event#357,Event#817].

（在这一系列事件之后，门将关闭。）

(The door will be closed after that sequence of events.)

图 8.4 描述了由这一系列事件导致的事态。possible（附录中还有其他示例possibleSequence。）这正是规划所需要的：有代理可以执行的一系列动作，在该序列之后，将满足关门的目标。

The state of affairs resulting from this sequence of events is depicted in figure 8.4. (There are other examples of possible and possibleSequence in the appendix.) This is precisely what is needed for planning: there is a sequence of actions that can be performed by the agent, and after that sequence, the goal of having the door closed will be satisfied.

考虑到这一点，我们可以想象一种基本的规划形式。PLAN我们将有一个将代理和目标公式作为参数的过程。该PLAN过程将返回一系列动作，代理可以从当前状态开始执行这些动作以使目标公式为真。例如，约翰可能想要计划以下目标，

With this in mind, we can imagine a basic form of planning. We would have a procedure PLAN that takes as arguments an agent and a goal formula. The PLAN procedure would return a sequence of actions that the agent can perform starting in the current state to make the goal formula true. For example, John might want to plan for the following goal,

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState.

Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState.

并希望得到答复[Event#357,Event#817]。也就是说，为了达到关门的目的，约翰可以移动到靠近门的地方，然后关上门。

and hope to receive the answer [Event#357,Event#817]. In other words, to achieve the goal of the door being closed, John can move to be near the door and then close it.

乍一看，我们可能会通过使用以下内容PLAN来为 John计算：FIND-ALL

At first blush, we might think of computing PLAN for John by using FIND-ALL over the following:

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Person#17 and Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after Seq:s.

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Person#17 and Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after Seq:s.

但是这个想法不太行得通。FIND-ALL在世界模型中寻找常量，我们不能期望看到可能需要考虑的所有（无限多）潜在事件序列的常量。

But this idea does not quite work. FIND-ALL looks for constants in the world model, and we cannot expect to see constants for all the (infinitely many) potential sequences of events that might need to be considered.

另一方面，如果我们知道我们正在寻找一个计划，其中正好有两个动作，并且模型中有我们可能想要考虑的每个单独事件的常量，那么我们可以使用以下公式FIND-ALL：

On the other hand, if we knew that we were looking for a plan with exactly two actions in it and there were constants in the model for each individual event we might want to consider, then we could use FIND-ALL over the following formula:

[Event:u,Event:v] is a possibleSequence for Person#17 and Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event:u,Event:v].

[Event:u,Event:v] is a possibleSequence for Person#17 and Door#58 has “closed” as a doorState after [Event:u,Event:v].

换句话说，找到两个原始事件，约翰可以使它们依次发生，然后门就会关闭。这应该正确返回组合Event#357, Event#817。正如我们将在下一章中看到的那样，这种基于记忆的更有限的计划概念对于常识性目的来说已经足够了。

In other words, find two primitive events such that John can cause them to occur in sequence, and after doing so, the door will be closed. This should correctly return the combination Event#357, Event#817. As we will see in the next chapter, this more limited memory-based notion of planning will be enough for commonsense purposes.

回答一般性问题

Answering Generic Questions

为了结束本章，让我们回到回答问题，但属于不同类型的问题。TEST我们考虑使用和上面的问题FIND-ALL是关于世界上的特定事物及其属性。但当人们谈论常识时，首先想到的是更笼统的问题，根本不涉及具体事物：

To conclude this chapter, let us return to answering questions, but ones of a different sort. The questions for which we considered using TEST and FIND-ALL above were about specific things in the world and their properties. But when people talk about common sense, what first comes to mind are more generic questions that are not about specific things at all:

• 鸟是会飞的动物吗？

• Is a bird a flying animal?

• 婴儿可以开车吗？

• Can a baby drive a car?

• 理发会比生日派对花的时间长吗？

• Will a haircut take longer than a birthday party?

• 灰熊比手推车重吗？

• Does a grizzly bear weigh more than a wheelbarrow?

虽然这些问题不是关于特定个人的，但确实有一些是关于个人的相关问题。例如，对于上面的第一个问题，我们可能会问是否所有的鸟都是飞行动物。bird假设我们已经有了和的属性flyingAnimal，我们可以使用TEST以下公式：

While these questions are not about specific individuals, there are indeed related ones that are about individuals. For the first question above, for instance, we might ask if all the birds are flying animals. Assuming we already have properties for bird and flyingAnimal, we can use TEST over the following formula:

It is not the case that

It is not the case that

there is a Bird:x where

there is a Bird:x where

Bird:x is a bird and

Bird:x is a bird and

it is not the case that Bird:x is a flyingAnimal.

it is not the case that Bird:x is a flyingAnimal.

如果不是有一只鸟不是飞行动物，则此TEST操作将返回，或者如果每只鸟都是飞行动物，则移除两个否定。TRUE但这显然与上面的通用问题不同。

This TEST operation will return TRUE if it is not the case that there is a bird that is not a flying animal, or removing the two negations, if every bird is a flying animal. But this is clearly not the same as the generic question above.

所以我们可能会问，以下两个英语问题之间到底有什么区别？

So we might start by asking, What exactly is the difference between the following two English questions?

1. 鸟是会飞的动物吗？（或者，鸟一般会飞吗？）

1. Is a bird a flying animal? (or, Are birds flying animals in general?)

2. 每只鸟都是飞行动物吗？（或者，所有的鸟都会飞吗？）

2. Is every bird a flying animal? (or, Are all the birds flying animals?)

主要有两点。首先，即使在 (2) 为假的情况下，(1) 也可能被认为是真的。我们可能想要相信鸟会飞（一般而言），即使我们知道一些例外情况，比如不会飞的企鹅 Chilly。其次，即使在相应的 (2) 为真的情况下，类似 (1) 的东西也可能被认为是假的。例如，假设我们所知道的唯一鸟类恰好是像 Chilly 这样的特殊鸟类。那么我们可能会相信所有这些鸟都生活在南极并且不会飞，尽管我们可能不想相信一般的鸟都是这样。一个明显的结果是，即使我们所知道的大多数鸟类都具有某种特性，我们也可能不愿意相信鸟类普遍具有这种特性。

There are two main things. First, (1) might be considered to be true even in cases where (2) is false. We may want to believe that birds fly (in general) even if we know some exceptions, like Chilly the penguin who does not fly. Second, something like (1) might be considered to be false even in cases where the corresponding (2) is true. For example, suppose that the only birds we know about happen to be exceptional ones like Chilly. Then we might believe that all of these birds live in the Antarctic and do not fly, even though we may not want to believe that birds in general are like this. As an obvious consequence, even when the majority of the birds we know about have some property, we may not want to believe that birds have the property in general.

正如我们在上面看到的，（2）是一个关于世界模型中代表的鸟类的问题，也是一个可以TEST处理的问题。但如何回答像（1）这样的问题？我们所说的与世界模型中所代表的鸟类不同的“一般”鸟类到底是什么意思？

As we saw above, (2) is a question about the birds represented in a world model, and so is a question that TEST can deal with. But how then to answer a question like (1)? What exactly do we mean by birds “in general” as distinct from those represented in a world model?

从某种意义上说，像 (1) 这样的一般性问题的答案涉及一个概念结构：当你考虑你对一只鸟的想法时，你会想到什么样的属性？您碰巧知道的特定鸟类的特性不会以这种或另一种方式决定答案。这里的复杂之处在于，我们与概念相关联的属性bird受到一系列复杂的限制和注释，包括默认和取消，在不同的强度和重要性级别，如前一章所示。我们真的不想探究概念模型的结构（例如，这个角色有多少限制？那个注释的强度是什么？），但我们确实想利用所有这些结构来回答问题.

In a sense, the answer to a generic question like (1) involves a conceptual structure: When you consider your idea of a bird, what sort of properties do you have in mind? Properties of the particular birds you happen to know about will not determine the answer one way or the other. The complication here is that the properties we associate with a concept like bird are subject to a complex array of restrictions and annotations, including defaults and cancellations, at various levels of strength and importance, as seen in the previous chapter. We do not really want to probe the structure of the conceptual model (as in, How many restrictions on this role? What is the strength of that annotation?), but we do want to make use of all of this structure in answering the question.

理解像 (1) 这样的问题的一种方法如下：

One way of making sense of a question like (1) is as follows:

  • 想象一下（假设地）一个世界状态，那里有一只你以前从未想过的新鸟。那东西是会飞的动物吗？
  • Imagine (hypothetically) a world state where there is a new bird you’ve never thought about before. Is that thing a flying animal?

换句话说，我们可以想象做一些类似于上一章所做的事情：我们通过使用bird概念模型中与其关联的所有属性实例化概念来扩展世界模型，直接或通过继承。这将产生一个新符号，例如Bird#247代表这只假想的鸟并具有多种属性。完成后，我们就可以使用TEST公式来确定

In other words, we can imagine doing something like what was done in the previous chapter: we extend the world model by instantiating the bird concept using all the properties associated with it in the conceptual model, either directly or through inheritance. This will produce a new symbol like Bird#247 representing this hypothetical bird and having a variety of properties. When this is done, we can then use TEST to determine if the formula

Bird#247 is a flyingAnimal.

Bird#247 is a flyingAnimal.

根据这个世界模型是正确的。

is true according to this world model.

这更接近我们对 (1) 的答案，尽管它仍然没有告诉我们飞行属性是由于默认值（以及应用默认值的强度）还是对概念更基本的限制（哪个当然，可能仍会被取消）。在前一种情况下，我们可能会倾向于用“是的，通常”来回答像 (1) 这样的问题；在后一种情况下，我们可能会回答“是的，作为一项规则”。在任何一种情况下，我们甚至可能包括一个代表默认或限制强度的数字。

This is much closer to the answer we are after for (1), although it still does not tell us whether the flying property is due to a default (and how strongly that default is applied) or a restriction more fundamental to the concept (which might still be canceled, of course). In the former case, we might be tempted to answer a question like (1) with “Yes, typically”; in the latter case, we might answer with something like “Yes, as a rule.” In either case, we might even include a number representing the strength of the default or restriction.

9

9

行动常识

Common Sense in Action

仅仅因为你制定了一个好的计划，并不意味着那会发生。

Just because you make a good plan, doesn’t mean that’s gonna happen.

——泰勒·斯威夫特，引自丽芙·斯宾塞的《泰勒·斯威夫特：白金版》

—Taylor Swift, quoted in Taylor Swift: The Platinum Edition, by Liv Spencer

正如我们一直在说的，常识是在决定在日常情况下做什么时有效利用普通背景知识的能力。在前两章中，我们研究了常识知识的符号表示和定义在这些表示上的一般推理操作。目的是让这些知识可用于计算。在本章中，我们通过展示如何将这些计算用于决定要做什么来完成这幅图画。具体来说，我们关注第 2 章中首次描述的常识的一个明显表现：被完全出乎意料的事情从熟悉的例程中惊醒。我们看一个计划出错的具体例子（正如泰勒斯威夫特所说），详细调查常识应该能够理解它，

Common sense, as we have been saying, is the ability to make effective use of ordinary background knowledge in deciding what to do in everyday situations. In the previous two chapters, we examined symbolic representations of commonsense knowledge and general reasoning operations defined over these representations. The purpose was to make that knowledge available for computation. In this chapter, we complete the picture by showing how these computations can be put to use in deciding what to do. Specifically, we focus on one clear manifestation of common sense first described in chapter 2: being jolted out of a familiar routine by something completely unexpected. We look at a concrete example of a plan going awry (just as Taylor Swift says), investigate in detail what common sense ought to be able to make of it, and then show how this can emerge from the sort of symbolic representation and reasoning seen in the previous two chapters.

请注意，我们不会尝试解决可能被视为常识的所有形式。我们将采取一种有点功利主义的观点，即常识只是为了立即采取行动。我们正在搁置其他不那么活跃的常识知识用途，比如做白日梦、回忆，甚至读书或看电影。重点是对“我现在应该做什么？”这个问题给出一个合适的答案。我们想到的可能答案是普通的、世俗的行为，我们期望对这些行为有普通的、世俗的知识。对于一个人来说，动作可能是说些什么，拿起一个对象，或前往某处。它们不会是控制内脏或接合肌肉之类的东西，尽管这些生物活动显然会涉及到。

Note that we are not going to try to address all forms of what might be considered common sense. We are going to take a somewhat utilitarian view, where common sense is only for immediate action. We are putting aside other less active uses of commonsense knowledge, like daydreaming, reminiscing, or even reading a book or watching a movie. The whole point will be to end up with a suitable answer to the question, “What should I do now?” The possible answers we have in mind are common, mundane actions, about which we expect to have common, mundane knowledge. For a person, the actions might be things like saying something, picking up an object, or heading off somewhere. They would not be things like controlling internal organs or engaging muscles, even though biological activities like these will clearly be involved.

从功利主义的角度来看，第 2 章首先提到的常识推理模式实际上只有两种——自上而下和自下而上：

From this utilitarian point of view, there are really only two modes of commonsense reasoning first mentioned in chapter 2—top-down and bottom-up:

  • • 自上而下的推理是代理人需要使用他们所知道的来实现他们正在努力实现的目标的结果。它的目的是回答诸如“我应该怎么做才能使命题P为真？”这样的问题。
  • • Top-down reasoning occurs as the result of agents needing to use what they know to achieve goals they are working on. Its purpose is to answer a question like “What should I do to make proposition P true?”
  • • 自下而上的推理是代理人需要使用他们所知道的来理解感知到的事物的结果。它的目的是回答诸如“我应该如何对命题P为真做出反应？”这样的问题。
  • • Bottom-up reasoning occurs as the result of agents needing to use what they know to make sense of something perceived. Its purpose is to answer a question like “How should I react to proposition P being true?”

正如我们将看到的，这两者都有助于回答“我现在应该做什么？” 问题。

As we will see, both of these will contribute to answering the “What should I do now?” question.

还请记住，当我们谈论常识推理时，我们想到的是比从已知事物中找出可能得出的一切更有限的东西。一个人很可能拥有所有必要的信息，能够确定他们应该打开一号门还是二号门，但出于某种原因无法确定是哪一扇门。这种无能不一定是常识的失败。我们心目中的常识显然包括从已知的事物中得出适当的结论，但不一定能够得出所有结论。

Also recall that when we talk about commonsense reasoning, we have in mind something more limited than figuring out everything that might follow from what is known. It may well be that a person has all the necessary information to be able to determine whether they should open door number one or door number two, but for one reason or another cannot determine which. This inability need not be a failure of common sense. What we have in mind for common sense will clearly include drawing appropriate conclusions from what is known, but not necessarily being able to draw all of them.

在开始使用常识之前，我们首先重新检查一种没有常识的死记硬背行为——一种使用简单形式的条件-动作规则的行为。然后，我们考虑如何将知识整合到流程中以及原因。

Before we get to using common sense, we begin by reexamining a kind of rote behavior with no common sense—one that uses a simple form of condition-action rules. We then consider how to incorporate knowledge into the process and why.

基于规则的行为

Rule-Based Behavior

让我们从例程的概念开始。正如我们在第 2 章中所说，我们人类在日常生活中处理的大部分事情都不足为奇。我们几乎所有的时间都花在至少对我们来说有些熟悉的情况下。我们一次又一次地遇到同样的事情，并学习处理它们的方法。它可能是想过马路、打开油漆罐或买杯咖啡之类的事情，也可能是我们观察到的事情，例如即将来临的暴风雨、烤面包的气味或接近的声音救护车。在最基本的形式中，发生的事情是这样的：我们认出熟悉的情况，从记忆中回忆起处理它的例程，然后按照规定的步骤进行。

Let’s begin with the notion of a routine. As we said in chapter 2, most of what we humans deal with in day-to-day life is not too surprising. We spend almost all of our time in situations that are at least somewhat familiar to us. We run into the same sorts of things over and over, and learn ways of dealing with them. It might be things like wanting to cross a street, open a paint can, or buy a cup of coffee, or it might be things we observe like the sight of an approaching storm, smell of burnt toast, or sound of an approaching ambulance. In its most basic form, here is what happens: we recognize the familiar situation, recall from memory a routine that deals with it, and follow the steps prescribed.

要以这种方式行事，我们至少需要两件事：

To behave in such a way, we need at a minimum two things:

  1. 1. 识别某些常见条件的能力，并以与任何目标或期望无关的上下文无关的方式进行识别。
  2. 1. The ability to recognize certain common conditions, and do so in a context-free way, independently of any goals or expectations.
  3. 2. 遵循例程（及其调用的任何子例程）的能力，同样以上下文无关的方式，独立于任何目标或期望。
  4. 2. The ability to follow a routine (and any subroutines it calls on), again in a context-free way, independently of any goals or expectations.

总的来说，我们可以将这种基本行为视为基于规则的：我们有一组形式为 [ X→ Y ]，其中每个X描述了世界上的一种情况，每个Y描述了要执行的例程。在其最原始的单一用途形式中，集合中只有一个规则——根据提示执行的单个例程。更普遍的行为是某种观察-决定-行动循环：我们反复观察世界，并在规则中 [ X→ Y ] 我们确定其条件X得到满足，我们决定（以某种方式）制定哪些例程Y，然后我们继续执行它们。（事实证明，如果这种基于规则的系统也可以访问它可以写入和读取的无限工作内存，那么由此产生的架构将足够通用，可以模拟任何其他计算系统。）

Overall, we can think of this basic behavior as rule based: we have a collection of rules of the form [X→Y], where each X describes a condition in the world, and each Y describes a routine to perform. In its most primitive single-purpose form, there is just one rule in the collection—a single routine to perform on cue. The more general behavior is some sort of observe-decide-act loop: we repeatedly observe the world, and among the rules [X→Y] whose condition X we determine to be satisfied, we decide (in some way) on which routines Y to enact, and we go ahead and act on them. (As it turns out, if a rule-based system of this sort also has access to an unbounded working memory that it can write to and read from, the resulting architecture will be general enough to emulate any other computational system.)

一旦我们决定执行例行程序，这个过程就有点像根据食谱烹饪。工作是按照指定的顺序执行步骤；这不是质疑为什么我们必须采取某些步骤，或者如果我们不这样做会发生什么。这些步骤可以被认为是要执行的小仪式。如果例程要求按三次按钮，我们执行这些步骤时就好像这些动作本身才是最重要的，而不是它们可能实现的任何效果。同样，当一名教官命令士兵用牙刷清洁地板时，重要的是这些具体行动；私人提出一些更好的完成工作的方法将是严重的不服从命令。

Once we have decided to perform a routine, the process is somewhat like cooking from a recipe. The job is to follow the steps in the specified order; it is not to question why we must do certain steps, or what would happen if we did otherwise. The steps can be thought of as small rituals to perform. If the routine says to push a button three times, we perform those steps as if the actions themselves are what mattered rather than any effect they might achieve. Similarly, when a drill sergeant orders a private to clean a floor with a toothbrush, it is those specific actions that count; it would be gross insubordination for the private to propose some better way of getting the job done.

例行程序的逐步执行可能是相当无脑和机械的——可以由适当编程的自动机执行的事情。然而，自动机不一定是简单的；它可能是一个完整的国际象棋下棋机或一个复杂的感染诊断机器。但执行应该是上下文无关的，也就是说，关于周围环境的广泛常识性知识不是执行中的一个因素。我们希望下国际象棋的自动机在龙卷风中或全球战争期间也能下同样的棋。唯一的除了对程序的输入之外，与世界的真正联系在于对例程本身的调用。

The step-by-step execution of a routine can be quite mindless and mechanical—something that can be performed by a suitably programmed automaton. The automaton need not be simple, however; it might be an entire chess-playing machine or a sophisticated infection-diagnosis machine. But the execution is expected to be context free, which is to say that broad, commonsense knowledge about the surrounding environment is not a factor in the execution. We expect a chess-playing automaton to play the same in the middle of a tornado or during a global war. The only real connection to the world beyond the inputs to the program is in the invocation of the routine itself.

如前所述，我们希望例程的调用基于识别世界上某些常见条件的能力，而不是对要寻找的内容有任何期望。很明显，人类具有这种能力，是通过某种学习过程获得的。如果我们正在观看一场棒球比赛，并且发生了一些完全出乎意料的事情，比如一辆消防车突然出现在赛场上，即使我们没有预料到会发生这样的事情，我们仍然可以认出那是一辆消防车。同样，我们可以认出路德维希·范·贝多芬第五交响曲的前几个音符即使在我们不希望听到任何音乐的情况下。这并不是说最一般形式的感知可以在没有自上而下的期望的情况下发生。在街景的模糊图像中，我们可能会将图像中的某个斑点识别为汽车，只是因为它在所描绘的场景中占据了我们期望被汽车之类的东西填充的位置。

As already noted, we expect the invocation of a routine to be based on an ability to recognize certain common conditions in the world, and without any expectations about what to be looking for. It is clear that humans have such an ability, acquired through some sort of learning process. If we are watching a baseball game and something totally unexpected happens, such as a fire truck suddenly appearing on the field, we can still recognize the thing as a fire truck even though we did not expect anything like it. Similarly, we can recognize the first few notes of Ludwig van Beethoven’s Symphony No. 5 even in contexts where we do not expect to hear anything musical. This is not to say that perception in its most general form can take place without top-down expectations. In a blurry image of a street scene, we might recognize a certain blob in the image as a car only because it occupies a position in the depicted scene that we expect to be filled by things like cars.

因为我们想象的动作和感知将以这种方式与上下文无关，所以可以提前限制与整体行为相关的参数。换句话说，这种基于规则的系统就是我们之前所说的封闭系统系统：具有一组可以预先列出的参数的系统。虽然参数是可预测的，但这些参数将采用的值不一定是。例如，即使您不知道对手会选择哪一步，您也会知道国际象棋的走法。您会知道打开冰箱门需要一定的力，即使您事先不知道该力是多大。只要事情进展顺利，我们就不会退后一步质疑我们在做什么，或者我们是否应该做其他事情。当然，这种封闭系统的概念可能非常强大。我们已经讨论了封闭的人工智能系统及其令人瞩目的成就。对于许多实际应用，这就足够了。但正如我们将看到的，在许多情况下，事实并非如此。

Because the action and perception we are imagining will be context free in this way, the parameters that are relevant for the overall behavior can be circumscribed in advance. In other words, a rule-based system of this sort is what we previously called a closed system: a system with a set of parameters that can be listed in advance. While the parameters are predictable, the values those parameters will take need not be. You will know what a chess move is supposed to look like, for example, even if you do not know which one your opponent will choose. You will know that a certain amount of force will be required to open a refrigerator door even if you do not know in advance what that force will be. As long as things are going well, we never step back and question what we are doing, or whether we should be doing something else. This notion of a closed system can, of course, be quite powerful. We already talked about closed AI systems and their impressive achievements. For many practical applications, this will be enough. But as we will see, in many cases, it is not.

打破规则

Breaking the Rules

当一个系统必须能够在一个无法预先限制的环境中正常工作时，一个封闭的系统是不够的——也就是说，在一个完全无法预料的事件可能发生的环境中发生。我们真的只需要从固定的规则集合中退后一步，并在出现不协调时使用常识——这违反了我们的期望。

Where a closed system will not be enough is when a system must be able to work properly in an environment that cannot be circumscribed in advance—that is, in one where events that are totally unanticipated may occur. We only really need to step back from a fixed collection of rules and use common sense when there is an incongruity—something that violates our expectations.

也许会发生完全出乎意料的事情。也许我们正在过马路，地面突然让路；也许我们进入酒店房间并闻到培根烹饪的味道；或者，也许我们正试图用螺丝刀打开油漆罐，有人大喊：“不要使用那把螺丝刀！” 它不需要是什么大事。也许我们在用来制作细面条的锅底发现了一只玩具长颈鹿。或者事情可能会以相反的方式发展：应该发生的事情并没有发生。也许炉子上的锅里的水永远不会沸腾；也许我们握手致意的人并没有主动与我们握手；或者也许我们刚刚在我们最喜欢的咖啡店订购的咖啡从未到货。在这种情况下，我们需要打破常规，重新考虑下一步该怎么做。

Maybe something completely unexpected happens. Maybe we are crossing the street and the ground suddenly gives way; maybe we enter our hotel room and smell bacon cooking; or maybe we are trying to open a paint can with a screwdriver and somebody shouts, “Don’t use that screwdriver!” It need not be something major. Maybe we spot a toy giraffe at the bottom of the pot we are going to use to make linguini. Or maybe things go the other way: something that is supposed to happen does not. Maybe the water in the pot on the stove never reaches a boil; maybe the person we are greeting with a handshake does not move to shake our hand; or maybe the coffee we just ordered at our favorite coffee shop never arrives. In cases like these, we need to break out of our routine and reconsider what to do next.

当然，基于规则的系统可能足够灵活，可以处理其中一些无法预料的情况。下棋程序或许能够找到合适的下法，即使对手的走法古怪而令人惊讶。过马路的例行程序可能能够很好地应对附近消防栓突然出乎意料的水流。基于规则的系统可能足够通用和灵活以处理许多此类变化。

Of course, a rule-based system might be flexible enough to deal with some of these unanticipated situations. A chess-playing program may be able to find an appropriate move to make even when the opponent moves in outlandish and surprising ways. A routine for crossing the street may be able to cope quite well with a sudden unanticipated flow of water from a nearby fire hydrant. A rule-based system might be general and flexible enough to deal with a number of such variations.

然而，在真正开放的环境中，系统参数之外的事情迟早会发生。我们根本不能指望有一套固定的规则来明智地处理现实生活中可能实际发生的一切。此外，正如已经提到的，虽然这些意外事件中的每一个可能都非常罕见，但因为它们太多了——可能发生这么多不同的奇怪事情——在现实生活中遇到其中一个的机会实际上很高。正如我们所说，极其罕见的事件很常见。

In a truly open environment, however, sooner or later something will happen that lies outside the parameters of the system. We simply cannot expect to have a fixed collection of rules that deals sensibly with everything that might actually happen in real life. Furthermore, as already mentioned, although each of these unanticipated events might be extremely rare individually, because there are so many of them—so many different bizarre things that can happen—the chance of encountering one of them in real life is actually high. As we said, extremely rare events are quite common.

那么，当我们遵循的常规无法应对当前情况时，会发生什么？我们需要重新考虑我们正在做的事情。但要做到这一点，例程必须做的不仅仅是指定要遵循的步骤（和子例程）。执行需要更加慎重，因此例程需要两个额外的组件：

So what has to happen when a routine we are following is unable to cope with the current situation? We need to reconsider what we are doing. But to allow this, a routine has to do more than just specify steps (and subroutines) to follow. The execution needs to be much more deliberate, and so the routine needs two additional components:

  1. 1. 对于需要采取某些行动的每个步骤，例程都需要明确该步骤的目的是什么，以便可以确定该步骤是否成功，如果该步骤被证明不成功，则允许代理考虑到达那里的其他方式。
  2. 1. For each step where some action is called for, the routine needs to make clear what the step is intended to accomplish so that it will be possible to ascertain if the step was successful and allow the agent to consider other ways of getting there should the step prove to be unsuccessful.
  3. 2. 对于例程要求等待直到某个条件成立的每个步骤，例程还需要明确等待多长时间是有意义的，以及检查条件的频率是合适的。
  4. 2. For each step where the routine says to wait until some condition holds, the routine also needs to make clear about how long it makes sense to wait and how often it would be appropriate to check for the condition.

换句话说，为了处理变化和故障，我们需要一种符号表示，强调通过例程中的步骤实现的世界条件。让我们用“计划”这个词来描述这种例程。（我们无意讨论所需的符号表示。它们与之前看到的类似。例如，一个计划可以使用语言 L 的公式来表示世界上的条件。）

In other words, to deal with variations and breakdowns, we need a symbolic representation that emphasizes conditions in the world being achieved by the steps in the routine. Let us use the word “plan” to describe a routine of this sort. (It is not our intent to discuss the symbolic representations needed. They would be analogous to what was seen before. For instance, a plan could use formulas of the language L to represent conditions in the world.)

计划的漫不经心（或盲目）执行就像上述例行程序的逐步执行一样，除了所涉及的操作之外，对任何事情都一无所知。另一方面，计划的有意（或有意识）执行也将监视世界上的情况，并在不满足某些条件时随时准备中断执行。

The inattentive (or mindless) execution of a plan would be just like the step-by-step execution of a routine described above, oblivious to anything other than the actions involved. The deliberate (or mindful) execution of a plan, on the other hand, would also be monitoring conditions in the world, standing by to interrupt the execution when certain conditions are not met.

因此，常识在行动中的作用是双重的：首先，我们需要观察我们正在做的事情，以确认我们关心的条件是否得到了应有的满足，并注意到何时发生了意想不到的事情；其次，在失败时，我们需要能够重新考虑我们是如何实现这些条件的，以及是否有其他方法可以做到这一点，同时考虑到我们正在制定的当前计划的结构，我们已经发现了什么目前的情况，以及我们对世界的一般常识。在本章的其余部分，我们将集中讨论当在有意执行计划时没有达到预期时应该采用什么常识。

So the role of common sense in action is twofold: first, we need to watch what we are doing to confirm that conditions we care about are being satisfied as they should and notice when unexpected things happen; and second, on failure, we need to be able to reconsider how we are achieving these conditions, and whether there might be other ways of doing so, taking into account the structure of the current plan we are working on, what we have discovered about the current situation, and our general commonsense knowledge of the world. In the rest of this chapter, we will be concentrating on what common sense should dictate when expectations are not met in the deliberate execution of a plan.

但显然还需要讲述另一个故事：究竟是什么触发了计划执行从无意识转变为更有意识的执行？（一个相关的问题是向另一个方向的转变：如何通过足够的练习，让新手有意识但有些沉闷的执行变成专家的无意识但流畅的执行？）

But clearly still another story needs to be told: What exactly triggers a shift from a mindless to a more mindful execution of a plan? (A related question is the shift in the other direction: How does the mindful but somewhat plodding execution of a novice become, with enough practice, the mindless but smooth execution of an expert?)

在我们看来，从无意识到有意识的转变本身并不是常识的产物。考虑像闹钟这样的东西。这并不是说您决定收听警报，这就是您听到警报的原因。警报将抓住无论您的信念和目标是什么，您的注意力都将与上下文无关。然而它的目的只是让你进入正念状态，你现在必须问自己：“发生了什么事？有什么我应该做的吗？” 在以这种方式受到冲击后决定你应该做什么是常识进入画面的地方。

In our opinion, the shift from mindless to mindful is itself not the product of common sense. Consider something like an alarm. It’s not as if you decide to listen for an alarm and that’s why you hear it. An alarm will grab your attention in a context-free way, whatever your beliefs and goals happen to be. Yet its purpose is only to put you into a state of mindfulness, where you must now ask yourself, “What’s going on? Is there something I should be doing?” Deciding on what you should do after you have been jolted in this way is where common sense enters the picture.

这个故事的困难在于它依赖于明确检测到的强烈信号，例如响亮的声音、明亮的闪光、刺鼻的气味、坚定的触摸，或者人们说“小心！”之类的警告语。或“注意！” 但也有可能被更微弱的事物转移到增强的正念状态，比如上面提到的罐子里意想不到的玩具长颈鹿，或者甚至是不寻常的时间流逝，比如水不沸腾。然而，并不是所有的意想不到的事情会以这种方式吸引你的注意力。如果你碰巧在你的自行车道上发现一只松鼠拿着顶针，你不会立即停下来重新考虑你应该做什么以及为什么。同样，如果你全神贯注于谈话，时间的流逝可能会被完全忽略。究竟什么应该或不应该引发对您当前状况的更深思熟虑的重新评估是一个棘手的问题，需要一个明确的解决方案。

The difficulty with this story is that it relies on strong signals that are detected unambiguously, such as loud sounds, bright flashing lights, sharp smells, firm touches, or people saying alarming things like “Be careful!” or “Pay attention!” But it is possible to be shifted into a state of increased mindfulness by something much weaker, like the unexpected toy giraffe in the pot mentioned above or even an unusual passage of time such as water refusing to come to a boil. And yet it is not as if all unexpected things grab your attention in this way. If you happen to spot a squirrel holding a thimble somewhere on your bicycle path, you do not immediately pause to reconsider what it is you should be doing and why. Similarly, the passage of time might be completely ignored if you are engrossed in a conversation. Exactly what should or should not trigger a more deliberate reappraisal of your current situation is a thorny problem that awaits a clear solution.

目标和计划

Goals and Plans

代理商的目标从何而来？简单的答案是它们大多来自其他目标！穿过某条街道的目标可能来自于到达特定餐厅的目标，这来自外出就餐的目标，来自获得食物（和社交）的目标。这并不是说获得食物需要穿过那条街。获取食物的方式有很多种，包括在家做饭。但我们所知道的是：一种获取食物的方式是外出就餐，一种外出就餐的方式是去那家特定的餐厅，而去那家餐厅的一种方式是穿过那条特定的街道。经常使用某个计划来获得食物，它就变成了例行公事——我们后来会完整地回忆起它作为实现目标的一种方式。

Where do agents’ goals come from? The easy answer is that they mostly come from other goals! The goal of crossing a certain street might come from a goal of getting to a specific restaurant, which comes from a goal of eating out, which comes from a goal of obtaining food (and socializing). This is not to say that obtaining food entails crossing that street. There are many ways of getting food, including cooking at home. But what we know is this: one way to get food involves eating out, one way to eat out involves getting to that specific restaurant, and one way to get to that restaurant involves crossing that specific street. Use a certain plan often enough to obtain food, and it becomes routine—something we later recall in its entirety as a way of achieving the goal.

吃饭的目的是什么？那是从哪里来的？有些目标不仅仅是实现其他目标的方法，而是更根本的驱动力。吃的需要不是我们有太多选择的东西。当然，我们可以选择不吃，但时间不能太长。每一个系统，无论是否是生物系统，都会有这样的驱动力，它不得不去处理，并且大约它几乎没有控制权。例如，可以驱动一个简单的计算机系统来执行其程序。一个更复杂的机器人助手可能会得到一个长期命令，让它去做任何它被告知要做的事情——可能要遵守作家艾萨克·阿西莫夫的机器人三定律——然后会从中出现各种子目标。

What about the goal of eating? Where does that come from? Some goals are not just ways of achieving other goals but instead are more fundamental drives. The need to eat is not something we have much choice over. We can choose not to eat, of course, but not for long. Every system, biological or not, will have drives like this that it is compelled to deal with, and about which it has little or no control. A simple computer system, for example, can be driven to execute its program. A more complex robotic assistant might be given a standing order to do whatever it is told to do—subject perhaps to something like author Isaac Asimov’s three laws of robotics—from which all sorts of subgoals will then emerge.

这并不是说只有当我们发现其他方法可以实现更高层次的目标时，目标才会改变。我们的价值观也可以改变。我们可能会获得一个目标，因为随着时间的推移，我们会意识到这个目标是值得拥有的。例如，我们可能不想阅读经典，但渴望成为那种阅读经典的人。从某种意义上说，我们的目标是最终成为拥有某些其他目标的人。目标也会受到我们已经做出的选择和承诺的影响。例如，一旦我们决定参加大学课程，我们所有后续目标都将受到该承诺的影响。

This is not to suggest that goals only change when we discover other ways of achieving the higher-level goals they derive from. Our values can change as well. We may acquire a goal because we come to realize over time that the goal is worth having. We may have no desire to read the classics, for instance, but aspire to be the kind of person who does. In a sense, our goal would be to eventually become the kind of person who has certain other goals. Goals are also affected by the choices and commitments we have already made. Once we have decided to enroll in a college program, for example, all our subsequent goals will be filtered by that commitment.

当谈到常识性行为时，我们问自己的主要问题是：鉴于我所知道的和我想要的，我现在应该做什么？对此进行扩展，问题更像是以下内容：
