When it comes to commonsense behavior, the main question we ask ourselves is this: Given what I know and what I want, what should I do now? Expanding on this, the question is more like the following:

  • 根据我目前的知识和目标，我认为最好的行动计划是什么，接下来我要做什么？
  • According to my current knowledge and goals, what plan of action do I think is best, and what does it have me doing next?

这里有更详细的信息：

And here it is in much more detail:

  • 根据我所知道的一切，考虑到很多我不知道但可能会发现的事实，并根据我所有的目标，包括我所有的需要和愿望、偏好和倾向、愿望和抱负，考虑到我迄今为止做出的所有选择和我打算遵守的承诺，在我所知道的目前可供我使用的所有行动计划中，有什么突出的吗？换句话说，我是否知道没有其他计划更好？
  • According to everything I know, allowing for the fact that there is a lot I do not know but may be able to find out, and according to all my goals, including all my needs and desires, preferences and inclinations, and aspirations and ambitions, and given all the choices I have made so far and the commitments I intend to respect, among all the plans of actions that I know are currently available to me, are there any that stand out? In other words, do I know of a plan for which there is no other that I can say is better?

那么，在这种情况下，一项计划优于另一项计划意味着什么？答案涉及某种常识性的成本收益分析：实现目标的收益与计划中的行动成本相比。您的目标可能是孤注一掷，比如去旧金山；除非你实现了这个目标，否则对你没有任何好处。但你也可能有享受假期或保持房屋清洁等目标，这些目标可能会得到不同程度的满足。另一方面，您在计划中考虑的每项行动都可能有成本——即即，对您关心的资源（如金钱、时间或社会资本）的负面影响。此外，我们希望将诸如努力和不便以及风险和危险程度等因素包括在此成本中。像跳伞这样的冒险行为本身并不是消极的，但最终可能会产生高昂的成本。

What then does it mean for one plan to be better than another in this context? The answer involves some sort of commonsense cost-benefit analysis: the benefit of achieving a goal against the cost of the actions in a plan for doing so. You may have goals like getting to San Francisco that are all-or-nothing; there is no benefit to you with respect to this goal unless you make it there. But you may also have goals like enjoying a vacation or keeping the house clean, which may be satisfied to varying degrees. On the other hand, each action you are considering in your plan may have costs—that is, negative effects on resources you care about (like money, time, or social capital). Moreover, we want to include in this cost things like effort and inconvenience as well as the degrees of risk and danger. Risky actions like skydiving are not inherently negative, but may end up incurring a high cost.

因此，对上述问题的简单回答是：如果一个计划预期以相同的成本为您带来更高的收益，或者以更低的成本为您带来同等的收益，那么它就比另一个更好。一个稍微更细微的答案允许一个计划可以比另一个更好，即使它的成本略高，只要它的收益也显着更高（同样对于收益略低但成本显着降低的行动）。

So the easy answer to the question above is this: one plan is better than another if it is expected to have a higher benefit to you at the same cost or an equal benefit to you at a lower cost. A slightly more nuanced answer allows that one plan can be better than another even if it has a slightly higher cost as long as its benefit is significantly higher as well (and similarly for actions with slightly lower benefit at significantly lower costs).

所有这些都表明，计划的表述不仅应该包括每个步骤实现的条件（换句话说，它的好处），还应该包括正在发生的成本。（同样，我们不会讨论符号表示细节。）

All of this suggests that a representation for a plan should include not only what conditions are being achieved by each step (its benefit, in other words) but also what costs are being incurred. (Again, we will not discuss the symbolic representational details.)

这并不是说收益和成本都可以在某种统一的尺度上进行比较。有些成本和收益显然是无法比较的。虽然常识不能解决所有的成对比较问题，但可以处理简单的问题，甚至是一些不太明显的问题，也许可以使用之前讨论过的数量级推理之类的东西。例如，虽然我们知道永远不要穿过繁忙的街道会更安全，但我们还是会穿过街道，因为我们知道到达另一边的好处远远超过不去的风险。

This is not to suggest that benefits and costs can all be compared on some uniform scale; some costs and benefits are quite plainly incomparable. Although common sense is not expected to be able to resolve all the pairwise comparisons, it is expected to handle the easy ones, and even some less obvious ones, perhaps using something like the order of magnitude reasoning discussed before. For example, although we know that it would be safer never to cross a busy street, we cross the street anyway because we know that the benefit of getting to the other side far outweighs the risk of not making it.

重新考虑规划

Planning Reconsidered

当谈到计划作为常识推理的一种形式时，我们在前一章中提出，要能够在现场组装可能实现所考虑目标的整个行动序列，要求太高了。这作为益智模式的活动可能还不错，但对于普通常识来说要求太高了。（这个问题在奖励章节中再次出现。）

When it comes to planning as a form of commonsense reasoning, we suggested in the previous chapter that it was asking too much to be able to assemble entire sequences of actions on the spot that might achieve a goal under consideration. This might be fine as a puzzle-mode activity, but it is too demanding for ordinary common sense. (This issue comes up again in the bonus chapter.)

相反，我们建议的是，当一个代理人需要找到一个计划时，它会在它的世界模型中寻找它已经知道的行动。这些行动当然可能是涉及多个步骤的复杂行动——换句话说，是预先制定的计划。代理必须能够在当前状态下执行（可能是复杂的）操作，因为它不会寻找可以使任何先决条件成立的额外准备行动。动作的可执行性是我们在上一章中使用该possible属性所考虑的。此外，对于作为要实现的目标的一部分的每个属性，我们希望能够确定该属性如何受到行为的影响，就像我们在前一章中对门状态所做的那样。所以总的来说，这里需要的那种基于内存的规划将利用和FIND-ALL操作TEST以及之前看到的其他符号机制。使用这些操作，我们应该能够计算出可以使目标条件为真的可执行操作的暂定列表，并可能首先对最熟悉的操作进行排序。

What we proposed instead is that when an agent needs to find a plan, it would go looking in its world model for actions it already knows about. These actions may of course be complex ones involving a number of steps—premade plans, in other words. The agent must be able to perform the (possibly complex) action in the current state since it will not be looking for additional preparatory actions that could make any prerequisites true. The executability of an action is what we considered in the previous chapter using the possible property. Furthermore, for each property that is part of a goal to be achieved, we would expect to be able to determine how that property can be affected by actions, just as we did for door states in the previous chapter. So overall, the sort of memory-based planning that will be required here will make use of the FIND-ALL and TEST operations along with the rest of the symbolic machinery seen before. Using those operations, we should be able to compute a tentative list of the executable actions that can make a goal condition true, sorted perhaps with the most familiar ones first.

寻找一个单一的行动来实现一个目标的想法似乎是一个过于强大的限制。例如，它似乎排除了使用电话联系某人的可能性，因为这可能需要先拿起电话，这有其自身的先决条件。但考虑这一点的一种方式是，打电话给某人实际上是一个（有点复杂的）动作，涉及多个步骤，其中一个步骤是拿起电话。因此，出于基于记忆的计划的目的，给某人打电话的真正先决条件是附近有可用的电话并且知道要拨打的电话号码。其他不太重要的问题，比如需要放下手拿的咖啡杯才能拿起电话，会在实际行动中解决，而不是在计划中解决。

The idea of looking for a single action to achieve a goal might seem like an overly strong restriction. For example, it might appear to rule out using a phone to contact someone since that might require first picking up the phone, with prerequisites of its own. But one way of thinking about this is that phoning someone is in fact one (somewhat complex) action involving a number of steps, one of which is picking up the phone. So for the purposes of memory-based planning, the real prerequisites of phoning someone are having a working phone nearby and knowing the number to call. Other less critical issues, such as needing to put down the coffee cup you are currently holding to be able to pick up the phone, would be sorted out in the actual performance of the action, not in the planning.

我们在这里回避的一个主要并发症涉及需要知识或知识生产的行动。前者是在其先决条件中具有知识条件的动作，例如给某人打电话，这需要知道要拨打的电话号码。后者是一些感知行为，例如查阅电话簿、窥视房间或将脚趾浸入湖中，这些行为并没有改变世界，而是改变了人们对它的了解。为了表示和推理此类行为，需要增强表示语言 L，因为虽然它可以谈论世界上现在或将来的真实情况，但它无法谈论现在或将被相信的事情。

One major complication we are sidestepping here concerns actions that are knowledge requiring or knowledge producing. The former are actions that have knowledge conditions in their prerequisites such as phoning someone, which requires knowing the number to call. The latter are perceptual actions like consulting a telephone directory, peering into a room, or dipping a toe into a lake, which do not change the world so much as change what is known about it. To represent and reason about actions like these, the representation language L would need to be augmented since while it can talk about what is or will be true in the world, it has no way of talking about what is or will be believed.

另一个复杂因素是成本的概念。关注一个动作的副作用很重要——也就是说，我们应该像上一章那样模拟动作产生的变化，然后在下面寻找与目标无关的动作影响的条件考虑（特别是对于具有多个步骤的操作）以确保没有隐藏的障碍或过高的成本（当然包括所需的时间）。

One additional complication is the notion of cost. It is important to keep an eye on the side effects of an action—that is, we should simulate the changes produced by the action as in the previous chapter, and then look for conditions affected by the action that are not related to the goal under consideration (especially for actions that have multiple steps) to ensure that there are no hidden snags or costs that are too high (including of course the time required).

更进一步，让我们简要考虑一下，如果您面临一个新的目标条件，而您尚未考虑可能实现该目标的个人行动，应该会发生什么。一切都没有丢失。您可能仍然能够在您的世界模型中找到处理类似事情的计划。然后，规划过程需要能够采用这些现有计划之一并使用它来构建新计划。

To go a bit further, let us briefly consider what should happen if you are faced with a novel goal condition, where you have not yet contemplated individual actions that might be able to achieve it. All is not lost. You may still be able to find a plan in your world model that deals with something analogous. The planning process would then need to be able to take one of these existing plans and use it to construct a new one.

这种形式的类比实际上如何在计算方面发挥作用？它很复杂，据我们所知，还没有一个完全令人满意的故事。在最简单的情况下，我们想象采取一个我们知道的单独行动，并用它来实例化一个相同的行动，除了不同的东西扮演所讨论的角色——物体、工具等等。这涉及构建一个新的符号表示，如第 7 章中所讨论的。概念模型对这些角色的价值限制将指导手头的哪些事物可能能够扮演所讨论的角色。您可能从未在此支付过账单例如，以前在餐厅，但您在其他类似场所也这样做过。您看到某人修理烤面包机的视频，现在考虑您修理面前烤面包机的类似动作。

How would this form of analogy actually work out in computational terms? It’s complex, and as far as we know, a completely satisfactory story has yet to be told. In the simplest case, we imagine taking an individual action we know about and using it to instantiate one that is identical except with different things playing the roles in question—the object, the instrument, and so on. This involves constructing a new symbolic representation, as discussed in chapter 7. The value restrictions on these roles from the conceptual model would guide which of the things at hand might be able to play the roles in question. You may have never paid the bill at this restaurant before, for example, but you have done so at other similar establishments. You see a video of someone repairing a toaster and now consider the analogous action of you repairing the toaster in front of you.

更一般地说，这个类比过程将涉及寻找一些源域中的个体行为与目标域中的个体行为之间的对应关系。如前所述，这些可能会通过相似性注释之类的东西提前连接起来。然后可以通过将其部分映射到新的目标域来构建与源活动的类似物。例如，作为蹒跚学步的孩子，您可能已经学会了绕着一个物体爬行（比如说向右、向左、向左和向右走）的想法，以此作为通过沙发或躲避可怕的叔叔的一种方式。通过类比，同样的动作可以映射到其他运动模式，例如当你第一次学习走路、游泳、滑雪或骑自行车时绕过障碍物。

More generally, this analogy process would involve finding correspondences between individual actions in some source domain and those in a target domain. These might be connected in advance by something like a similarity annotation, as discussed before. Analogues to a source activity can then be constructed by mapping its parts onto the new target domain. For example, as a toddler, you might have learned the idea of crawling around an object (going right, left, left, and right, say) as a way of getting past a sofa or avoiding a scary uncle. By analogy, this same maneuver can then be mapped onto other modes of locomotion, such as getting around obstacles when you first learn to walk, swim, ski, or ride a bicycle.

一个例子：中断的旅程

An Example: The Interrupted Journey

要了解这些想法在实践中如何实际发挥作用，值得详细研究一个具体的日常案例。我们将想象遵循一个计划，以一种意想不到的方式违反我们的期望，然后使用常识来弄清楚该怎么做。

To see how these ideas might actually work out in practice, it is worth looking at a concrete everyday case in detail. We are going to imagine following a plan, having our expectations violated in an unanticipated way, and then using common sense to figure out what to do.

当然，我们并不期待这里有魔法。尽管未预料到的情况将超出系统的行为参数，但它不应该完全与系统无关。也就是说，我们期望有那种已​​经被考虑用于决定做什么的相关常识性知识。使情况变得新奇和出乎意料的是，这些背景知识与相关行为之间没有直接联系。我们拥有的知识只是关于世界的方式的信息，与任何特定的应用程序或行为无关，当然也与我们遵循的计划无关。同样，我们正在遵循的计划不会预先与出现问题时可能证明相关的所有考虑因素挂钩。

Of course, we are not expecting magic here. Although the unanticipated situation will be outside the behavioral parameters of the system, it should not be totally foreign to the system. That is, we expect there to be relevant commonsense knowledge of the sort already considered to use in deciding what to do. What makes the situation new and unexpected is that there will be no direct connection between this background knowledge and the behavior in question. The knowledge we have is simply information about the way the world is, not tied to any particular application or behavior, and certainly not to the plan we are following. Similarly, the plan we are following will not be tied in advance to all the considerations that may turn out to be relevant when something goes awry.

现在考虑这个场景，第一次出现在本书开头的预览中：

Consider now this scenario, first seen in the preview at the start of the book:

你在一个假期的早上很晚才出发去杂货店买东西准备下午的烧烤。当您开车前往琼斯的杂货店时，您会接近布拉德福德和维多利亚的一个十字路口，您通常会在前往那里的路上经过。交通灯恰好是红色的，所以你停下来等它变绿。这都是例行公事。然而，现在发生了一些奇怪的事情。三分钟过去了，指示灯仍然是红色。五分钟过去了，灯还是红的。您知道，在一些繁忙的十字路口，红灯可能会持续很长时间——超过五分钟。但你也知道这不是其中之一。出了点问题。

You set off late one holiday morning to do some grocery shopping for an afternoon barbecue. As you drive toward Jones’s Grocery Store, you approach an intersection at Bradford and Victoria that you normally drive through on your way there. The traffic light happens to be red, so you stop and wait for it to turn green. This is all routine. Something strange now happens, however. Three minutes go by, and the light stays red. Five minutes go by, and the light is still red. You know that at some busy intersections, a light can stay red for a long time—longer than five minutes. But you also know that this is not one of them. Something is wrong.

你该怎么办？

What should you do?

接下来，我们将探讨一系列突发事件，并找出在每种情况下应该告诉您的常识。但有人可能会问，这些意外事件难道不是原计划的一部分吗？有了足够的经验，我们以前不能从这种情况中吸取教训吗？难道我们不对自己说：“啊哈！旧的红绿灯业务。我上当了！” 我们已经有了可行的计划？答案显然是肯定的. 但我们想象的是一个开放的系统，无论我们有多少经验，无论发生了多少学习，我们迟早会遇到事先没有考虑到的情况。出于此示例的目的，让我们将交通灯卡在红色上作为这些不可预见的事件之一。（如果这看起来太常规，很容易想出更不可能的情况。）

In what follows, we will explore a range of contingencies and figure out what common sense should tell you in each case. But one might ask, Could these contingencies not be part of the original plan? With enough experience, could we not have learned from situations like this before? Might we not have said to ourselves, “Aha! The old traffic-light-stuck-on-red business. I’m on it!” for which we already have workable plans? The answer is clearly yes. But we are imagining an open system, and no matter how much experience we have, and no matter how much learning has taken place, sooner or later we will run into situations that have not been considered in advance. For the purpose of this example, let us imagine a traffic light being stuck on red as one of those unforeseen eventualities. (If this seems too routine, it is easy to come up with even less likely situations.)

那么遇到这样卡住的红绿灯应该怎么办呢？答案当然是视情况而定！没有唯一正确的行动方针；上下文就是一切。这正是需要常识的原因。这我们最好笼统地说，您需要考虑您所处的特定情况，并以常识为指导。正如我们将看到的，根据具体情况，有一个可能相关的因素的开放式列表。

So what should a person do with a stuck traffic light like this? The answer, of course, is it depends! There is no single right course of action; context is everything. This is precisely why common sense is needed. The best we can say in general terms is that you need to consider the particular situation you find yourself in and let common sense be your guide. As we will see, depending on the circumstances, there is an open-ended list of factors that might be relevant.

让我们开始吧。要了解讨论的方位，请参阅图 9.1，其中显示了相关的街道和杂货店、麻烦的交通信号灯，甚至是来自东方的一些遥远的铜管乐的可能来源。在顽固的红灯情况下，最明显的考虑是打右转灯，在 Victoria 右转（在安全的情况下），然后找到替代方法去琼斯的商店，也许走巴里街。在许多情况下，这将是最终的常识性反应。

Let’s get started. To get one’s bearings in the discussion to follow, consult figure 9.1, which shows the relevant streets and grocery stores, the troublesome traffic light, and even a possible source of some distant brassy music coming from the east. Perhaps the most obvious thing to consider doing in the case of a stubborn red light is to put on the right turn signal, make the right-hand turn at Victoria (when it is safe to do so), and then find an alternate way to get to Jones’s store, perhaps taking Barrie Street. In many cases, this will be the final commonsense response.

但很容易想象常识告诉你的情况并非如此。例如，如果您认为红灯一直亮是因为 Victoria 恰好有游行（如预览中所示），那么常识当然不会鼓励您向右转。同样，如果您知道维多利亚是一条走错方向的繁忙单行道，那么常识也不应该告诉您向右转。在某些司法管辖区，红灯右转甚至是不合法的（尽管它最终可能仍是您的最佳选择）。即使转弯是合法的，当来自维多利亚州左侧的交通又快又堵时，您可能无法在信号灯亮时安全转弯。避免右转还有其他原因。例如，您可能知道 Victoria 是高速公路的入口匝道（在我们的图中不是这种情况，但它可能是）。离开高速公路并蜿蜒返回杂货店可能需要相当长的时间。但是，如果其他选择都用尽了，您可能仍需要右转并凑合。

But it is easy to imagine circumstances where common sense should tell you otherwise. For example, if you believe that the light is staying red because there happens to be a parade on Victoria (as in the preview), common sense should certainly not encourage you to turn right. Similarly, if you know that Victoria is a busy one-way street going in the wrong direction, common sense again should not be telling you to turn right. In some jurisdictions, a right turn on red is not even legal (although it might still end up being your best option). And even if the turn is legal, when the traffic coming from the left on Victoria is fast and heavy, you may be unable to make the turn safely while your signal is red. And there are other reasons for avoiding a right turn. For example, you might know that Victoria is the on-ramp to a freeway (this is not the case in our figure, but it could be). It might take considerable time to get off the freeway and wind your way back to the grocery store. If other options are exhausted, however, you might still need to take that right turn and make do.

如果右转维多利亚是一个糟糕的选择，那么常识可能会建议一些其他选择。直闯红灯显然是违法的，但最终可能是您最好的选择，尤其是在维多利亚州交通很少或没有交通的情况下，例如在一条安静的乡村街道上。在 Victoria 左转也是一种可能，但红灯左转几乎肯定比直行更糟糕，而且是最后的选择。否则，在 Bradford 掉头将是更好的选择（除非恰好是繁忙的单行道或分开的高速公路）。如果您的右侧附近有车道（如图所示），那将是进行机动的合理位置。否则你将不得不在街上掉头，这意味着可能会有麻烦来自其他汽车，尤其是快速离开维多利亚的汽车。转身后，快速左转几次进入公园，然后巴里可能会工作，除非有游行，在这种情况下，巴里和维多利亚的十字路口可能会遇到同样的问题。在公园右转也是一种选择，但需要更迂回的路线。最后，你可能想去另一家杂货店（比如史密斯或罗伯特），或者如果情况真的很糟糕，此时完全放弃购物。

If the right turn on Victoria is a bad choice, then common sense might suggest some other options. Going straight through the red light is clearly illegal, but may end up being your best bet, especially if Victoria has little or no traffic, such as on a quiet rural street. A left turn at Victoria is also a possibility, but a left on red is almost certainly worse than going straight and somewhat of a last resort. Otherwise, turning around on Bradford will be the better choice (unless it happens to be a busy one-way street or divided highway). If there is a driveway nearby on your right (as in the figure), it would be a reasonable place for the maneuver. Otherwise you will have to turn around on the street itself, which means that there could be trouble from other cars, especially cars coming quickly off Victoria. Having turned around, making a couple of quick lefts onto Park and then Barrie might work, unless there is a parade coming, in which case the intersection at Barrie and Victoria would likely have the same problem. Turning right at Park is also an option, but for a much more roundabout route. In the end, you may want to go to a different grocery store (like Smith’s or Robert’s), or if things are really dire, give up shopping altogether at this time.

当然，还有许多其他因素可能会影响决定做什么。例如，是否有人站在十字路口中间指挥交通并示意您等待？是警察，还是更像一个十岁的孩子？你前面有车吗？即使有礼貌地按喇叭，那辆车还能停在原地吗？你身后是否也有车在围堵你？维多利亚另一边的布拉德福德似乎被封锁了吗？如果没有，十字路口另一边的司机在做什么？杂货店要开多久？车里有多少汽油（或电荷）？汽车座椅上是否有儿童？这场世纪风暴什么时候来袭？但也许我们已经看够了。

Of course, there are many other factors that might enter into deciding what to do. Is there a person, say, standing in the middle of the intersection directing traffic and signaling you to wait? Is it a police officer, or more like a ten-year-old child? Is there a car ahead of you? Does that car stay put even with a polite toot on the horn? Are there cars behind you as well, boxing you in? Does Bradford on the other side of Victoria appear to be blocked off? If not, what are drivers on the other side of the intersection doing? How much longer is the grocery store going to be open? How much gas (or charge) is there in the car? Is there a child onboard in a car seat? When is that storm-of-the-century supposed to hit? But maybe we have seen enough.

这个例子告诉我们什么常识？主要要观察的是，在这种情况下使用常识既有自上而下的考虑，也有自下而上的考虑。自上而下的目标处理正在追求的目标：开车去商店作为购买杂货计划的一部分作为获取食物计划的一部分。自下而上的方法处理现场检测到的情况：不工作的红灯、十字路口的交通、游行、附近的汽车在做什么、有人在指挥交通，等等。

What does this example tell us about common sense? The main thing to observe is that there are both top-down and bottom-up considerations in using common sense in a situation like this. The top-down ones deal with the goals being pursued: driving to the store as part of a plan to get groceries as part of a plan to obtain food. The bottom-up ones deal with what was detected at the scene: the inoperative red light, the traffic on the cross street, a parade, what nearby cars are doing, somebody directing traffic, and so on.

在接下来的两节中，我们将以更系统的方式讨论这些自上而下和自下而上的问题，并建议如何使用第 7-8 章的机制来应用常识性知识来做出上述常识性决策.

In the next two sections, we will go over these top-down and bottom-up issues in a more systematic way, and suggest how commonsense knowledge gets to be applied using the machinery of chapters 7–8 to make commonsense decisions like those outlined above.

自上而下的常识

Common Sense from the Top Down

让我们从自上而下的推理开始。我们可能会想问问自己，

Let us start with the top-down reasoning. We might think of asking ourselves,

有没有办法不经过那个麻烦的十字路口就可以到达那家杂货店？

Is there a way of getting to that grocery store without going through that troublesome intersection?

不过，这不是正确的问题。如果确实有另一种方式可以到达商店，但在您到达那里时商店已经关门，那么常识不应该支持这种选择。毕竟，此行的目的不是去商店；那只是为了其他更高层次的目标。

This is not the right question, though. If there is indeed another way to get to the store but it will be closed by the time you get there, then common sense should not favor that choice. The point of the trip, after all, was not to get to the store; that was only in service of other, higher-level goals.

所以也许在这里问自己的真正问题更像是这样：

So maybe the real question to ask yourself here is more like this:

以我目前的处境，我应该如何去完成我原本打算做的事情——为烧烤准备食物？

In light of my current situation, how should I go about achieving what I was originally setting out to do—that is, getting food for the barbecue?

如果你只满足于在你现在所处的新环境下获得你想要的食物的最佳方式，那么除了重新考虑你所有的选择并制定一个全新的食物计划之外别无选择从头开始。但同样，这种第一性原理推理很少有实际意义，也不是常识真正应该针对的目标。

If you will settle for nothing less than the best way of obtaining the kind of food you want given the new circumstances you now find yourself in, then there is really no alternative but to reconsider all of your options and construct an entirely new plan for food from scratch. But again, this kind of first-principles reasoning is rarely practical and not really what common sense should be aiming for either.

那么常识在这里做什么呢？这是关键问题。常识如何告诉你在某些情况下向右转，但在其他情况下完全放弃去这家杂货店？我们想建议的是，有一个常识推理过程建立在之前的符号运算之上，并提供此类问题的答案。我们将调用这个过程MODIFY-PLAN并描述它是如何工作的。

So what does common sense do here? This is the critical question. How does common sense come to tell you to turn right in some cases, but to give up on going to this grocery store altogether in others? What we want to suggest is that there is a commonsense reasoning procedure that builds on the symbolic operations from before and provides answers to questions like this. We will call this procedure MODIFY-PLAN and sketch how it works.

让我们想象一下，当我们遇到顽固的红绿灯时，我们正在执行一个结构如图 9.2 所示的计划。（如上所述，我们假设计划的符号结构包含要执行的动作序列以及要实现的目标和子目标，以及每个动作的成本度量。）

Let us imagine that when we encounter the stubborn traffic light, we are in the process of following a plan structured somewhat as shown in figure 9.2. (As noted above, we are assuming a symbolic structure for a plan that contains the sequences of actions to be performed as well as the goals and subgoals to be achieved, and some measure of the cost of each action.)

在这里，非正式地介绍了MODIFY-PLAN对现有计划进行更改的过程，例如上述计划：

Here, presented informally, is the MODIFY-PLAN procedure for making a change to an existing plan like the one above:

  • • 查看给定的计划并考虑失败的最具体的子目标。在此示例中，由于顽固的红灯，未能通过布拉德福德和维多利亚十字路口的目标 (1.B.4)。根据目前已知的当前情况，找出实现此子目标的最佳方法。TEST通过和FIND-ALL如上所述使用基于内存的规划来执行此操作。
  • • Look at the given plan and consider the most specific subgoal that failed. In this example, it was the goal (1.B.4) of getting through the intersection at Bradford and Victoria that failed because of the stubborn red light. Find the best way of achieving just this subgoal given what is now known about the current situation. Use memory-based planning via TEST and FIND-ALL as described above for doing this.
  • • 现在假设您在前面的步骤中找到了一个计划，也许涉及首先在 Victoria 右转，看看它的成本。如果成本不比计划中此子目标的成本高多少最初，更改总体计划以合并这个新的子计划，您就完成了。
  • • Now assuming you found a plan in the previous step, maybe one that involves first turning right at Victoria, look at its cost. If the cost is not much higher than what you had for this subgoal in the plan originally, change the overall plan to incorporate this new subplan, and you’re done.
  • • 但是，如果在上一步中没有找到任何计划，或者如果成本差异太大，请再次返回给定计划并考虑立即产生该子目标的目标。在本例中，目标 (1.B) 是开车去琼斯的杂货店。（我们正试图通过十字路口，因为我们正试图开车去琼斯家。）找到在当前情况下实现该目标的最佳方法。同样，使用基于记忆的计划。现在这可能涉及不同的路线。如果这条新路线的成本并不比您原来路线的成本高多少，请合并这个新的子计划，然后您就可以继续了。
  • • But if no plan was found in the previous step or if the difference in cost is too high, go back to the given plan again and consider the goal that gave immediate rise to that subgoal. In this instance, it was the goal (1.B) of driving to Jones’s Grocery Store. (We were trying to get through the intersection because we were trying to drive to Jones’s.) Find the best way of achieving just that goal in the current situation. Again, use memory-based planning. This might now involve a different route. If this new route has a cost that is not much higher than what you had for the original route, incorporate this new subplan, and again you’re good to go.
  • • 如果没有，再次查看计划并考虑下一个更高层次的目标。在这种情况下，目标 (1) 是去一家卖好牛排的杂货店。（我们开车去 Jones's 是因为我们想去一家卖好牛排的商店。）看看现在如何最好地实现这个目标在当前情况下以及额外费用是多少。现在这可能涉及开车去另一家杂货店。同样，如果到这家新店的成本合理，那么采用新的子计划，然后就可以走了。
  • • If not, look at the plan again and consider the next higher-level goal. In this case, it was the goal (1) of getting to some grocery store that sells good steaks. (We were driving to Jones’s because we were trying to get to a store with good steaks.) See how that goal might now be best achieved in the current situation and at what extra cost. This might now involve driving to a different grocery store. Again, if the cost of getting to this new store is reasonable, then adopt the new subplan, and away you go.
  • • 必要时继续这样做，或直到达到最高目标。
  • • Continue like this as necessary or until the top-level goal is reached.

此MODIFY-PLAN过程用新计划替换现有计划，但它会查找在某种程度上与原始计划相似的计划。在最坏的情况下，您可能最终不得不重新考虑整个顶级目标，但在大多数情况下，您只会处理更具体的子目标，例如通过麻烦的十字路口的替代方法。

This MODIFY-PLAN procedure replaces an existing plan with a new one, but it looks for plans that are similar in a certain way to the original one. In the worst case, you might end up having to reconsider the entire top-level goal, yet in most situations, you will only deal with much more specific subgoals like alternative ways of getting through the troublesome intersection.

为了避免不得不重新考虑计划中的顶级目标，在执行过程中默许更高的成本是有意义的MODIFY-PLAN。例如，我们可能最初拒绝将右转作为通过十字路口的方式所涉及的成本，但随后在程序的后期，当我们意识到右转时决定接受计划中更高的相同成本那个转弯将是前往任何杂货店的最佳方式。

To avoid having to reconsider the top-level goals in a plan, it makes sense to acquiesce to ever higher costs during the execution of MODIFY-PLAN. For example, we might initially reject the cost involved in making a right turn as a way of getting through the intersection, but then, later in the procedure, decide to accept that same cost higher up in the plan when we come to realize that making that turn will be the best way of getting to any grocery store.

在杂货店购物的例子中，MODIFY-PLAN上面的推理过程首先会询问是否有其他方法可以通过十字路口（步骤 1.B.4）。事实证明，大多数具有少量经验的驾驶员确实知道实现此目标的第二种（合法）方法。这个动作没有名字，但它是这样的：右转，然后掉头，然后再右转。（不耐烦的司机有时会用这个动作来避免等长红灯。）即使是没有经验的司机也应该知道如何绕过障碍物——向右、向左、向左和向右——就像我们之前看到的那样。此举会让您越过十字路口，但会让您走得更远。所以假设基于记忆的规划可以在世界模型中找到像这样的行动，唯一剩下的问题就是成本。

In the grocery shopping illustration, the MODIFY-PLAN reasoning procedure above would first ask if there was some other way of getting through the intersection (step 1.B.4). As it turns out, most drivers with a modicum of experience will indeed know a second (legal) way of achieving this goal. The maneuver has no name, but it goes like this: make a right turn, then a U-turn, and then another right turn. (Impatient drivers sometimes use this move to avoid waiting for long red lights.) Even inexperienced drivers would be expected to know about getting around obstacles—going right, left, left, and right—as we saw before. This move gets you past the intersection, but puts you farther down the road. So assuming memory-based planning can find actions like these in the world model, the only remaining issue is the cost.

对于这种右转右转的操作，每次右转都会产生成本，但让我们忽略这些，只考虑掉头。（关于我们如何计算和记住这些动作的成本，这本身就是一个有趣的问题，但很明显，规则的、不受阻碍的右转经常发生，以至于它们变得无意识或低成本，而掉头需要更仔细的感知活动、对合法性的担忧以及注意两个不同方向的交通。）关于掉头的成本，我们可以提前知道什么？努力、时间和不便是都可以忽略不计；真正的问题是风险。如果我们靠近右侧的另一个十字路口，并且在一个欢迎在十字路口掉头的司法管辖区，那么掉头的风险就会很低；否则，如果我们可以在附近有左转交通信号灯的十字路口进行转弯（这样就不会有其他车辆驶来），风险就很低；或者，如果要在十字路口中间掉头，则根据该街道上的交通情况，风险介于中等和极高之间。

For this right-U-right maneuver, each right turn will have a cost, but let us ignore those and consider just the U-turn. (It is an interesting question in itself as to how we calculate and remember the costs of these actions, but it is clear that regular, unimpeded right turns happen so frequently that they become mindless or low cost, whereas U-turns require more careful perceptual activities, concerns about legality, and paying attention to traffic going in two different directions.) What can we be expected to know in advance about the cost of making a U-turn? The effort, time, and inconvenience are all negligible; the real issue is the risk. If we are close to another intersection on the right and in a jurisdiction where U-turns at intersections are welcomed, the risk of a U-turn will be low; otherwise, if we can perform the turn at a nearby intersection with a left turn traffic signal (so that no traffic will be coming the other way), the risk is low; or otherwise, if the U-turn is to be made in the middle of the cross street, the risk is somewhere between medium and extremely high according to the traffic on that street.

根据当前情况，当然可能有其他方式以更低的成本通过十字路口。然而最终，如果实现特定子目标的成本太高，常识表明我们需要重新考虑更高层次的目标，如上文所述。

Depending on the current situation, there may of course be other ways of getting through the intersection at a lower cost. Yet in the end, if the cost of achieving a particular subgoal is too high, common sense dictates that we will need to reconsider higher-level goals, as sketched above.

自下而上的常识

Common Sense from the Bottom Up

现在让我们转向常识所需的自下而上推理。当然，有时您需要立即对情况做出反应，而无需多加考虑。如果一块石头砸穿了你的挡风玻璃，或者你前面的汽车突然起火，那么现在不是考虑去杂货店的好处的时候。在某种程度上，当路上的警察指着你并指示你开车去某个地方时，也是如此。在这种情况下，您不会真正就该做什么做出合理的决定。你的反应——或者至少是你的直接反应——将更少受常识控制，而更多地受反射或条件动作规则之类的东西控制。

Let us now turn to the bottom-up reasoning needed for common sense. Certainly there are times when you need to react to a situation immediately without much additional thought. If a rock smashes through your windshield or the car in front of you suddenly bursts into flames, then this is not the time to ponder the fine points of getting to a grocery store. To a certain extent, this is also true when a police officer on the road points at you and directs you to drive somewhere. In cases like these, you will not really be making reasoned decisions about what to do. Your reaction—or at least your immediate one—would be controlled less by common sense and more by something like a reflex, or perhaps a condition-action rule.

但并不是所有的反应都是这样的。在不那么紧急的情况下，您需要深思熟虑地决定要做什么。认为对新情况的反应必须总是立即下意识的反应，或者认为常识仅在事后用于合理化或重构发生的行为的想法是错误的。利用你在现场所知道的知识的能力使你能够选择如何以明智的方式做出反应。

But not all reactions are like this. In less urgent cases, you will want to make a thoughtful decision about what to do. It is a mistake to think that reactions to new situations must always be immediate knee-jerk ones, or that common sense is only used after the fact to rationalize or reconstruct the behavior that took place. The ability to make use of what you know on the spot is what allows you to choose how to react in a sensible way.

在上面的杂货店购物示例中，最初购买杂货的计划失败了，因为预期的事情没有发生。但除此之外，现场可能没有任何异常。在那种情况下，自下而上的推理将（相对）简单明了。在决定做什么时，你主要需要利用到达十字路口之前的知识和周围场景的一些具体细节：你的车里有多少乘客，十字路口的交通情况，其他汽车面向哪个方向，哪些停放等等，所有这些都应该反映在您当前的世界模型中。

In the grocery shopping example above, the original plan to get the groceries failed because something expected did not happen. But beyond that, there may have been nothing out of the ordinary at the scene. In that case, the bottom-up reasoning would be (relatively) straightforward. In deciding what to do, you will mainly need to use the knowledge you had before you arrived at the intersection and some specific details about the scene around you: how many passengers are in your car, the traffic on the cross street, which way other cars are facing, which ones are parked, and so on, all of which should be reflected in your current world model.

你事先知道的一些事情涉及关于你的世界的基本事实。例如，您将知道如何去杂货店，但可能还会知道如果必须右转，您将如何到达那里。换句话说，假设这是一条熟悉的路线，您将在脑海中绘制出您所在的位置以及如何到达目的地的地图。这并不是说你的头脑中需要某种二维笛卡尔表示，如图 9.1 中的图像。你需要的是一个世界模型，它可以让你自己定位：什么道路连接到什么方向的什么十字路口。世界模型的这一部分就像您所在区域的模拟，就像二维地图一样。如果这不是一条熟悉的路线，您可能需要查阅地图或导航设备来构建某种内部地图。

Some of what you knew in advance concerns basic facts about your world. You will know how to get to the grocery store, for instance, but probably also how you would get there if you had to turn right. In other words, assuming this is a familiar route, you will have a mental map of where you are and how to get to where you are going. This is not to suggest that you need some sort of two-dimensional Cartesian representation in your head such as the image in figure 9.1. What you need is a world model that will enable you to orient yourself: what roads are connected to what intersections in what directions. This part of a world model acts like an analogue of your locale, just like a two-dimensional map would. If this is not a familiar route, you may need to consult a map or navigation aid to build some sort of internal map. Your world model would probably come with additional information about the roads, freeways, one-way restrictions, and trouble spots.

然而，自下而上的推理更多地涉及到现场发生意想不到的事情。在这种情况下，很可能直接周围的新事物最终决定了下一步该做什么。为了解决这个问题，你需要能够识别一个事物，不仅是某种基本类型，比如山羊、绷带或卡车，而且还需要根据它对后续行动的暗示，或者心理学家所说的它的可供性：你可以坐在上面的东西，可以扔的东西，或者可以写的东西，更一般地说，你可以使用的东西，可以忽略的东西，或者可以积极避免的东西。

Where bottom-up reasoning gets more involved, however, is when something unexpected takes place at the scene. In that case, there may well be new things in the immediate surroundings that end up determining what to do next. To sort this out, you need to be able to recognize a thing not just as being of some fundamental type, like a goat, bandage, or truck, say, but also in terms of what it suggests for subsequent action, or what psychologists call its affordances: something you can sit on, something to throw, or something to write with, and more generally, something you can make use of, something to ignore, or something to actively avoid.

这种自下而上的推理是如何发生的？从广义上讲，需要发生的事情是需要根据概念结构对所讨论的事物进行分类和理解。这是第 7 章中介绍的概念模型（与世界模型不同）发挥直接作用的地方。总的来说，您需要根据必须使用的概念集合来理解事物。对于每个这样的概念，您都会问自己，所讨论的事物会是其中之一吗？如果它是其中之一，是否表明存在其他需要注意的东西？如果过马路的是成年鸭子，后面不远处会不会有小鸭子？如果它是一辆翻倒的皮卡车，它的内容是否会在您视线之外洒在路上？

How does this bottom-up reasoning take place? In broad terms, what needs to happen is that the thing in question needs to be classified and understood in terms of a conceptual structure. This is one place where the conceptual model presented in chapter 7 (as distinct from the world model) gets to play a direct role. Overall, you will need to make sense of the thing according to the collection of concepts you have to work with. For each such concept, you ask yourself, Could the thing in question be one of those? And if it is one of those, does that suggest the presence of something else to watch for? If it’s an adult duck crossing the road, might there be baby ducks not far behind? If it’s an overturned pickup truck, might its contents have spilled on the road just out of your line of sight?

此过程由概念模型中的层次结构驱动。对于任何给定的概念，我们可以通过概念相关概念的模型：在一种情况下，我们想知道一个概念的实例是否也可能是另一个概念的实例（概念模型的分类“成为”部分）；在另一种情况下，我们想知道一个概念的实例是否可以在另一个实例中发挥作用（概念模型的“有”部分）。正如第 6 章在明斯基框架的上下文中所建议的那样，在某种程度上相似或相关的概念之间可能存在其他有用的联系。

This process is driven by the hierarchical organization in the conceptual model. For any given concept, we can look through the conceptual model for related concepts: in one case, we want to know if instances of one concept might also be instances of another (the taxonomic “to be” part of the conceptual model); in the other case, we want to know if instances of one concept might have a role to play in instances of another (the “to have” part of the conceptual model). There may be other useful connections among concepts that are similar or related somehow, as suggested in chapter 6 in the context of Minsky frames.

在杂货店购物的情况下，假设在等待绿灯时，您观察到——也许以一种与上下文无关的方式——一个人走在十字路口，他恰好有一个圆圆的红鼻子。怎么办？在问自己与什么样的人打交道时（查看概念模型中的子概念），您可能会推测此人是小丑，然后通过寻找和发现其他东西（例如大软底鞋）来证实这一点。但你不止于此。您可能想知道小丑在这条十字路口做什么，并问自己这是否是现场其他事物的一部分。然后你可能会推测（再次使用你的概念模型）小丑是游行队伍的一部分——它的存在可能会被远处一支尚未出现的行进乐队的音乐所证实。

In the grocery shopping situation, suppose that while waiting for the light to turn green, you observe—in a context-independent way perhaps—a person walking on the cross street who happens to have a round red nose. What to make of that? In asking yourself what kind of person you are dealing with (looking through subconcepts in your conceptual model), you might conjecture that the person is a clown, and then confirm this by looking for and finding other things like big floppy shoes. But you don’t stop there. You might wonder what a clown is doing on this cross street, and ask yourself whether it is part of something else on the scene. You might then conjecture (using your conceptual model again) that the clown is part of a parade—something whose presence might be confirmed by distant music from an as-yet-unseen marching band. You might then continue by asking what kind of parade this might be, and whether the parade is playing a role as part of something else, and so on.

这种自下而上的分类与正在考虑的自上而下的计划有直接关系。一旦您认识到十字路口存在游行（并将其纳入世界模型），一些前往杂货店的潜在计划最终将被拒绝。同样，识别出其他事物的存在（例如附近电线杆上的开关，用于手动改变交通信号灯）将使您能够考虑自上而下的计划，否则这些计划可能被认为不合适。最后，这就是如何回答这个问题：这是什么样的事情，在此基础上并考虑到我正在努力完成的事情，我接下来应该做什么？

This sort of bottom-up classification has a direct bearing on the top-down plans being considered. Once you recognize the presence of a parade on the cross street (and incorporate this into the world model), some of the potential plans for getting to the grocery store will end up being rejected. Similarly, recognizing the presence of other things (like a switch on a nearby telephone pole for manually changing the traffic light) will allow you to consider top-down plans that might have been judged unsuitable otherwise. In the end, this is how to answer the question: What kind of thing is this, and on that basis and given what I’m trying to accomplish, what should I be doing next?

常识如何运作：回顾

How Common Sense Works: Recap

在了解了常识的自上而下和自下而上的两个方面之后，让我们退后一步，总结一下我们在本章以及之前的章节中讲述的关于常识计算的故事。

Having looked at both the top-down and bottom-up aspects of common sense, let us step back and summarize the story we have told about the computation of common sense in this chapter as well as those that preceded it.

我们的立场是，常识是一种特定的能力——具体来说，是一种利用特定背景知识来决定做什么的能力。常识性知识是关于世界上的事物及其具有的属性，由我们所谓的概念结构介导，概念结构是关于可能存在的事物种类及其可能具有的属性种类的想法的集合。知识将通过符号化表示并在这些符号结构上执行计算操作来使用。关于做什么的常识性决定相当于使用这种代表的知识来考虑如何实现目标以及如何对观察到的情况做出反应。

Our position has been that common sense is a certain ability—specifically, an ability to make use of certain background knowledge in deciding what to do. Commonsense knowledge is about the things in the world and the properties they have, mediated by what we called a conceptual structure, a collection of ideas about the kinds of things there could be, and the kinds of properties they could have. Knowledge would be put to use by representing it symbolically and performing computational operations over those symbolic structures. The commonsense decisions about what to do would amount to using this represented knowledge to consider how to achieve goals and how to react to what has been observed.

在第 5 章中，我们认为上面的故事预设了某种世界观：我们必须能够根据因事件而改变的事物和属性来思考世界，其中一些事件是由代理人执行的动作。在第 6 章中，我们认识到概念结构必须处理边界模糊的概念，以及典型和例外情况。在第 7 章中，我们研究了构建世界状态的符号模型和作为知识表示的概念结构。在第 8 章中，我们研究了如果根据表示的知识公式为真，需要计算什么，在某些事件发生后它是否为真，以及所涉及的主体是否有可能使这些事件发生。

In chapter 5, we argued that the story above presupposed a certain worldview: we had to be able to think of the world in terms of things and properties that change as a result of events, where some of those events were actions performed by agents. In chapter 6, we recognized that a conceptual structure had to deal with concepts with indistinct boundaries, and both typical and exceptional cases. In chapter 7, we looked at building symbolic models of states of the world and conceptual structures as representations of knowledge. In chapter 8, we looked at what it would take to compute if a formula was true according to this represented knowledge, whether it would be true after some events took place, and whether it was possible for the agent involved to make those events occur.

最后，在本章中，我们回到了对常识本身的分析。我们认为，如果有足够的经验，通常可以在没有任何常识的情况下凑合使用。然而，当意外发生时，我们需要能够以自上而下和自下而上的方式利用我们所知道的。自上而下的推理涉及审视我们所知道的行动，包括类似领域的行动，以找到其他合理的方式来实现已受阻的目标；自下而上的推理涉及审视我们所知道的概念，看看观察到的东西是否会对我们试图实现的目标产生影响。这两种形式的推理都需要迅速并协同运作，以就该做什么做出有效的决定，

Finally, in this chapter, we returned to the analysis of common sense itself. We argued that with enough experience, it is often possible to make do without anything like common sense. When something unanticipated happens, however, we need to be able to make use of what we know in both a top-down and bottom-up way. The top-down reasoning involves looking through the actions we know about, including those in analogous areas, to find other reasonable ways of achieving goals that have been stymied; the bottom-up reasoning involves looking through the concepts we know about to see if something observed could have a bearing on the goals we are trying to achieve. Both of these forms of reasoning need to function expeditiously and in tandem to make effective decisions about what to do, and we saw how the symbolic representation and reasoning of chapters 7–8 provided the necessary ingredients.

当然，常识不仅仅是从例行公事中摆脱出来的。但至少对于这一部分，据我们估计，这就是常识的运作方式。

Of course, there is more to common sense than being jolted out of a routine. But for that part of it at least, this, in our estimation, is how common sense works.

请注意，此帐户并未为认知主体设计计算架构，常识位于荣誉位置附近的顶部。事实上，它根本没有解释常识如何管理和控制代理人的整体行为。原因很简单：在我们看来，这不是正确的思考方式。一个有常识的代理人不会变成某种行动哲学家，不断地问自己，“根据我所知道的和我想要的，我接下来真正应该做什么？” 相反，我们假设代理人将继续受习惯和例行公事的支配，或者可能是本章开头讨论的那种不断发展的规则集合。只有当这种情况崩溃时才会诉诸常识：新的事情发生了，预期的事情失败了，或者出现的事情本身表明需要格外小心或正念。这是我们期望看到更深思熟虑的行为形式的时候，代理人会问自己它的目标是什么，它对当前情况了解多少，等等，如图所示。如果这张图片至少大致正确，那么就没有常识的整体认知架构。常识在代理人的心理生活中只起次要作用，使习惯和惯例比其他情况下更加灵活、多才多艺和稳健——也更聪明。如果这张图片至少大致正确，那么就没有常识的整体认知架构。常识在代理人的心理生活中只起次要作用，使习惯和惯例比其他情况下更加灵活、多才多艺和稳健——也更聪明。如果这张图片至少大致正确，那么就没有常识的整体认知架构。常识在代理人的心理生活中只起次要作用，使习惯和惯例比其他情况下更加灵活、多才多艺和稳健——也更聪明。

Notice that this account does not lay out a computational architecture for a cognitive agent, with common sense somewhere near the top in a position of honor. In fact, it does not explain at all how the overall behavior of an agent would be managed and controlled by common sense. The reason is simple: in our opinion, this is not the right way to think about it. An agent with common sense does not turn into some sort of philosopher of action, constantly asking itself, “According to what I know and what I want, what should I really be doing next?” Instead, we imagine that the agent would continue to be governed by habits and routines, or perhaps an evolving collection of rules of the sort discussed at the start of this chapter. An appeal would be made to common sense only when this breaks down: something new happens, something expected fails to, or something presents itself that suggests extra care or mindfulness is called for. This is when we would expect to see a much more deliberate form of behavior, an agent asking itself what its goals are, what it knows about its current situation, and so on, as seen here. If this picture is at least roughly right, then there is no overall cognitive architecture for common sense. Common sense has only a subordinate role to play in the mental life of an agent, making habits and routines much more flexible, versatile, and robust—more intelligent—than they would otherwise be.

10

10

实施步骤

Steps toward Implementation

水上行走非一日建成。

Walking on water wasn’t built in a day.

——杰克·凯鲁亚克，“一些西方俳句”

—Jack Kerouac, “Some Western Haikus”

当我们开始结束对常识的研究时，是时候停下来思考一下被绕过或只是匆匆一瞥的话题。在这短短的一章中，我们想关注一个我们根本没有真正花时间讨论的具体问题：实际构建具有常识的人工智能系统需要什么？即使在本书到目前为止考虑了所有内容之后，我们也不会假装剩下的只是更多相同或几天的例行工作。如果有那么容易，早就有人做到了。但我们确实想简要调查一下我们认为涉及的内容。

As we begin to wind down our study of common sense, it is a good time to pause for a moment to reflect on topics that were either bypassed or given only a passing glance. In this short chapter, we want to focus on one specific question that we did not really spend any time on at all: What would it take in practical terms to actually build an AI system with common sense? Even after everything considered so far in this book, we are not going to pretend that what is left is just more of the same or a few days of routine work. If it were that easy, somebody would have done it by now. But we do want to survey briefly what we think is involved.

我们的观点在本书中反复出现，即常识是一种将我们所谓的常识性知识充分利用的能力。我们讨论了所涉及的知识种类，这些知识如何以符号形式表示，以及如何使用它真的意味着为了特定目的以特定方式处理符号结构，我们称之为常识推理。因此，要真正构建具有常识的 AI 系统，我们需要考虑构建两件事：一个常识推理器和一个常识知识库，供其工作。

Our view, repeated throughout this book, is that common sense is an ability to put what we called commonsense knowledge to good use. We talked about the kind of knowledge involved, how this knowledge could be represented in symbolic form, and how putting it to use really meant processing the symbolic structures in a certain way for certain purposes, which we called commonsense reasoning. So to actually build an AI system with common sense, we need to think about building two things: a commonsense reasoner, and a commonsense knowledge base for it to work on.

建立一个常识推理者

Building a Commonsense Reasoner

让我们先来推理。我们可能会问，人类的常识性推理从何而来？例如，如果我们被告知杰克是看着安妮，我们立即得出结论，杰克在看某个人，而无需被告知如何弄清楚这一点。如果我们被告知巴巴尔是一头大象并且已经知道大象长什么样，那么没有人需要告诉我们如何应用大象的知识来得出有关巴巴尔的颜色或耳朵大小的初步结论。人类在这种情况下进行的推理是合乎逻辑的，但它是一种基本形式的逻辑，不需要在课堂上或从教科书中学习。

Let’s take the reasoning first. We might ask, Where does commonsense reasoning come from in humans? For example, if we are told that Jack is looking at Anne, we immediately come to the conclusion that Jack is looking at somebody, without having to be told how to figure this out. If we are told that Babar is an elephant and already know what elephants are like, nobody has to tell us how to apply that elephant knowledge to draw tentative conclusions about Babar’s color or the size of his ears. The reasoning that humans perform in cases like these is logical, but it is logic of a basic form that does not need to be learned in a classroom or from a textbook.

但是这个逻辑从何而来呢？就人类而言，这是发展心理学的一个复杂课题。这显然不是通过学习一些专门的程序获得的能力，比如如何求解线性方程组或制作烤阿拉斯加。真正的问题是推理是否是我们所有人都凭借作为人类（除非出现问题）而获得的东西，例如长头发的能力，或者它是否是我们仅以基本形式获得但随后必须发展的东西，例如作为扔足球的能力。人们真的可以在常识推理方面做得更好吗？整个自助行业似乎旨在帮助人们更有效地做到这一点：更有条理、更专注、更专注、更善于区分相关与无关的事物，并且不太容易出现精神错乱。《高效能人士的七个习惯》似乎主要针对公司经理，好像这种效率不太受钣金工人的关注。）

But where does this logic come from? In the case of humans, this is a complex subject for developmental psychology. It is clearly not an ability acquired by learning some specialized procedures to follow, like how to solve a system of linear equations or make Baked Alaska. The real question is whether the reasoning is something we all just get by virtue of being human (unless something goes wrong) like the ability to grow hair, or whether it is something we get only in rudimentary form, but then have to develop, such as the ability to throw a football. Can people actually get better at commonsense reasoning? There is an entire self-help industry that seems to be geared to helping people be more effective at it: better organized, better focused and attentive, better at separating the relevant from the irrelevant, and less prone to mental flubs. (Curiously, books like The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People appear to be aimed mainly at corporate managers, as if this effectiveness was less of a concern for, say, sheet metal workers.)

然而，对于机器，我们别无选择，只能卷起袖子手动编写所有这些形式的推理代码。是的，如果所有必要的推理过程都可以通过某种机器学习过程自发出现，那就太好了。但在这一点上，这是一个艰难的赌注。有一些结果表明某些专门的神经网络架构实际上可以学习程序（例如二进制数的乘法），但这些目前看起来更像是一个绝技演示，而不是构建系统的实用方法。

In the case of machines, however, we see no alternative but to roll up our sleeves and code all these forms of reasoning by hand. Yes, it would be nice if all the necessary reasoning procedures could emerge spontaneously through some sort of machine learning process. But at this point, this is a tough bet to take. There are some results indicating that certain specialized neural net architectures can actually learn procedures (such as the multiplication of binary numbers), but these currently look more like a tour de force demonstration than a practical methodology for building systems.

从积极的方面来看，我们的感觉是应该只执行几十个推理程序，而不是像 Cyc 这样的系统建议的数千个。这些程序属于前面章节中讨论或提到的那种。我们对程序进行了相当详细的说明，例如GET-PARTS、TEST和MODIFY-PLAN。但我们只是勾勒出可能涉及的内容，例如实例化概念、模拟更改、处理不一致或使用注释，例如强度或重要性。我们几乎没有谈到自下而上的调用、类比和相似性的使用、情境的识别以及常识在更大的认知架构中的整体定位和协调。在这些事情及其整合方面仍有许多艰苦的工作要做。

On the positive side, our sense is that there should only be dozens of reasoning procedures to implement rather than the thousands suggested by systems like Cyc. These procedures would be of the kind discussed or alluded to in previous chapters. We gave fairly detailed accounts of procedures like GET-PARTS, TEST, and MODIFY-PLAN. But we only sketched what might be involved in things such as instantiating concepts, simulating change, dealing with inconsistencies, or making use of annotations like strength or importance. And we said almost nothing about bottom-up invocation, the use of analogy and similarity, the recognition of situations, and the overall position and coordination of common sense in a larger cognitive architecture. Much hard work remains to be done on these things and their integration.

建立常识性知识库

Building a Commonsense Knowledge Base

现在让我们转向常识性知识。在这里我们不能指望只有几十个项目需要考虑。如果有关医院的知识算作一个，有关生日聚会的知识算作两个，那么我们应该预计会涉及数万甚至数十万项。所有这些知识将从何而来？

Let us now turn to commonsense knowledge. Here we cannot expect there to be only dozens of items to consider. If knowledge about hospitals counts as one, and knowledge about birthday parties counts as two, then we should expect tens or maybe hundreds of thousands of items to be involved. Where is all of this knowledge going to come from?

从人的角度来说，就清楚多了。如第 1 章所述：

In terms of humans, it is much clearer. As stated in chapter 1:

在某些情况下，我们通过反复的经验获得理解（例如如何在炎热的夏日吃到融化的冰淇淋甜筒）；在某些情况下，我们会从朋友那里得到建议（比如参加派对穿什么，不穿什么）；在其他情况下，我们的理解很可能来自指南或手册之类的东西（例如如何设置家用打印机）。

In some cases, we get our understanding through repeated experience (like how to eat a melting ice cream cone on a hot summer day); in some cases, we get advice from friends (such as what to wear—and not wear—for a party); and in other cases, our understanding may well come from something like a guide or manual (like how to set up a home printer).

换句话说，对于人类来说，一些知识来自个人经验的第一手资料，还有一些来自其他人的语言（口头或书面）的二手资料。

In other words, for humans, some of the knowledge comes firsthand from personal experience, and some of it comes secondhand from the language of other humans (spoken or written).

对于机器？既然我们真的不能指望深度学习能够交付货物（至少不是以任何明显的方式），我们是否必须本着 Cyc 的精神，放弃自己手动构建这些庞大的知识库？也许其中一些知识必须由人手工制作，但让我们探索可能的替代方案。

And for machines? Since we cannot really expect deep learning to deliver the goods (at least not in any obvious way), do we have to resign ourselves to building these enormous knowledge bases by hand, in the spirit of Cyc? Maybe some of this knowledge will have to be handcrafted by people, but let us explore the possible alternatives.

对于人类通过语言获得的知识——即在某处写下来或记录下来供人类使用的知识——尝试找到一种方法让机器利用这些信息当然是有意义的，我们将讨论更多关于下面的前景。

For knowledge that humans get through language—that is, knowledge that has been written down or recorded somewhere for humans to use—it would certainly make sense to try to find a way to get machines to avail themselves of that information, and we will talk more about that prospect below.

但是对于人类通过个人经验获得的知识，我们是否应该期望机器有类似的经验并以类似的方式从中学习？如果这对人类来说需要很多年，那么对机器来说是否也一样？在 Ted Chiang 的精彩科幻故事“软件对象的生命周期”中，我们发现：

But for knowledge that humans get through personal experience, should we expect machines to have similar experiences and learn from them in a similar way? If this takes many years for humans, will it be the same for machines? In a wonderful science fiction story called “The Lifecycle of Software Objects” by Ted Chiang, we find this:

没有捷径；如果你想创造来自世界上二十年的常识，你需要投入二十年的时间来完成这项任务。您无法在更短的时间内组装出等效的启发式集合；经验在算法上是不可压缩的。

There are no shortcuts; if you want to create the common sense that comes from twenty years of being in the world, you need to devote twenty years to the task. You can’t assemble an equivalent collection of heuristics in less time; experience is algorithmically incompressible.

也许这是真的。然而，即使经验本身是不可压缩的，一些需要从中学习的东西可能仍然是可压缩的。让我们尝试更具体地了解所涉及的知识种类。

Maybe this is true. Even if experiences themselves are incompressible, though, some of what needs to be learned from them might still be compressible. Let us try to be more specific about the kind of knowledge involved.

经验知识

Knowledge from Experience

关于个人体验的关键观察是：它们是由感官调节的。除非你看到、触摸、闻到等等，否则你无法体验物质世界中的某样东西。为简单起见，让我们将注意力限制在视觉体验上。（人类也会在没有感知的情况下在内部体验事物，但我们现在将忽略这一点。）

The key observation when it comes to personal experiences is this: they are mediated by the senses. You cannot experience something in the physical world unless you see it, touch it, smell it, and so on. For simplicity, let us restrict our attention to visual experiences. (Humans also experience things internally without sensing them, but we will ignore that at this point.)

通过特别关注感官和视觉，我们并不意味着我们对世界的体验主要是被动的。例如，考虑触觉。我们当然可以触摸喇叭之类的物体，但更重要的是，我们可以拿起它并对其采取行动。我们感觉到它的重量、硬度和质地。我们把它翻过来，从不同的角度看到它的光泽，用指甲轻敲它，然后听到金属环的声音。我们可以移动阀门，但无法移动吹嘴。我们将一种覆盆子吹入吹嘴中，然后听到结果。这就是我们认识小号的方式。这些体验是感官的，甚至可能是感性的，但它们也是积极参与物质世界的一部分。

By focusing on the senses and vision in particular, we do not mean to suggest that our experience of the world is primarily passive. Consider the sense of touch, for example. We can certainly touch an object like a trumpet, say, but more important, we can pick it up and act on it. We feel its weight, rigidity, and texture. We turn it over, see its sheen from different angles, rap it with a fingernail, and then hear the metallic ring. We can move the valves but fail to move the mouthpiece. We blow a kind of raspberry into the mouthpiece and hear the result. This is how we get to know trumpets. The experiences are sensory or maybe even sensual, but they are also part of an active engagement with the physical world.

我们显然期望从一生的视觉体验中获得的一件事是识别事物的能力。如前所述，您看到足够多的消防车（或它们的图像），能够以上下文无关的方式可靠地识别出一辆。这很可能通过深度学习之类的东西来完成。掌握了这些知识后，您就可以将获得的感知参数集连接到代表消防车的世界模型中的符号——比如说，——然后从那里连接到概念上相关事物的符号，如梯子、软管Truck#95、消防员和火灾事件。（这会让你在想到一辆消防车时也能联想到消防车。）值得注意的是，这种形式的符号接地仅适用于代表我们之前所说的中间宏对象的符号。代表我们其他事物的符号想想，像政党和财产税，不能以这种方式为基础。

One thing we clearly expect to acquire from a lifetime of visual experiences is the ability to recognize things. You see enough fire trucks (or images of them) to be able to reliably recognize one in a context-free way, as suggested before. This might well be done through something like deep learning. With this learning in hand, you would then be in a position to connect the set of perceptual parameters acquired to a symbol in a world model representing a fire truck—say, Truck#95—and from there to symbols for conceptually related things like ladders, hoses, firefighters, and fire events. (This would allow you to conjure an image of a fire truck whenever you were thinking about one too.) It is worth noting that this form of symbol grounding only works for symbols that represent what we earlier called medial macro-objects. Symbols standing for the other things we think about, like political parties and property taxes, cannot be grounded in this way.

但是，从视觉经验中学习的似乎比如何识别或形象化事物更多。亲眼了解人们在冬天穿暖和的衣服怎么样？通过视觉感知获得这种知识更难解释。正如我们在第 4 章中看到的，视觉图像不适合这种思考，原因很简单，除了它看起来像什么（以及它如何与其他图像聚合在一起看起来很像）。

But there appears to be more to learn from visual experience than how to recognize or visualize things. What about learning with your own eyes that people wear warm clothing in the winter? Acquiring this kind of knowledge through visual perception is tougher to account for. As we saw in chapter 4, visual images do not lend themselves to this kind of thinking for the simple reason that they do not make clear what is germane in the image, other than what it looks like (and how it aggregates with other images that look similar).

然而，为了了解其中涉及的内容，考虑一个人类通过个人经验了解世界的明确案例是很有用的——在这个案例中，人类语言必然扮演的角色不那么突出：幼儿的学习经验。

To get a glimpse of what is involved, however, it is useful to consider one clear case of humans learning about the world through personal experience—a case where human language must necessarily play a much less prominent role: the learning experiences of toddlers.

当一个人足够年轻时，我们希望他们主要从与世界的个人互动中学习（通常由成年人指导，但并非总是如此）。孩子在一年级之前在学前班接受的就是通常所说的幼儿教育(ECE)。我们希望 ECE 主要与社会和情感发展有关，但其中一些与世界知识有关。

When a person is young enough, we expect them to learn primarily from their personal interaction with the world (generally guided by an adult, but not always). What a child gets in preschool, before first grade, is what is usually called early childhood education (ECE). We expect ECE to be mostly about social and emotional development, but some of it concerns knowledge of the world.

朱迪·赫尔 (Judy Herr) 有一本书，名为《幼儿课堂的创意资源》。看看它认为适合纳入 ECE 课堂的“主题”范围很有趣：

There is a book by Judy Herr called Creative Resources for the Early Childhood Classroom. It is interesting to look at the range of “themes” it considers suitable for inclusion in an ECE classroom:

蚂蚁

Ants

苹果

Apples

艺术

Art

鸟类

Birds

蓝色的

Blue

面包

Breads

画笔

Brushes

气泡

Bubbles

建筑物

Buildings

野营

Camping

关爱我们的地球

Caring for our earth

汽车、卡车和公共汽车

Cars, trucks, and buses

猫

Cats

中国新年

Chinese New Year

圣诞节

Christmas

五月五日节

Cinco de Mayo

马戏团

Circus

衣服

Clothing

沟通

Communication

施工工具

Construction tools

集装箱

Containers

创意运动

Creative movement

乳制品

Dairy products

牙医

Dentist

排灯节

Diwali

医生和护士

Doctors and nurses

小狗

Dogs

复活节

Easter

蛋

Eggs

落下

Fall

家庭

Families

农场动物

Farm Animals

情怀

Feelings

脚

Feet

消防员

Firefighters

鱼

Fish

花朵

Flowers

朋友们

Friends

青蛙

Frogs

水果和蔬菜

Fruits and vegetables

花园

Gardens

万圣节

Halloween

光明节（Chanukah）

Hanukkah (Chanukah)

帽子

Hats

健康

Health

家园

Homes

昆虫和蜘蛛

Insects and spiders

宽扎节

Kwanzaa

邮递员

Mail carrier

老鼠

Mice

音乐

Music

数字

Numbers

儿歌

Nursery rhymes

职业

Occupations

宠物

Pets

植物

Plants

木偶

Puppets

紫色的

Purple

雨

Rain

斋月

Ramadan

红色的

Red

安全

Safety

剪刀

Scissors

形状

Shapes

运动的

Sports

春天

Spring

夏天

Summer

感恩

Thanksgiving

树木

Trees

情人节

Valentine’s Day

水

Water

车轮

Wheels

冬天

Winter

蠕虫

Worms

黄色的

Yellow

动物园里的动物

Zoo animals

对于这 76 个主题中的每一个，本书都提出了有关如何组织适合学龄前儿童的课程的想法。例如，对于上面的“建筑工具”主题，作者建议了一些适合学龄前儿童的课堂活动：

For each of these seventy-six themes, the book presents ideas on how to organize a curriculum appropriate for a preschool child. For example, for the “construction tools” theme above, the author suggests a number of classroom activities for preschool children:

  • • 剪下工具的轮廓并将它们放在布告栏上。
  • • Cut out silhouettes of the tools and place them on a bulletin board.
  • • 为每个工具唱“这就是……”。
  • • Sing “This is the way …” for each tool.
  • • 练习用小锤子敲打。
  • • Practice pounding with small hammers.
  • • 探索带有各种工具的显示器。
  • • Explore a display with various tools on it.
  • • 参观鞋匠店或工艺品店
  • • Visit a shoemaker’s store, or an arts and craft store
  • • 将小工具浸入颜料中并打印在纸上
  • • Dip a small tool into paint and print it on paper
  • • 讨论工具的安全规则
  • • Discuss safety rules for tools
  • • 参与工具清理
  • • Participate in tool cleanup

对于每个主题，本书还介绍了孩子可能需要掌握的词汇。对于“施工工具”主题，它是这样的：

For each theme, the book also presents the vocabulary a child might be expected to pick up. For the “construction tools” theme, it’s this:

  • 工具：帮助我们的对象
  • 钻头：一种钻孔的工具
  • 扳手：用来夹东西的工具
  • 螺丝刀：转动螺丝的工具
  • 锯：一种边缘锋利的切割工具
  • 锤子：用来插入或取出钉子等物体的工具
  • 钳子：用来夹持的工具
  • 夹子：用来连接或固定东西的工具
  • 尺子：量具
  • 楔子：用于分裂的工具
  • 刨：刨木头用的工具
  • tool: an object to help us
  • drill: a tool that cuts holes
  • wrench: a tool that holds things
  • screwdriver: a tool that turns screws
  • saw: a cutting tool with sharp edges
  • hammer: a tool used to insert or remove objects such as nails
  • pliers: a tool used for holding
  • clamp: a tool used to join or hold things
  • ruler: a measuring tool
  • wedge: a tool used for splitting
  • plane: a tool used for shaving wood

最后，但对我们的目的来说最有趣的是，对于每个主题，本书都介绍了孩子可以从课程活动中学到的主要思想。（作者称这些想法为“概念”，但也许“命题”是一个更好的名字。）以下是书中所说的“构造工具”主题：

Finally, but most interesting for our purposes, for each theme, the book presents the main ideas that a child can be expected to learn from the curriculum activities. (The author calls these ideas “concepts,” but maybe “propositions” is a better name.) Here is what the book says are the ones for the “construction tools” theme:

  1. 1.工具可以是电动的，也可以是手动的。
  2. 2. 构建时工具很有帮助。
  3. 3. 钳子、镊子和夹子用来夹东西。
  4. 4. 钻头、钉子和螺钉打孔。
  5. 5、刨、锯、剪刀切割材料。
  6. 6. 钉子、螺钉的装卸使用锤子和起子。
  7. 7. 尺子是用来测量的。
  8. 8. 为了安全起见，工具需要轻拿轻放。
  9. 9、使用工具时应戴护目镜保护眼睛。
  10. 10、工具使用后需收好。
  1. 1. Tools can be electric or hand-powered.
  2. 2. Tools are helpful when building.
  3. 3. Pliers, tweezers, and clamps hold things.
  4. 4. Drills, nails, and screws make holes.
  5. 5. Planes, saws, and scissors cut materials.
  6. 6. Hammers and screwdrivers are used to put in and remove nails and screws.
  7. 7. Rulers are used for measuring.
  8. 8. To be safe, tools need to be handled with care.
  9. 9. Goggles should be worn to protect our eyes when using tools.
  10. 10. After use, tools need to be put away.

因此，似乎期望孩子们从他们在 ECE 课堂上的经历中获得的很大一部分是可以用英语非常清楚地表达的普通常识性知识。这里的寓意很耐人寻味：虽然学龄前儿童可能无法理解“使用工具时应戴护目镜以保护我们的眼睛”这样的句子，但希望他们能够通过体验了解这句话的含义.

So it seems that a good part of what the children are expected to acquire from their experience in an ECE classroom is ordinary commonsense knowledge that can be stated quite clearly in English. The implication here is intriguing: although preschoolers may not be able to make much sense of a sentence like “Goggles should be worn to protect our eyes when using tools,” it is expected that they will be able to learn what that sentence says through experience.

这是另一个例子，对于上面的“露营”主题，有以下想法需要学习：

Here is another example, for the “camping” theme above, with the following ideas to be learned:

  1. 1. 帐篷是用来露营的避难所。
  2. 2. 我们可以在树林里或露营地露营。
  3. 3. 我们也可以在公园、湖边或自家后院露营。
  4. 4. 热狗、鱼、棉花糖、豆类都是野营食品。
  5. 5. 露营车可以被驾驶或连接到汽车或皮卡车的后部。
  6. 6. 灯笼和手电筒是野营时使用的光源。
  7. 7. 睡袋是野营用的毯子。
  8. 8、有人在湖边扎营滑水，划船钓鱼。
  1. 1. A tent is a shelter used for camping.
  2. 2. We can camp in the woods or at a campground.
  3. 3. We can also camp in a park, at a lake, or in our backyard.
  4. 4. Hot dogs, fish, marshmallows, and beans are all camping foods.
  5. 5. A camper can be driven or attached to the back of a car or pickup truck.
  6. 6. Lanterns and flashlights are sources of light used for camping.
  7. 7. A sleeping bag is a blanket used for camping.
  8. 8. Some people camp by a lake to water ski and go boating and fishing.

以下是“冬季”主题要学习的内容：

Here is what is to be learned for the “winter” theme:

  1. 1. 冬天是四个季节之一。
  2. 2. 冬天通常是最冷的季节。
  3. 3、部分地区冬天下雪。
  4. 4.人们在冬天穿暖和的衣服。
  5. 5.有些动物在冬天冬眠。
  6. 6. 树木在冬天可能会落叶。
  7. 7. 湖泊、池塘和水在冬天可能会结冰。
  8. 8. 雪橇、滑雪、平底雪橇和滑冰是寒冷地区的冬季运动。
  9. 9. 为了除雪，人们用铲子和犁犁。
  10. 10. 十二月、一月和二月是冬季月份。
  1. 1. Winter is one of the four seasons.
  2. 2. Winter is usually the coldest season.
  3. 3. It snows in the winter in some areas.
  4. 4. People wear warmer clothes in the winter.
  5. 5. Some animals hibernate in the winter.
  6. 6. Trees may lose their leaves in the winter.
  7. 7. Lakes, ponds, and water may freeze in the winter.
  8. 8. Sledding, skiing, tobogganing, and ice skating are winter sports in colder areas.
  9. 9. To remove snow, people shovel and plow.
  10. 10. December, January, and February are winter months.

这种早期学习表明，从个人经验中获得的东西包括两种截然不同的东西：(a) 识别和命名某些类别的普通物理对象的能力，如消防车、钳子、帐篷和雪橇；(b) 一些可以用语言表达的额外想法（即使年轻人可能无法充分理解所涉及的语言）。因此，将 (a) 留给深度学习之类的东西，现在让我们转向 (b)。

What this early learning suggests is that what is acquired from personal experience comprises two distinct things: (a) the ability to recognize and name certain categories of mundane physical objects like fire trucks, pliers, tents, and sleds; and (b) some additional ideas that can be expressed in language (even if a young human may be unable to make much sense of the language involved). So leaving (a) for something like deep learning, let us now turn to (b).

来自语言的知识

Knowledge from Language

虽然人工智能系统能够像人类一样从文本中学习肯定会很方便，但第 3 章中指出了一个严重的障碍：需要理解该文本。大量未经分析的英文文本可能正是某些任务所需要的，例如检索（“给我找到非洲以外的所有关于埃博拉的医学文章”）或基本形式的翻译（“你怎么说'现在几点了？'在葡萄牙语？”）。但是为了常识，我们想要构建符号表示，以适应已经看到的那种推理过程。这意味着我们需要从文本中弄清楚声称存在什么样的事物以及声称它们具有什么样的属性。这就是常识知识需要什么，以及像英语这样的语言的陈述句旨在提供什么。

While it would certainly be convenient for AI systems to be able to learn from texts the way humans do, there is a serious impediment noted in chapter 3: the need to make sense of that text. Massive amounts of unanalyzed English text might be just what is needed for certain tasks like retrieval (“Find me all the medical articles about Ebola outside Africa”) or basic forms of translation (“How do you say ‘What time is it?’ in Portuguese?”). But for common sense, we want to construct symbolic representations amenable to reasoning procedures of the sort already seen. This means we need to figure out from the text what kinds of things are claimed to exist and what kinds of properties they are claimed to have. This is what commonsense knowledge wants, and what the declarative sentences of a language like English purport to offer.

这样做的问题是陈述句（换句话说，线性字符串）和这些符号结构之间存在很大差距。即使撇开隐喻和诗意的文本不谈，普通说明性文本的英文句子表达思想的方式也是密集而复杂的，留下了许多必要的细节，需要知识渊博的语言使用者来填补。这值得仔细研究，因为它对人工智能系统如何利用在线文本资源产生巨大影响。

The problem with this is that there is a large gap between declarative sentences (linear strings of words, in other words) and these sorts of symbolic structures. Even putting aside metaphoric and poetic text, the English sentences of ordinary expository text express ideas in a dense and complicated way, leaving many of the necessary details to be filled in by a knowledgeable language user. This is worth examining closely since it has a tremendous impact on how AI systems will be able to make use of online textual resources.

考虑一个简单的例子：英语短语“a small dog”。请注意，除非您弄清楚这涉及大小属性，否则您无法真正构建所需类别的符号表示。但是这个短语中没有提到“大小”。在所谓的名词-名词修饰中，我们可以更清楚地看到这种省略。考虑“木桌”与“咖啡桌”。一个与材料构成有关，一个与目的有关，但这两个短语中都没有说明这一点。如果我们想建立一个符号表示，我们不能像英语中单词的连接方式那样将“咖啡”的概念和“餐桌”的概念连接起来。一旦我们解决了“咖啡桌”的整个液体问题，我们将需要重新考虑“地下水位”之类的东西。相似地，我们需要知道“植物性食物”是植物的食物，而“食物植物”是指来自植物的食物（所以要小心你决定吃哪一个！）。在某些情况下，未指定的属性需要一个复杂的故事。很明显，“古老的家庭食谱”不像“古老的炖牛肉食谱”，但不太清楚食谱必须是什么样的东西才能拥有涉及家庭的财产。有时英语短语只不过是一堆名词，所有属性分析都需要完成，比如“卡车停靠餐厅星期四晚上汉堡拼盘特价”。（是否有“星期四晚餐”或“夜间汉堡包”之类的东西？）很明显，“古老的家庭食谱”不像“古老的炖牛肉食谱”，但不太清楚食谱必须是什么样的东西才能拥有涉及家庭的财产。有时英语短语只不过是一堆名词，所有属性分析都需要完成，比如“卡车停靠餐厅星期四晚上汉堡拼盘特价”。（是否有“星期四晚餐”或“夜间汉堡包”之类的东西？）很明显，“古老的家庭食谱”不像“古老的炖牛肉食谱”，但不太清楚食谱必须是什么样的东西才能拥有涉及家庭的财产。有时英语短语只不过是一堆名词，所有属性分析都需要完成，比如“卡车停靠餐厅星期四晚上汉堡拼盘特价”。（是否有“星期四晚餐”或“夜间汉堡包”之类的东西？）

Consider a simple example: the English phrase “a small dog.” Observe that you cannot really construct a symbolic representation of the desired sort unless you figure out that this involves the property of size. But “size” is not mentioned in the phrase. We can see this sort of omission even more clearly in what is called noun-noun modification. Consider “a wood table” versus “a coffee table.” One has to do with material composition and one has to do with purpose, but nothing in either phrase spells this out. If we want to build a symbolic representation, we cannot just conjoin the idea for “coffee” and the idea for “table” the way the words are conjoined in English. And once we resolve the whole liquid issue for “coffee table,” we will need to think again for something like a “water table.” Similarly, we need to know that “plant food” is food for plants, while a “food plant” involves food from plants (so be careful which one you decide to eat!). In some cases, the properties left unspecified demand a complex story. It’s clear that an “old family recipe” is not like an “old goulash recipe,” but it’s less clear what kind of thing a recipe has to be for it to have a property involving families. Sometimes English phrases are no more than a jumble of nouns, with all the analysis of properties left to be done, like a “truck stop diner Thursday night hamburger platter special.” (Is there such a thing as a “diner Thursday” or “night hamburger”?)

在歧义的情况下，对先验知识的需求更为明显。假设我们正在尝试为之前使用的句子构建某种符号表示：

The need for prior knowledge is even more evident in the case of ambiguity. Suppose we are trying to construct some sort of a symbolic representation for the sentence used before:

大球撞穿了桌子，因为它是钢制的。

The large ball crashed through the table because it was made of steel.

这里所有的词义都相当清楚。我们想要构建一个世界模型，其中有两个东西，一个球和桌子，球具有由钢制成的特性。然而，如前所述，句子中的单个词没有任何内容表明球是钢制的。一张桌子不是比一个大球更有可能是钢制的吗？

All the word senses here are reasonably clear. We would want to construct a world model where, among other things, there were two things, a ball and table, and the ball had the property of being made of steel. As noted before, however, nothing in the individual words of the sentence points to the ball as the thing made of steel. And isn’t it more likely that a table would be made of steel than a large ball?

所以，是的，无需对句子的含义或使用方式进行任何系统分析，就可以处理大量文本（例如，在谷歌翻译等应用程序中），这是非常了不起的。出于许多目的，“plant food”和“food plant”之间的差异并不值得担心，除了它们出现的文本方面。但是如果要将英文文本用作常识性知识库的基础，它需要转换成适合常识推理的形式，这似乎确实需要更密切地关注陈述句实际陈述的内容。

So yes, it is quite remarkable what can be done with massive amounts of text (in applications like Google Translate, say) without any sort of systematic analysis of what the sentences mean or how they are being used. For many purposes, the differences between “plant food” and “food plant” are just not worth worrying about, except in terms of the texts they appear in. But if English text is to be used as the basis for a commonsense knowledge base, it will need to be converted into a form that is suitable for commonsense reasoning, and this does seem to require much closer attention to what the declarative sentences are actually declaring.

总而言之，我们在这里遇到了一个难题：我们想从英文文本中构建常识知识的表征，但要做到这一点，我们需要能够理解文本，这需要常识知识！

In sum, what we have here is a quandary: we want to build representations of commonsense knowledge from English text, but to do so, we need to be able to make sense of the text, which requires commonsense knowledge!

我们如何打破这个循环？当前一些建立大型知识库的 AI 努力只是忽略了它。像前面提到的 NELL 或麻省理工学院的众包 ConceptNet 等项目试图产生大量常识性事实和规则，而无需过多关注所涉及的事物和属性。然而，正如 Marcus 和 Davis 在Rebooting AI一书中清楚表明的那样，由此产生的符号表示往往有些混乱。这些项目不仅没有在推理方面花费足够的时间，而且还不清楚由此产生的知识库是否具有足够的内部连贯性，以便推理程序以完全自动化的方式对它们进行处理。

How do we break out of this loop? Some current AI efforts to build large knowledge bases just ignore it. Projects like the previously mentioned NELL or the crowdsourcing ConceptNet effort out of MIT seek to produce a multitude of commonsense facts and rules without too much concern for the things and properties involved. Yet as clearly shown in the Marcus and Davis book Rebooting AI, the resulting symbolic representations tend to be somewhat chaotic. Not only do the projects not spend nearly enough time on the reasoning aspects, it is far from clear that the resulting knowledge bases are internally coherent enough for reasoning procedures to work on them in a fully automated way.

这种连贯性问题也出现在人们手工制作的知识库中，尤其是当系统的各个部分由不同的人组装时。一个人关于如何将世界分解为事物和属性类别的观点可能与另一个人的观点不太吻合。从实际工程的角度来看，需要某种管理来解决大型分布式项目中自然出现的冲突和误解。

This issue of coherence arises in knowledge bases handcrafted by people as well, especially if the various parts of the system are assembled by different people. One person’s view about how to break the world into categories of things and properties might not fit well with another’s. From a practical engineering point of view, there needs to be some sort of curation to resolve the clashes and misunderstandings that naturally arise in big distributed projects.

那么如何更有原则地应对上述困境呢？一个想法是认真对待这样一个事实，即对于人类来说，理解英文文本的能力并不是一种随着年龄增长而形成的单一整体技能十八岁，比如说；它分阶段进行。你可以理解和使用语言而不需要全部理解。青少年，甚至是高级儿童，可能无法理解哲学家伊曼纽尔康德的著作。八岁的孩子可能无法在一些普通的成人谈话中做出正面或反面的判断。

How then to deal with the quandary above in a more principled way? One idea is to take seriously the fact that for humans, the ability to make sense of English text is not a single monolithic skill that arrives at age eighteen, say; it comes in stages. You can understand and use language without understanding it all. Teenagers, even advanced ones, may not be able to make much sense of the writings of philosopher Immanuel Kant. Eight-year-olds might not be able to make heads or tails of some ordinary adult conversation.

即使对于两岁的孩子也是如此。考虑一下著名读者晚安月亮为年轻孩子们写的这些话：

And the same is true even for two-year-olds. Consider these lines from the famous reader Goodnight Moon for young tots:

在伟大的绿色房间里

有一个电话

还有一个红气球

和一张照片

牛跳过月亮。

In the great green room

There was a telephone

And a red balloon

And a picture of

The cow jumping over the moon.

这些单词中的一些与所附插图的某些部分之间的联系即使对于两岁的孩子来说也是有意义的。但是游戏中的语言能力显然是相当有限的。当涉及到无法在图片中显示的文字时，可能与插图没有任何联系，例如：

The connection between some of these words and parts of the accompanying illustrations will be meaningful even for two-year-olds. But the language skills in play are obviously quite limited. And there is no possible connection to illustrations when it comes to words that that cannot be shown in pictures, like these:

  • 帐户、行为、添加、调整、协议、数量、娱乐、回答、批准、争论、尝试、注意力、吸引力、权威。
  • account, act, addition, adjustment, agreement, amount, amusement, answer, approval, argument, attempt, attention, attraction, authority.

这不是随机的A词列表；这些是构成所谓的基础英语（由哲学家查尔斯·奥格登在 1930 年代发明）的 850 个单词中的前 14 个名词。这些特殊的名词据说是“不可想象的”。尽管它们不是真正的技术术语，但要使用它们需要超出两岁儿童所能达到的水平。

This is not a random list of A words; these are the first 14 nouns of the 850 words that make up what is called Basic English (invented by philosopher Charles Ogden in the 1930s). These particular nouns are said to be “nonpicturable.” Even though they are not really technical terms, an extra degree of sophistication beyond what a two-year-old can muster is needed to make use of them.

所有这一切对 AI 来说意味着，我们或许应该愿意将从文本中提取知识的问题视为需要分阶段开发的问题。该系统可以从理解以基本方式使用英语的简单说明性文本开始。完成后，它就可以使用获得的知识（以及通过其他方式获得的任何额外知识）来帮助理解下一轮要求稍高的文本。并且该过程迭代。

What all of this suggests for AI is that we should perhaps be willing to treat the problem of extracting knowledge from text as something to be developed in stages. The system can start by making sense of simple expository texts that use English in a basic way. With this done, it can then use the knowledge acquired (and any additional knowledge acquired by other means) to help make sense of the next round of slightly more demanding texts. And the process iterates.

虽然这种自力更生的想法在实践中可能会失败，但有几个因素可以证明它的可信度。首先是我们已经讨论过分阶段构建世界和概念模型方式。正如我们在第 6 章中所说，我们应该期望从医院和生日派对等概念的直截了当、头脑简单的版本开始，并准备好在后续轮次中完善和注释它们。因此，我们并不希望复杂的概念仅以某种最终的、确定的形式进入概念模型。事实上，认为概念的初步版本会被更复杂的概念所取代的想法可能是错误的；他们都有自己的角色。回到医院，有时我们确实想将它们视为物理建筑物，而在其他时候我们想将它们视为仅安置在这些建筑物中的社会机构。这解释了某物如何既有第三层又有董事会。

While this bootstrapping idea may turn out to be a bust in practical terms, there are a couple of factors that give it credence. The first is that we already talked about building world and conceptual models in a staged way. As we said in chapter 6, we should expect to begin with blunt, simpleminded versions of concepts like hospitals and birthday parties, and be prepared to refine and annotate them in subsequent rounds. So it’s not as if we expect complex notions to enter conceptual models only in some sort of final, definitive form. Indeed, it is perhaps a mistake to think of preliminary versions of concepts as being superseded by more sophisticated ones; they both have roles to play. Going back to hospitals, sometimes we do want to think of them as physical buildings, and at other times we want to think of them as social institutions that are merely housed in those buildings. This explains how something can have both a third floor and a board of trustees.

第二个因素是，已经存在丰富的文本资源，这些资源并没有假定人类成年人的全部语言能力——值得简要研究一下。

The second factor is that there already exist rich textual resources that do not presume the full language abilities of human adults—and are worth briefly looking into.

在线资源

An Online Resource

维基百科有一个名为 KidzSearch 的版本，专为儿童阅读和理解而设计。据说该合集包含 20 万篇以更适合儿童（具体年龄不详，但不包括学步儿童）的简体英语撰写的文章。句子往往简短而直接，行话保持在最低限度。

There is a version of Wikipedia called KidzSearch that has been designed to be read and understood by children. The collection is said to contain two hundred thousand articles written in a simplified English that is more suitable for children (of what age is not clear, but not toddlers). The sentences tend to be short and direct, with jargon kept to a minimum.

例如，这是一篇关于 gophers 的文章的开头：

Here, for example, is the start of an article on gophers:

地鼠是小型的穴居啮齿动物。美国有 100 多种地鼠。地鼠有长门牙、微小特征和短尾巴。他们生活在非常复杂的地下隧道中。他们独自生活，以根和灌木为食。众所周知，它们是害虫，会破坏人们的草坪和花园。

Gophers are small, burrowing rodents. There are over 100 kinds of gophers in America. Gophers have long front teeth, tiny features, and short tails. They live in very complex tunnels underground. They live by themselves and feed on roots and shrubs. They are known to be pests and ruin people’s lawns and gardens.

相比之下，这是维基百科关于 gophers 的文章的开头（针对年长的读者）：

In contrast, here is the start of the Wikipedia article on gophers (for older readers):

口袋地鼠，通常简称为地鼠，是地鼠科的穴居啮齿动物。大约有 35 种，都是北美洲和中美洲特有的。他们以广泛的隧道活动和摧毁农场和花园的能力而闻名。

Pocket gophers, commonly referred to as just gophers, are burrowing rodents of the family Geomyidae. There are about 35 species, all endemic to North and Central America. They are commonly known for their extensive tunneling activities and their ability to destroy farms and gardens.

要查看第二个示例，这里是一篇关于歌剧的文章的一部分。首先，KidzSearch 版本：

To see a second example, here is part of an article on opera. First, the KidzSearch version:

歌剧就像一出戏，里面的一切都是唱出来的，而不是说出来的。歌剧通常在歌剧院演出。唱歌和表演故事的歌手在舞台上，乐队在舞台前但在乐池下方，让观众看到舞台。

An opera is like a play in which everything is sung instead of spoken. Operas are usually performed in opera houses. The singers who sing and act out the story are on the stage, and the orchestra is in front of the stage but lower down, in the orchestra pit, so that the audience can see the stage.

然后是维基百科：

Then the Wikipedia one:

歌剧是一种以音乐为主角，由歌手担任部分的戏剧形式，但有别于音乐剧。这样的“作品”（意大利语“歌剧”的字面翻译）通常是作曲家和编剧之间的合作，并结合了许多表演艺术，例如表演、布景、服装，有时还包括舞蹈或芭蕾舞。表演通常在歌剧院进行，由管弦乐队或较小的音乐合奏伴奏，自 19 世纪初以来一直由指挥领导。

Opera is a form of theater in which music has a leading role and the parts are taken by singers, but is distinct from musical theater. Such a “work” (the literal translation of Italian word “opera”) is typically a collaboration between a composer and a librettist and incorporates a number of the performing arts, such as acting, scenery, costume, and sometimes dance or ballet. The performance is typically given in an opera house, accompanied by an orchestra or smaller musical ensemble, which since the early 19th century has been led by a conductor.

有一些明显的差异，但并不显着。KidzSearch 的文字不像维基百科的那样详尽，但它仍然充满了信息。如果您能够理解 KidzSearch 文章并访问全部 20 万篇文章，您可以学到很多东西。更重要的是，如果您能够有效地利用这些 KidzSearch 文章中包含的所有知识，那么您将能够很好地掌握理解下一轮要求更高的文本所需的知识。

There are some obvious differences, but they are not dramatic. The KidzSearch text is not as elaborate as Wikipedia’s, but it is still full of information. If you are able to make sense of KidzSearch articles and have access to all two hundred thousand of them, you can learn a lot. More to the point, if you were able to make effective use of all the knowledge contained in those KidzSearch articles, you would be well on your way to having what you need to make sense of the next round of more demanding text.

当然，作为一种利用在线文本资源的方式，这种分阶段的方法留下了两个主要问题。开发足够知识（并且语言能力足够）的 AI 系统来正确理解上面关于 gophers 的 KidzSearch 文章需要什么？除了所有这些 KidzSearch 文章之外，人工智能系统还需要了解什么才能理解针对成人的要求更高的文本？这些都没有简单明了的答案。

Of course, as a way of making use of online textual resources, this staged approach leaves open two major questions.
