    After the closing of Door#58, its opening, and a closing of Door#59, Door#58 is open.

执行一系列操作

Performing a Sequence of Actions

回想一下第 8 章中关于模拟变化的约定，我们可以通过将“after”分布在派生子句的嵌入公式中来对任何派生属性使用“after”。possible这也包括财产。有了这个想法，我们可以有一个派生属性possibleSequence，表示可以由代理发生一系列事件，其特征在于以下两个子句：

Recalling the convention on simulating change in chapter 8, we can use “after” with any derived property by distributing the “after” inside the embedded formula of the derivation clause. This includes the possible property as well. With this idea, we can have a derived property possibleSequence that says that a sequence of events can be made to occur by an agent, characterized by the following two clauses:

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Agent:x when Seq:s is [].

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Agent:x when Seq:s is [].

Seq:s|Event:e is a possibleSequence for Agent:x

Seq:s|Event:e is a possibleSequence for Agent:x

when

when

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Agent:x and

Seq:s is a possibleSequence for Agent:x and

Event:e is possible for Agent:x after Seq:s.

Event:e is possible for Agent:x after Seq:s.

这表示始终可以执行空序列的动作，并且如果（递归地）可以执行序列t 1 ，则可以执行非空序列| t 1 t 2 ，并且在序列t 1已经执行。

This says that the empty sequence of actions can always be performed, and that a nonempty sequence t1 | t2 can be performed if (recursively) the sequence t1 can be performed, and the final action t2 is possible for the agent after the sequence t1 has been performed.

关于可以执行哪些操作的推理

Reasoning about What Actions Can Be Executed

假设在当前状态下，Door#58是开着的，并且Person#17（约翰）不在那扇门附近，但是有一个移动事件，Event#357约翰可以在当前状态下执行，这会让他靠近门。然后我们得到以下内容：

Suppose that in the current state, Door#58 is open and Person#17 (John) is not near that door, but that there is a moving event, Event#357, John can perform in the current state, and it would put him near the door. Then we get the following:

  • TEST[Person#17 is near Door#58]=FALSE

    约翰目前不在门口。

  • TEST[Person#17 is near Door#58] = FALSE

    John is currently not near the door.

  • TEST[Person#17 is near Door#58 after [Event#357]]=TRUE

    约翰搬家后就在门口附近。

  • TEST[Person#17 is near Door#58 after [Event#357]] = TRUE

    John is near the door after moving.

  • TEST[Event#817 is possible for Person#17]=FALSE

    约翰目前无法关门。

  • TEST[Event#817 is possible for Person#17] = FALSE

    John cannot currently close the door.

  • TEST[Event#357 is possible for Person#17]=TRUE

    约翰目前可以靠近门。

  • TEST[Event#357 is possible for Person#17] = TRUE

    John can currently move near the door.

  • TEST[Event#817 is possible for Person#17 after [Event#357]]=TRUE

    约翰可以在靠近门后关上门。

  • TEST[Event#817 is possible for Person#17 after [Event#357]] = TRUE

    John can close the door after moving near it.

  • TEST[[Event#357,Event#817] is a possibleSequence for Person#17]= TRUE

    约翰可以完成移动到门附近并关上门的顺序。

  • TEST[[Event#357,Event#817] is a possibleSequence for Person#17] = TRUE

    John can do the sequence of moving near the door and closing it.

生动公式中使用的缩写

Abbreviations Used in Vivid Formulas

在奖金章节中，使用了以下公式缩写：

In the bonus chapter, the following formula abbreviations are used:

  • • The t 1 ,t 2,  … ,t n are distinct
    • 用于表示公式
    • It is not the case that … or t i is t j or … ,
    • 其中析取范围遍及所有索引对，使得i < j ≤ n。
  • • The t1, t2, … , tn are distinct
    • is used to stand for the formula
    • It is not the case that … or ti is tj or… ,
    • where the disjuncts range over all pairs of indexes such that i < j ≤ n.
  • • The pairs t 1 吨’ 1,吨2 吨’ 2,  … , t n t′ n are distinct
    • 用于表示公式
    • It is not the case that … or t它 is t j and t'它 is _' j or … ,
    • 其中析取范围遍及所有索引对，使得i < j ≤ n。
  • • The pairs t1 t′1, t2 t′2, … , tn t′n are distinct
    • is used to stand for the formula
    • It is not the case that … or ti is tj and t′i is t′j or… ,
    • where the disjuncts range over all pairs of indexes such that i < j ≤ n.
  • • There is at most nc（“ is”和c可能复数）
    • 用于表示公式
    • It is not the case that
    • there is a v 1,  … , a v n , and a v where
    • the v 1,  … , v n , v are distinct,
    • v 1 is a c,  … , v n is a c , and v is a c ,
    • 其中变量v i和v都被选择为不同的。
  • • There is at most n c (with the “is” and c possibly pluralized)
    • is used to stand for the formula
    • It is not the case that
    • there is a v1, … , a vn, and a v where
    • the v1, … , vn, v are distinct,
    • v1 is a c, … , vn is a c, and v is a c,
    • where the variables vi and the v are all chosen to be distinct.
  • • There is at most nr（“ is”和r可能复数）
    • 用于表示公式
    • It is not the case that
    • there is a v 1 , a u 1,  … , a v n , a u n , a v , and a u where
    • the pairs v 1 , u 1,  … ,v n ,u n ,v , u are distinct,
    • v 1 has u 1 as an r,  … , v n has u n as an r , and v has u as an r ,
    • 其中变量v i、u j、v和u都被选择为不同的。
  • • There is at most n r (with the “is” and r possibly pluralized)
    • is used to stand for the formula
    • It is not the case that
    • there is a v1, a u1,  … , a vn, a un, a v, and a u where
    • the pairs v1, u1, … , vn, un, v, u are distinct,
    • v1 has u1 as an r, … , vn has un as an r, and v has u as an r,
    • where the variables vi, uj, v, and u are all chosen to be distinct.

奖励章节：常识的逻辑

Bonus Chapter: The Logic of Common Sense

逻辑，如威士忌，如果摄入量太大，就会失去其有益效果。

Logic, like whiskey, loses its beneficial effect when taken in too large quantities.

——邓萨尼勋爵，引自詹姆斯·R·纽曼编辑的《数学世界》

—Lord Dunsany, quoted in The World of Mathematics, edited by James R. Newman

在第 7-8 章中，我们看到了如何在世界模型中表示知识（在概念模型和推导子句的帮助下），以及如何从这样的模型计算语言 L 的哪些公式应该被认为是正确的. 在这一附加章节中，针对那些可能想要更深入地研究所涉及问题的人，我们从逻辑的角度重新考虑这些推理操作，其中有一些重要的教训需要学习。

In chapters 7–8, we saw how knowledge could be represented in a world model (with help from a conceptual model and derivation clauses), and then how to compute from such a model which formulas of the language L should be considered to be true. In this bonus chapter, aimed at those who might want to dive a little deeper into the issues involved, we reconsider these reasoning operations from the standpoint of logic, where there are some significant lessons to learn.

书中考虑的推理操作显然与经典（演绎）逻辑中的内容相关。在逻辑中，我们从某些前提或假设开始，逻辑规则告诉我们其他哪些句子也应该被认为是真实的作为逻辑结果。唯一真正的区别是，在第 7 章和第 8 章中，推理是从一个世界模型开始的，而不是一组最初给出的真实前提。通常在逻辑中，前提被认为是公理化的——具有绝对数学确定性的真——因此结果也将被保证为真——数学定理。但逻辑实际上是关于从某些前提得出的结论是正确的，无论它们多么确定。强调确定性并不是逻辑所固有的，显然也不是常识所需要的。

The reasoning operations considered in the book are clearly related to what is seen in classical (deductive) logic. In logic, we start with certain premises or postulates, and the rules of logic tell us what other sentences should also be considered to be true as logical consequences. The only real difference is that in chapters 7–8, the reasoning starts with a world model, not a set of premises given initially to be true. Often in logic the premises are taken to be axiomatic—true with absolute mathematical certainty—so that the consequences will be guaranteed to be true as well—mathematical theorems. But logic is really about what follows from some premises being true, however certain they may be. An emphasis on certitude is not inherent in logic, and clearly not what is needed for common sense.

但就常识的运作而言，从世界模型开始作为知识的表示有多重要？既然我们现在有了 L 的公式供我们使用，难道我们不能简单地使用它们来表示已知的东西并完全放弃世界模型吗？其他研究人员，如 Doug Lenat 和 Cyc，认为常识的表示必须从丰富且富有表现力的逻辑开始，甚至是所谓的高阶逻辑。我们为什么不那样做？

But in terms of the workings of common sense, how important is it to start with a world model as the representation of knowledge? Since we now have the formulas of L at our disposal, could we not simply use them to represent what is known and dispense with world models entirely? Other researchers, like Doug Lenat with Cyc, have argued that the representations for common sense must begin with rich and expressive logics, or even what are called higher-order logics. Why would we not do that?

在本附加章节中，我们将更仔细地研究这些问题，并表明虽然可以使用 L 的公式而不是世界模型来表示我们的知识，但有一些很好的理由不这样做——理由以更小的数量来考虑我们的逻辑。特别是，我们将看到，从 L 的公式作为前提得出结论所需的那种计算通常要求太高，无法作为常识的基础。事实上，我们走得更远：我们证明了世界模型可以被认为是 L 的特殊公式，这些公式受到足够的限制以允许更适度的逻辑推理形式，更适合常识的日常世俗需求。

In this bonus chapter, we are going to look at these questions more closely and show that while it might be possible to use formulas of L instead of world models as our representation of knowledge, there are some good reasons not to do so—reasons to take our logic in much smaller quantities. In particular, we will see that the sort of computation needed to draw conclusions from formulas of L as premises is too demanding in general to serve as the basis for common sense. In fact, we go further: we demonstrate that world models can be thought of as special formulas of L that are restricted enough to admit a more modest form of logical reasoning much better suited to the everyday mundane needs of common sense.

世界模型作为生动的公式

World Models as Vivid Formulas

让我们回到第 7 章示例中使用的具有七个项目的世界模型：

Let us return to the world model with seven items used in the examples of chapter 7:

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 is a person.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has “John” as a firstName.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

Person#17 has Event#23 as a birth.

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 is a pointInTime.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

TimePt#24 has 1979 as an enclosingYear.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 is a birthEvent.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

Event#23 has TimePt#24 as a time.

这种表示告诉我们关于世界的什么？按照 Bertrand Russell 的建议（在第 6 章中讨论），我们应该将这样的世界模型视为告诉我们存在什么事物以及它们具有什么属性：有一个人、出生事件和具有某些属性的时间点。名称的选择Person#17并不重要。所以world model所携带的信息类似于用变量代替上面常量的公式所说的：

What does this representation tell us about the world? Following the advice of Bertrand Russell (discussed in chapter 6), we should think of a world model like this as telling us what things exist and what properties they have: there is a person, birth event, and time point with certain properties. The choice of a name like Person#17 is not important. So the information carried by the world model is similar to what is said by a formula that replaces the constants above by variables:

There is a Person:x, a TimePt:y, and an Event:z where

There is a Person:x, a TimePt:y, and an Event:z where

Person:x is a person,

Person:x is a person,

Person:x has “John” as a firstName,

Person:x has “John” as a firstName,

Person:x has Event:z as a birth,

Person:x has Event:z as a birth,

TimePt:y is a pointInTime,

TimePt:y is a pointInTime,

TimePt:y has 1979 as an enclosingYear,

TimePt:y has 1979 as an enclosingYear,

Event:z is a birthEvent, and

Event:z is a birthEvent, and

Event:z has TimePt:y as a time.

Event:z has TimePt:y as a time.

但不仅如此。例如，公式

But there is more to it than this. For instance, the formula

There is a Thing:u where Thing:u has “Harry” as a firstName.

There is a Thing:u where Thing:u has “Harry” as a firstName.

根据世界模型（和操作TEST）被认为是错误的，但上面的公式（即带有Person:x、TimePt:y和 的公式Event:z）中没有任何内容表明这一点。

is considered to be false according to the world model (and the TEST operation), but nothing in the formula above (that is, the one with Person:x, TimePt:y, and Event:z) suggests this.

在使用世界模型时，我们认识到我们并不是在为整个世界建模：世界上有太多的东西，其中有太多的属性，其中大部分我们一无所知。世界模型仅捕获某个状态下的世界片段。

In using a world model, we recognize that we are not modeling an entire world: there are too many things in the world and too many properties among them, most of which we will know nothing about. A world model captures only a fragment of the world in some state.

然而，一旦我们接受世界模型处理这样的片段，我们也接受它呈现所有存在的事物以及该片段中包含的所有属性。这就是有时被称为表示的“封闭世界”解释。它允许我们将世界模型视为它所代表的世界片段的类比。#片段中的事物与模型中它们的符号（包含 a ）之间存在一一对应关系。片段中事物的基本属性与模型中对应的符号结构也存在一一对应关系。世界模型与世界片段具有部分对应关系，就像模型飞机与真实飞机具有部分对应关系一样。

Once we accept that a world model deals with a fragment like this, however, we also accept that it presents all the things that exist and all the properties that hold in that fragment. This is what is sometimes called a “closed-world” interpretation of the representation. It allows us to treat a world model as an analogue of the fragment of the world it represents. There is a one-to-one correspondence between the things in the fragment and the symbols for them (containing a #) in the model. There is also a one-to-one correspondence between the basic properties of things in the fragment and the corresponding symbol structures in the model. The world model has a part-by-part correspondence with the world fragment in the same way a model airplane has a part-by-part correspondence with a real airplane.

关于这一点还有很多要说的，但足以说明我们从模型拥有的东西中得出结论，但也从它没有的东西中得出结论。根据模型上的类似部件，我们得出结论，飞机的每个机翼下方都有一个喷气发动机。但我们也得出结论，由于模型上没有相应的部件，飞机的尾翼上没有喷气发动机。

There is a lot more to be said about this, yet suffice it to note that we draw conclusions from what a model has, but also from what it does not have. We conclude that an airplane has a jet engine below each wing based on the analogous pieces on the model. But we also conclude that the airplane does not have a jet engine on the tail fin from the absence of a corresponding piece on the model.

世界模型将是相同的。因此，例如，我们可以通过计算世界模型中有多少个符号具有相应的属性来找出世界上有多少个人具有某种属性。我们可以找出某个人是否以某种方式与另一个人相关通过检查代表第一个人的符号是否以正确的方式连接到世界模型中代表第二个人的符号来创建世界。这正是我们期望能够使用类比模型的方式。

World models will be the same. So for example, we can find out how many individuals in the world have a certain property by counting how many symbols have a corresponding property in the world model. We can find out if a certain individual is related in some way to another in the world by checking if the symbol standing for the first individual is connected in the right way to the symbol standing for the second in the world model. This is exactly how we expect to be able to use analogical models.

有了这种封闭世界的理解，L 中就有一种特定类型的公式可以捕获世界模型所代表的所有信息。它被称为生动公式，具有以下一般形式：

With this closed-world understanding, there is a specific type of formula in L that captures all the information represented by a world model. It is called a vivid formula and has the following general form:

There is variables where distinct, middle, at most.

There is variables where distinct, middle, at most.

以下是详细信息：公式的变量部分是与世界模型中每个命名个体对应的变量列表（字符串、数字和序列除外）；distinct部分是一个缩写，表示这些个体彼此不同（具体细节见附录）；中间是一系列原子公式，与世界模型相同，只是使用变量而不是常量（如上所示）；最后，至多是一系列缩写（再次在附录中描述），以单词“ there is at most”开头，范围涵盖世界模型中使用的每个概念和角色，并考虑到原子公式的数量提到那个概念或角色的中间部分。

Here are the details: the variables part of the formula is a list of variables corresponding to each named individual in the world model (other than strings, numbers, and sequences); the distinct part is an abbreviation saying that these individuals are all different from each other (see the appendix for the exact details); middle is a sequence of atomic formulas that is identical to the world model except that the variables are used instead of the constants (as was done above); and finally, at most is a sequence of abbreviations (again described in the appendix) starting with the words “there is at most,” and ranging over every concept and role used in the world model as well as taking into account the number of atomic formulas in the middle part that mention that concept or role.

对于具有上述七项的世界模型，生动的公式如图B.1所示。这个生动的公式说，世界上有三种不同的事物具有所列的七个属性，不多也不少。（严格来说，一个生动的公式需要多说一点：它需要排除命名的概念和角色中没有任何属性的事物的可能性。我们在这里忽略这个复杂性。）

For the world model with the seven items above, the vivid formula is shown in figure B.1. This vivid formula says that there are three distinct things in the world having the seven properties exactly as listed, no more, no less. (Strictly speaking, a vivid formula needs to say one additional thing: it needs to rule out the possibility of things without any properties among the named concepts and roles. We ignore that complication here.)

生动的公式突出了世界模型在它可以表示的方面实际上是多么有限。除了明确列出的内容之外，它不允许存在他们可能拥有的事物或属性的可能性。

The vivid formula highlights just how restricted a world model actually is in terms of what it can represent. It does not allow for the possibility of there being things or properties they might have other than those it lists explicitly.

但是，如何表示关于（比方说）约翰出生年份未知的世界的知识呢？还是我们想要开放存在其他人的可能性的世界？

But how then to represent knowledge about a world where (say) John has a birth year that is not known? Or a world where we want to leave open the possibility of there being other people?

正如第 6 章首先指出的，这需要一种不同的表示方式。我们必须改变方式，不再像我们对世界模型所做的那样直接表示事物及其属性，而是表示有关事物及其属性的信息。这可以使用不生动的 L 公式最容易地完成。

As first noted in chapter 6, this requires a different mode of representation. We have to change gears, and represent not things and their properties directly, as we have been doing with world models, but rather information about things and their properties. This can be done most easily using formulas of L that are not vivid.

非生动的知识表示

Nonvivid Knowledge Representation

要了解这是如何工作的，让我们重新考虑第 6 章中介绍的高中舞会示例。对于第一个变体（图 6.2），直接从给定信息构建世界模型并不难：所有相关个人及其列出属性。它看起来像这样：

To see how this works, let us reconsider the high school prom example presented in chapter 6. For the first variant (figure 6.2), it is not too hard to construct a world model directly from the given information: all the relevant individuals and their properties are listed. It would look something like this:

Boy#51 is a boy. Boy#52 is a boy. Boy#53 is a boy.

Boy#51 is a boy. Boy#52 is a boy. Boy#53 is a boy.

Girl#54 is a girl. Girl#55 is a girl. Girl#56 is a girl.

Girl#54 is a girl. Girl#55 is a girl. Girl#56 is a girl.

Boy#51 has “Bob” as a name. Boy#52 has “Bill” as a name.

Boy#51 has “Bob” as a name. Boy#52 has “Bill” as a name.

Boy#53 has “Brad” as a name. Girl#54 has “Gabby” as a name.

Boy#53 has “Brad” as a name. Girl#54 has “Gabby” as a name.

Girl#55 has “Gail” as a name. Girl#56 has “Gina” as a name.

Girl#55 has “Gail” as a name. Girl#56 has “Gina” as a name.

Boy#51 has Girl#56 as a promDate.

Boy#51 has Girl#56 as a promDate.

Boy#52 has Girl#55 as a promDate.

Boy#52 has Girl#55 as a promDate.

Boy#53 has Girl#54 as a promDate.

Boy#53 has Girl#54 as a promDate.

该模型包含三个男孩和三个女孩的名字，Bill ( Boy#52) 将 Gail ( Girl#55) 作为舞会约会对象，依此类推。（为了简单，promDate被认为是这些男孩的特性。更对称的表示是可能的。）这个世界模型在图 B.2 中以图形形式显示。

This model has the three boys and three girls with their given names, with Bill (Boy#52) having Gail (Girl#55) as a prom date, and so on. (For simplicity, promDate is taken to be a property of the boys in question. A more symmetrical representation is possible.) This world model is shown in graphical form in figure B.2.

按照上面的方法，图 B.3 中显示了一个捕获此信息的有点罗嗦的生动公式。总之，恰好有三个男孩、三个女孩、六个名字属性和三个舞会日期属性，与世界模型中列出的完全一样。

Following the recipe above, a somewhat-wordy vivid formula that captures this information is shown in figure B.3. In sum, there are exactly three boys, three girls, six name properties, and three prom date properties, exactly as listed in the world model.

现在将我们的注意力转向图 B.3 中舞会的第二个变体（逻辑谜题），立即清楚的是我们无法为这个变体构建世界模型。我们必须将 Bob 的符号与他参加舞会的日期联系起来，但我们只被告知这是 Gail 以外的其他人。链接会去哪里？虽然我们不能直接在世界模型中表示给定的信息，但我们仍然可以使用 L 的非生动公式来表示该信息。这个公式是通过替换三个项目得到的

Turning our attention now to the second variant of the prom in figure B.3 (the logic puzzle), what is immediately clear is that we cannot construct a world model for this variant. We would have to link the symbol for Bob to his date for the prom, but all we are told is that it is someone other than Gail. Where would the link go? While we cannot represent the given information directly in a world model, we can still represent that information using a nonvivid formula of L. This formula is obtained by replacing the three items

Boy:u has Girl:z as a promDate

Boy:u has Girl:z as a promDate

Boy:v has Girl:y as a promDate

Boy:v has Girl:y as a promDate

Boy:w has Girl:x as a promDate

Boy:w has Girl:x as a promDate

在图 B.3 的生动公式中由以下九项组成：

in the vivid formula of figure B.3 by the following nine items:

There is a Person:p where Boy:u has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Boy:u has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Boy:v has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Boy:v has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Boy:w has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Boy:w has Person:p as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:x as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:x as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:y as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:y as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:z as a promDate

There is a Person:p where Person:p has Girl:z as a promDate

It is not the case that Boy:u has Girl:y as a promDate

It is not the case that Boy:u has Girl:y as a promDate

It is not the case that Boy:w has Girl:y as a promDate

It is not the case that Boy:w has Girl:y as a promDate

Boy:w has Girl:x as a promDate or

Boy:w has Girl:x as a promDate or

Boy:v has Girl:x as a promDate

Boy:v has Girl:x as a promDate

由此产生的公式不再说明谁将和谁一起去参加舞会。相反，它说三个男孩中的每一个都和某人一起去，三个女孩中的每一个都和某人一起去，然后提供给定的三个线索：Bob 不会和 Gail 一起去，Gail 不会和 Brad 一起去，而 Gabby 会和 Brad 或 Bill 一起去。

The resulting formula no longer says who is going to the prom with whom. Instead it says that each of the three boys is going with someone and each of the three girls is going with someone, and then provides the three given clues: Bob is not going with Gail, Gail is not going with Brad, and Gabby is going with Brad or Bill.

关于这两个舞会公式——生动的公式和更大的、不生动的公式，我们能说些什么？就逻辑而言，这两个公式是等价的：当另一个为真时，一个为真。如果我们从给出 Bob 和 Gina 等的生动公式开始，我们可以看到非生动公式为真——例如，Bob 不会和 Gail 一起去，而 Gabby 会和 Brad 一起去或比尔。相反，如果我们从非生动的开始，我们得到 Bob 不会和 Gail 一起去以及所有其他线索，并假设我们现在解决了这个谜题，我们可以看到生动的那个将是真实的——例如， Bob 和 Gina 一起去，Gail 和 Bill 一起去，Brad 和 Gabby 一起去。

What can we say about these two prom formulas—the vivid one and the larger, nonvivid one? In terms of logic, the two formulas are equivalent: one is true exactly when the other is. If we start with the vivid formula where we are given that Bob is going with Gina and so on, we can see that the nonvivid one will be true—for instance, that Bob is not going with Gail, and that Gabby is going with Brad or Bill. Conversely, if we begin with the nonvivid one where we are given that Bob is not going with Gail and all the other clues, and assuming that we now solve the puzzle, we can see that the vivid one will be true—for example, that Bob is going with Gina, Gail is going with Bill, and Brad is going with Gabby.

然而这两个公式显然并不相同。如前所述，在第一种情况下弄清楚 Bob 带谁去参加舞会非常容易，但在第二种情况下弄清楚 Bob 带谁去参加舞会需要解决难题。

And yet the two formulas are clearly not identical. As already noted, figuring out who Bob is taking to the prom in the first case is dead easy, but figuring out who Bob is taking to the prom in the second case requires solving the puzzle.

综上所述，对于每一个世界模型，都会有一个携带相同显式信息的L公式，反之则不成立。L 的公式可以省略需要在世界模型中阐明的细节。事实上，我们可以很容易地构造出比上面的非生动公式遗漏更多的其他非生动公式。

To summarize, for every world model, there will be a formula of L carrying the same explicit information, but the converse does not hold. A formula of L can omit details that would need to be spelled out in a world model. In fact, we can easily construct other nonvivid formulas that leave out even more than the nonvivid formula above.

比如从图B.3的生动公式入手，去掉distinct和at most部分。想想结果公式为真的世界模型。它会说鲍勃像以前一样和吉娜一起去，但现在留下其他可能性。例如，名为“Bob”的人很可能与名为“Brad”的人是同一个人，因此也可能会和 Gabby 一起去参加舞会。此外，鲍勃可能会带其他三个女孩以外的其他女孩（就此而言，还有一些男孩）。在这种情况下，确定 Bob 是否带 Gina 以外的人不是解决难题的问题；那里找不到信息。

For example, start with the vivid formula of figure B.3, and remove the distinct and at most parts. Think of world models where the resulting formula would be true. It would say that Bob is going with Gina as before, but now leave open other possibilities. The individual named “Bob” might well be the same as the one named “Brad,” for instance, and so might also be going to the prom with Gabby. Furthermore, Bob may be taking other girls beyond the three named ones (and some boys too, for that matter). In this case, it is not a matter of solving a puzzle to determine if Bob is taking someone other than Gina; the information is not there to be found.

那么回到一开始的问题，L的公式可以代替世界模型来表示知识吗？我们现在可以看出答案是肯定的。在封闭世界的解释下，对于每个世界模型，都有一个生动的 L 公式（带有适当的“不同”和“至多”子公式）说的是完全相同的事情。然而，有一些 L 的公式超出了世界模型中可以表示的范围。像 L 这样的语言的表达能力在于它可以留下什么并且悬而未决。通过使用世界模型作为我们的知识表示（当然连同概念模型和推导子句），我们显然将自己限制在可以表示的知识种类上。

So returning to the question at the beginning, could a formula of L take the place of a world model as a representation of knowledge? We can now see that the answer is yes. Under the closed-world interpretation, for every world model, there is a vivid formula of L (with appropriate “distinct” and “at most” subformulas) that says exactly the same thing. There are formulas of L, however, that go beyond what can be represented in world models. The expressive power of a language like L lies in what it can leave open and unresolved. By using world models as our representation of knowledge (together with conceptual models and derivation clauses, of course), we are plainly restricting ourselves in the kind of knowledge that can be represented.

我们为什么要这样做呢？为什么我们将可以表示和推理的知识种类限制为这些生动的公式？我们将在最后一节中谈到这一点。但是让我们首先在一个更简单的例子中更仔细地看看生动和非生动案例之间的区别。

Why are we doing this? Why are we limiting the kinds of knowledge that can be represented and reasoned with to what amounts to these vivid formulas? We will get to that in the final section. But let us first look more closely at the difference between the vivid and nonvivid cases in an even simpler example.

生动与非生动的界限

On the Boundary between Vivid and Nonvivid

查看第 6 章的舞会示例，很明显第二个版本是某种逻辑难题。它有这样的信息

In looking at the prom example from chapter 6, it was clear that the second version was some sort of logic puzzle. It had information like

鲍勃要和盖尔以外的人一起去参加舞会。

Bob is going to the prom with someone other than Gail.

嘉比要和布拉德或比尔一起去参加舞会。

Gabby is going to the prom with Brad or Bill.

必须使用“不”、“或”和“存在”等逻辑运算符来表示。然而，构建不需要像这样的运算符的谜题是可能的。这是一个：

which had to be represented using logical operators such as “not,” “or,” and “there is.” Yet it is possible to construct puzzles that do not require operators like these. Here is one:

杰克、安妮和乔治在一个房间里。杰克看着安妮，安妮看着乔治。杰克结婚了，乔治离婚了。

Jack, Anne, and George are together in a room. Jack is looking at Anne, and Anne is looking at George. Jack is married, and George is divorced.

已婚的人在看未婚的人吗？

Is a married person looking at a person who is not married?

首先要注意的是，问题的答案并不是立即显而易见的。事实上，心理学家已经就这个问题对人们进行了测试，大多数受试者认为问题陈述中没有足够的信息来以这种或那种方式回答问题。不知道安妮的婚姻状况怎么能回答呢？

The first thing to observe is that the answer to the question is not immediately obvious. In fact, psychologists have tested people on this problem, and most subjects think that there is not enough information in the statement of the problem to answer the question one way or the other. How can you answer without knowing Anne’s marital status?

事实证明，问题实际上可以从给定的信息中得到回答。要看清这一点，请考虑安妮的婚姻状况：如果安妮已婚，那么她是一个已婚的人看着一个未婚的人（乔治）；如果安妮没有结婚，那么杰克就是一个已婚的人看着一个未婚的人（她）。我们没有被告知安妮是否已婚，但这并不重要；不管怎样，一个已婚的人正在看一个未婚的人。所以这是一个与毕业舞会不同的谜题，可以通过解开谜题来回答问题。（请注意，这里没有足够的信息来确定未婚者是否在看未婚者。）

As it turns out, the question can in fact be answered from the given information. To see this, consider Anne’s marital status: if Anne is married, then she is a married person looking at an unmarried one (George); if Anne is not married, then Jack is a married person looking at an unmarried one (her). We are not told if Anne is married, but it doesn’t matter; either way, a married person is looking at a person who is not married. So this is a puzzle not unlike the prom one, and the question can be answered by solving the puzzle. (Note that there is not enough information here to determine if an unmarried person is looking at a person who is not married.)

如果我们上一节的分析是正确的，那么应该不可能使用世界模型（或生动的公式）来表示给定的信息。但是考虑一下这个：

If our analysis from the previous section is correct, it should not be possible to use a world model (or vivid formula) to represent the given information. But consider this one:

Person#31 is a person. Person#31 has “Jack” as a name.

Person#31 is a person. Person#31 has “Jack” as a name.

Person#32 is a person. Person#32 has “Anne” as a name.

Person#32 is a person. Person#32 has “Anne” as a name.

Person#33 is a person. Person#33 has “George” as a name.

Person#33 is a person. Person#33 has “George” as a name.

Person#31 has Person#32 as an itemInView.

Person#31 has Person#32 as an itemInView.

Person#32 has Person#33 as an itemInView.

Person#32 has Person#33 as an itemInView.

Person#31 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

Person#31 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

Person#33 has “divorced” as a maritalStatus.

Person#33 has “divorced” as a maritalStatus.

这似乎代表了给定的信息。像这样的世界模型不能完成这项工作吗？

This seems to represent the given information. Does a world model like this not do the job?

不，不是的。问题是根据世界模型的封闭世界解释，正如公式

No, it does not. The problem is that according to the closed-world interpretation of world models, just as the formula

Person#33 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

Person#33 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

根据这个模型会被认为是错误的（适当的：乔治离婚了），公式

would be considered to be false according to this model (as appropriate: George is divorced), the formula

Person#32 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

Person#32 has “married” as a maritalStatus.

也将被认为是错误的，因为模型中没有关于 Anne 的婚姻状况的陈述。事实上，在这两种情况下，该TEST操作都会返回答案FALSE。换句话说，就这个模型而言，Anne 和 George 都没有已婚属性，而在拼图本身中，只提到了 George 的婚姻状况，而 Anne 的婚姻状况是开放的。得出安妮未婚的结论太过分了。所以上面的世界模型（或相应的生动公式）并不能正确地表示给定的信息。（可以使用非生动的公式忠实地表示给定的信息，就像我们在上一节中所做的那样。我们会在公式中使用“有”来表示安妮确实有婚姻状况，但不说明它是什么是。）

would also be considered to be false because there is no statement about Anne’s marital status in the model. Indeed, the TEST operation would return the answer FALSE in both cases. In other words, as far as this model is concerned, neither Anne nor George have the property of being married, whereas in the puzzle itself, only the marital status of George is mentioned and Anne’s is left open. To conclude that Anne is not married is a step too far. So the world model above (or corresponding vivid formula) does not correctly represent the given information. (It is possible to represent the given information faithfully using a nonvivid formula, much as we did in the previous section. We would use a “there is” within the formula to say that Anne does have a marital status, without spelling out what it is.)

所有这些都表明，使这些难题难以解决的不是问题陈述中“不”或“或”等运算符的存在，而是一些相关细节被遗漏的事实——我们会遗漏的细节需要知道在世界模型中表示给定的信息，并且需要拼图才能解决问题。

What all of this suggests is that what makes these puzzles hard to solve is not the presence of operators such as “not” or “or” in the statement of the problem but rather the fact that some relevant details are left out—details we would need to know to represent the given information in a world model, and would need to puzzle through in order to solve the problem.

请注意，如果安妮的婚姻状况已作为问题陈述的一部分提供，则工作将完全改变。考虑这个变体：

Note that if Anne’s marital status had been provided as part of the statement of the problem, the effort would change completely. Consider this variant:

杰克、安妮和乔治在一个房间里。杰克看着安妮，安妮看着乔治。杰克已婚，安妮单身，而乔治离婚了。

Jack, Anne, and George are together in a room. Jack is looking at Anne, and Anne is looking at George. Jack is married, Anne is single, and George is divorced.

已婚的人在看未婚的人吗？

Is a married person looking at a person who is not married?

答案现在很明显了。并非巧合的是，我们现在还可以确定问题中已婚和未婚的人分别是谁：杰克和安妮。如果安妮的婚姻状况是已婚、丧偶或离婚，情况也是如此。在每一种情况下，很容易看出一个已婚的人在看一个未婚的人。从我们的角度来看，使包括安妮的婚姻状况在内的变体易于推理的原因是可以在世界模型中准确捕获相关信息。

The answer is now obvious. Not coincidentally, we can now also determine who the married and unmarried persons in the question are: Jack and Anne, respectively. The same would be true if Anne’s marital status had been given as married, widowed, or divorced. In each case, it would be easy to see that a married person was looking at an unmarried one. From our point of view, what makes the variants that include Anne’s marital status easy to reason with is that the relevant information can be captured exactly in a world model.

常识课

The Lesson for Common Sense

人们更容易用足够具体的信息进行推理，以在世界模型中表示，这一观察结果是我们在本书中提出的常识机制的核心。

The observation that it is easier for people to reason with information that is specific enough to be represented in a world model is at the heart of what we are proposing in this book as a mechanism for common sense.

要看到这一点，请再次考虑舞会示例和以下公式，表示 Bob 将与 Gina 一起去参加舞会：

To see this, consider the prom example once again and the following formula that says that Bob is going to the prom with Gina:

There is a Person:x and a Person:y where

There is a Person:x and a Person:y where

Person:x has “Bob” as a name,

Person:x has “Bob” as a name,

Person:y has “Gina” as a name, and

Person:y has “Gina” as a name, and

Person:x has Person:y as a promDate.

Person:x has Person:y as a promDate.

舞会示例的两个变体都将此公式作为逻辑结果。也就是说，给定生动公式或非生动公式，仅使用逻辑规则就可以确定上面的公式为真：它们在逻辑上都蕴含鲍勃要和吉娜去参加舞会。

Both variants of the prom example have this formula as a logical consequence. That is, given either the vivid or nonvivid formula, it is possible to determine that the formula above is true using just the rules of logic: they both logically entail that Bob is going to the prom with Gina.

但是这两种情况是有区别的，是计算性的。在生动的情况下，可以使用适当的世界模型上的过程轻松确定公式的真实性TEST：找到一对常数，使得上面公式中的三个原子公式出现在模型中。TEST换成直接在生动的公式上工作而不是在世界模型上工作来获得这个答案并不难。

But there is a difference between the two cases, and it is a computational one. In the vivid case, the truth of the formula can be easily determined using the TEST procedure on the appropriate world model: find the pair of constants such that the three atomic formulas in the formula above appear in the model. It would not be hard to change TEST to work directly on the vivid formula instead of on the world model to obtain this answer.

但在非生动的情况下，这种具体策略将行不通。要确定上述公式在那种情况下为真，需要采用非生动公式中给出的内容，然后采取必要的措施来解决这个难题。一般来说，在没有明确限制的情况下，确定一个公式是否是另一个公式的逻辑结果需要相当多的逻辑机制——就像在逻辑教科书中看到的那种（并且超出了本书的范围）。这种计算也许适用于拼图推理，但远远超出了我们对普通常识的预期。

But in the nonvivid case, this concrete strategy would not work. To determine that the above formula is true in that case requires taking what is given in the nonvivid formula and then doing what is necessary to solve the puzzle. In general, determining whether one formula is a logical consequence of another without the vivid restriction requires considerable logical machinery—just the sort seen in logic textbooks (and beyond the scope of this book). This computation is suitable for puzzle-mode reasoning perhaps, but well beyond what we can expect for ordinary common sense.

这里的关键点在于：我们需要常识推理足够简单，以便可以以完全自动化的方式对其进行例行计算，无需付出太多努力或仔细监控，即使是在庞大的知识库中也是如此。我们的意思是，存在一种基于具有此属性的经典逻辑的通用推理形式。然而，这种逻辑必须限于一种受限形式的前提：生动的公式。如果我们要放弃对世界模型的封闭世界解释，所需的逻辑推理将变得过于苛刻而无法用于此目的。（这是关于真理的推理：什么是真的，什么将是真的，或者如何使某事成为真的。更多联想的推理，比如x如何连接到y，或更类比，比如P与Q有何相似之处，需要自己进行分析。）

The key point here is this: we need commonsense reasoning to be easy enough that it can be computed routinely in a completely automated way, without much effort or careful monitoring, even over enormous knowledge bases. What we are suggesting is that there is a generic form of reasoning based on classical logic that has this property. This logic, however, must be limited to premises of a restricted form: vivid formulas. If we were to give up on the closed-world interpretation of world models, the required logical reasoning would become too demanding to serve for this purpose. (This is for reasoning about truth: what is true, what will be true, or how to make something true. Reasoning that is more associational, like how is x connected to y, or more analogical, like how is a P similar to a Q, would need its own analysis.)

这就是使用世界模型（增加了概念模型和推导子句）作为常识推理基础的关键计算理由。这就是为什么常识可以建立在逻辑推理的基础上而不必卷入复杂的逻辑中。最后，使用逻辑的专业知识并不是常识的先决条件。

This then is the crucial computational justification for using world models (augmented with conceptual models and derivation clauses) as the basis for commonsense reasoning. This is what explains how common sense can rest on a foundation of logical reasoning without having to be embroiled in the intricacies of logic. In the end, expertise in the use of logic is not a prerequisite for common sense.

它还有助于理解一个奇怪的现象。在谜题之外的常识上下文中，人类似乎被迫填写他们所获得的信息中遗漏的细节。例如，当我们被告知一只狗追逐着一只猫绕着一棵树转了一圈又一圈时，我们很难不去想象这些动物在顺时针或逆时针方向移动。如果我们被告知一个年轻女孩站在前总统罗纳德里根旁边拍照，我们会发现很难不把这个女孩放在里根的左边或右边。这与我们之前提到的心理学家所说的重建记忆有关。这个想法是当我们试图记住我们过去经历过或被告知的事情时，我们最终会回忆起各种可能有意义的细节，但这些细节不属于我们当时所提供的内容。原则上，逻辑公式可以用来表示给定的信息，而不指定那些额外的细节（就像我们在上面对 Gabby 的日期所做的那样），但我们似乎被推向使用想要更具体的心理表征。有人可能会争辩说，这实际上可以用视觉意象来解释：我们不仅在思考涉及狗和猫的事件，而且也在我们脑海中以某种方式想象一个视觉场景，这个场景不禁显示追逐的顺时针或逆时针方向。但是正如我们在第 4 章中看到的，视觉图像本身并不是一种非常适合常识推理的表示。也许更好的表达方式是说真实的或想象的视觉场景产生（或以某种方式连接）世界模型，它们是世界的模拟物，与图像不同，它们适合于一种易于计算的推理形式.

It also helps make sense of a curious phenomenon. In a commonsense context outside of puzzles, humans seem to be compelled to fill in details left out of the information they are given. For example, when we are told that a dog chased a cat round and round a tree, we find it hard to think about it without imagining the animals moving in a clockwise or counterclockwise direction. If we are told that a young girl stood beside former president Ronald Reagan for a photograph, we find it hard to think about it without putting the girl on Reagan’s left or right. This is related to what psychologists call reconstructive memory, which we touched on earlier. The idea is that when we try to remember something we experienced or were told about in the past, we end up recalling all sorts of details that might make sense, but were not part of what we were given at the time. In principle, logical formulas could have been used to represent the given information leaving those extra details unspecified (as we did with Gabby’s date above), but we seem to be pushed toward using a mental representation that wants to be more specific. It might be argued that this is actually explainable in terms of visual imagery: we are not just thinking about an incident involving a dog and cat but are imagining a visual scene somehow in our mind’s eye too, and the scene can’t help but show a clockwise or counterclockwise direction for the chase. But as we saw in chapter 4, a visual image by itself is not the sort of representation well suited for commonsense reasoning. Maybe a better way of putting it is to say that real or imagined visual scenes give rise (or are connected in some way) to world models, which are analogues of the world not unlike images, which lend themselves to a readily computable form of reasoning.

值得指出的是，逻辑和常识之间存在最后但微妙的联系。首先请注意，当我们谈论一个被相信的公式时，我们的意思是根据世界模型（由操作计算），它被认为是真实的TEST。所以我们真的有两个这里有不同的概念：可以直接在世界模型中表示的信息，正如我们所讨论的那样，在逻辑形式上受到限制；以及可以相信的公式——一个更大的集合——从而可以更自由地使用逻辑运算符。要记住的是：当我们说相信一个逻辑上复杂的公式时，必须有一个支持该信念的幕后简单世界模型。例如，考虑一下表示 Bob 正带 Gail 以外的人去参加舞会的公式。如果完全相信该公式，那是因为在基础世界模型中，Bob 的日期是指定的并且恰好是 Gail 以外的其他人。

There is a final but subtle connection between logic and common sense that is worth pointing out. First note that when we talk about a formula being believed, we mean that it is considered to be true according to a world model (as computed by the TEST operation). So we really have two distinct notions here: the information that can be represented directly in a world model, which as we argued, is restricted in logical form; and the formulas that can be believed—a much larger set—and thus get to use logical operators much more freely. The thing to remember is this: when we say that a logically complex formula is believed, there has to be a simple world model behind the scenes that supports that belief. So consider, for example, the formula that says that Bob is taking someone other than Gail to the prom. If that formula is believed at all, it is because in the underlying world model, Bob’s date is specified and happens to be someone other than Gail.

这种理解信念的方式导致了以下有点令人惊讶的结论：

This way of understanding belief leads to the following, somewhat-surprising conclusion:

  • 如果相信公式P并且P在逻辑上蕴含Q，
  • If a formula P is believed and P logically entails Q,
  • 那么公式Q也将被相信。
  • then the formula Q will also be believed.

这就是所谓的在逻辑蕴涵下“封闭”的信念。然而，重要的是要强调，我们不能从这个事实中得出结论，agent 必须是某种逻辑巫师，能够执行任何数量的逻辑推理，从P到它所需要的任何东西。（这就是哲学家 Jaakko Hintikka 所说的逻辑无所不知。）事实上，我们并没有提到代理能够以这种方式从公式P开始工作；它必须从一个世界模型开始它的工作。此处得出的正确结论是，如果智能体可以从其世界模型（或生动的公式）得到P ，它也将能够从同一模型得到Q。从外部看，我们可能能够看到从P到Q之间存在逻辑联系，但我们并不坚持常识代理能够看到它。

This is what is known as belief being “closed” under logical entailment. Yet it is important to stress that we cannot conclude from this fact that the agent must be some sort of logical wizard, able to carry out any amount of logical reasoning, to go from P to anything it entails. (This is what philosopher Jaakko Hintikka calls logical omniscience.) In fact, we have said nothing about the agent being able to work from a formula P in this way; it must start its work from a world model. The right conclusion to draw here is that if the agent can get to P from its world model (or vivid formula), it will also be able to get to Q from that same model. From the outside, we may be able to see that there is a logical connection from P to Q, but we are not insisting that a commonsense agent be able to see it.

一些并发症和局限性

Some Complications and Limitations

在这一附加章节中，我们探讨了这样一种想法，即虽然从世界模型中得出结论是一种可行的常识推理形式，但从更普遍的公式中得出结论并不是必需的。然而，我们在表示和推理方面都掩盖了许多微妙之处，我们通过查看其中的一些来得出结论。

In this bonus chapter, we explored the idea that while drawing conclusions from a world model was a feasible form of commonsense reasoning, drawing conclusions from formulas more generally need not be. There are many subtleties we glossed over, however, both in terms of the representation and the reasoning, and we conclude by looking at some of them.

让我们先考虑推理。尽管之前的TESTandFIND-ALL操作与无限制的逻辑推理相比确实相对容易，但在某些情况下，它们要做的事情对于常识性应用来说可能仍然要求过高。

Let us consider reasoning first. Even though the TEST and FIND-ALL operations from before are indeed relatively easy compared to unrestricted logical reasoning, there are cases where what they have to do might still be too demanding for commonsense applications.

想象一下，例如，使用TEST来确定涉及五个变量的“存在”公式是否为真。在这种情况下，TEST需要看看它是否可以在世界模型中找到五个常数的组合来使公式成立。让我们假设模型提到了 1,000 个常量。然后TEST可能仍然需要查看多达 10 15种不同的组合，看看它们是否有效。就算每秒考虑十亿个组合，也需要十几天的时间才能全部推完！

Imagine, for example, using TEST to determine if a “there is” formula is true where five variables are involved. In this case, TEST needs to see if it can find a combination of five constants in the world model to make the formula true. Let us suppose that the model mentions 1,000 constants. Then TEST might still have to look at as many as 1015 different combinations to see if any of them work. Even if it could consider a billion combinations every second, it would still take more than ten days to go through them all!

不过，这里有一些缓解因素。一是很少有必要找到像这样的五个相互关联的事物的组合。成对的东西，是的，有时是三倍的，但很少超过。另一个是TEST可以比穷尽所有组合做得更好。FIND-ALL它可以自下而上地逐步计算这五个变量的答案。例如，如果公式是连词并且包含

There are mitigating factors here, though. One is that it will seldom be necessary to find a combination of five interconnected things like this. Pairs of things, yes, and sometimes triples, but rarely beyond. The other is that TEST can do much better than to search exhaustively through all combinations. It can compute the answers to FIND-ALL for those five variables incrementally from the bottom up. For example, if the formula is a conjunction and contains

Person:x has Person:y as a friend

Person:x has Person:y as a friend

作为其合取项之一，答案仅需包含世界模型中与朋友相关的Person:x值，而不是所有 10 6 个组合。如果公式中还有其他仅使用这两个变量的连词，那么这个数字还可以进一步减少。如果对于下一个变量，有一个合取Person:yPerson:z

as one of its conjuncts, an answer only has to include values for Person:x and Person:y that are friend related in the world model, not all 106 combinations. If there are other conjuncts in the formula that just use these two variables, then that number can be further reduced. If for the next variable Person:z, there is a conjunct

Person:z has Person:y as a brother

Person:z has Person:y as a brother

那么答案只需要包括Person:z世界模型中兄弟相关的值到Person:y目前答案中的一些值，而不是所有 10 9三元组。等等。这是所谓的数据库联合查询评估的基础，并且已被发现在实践中非常有效，即使对于非常大的数据库也是如此。

then an answer only has to include values of Person:z that are brother related in the world model to some Person:y in the answer so far, not all 109 triples. And so on. This is the basis of what is called conjunctive query evaluation for databases and has been found to be quite effective in practice even for extremely large databases.

另一个复杂的TEST问题是递归。虽然能够说我们可以在模型中TEST寻找关系链（如第 8 章中所见）是件好事，但这实际上是一个强大的操作。parent我们是否保证TEST将始终停止扩展递归定义并得出最终答案？不会。有一些递归定义的属性可以让TEST（或任何计算引擎）永远运行。这里的缓解因素是，出于常识目的，递归只能以有限的方式使用，例如用于传递闭包（如从到parent）ancestor，为此可以使用专用机器。

Another complication with TEST concerns recursion. While it is nice to be able to say that we can have TEST look for chains of parent relationships in a model (as seen in chapter 8), this is in fact a powerful operation. Are we guaranteed that TEST will always stop expanding recursive definitions and come to a final answer? No. There are recursively defined properties that would keep TEST (or any computational engine) running forever. The mitigating factor here is that for commonsense purposes, recursion would only be used in limited ways, such as for transitive closures (like going from parent to ancestor), for which special-purpose machinery is available.

一个相关的并发症涉及数字。我们可以很容易地进行修改，TEST以便2*3 < 5+4通过执行必要的算术，它可以将没有变量的公式识别为真。但是我们不应该期望TEST能够将带有变量的算术公式作为常识推理的一部分进行评估。是否有除二以外的偶数不是两个质数之和？连专家都不知道。这里的一个缓解因素是，当涉及到变量时，TEST和FIND-ALL操作仅限于查找模型中出现的常量。例如，FIND-ALL对于公式6 < Number:x只会返回模型中实际出现的大于 6 的（有限多个）数值常量，而不会尝试返回大于 6 的无限数量的数字。

A related complication concerns numbers. We can easily modify TEST so that it will recognize a formula without variables like 2*3 < 5+4 as true by doing the necessary arithmetic. But we should not expect TEST to be able to evaluate arithmetic formulas with variables as part of commonsense reasoning. Is there an even number other than two that is not the sum of two prime numbers? Not even the experts know. One mitigating factor here is that when it comes to variables, the TEST and FIND-ALL operations are restricted to look for constants that appear in the model. So for example, FIND-ALL for the formula 6 < Number:x will only return the (finitely many) numerical constants greater than six that actually appear in the model and not attempt to return the infinite number of numbers that are greater than six.

同样的问题也适用于序列，正如在第 8 章的规划上下文中所讨论的那样。像这样的操作FIND-ALL不能用于定位实现某个目标的动作序列，除非模型中有代表它们的常量。我们期望在这个世界上看到什么模型是过去被发现有用的动作的表示。（这是第 2 章讨论的常识的关键要素之一。）当动作不是原始动作时，它将在模型中与一系列原始动作相关联。然后操作FIND-ALL应该能够找到那些记住的动作序列以用于计划目的。正如我们在第 9 章中看到的，这种更为有限的规划概念更适合常识性目的。从第一原理组装一个全新的动作序列的操作是一项计算要求高的任务，最好留给拼图模式推理。

The same issue applies to sequences, as discussed in the context of planning in chapter 8. An operation like FIND-ALL cannot be used to locate sequences of actions that achieve some goal, unless there are constants in the model representing them. What we would expect to see in a world model are representations of actions that have been found to be useful in the past. (This is one of the key elements of common sense discussed in chapter 2.) When the action is not primitive, it will be associated in the model with a sequence of primitive actions. The FIND-ALL operation should then be able to locate those remembered sequences of actions for planning purposes. As we saw in chapter 9, this much more limited notion of planning is more appropriate for commonsense purposes. The operation of assembling a totally new sequence of actions from first principles is a computationally demanding task best left for puzzle-mode reasoning.

现在让我们转向代表性。我们提出的是，基本知识将在世界模型中表示（第 7 章），而表达为公式的信念将从中导出（第 8 章）。这遗漏了如何处理我们在第 6 章中称为不完整知识的内容，其中缺少有关特定事物和属性的相关细节。在这一附加章节中，我们看到了处理这类知识如何需要解决逻辑难题，这超出了我们对常识的预期。

Let us now turn to representation. What we have proposed is that basic knowledge would be represented in world models (chapter 7), and the beliefs expressed as formulas would be derived from them (chapter 8). This leaves out what to do with what we called in chapter 6 incomplete knowledge, where relevant details are missing about the specific things and properties involved. In this bonus chapter, we saw how dealing with this kind of knowledge can require solving logical puzzles, beyond what we can expect of common sense.

但是还有其他形式的不完整知识。例如，考虑阅读一本推理小说，其中三名嫌疑人中的一名犯下谋杀罪。我们可以想象从一个世界模型开始，其中三个常量代表三个人，以及关于他们的各种事实，如第 7 章所示。一旦我们发现其中一个是凶手，这个方案就会崩溃。从某种意义上说，悬疑小说确实变成了谜题。我们承认，在我们找出凶手是谁之前，可能会有一些线索需要处理和得出结论，就像上面的舞会例子一样。

But there are other forms of incomplete knowledge. Consider, for example, reading a mystery novel where a murder was committed by one of three suspects. We can imagine starting with a world model with three constants representing the three individuals and various facts about them represented as in chapter 7. Once we discover that one of them is the murderer, however, this scheme breaks down. In one sense, the mystery novel does indeed become a puzzle. We accept that there may be clues to deal with and conclusions we will not get to until we find out who the murderer is, just like in the prom example above.

不过，很明显，在解开谜题之前，我们还需要能够对凶手进行推理。例如，杀人犯出生在某个地方，有母亲，需要呼吸等等，这是常识，就像其他人一样。如果像这样的结论必须等到我们知道凶手是谁，我们对小说的理解就不会太远。例如，如果我们在小说的早期发现凶手早餐吃了格兰诺拉麦片，我们就应该能够得出结论，凶手那天早上吃了东西，而不必先弄清楚凶手是谁。

Still, it is clear that we also need to be able to reason about the murderer before solving the puzzle. For instance, it is common sense that the murderer was born somewhere, has a mother, needs to breathe, and so on, like any other person. We will not get far in our understanding of the novel if conclusions such as these have to wait until we know who the murderer is. If we find out early in the novel that the murderer had granola for breakfast, say, we should be able to conclude that the murderer ate something that morning without having to first figure out who the murderer is.

那么我们如何在世界模型中表示这种不完整的知识呢？最明显的答案是我们应该在模型中使用第四个常数代表凶手。然后我们可以表示信息关于凶手作为一个人并从中得出结论，就像我们对三个嫌疑人中的每一个一样。

So how do we represent this kind of incomplete knowledge in a world model? The most obvious answer is that we should use a fourth constant in the model standing for the murderer. We can then represent information about the murderer as a person and draw conclusions from it, just as we would for each of the three suspects.

但是，这有问题。首先，我们不能再假设 L 的每个公式都将被认为是真或假。例如，如果第一嫌疑人表示为Person#92，凶手表示为UnknownPerson#17，则公式

There are problems with this, though. First and foremost, we can no longer assume that every formula of L will be considered to be true or false. For example, if the first suspect is represented as Person#92 and the murderer is represented as UnknownPerson#17, then the formula

Person#92 is UnknownPerson#17.

Person#92 is UnknownPerson#17.

不能仅仅因为这两个常数不同就被认为是假的，就像我们迄今为止的惯例一样。在这个虚构的世界里，我们有三个人，但有四个常数。因此，TEST操作显然必须改变。（仔细阅读第 7 章会发现我们已经遇到了这个问题。我们将 John 的出生地点表示为SpacePt#25，但我们真的不知道这一点是否与我们可能已经考虑过的波士顿市的其他地点不同。 )

cannot be taken to be false just because the two constants are different, as has been our convention so far. We have three people in this fictional world, but four constants. So the TEST operation clearly has to change. (A close reading of chapter 7 will show that we already have this problem. We represented the location of John’s birth as SpacePt#25, but we do not really know whether this point is different from other points in the city of Boston we might have already considered.)

要了解所涉及的一些并发症，请注意公式

To get a glimpse of some of the complications involved, note that the formula

There is a Person:x where Person:x is a person and

There is a Person:x where Person:x is a person and

it is not the case that Person:x is UnknownPerson#17.

it is not the case that Person:x is UnknownPerson#17.

应该被认为是真实的，即使我们不能在四个中命名一个常量来替代以Person:x使嵌入的公式为真。因此，该TEST操作不仅需要在等式公式上表现得完全不同，而且在其他公式上也需要表现得完全不同。

should be considered to be true, even though we cannot name a constant among the four to substitute for Person:x to make the embedded formula true. So the TEST operation would need to behave quite differently not only on equality formulas but on the other formulas as well.

现在考虑另一种形式的不完整知识。假设后院有几只狗，我们被告知它们都是吉姆的。如果我们知道涉及四只狗，我们可以用这四只狗的表示构建一个模型，并指出它们中的每一只都归吉姆所有。没问题。但是如果我们不知道有多少只狗，我们怎么能表示它们都是吉姆所有的呢？看起来我们应该能够处理这样的事实，而不必处理每只狗的表现。当我们考虑这个陈述时，第 6 章中出现了一个相关问题：

Now consider a different form of incomplete knowledge. Suppose there are some dogs in the backyard and we are told that they all belong to Jim. If we know there are four dogs involved, we can construct a model with representations of those four dogs, noting that each one of them is owned by Jim. No problem. But if we have no idea how many dogs there are, how can we represent the fact that they are all owned by Jim? It seems like we ought to be able to handle a fact like this without having to deal with the representation of each individual dog. A related issue came up in chapter 6 when we considered this statement:

约翰地下室里所有的油漆罐都布满了灰尘。

All the paint cans in John’s basement are covered in dust.

同样，似乎我们应该能够表示此信息，而不必识别每个单独的油漆罐并表示其属性。这对于类似的东西更加明显

Again, it seems we should be able to represent this information without having to identify each individual paint can and represent its properties. This is even more obvious with something like

银河系中的所有恒星都比海王星大。

All the stars in the Milky Way galaxy are bigger than Neptune.

其中涉及一千亿人。

where one hundred billion individuals are involved.

这又是一种不完整的知识形式，附近潜伏着一些逻辑难题。这是一个改编自心理学家 Philip Johnson-Laird 的例子：

This is once again a form of incomplete knowledge, with some logical puzzles lurking nearby. Here is one, adapted from an example by psychologist Philip Johnson-Laird:

假设后院有几只狗，我们有以下两个事实：

Suppose there are some dogs in the backyard, and we have the following two facts:

1.后院所有的狗都是吉姆所有的。

1. All the dogs in the backyard are owned by Jim.

2.后院没有小型犬。

2. No small dogs are in the backyard.

那么下面哪三个陈述也一定是正确的？

Then which of the following three statements must also be true?

3.有些小狗不是吉姆所有的。

3. Some small dogs are not owned by Jim.

4.吉姆养的一些狗不小。

4. Some dogs owned by Jim are not small.

5.吉姆养的狗都不小。

5. None of the dogs owned by Jim are small.

这是一道谜题，这里的正确答案是（4）。和以前一样，我们不应该期望仅仅从（1）和（2）中得出这个结论，这仅仅是常识问题。

This is a puzzle, and the correct answer here is (4). As before, we should not expect to be able to get to this conclusion from (1) and (2) alone, as a matter of mere common sense.

然而，我们在第 6 章中提出的问题仍然存在：对于像 (1) 这样的基本事实，究竟应该如何处理？Johnson-Laird 提出了一种类似于我们的世界模型的表示，但具有许多附加功能。除其他事项外，Johnson-Laird 模型包括表示可能存在或可能不存在的假设对象的符号。因此，例如，我们将有一定数量的符号表示后院的狗，所有这些符号都标记为吉姆所有，还有一些表示吉姆拥有的其他对象，但不是后院的狗。换句话说，表示法假设存在许多单独的事物，然后使用生成的模型（或多个模型）从中得出涉及“全部”、“一些”和“无”的一般结论。（这与第 8 章末尾如何处理关于鸟类是飞行动物的一般问题有关。）从推理的角度来看，这是一个有吸引力的提议，尽管它需要作为一般表示机制进行进一步研究。例如，我们如何避免从这些模型中得出关于实际存在或不存在的虚假结论？

Yet the question we asked in chapter 6 remains: What exactly should be done with a basic fact like (1) by itself? Johnson-Laird proposes a representation that is similar to our world models, but with many additional features. Among other things, the Johnson-Laird models include symbols representing hypothetical objects which may or may not exist. So for example, we would have a certain number of symbols representing dogs in the backyard, all of which are marked as owned by Jim, and some representations of other objects owned by Jim that are not dogs in the backyard. The representation, in other words, postulates the existence of a number of individual things, and then uses the resulting model (or models) to derive general conclusions involving “all,” “some,” and “none” from them. (This is related to how a generic question about birds being flying animals was handled at the end of chapter 8.) This is an attractive proposal from the point of view of reasoning, although it needs further study as a general representational mechanism. How, for instance, do we avoid drawing spurious conclusions from these models about what actually does or does not exist?

用常识术语处理不完整知识的另一种可能性是，毕竟允许任意通用公式成为知识库的一部分（包括否定、析取、量化、模态、或其他），但只能从中得出某些肤浅的结论——肤浅到无法解决难题，但肤浅到可以很容易地计算。当知识库恰好生动时，肤浅的推理很可能与TEST操作相吻合。然而，在知识库中使用像 (1) 这样的公式，我们可能能够得出某些明显的结论，例如后院所有的棕色狗都是吉姆所有的事实，但无法将其与其他事实结合起来像（2）一样得出像（4）这样的结论，至少不是没有额外的脑力劳动。该提案再次需要进一步研究。

Another possibility for dealing with incomplete knowledge in commonsense terms is to allow arbitrary general formulas to be part of the knowledge base after all (including negations, disjunctions, quantifications, modalities, or whatever), but to draw only certain superficial conclusions from them—too superficial to allow hard puzzles to be solved, but superficial enough to be readily computable. When the knowledge base happens to be vivid, the superficial reasoning might well align with the TEST operation. With a formula like (1) in the knowledge base, however, we might be able to draw certain obvious conclusions, such as the fact that all the brown dogs in the backyard are owned by Jim, but be unable to combine it with other facts like (2) to draw conclusions like (4), at least not without additional mental effort. The proposal again needs further study.

顺便说一句，知识表示和推理的AI 子领域的大部分研究涉及在逻辑和概率推理的海洋中寻找其他“易处理的岛屿”，着眼于常识。换句话说，除了本书中描述的那些之外，从逻辑和概率的角度来看有意义，但即使在知识的大量符号表示上也能以足够有效的自动化方式执行的自动推理形式是什么？这与理论计算机科学中称为计算复杂性的部分更广泛的努力相吻合，以了解是什么使计算任务变得容易或困难。

Incidentally, a big part of the research in the AI subarea of knowledge representation and reasoning involves looking for other “islands of tractability” in the sea of logical and probabilistic reasoning, with an eye toward common sense. In other words, what are forms of automated reasoning beyond those described in this book that make sense from the point of view of logic and probability, but that can be carried out in an automated way efficiently enough even over enormous symbolic representations of knowledge? This dovetails with a broader effort in the part of theoretical computer science called computational complexity to understand what it is that makes computational tasks easy or hard.

致谢

Acknowledgments

这本书反映了我们自己对 AI 中重要事项的看法，并大量借鉴了我们在研究生涯中最终探索的主题。我们的名字如此频繁地出现在参考书目中并非巧合。我们中的一个人 (RJB) 主要在工业界工作，另一个人 (HJL) 主要在学术界工作，但我们都很幸运能够与人工智能领域一些最聪明的人一起工作并向他们学习。四十年后，要感谢的人太多了，但我们确实要感谢我们尊敬的同事、学生、博士后研究员和员工，没有他们，我们肯定会少很多话要说。

This book reflects our own views on what matters in AI and draws heavily on the topics we ended up exploring during our research careers. It’s not just a coincidence that our names show up so often in the bibliography. One of us (RJB) worked mostly in industry, and the other (HJL), mostly in academia, but we were both fortunate to have worked with and learned from some of the smartest people in AI. After forty years, there are too many people to thank by name, but we do want to acknowledge our esteemed colleagues, students, postdoctoral fellows, and employees, without whom we would certainly have had a lot less to say.

让我们谈谈具体情况。正如我们在笔记中提到的，在看到加里·马库斯和欧内斯特·戴维斯最近出版的书以及梅兰妮·米切尔的书后，我们受到启发，开始了这个项目。这三位作者愿意查看我们本书的初稿，并为我们提供了许多有益的评论。我们也感谢 Gerhard Lakemeyer、Gregg Vesonder 和三位匿名审稿人的评论。我们相信这本书因为他们的建议而变得更好。当然，我们进行了最终剪辑，因此本书中任何遗留的错误和疏忽都是我们的问题，而不是他们的问题。我们特别感谢 Bruce Brachman 提供的精美插图，如图 8.4 和 9.1 所示。

Let’s talk specifics. As we mention in the notes, we were inspired to take on this project after seeing the recent book by Gary Marcus and Ernest Davis as well as the one by Melanie Mitchell. Those three authors were willing to look at an early draft of our book and provided us with many helpful comments. We are also grateful for comments from Gerhard Lakemeyer, Gregg Vesonder, and three anonymous reviewers. We believe that the book is much better because of their advice. We had the final cut, of course, so any remaining errors and oversights in the book are our problem, not theirs. We especially thank Bruce Brachman for the terrific illustrations appearing as figures 8.4 and 9.1.

我们还要感谢麻省理工学院出版社的好心人。Alex Hoopes 和 Elizabeth Swayze 总是很友善和鼓励，并在整个过程中为我们提供了很好的建议。我们的编辑弗吉尼亚·克罗斯曼 (Virginia Crossman) 是一位出色的合作伙伴，对我们的理解至关重要终点线。我们不知道其他作者在其他出版社的竞争是什么，但与麻省理工学院出版社合作一直很愉快。

We also wish to acknowledge the good folks at MIT Press. Alex Hoopes and Elizabeth Swayze were invariably kind and encouraging, and helped us with excellent suggestions all the way through the process. Virginia Crossman, our editor, was a great partner and was critical to getting us across the finish line. We have no idea what other authors contend with at other publishing houses, but MIT Press has always been a joy to work with.

最后但同样重要的是，我们要感谢我们的家人；在写作和无数次 Zoom 会议期间，他们都在我们身边，我们敲定了所有细节。因此，对于 Gwen 和 Pat：感谢你们在所有嘈杂的敲击声中给予的爱、支持和耐心。

Last but not least, we wish to thank our families; they were there for us during the writing and myriad Zoom meetings where we hammered out all the details. So to Gwen and Pat: thank you for your love, support, and patience during all of that noisy hammering.

2021 年 4 月

April 2021

笔记

Notes

这本书在很大程度上借鉴了我们在长期研究生涯中对人工智能的了解。在本书的这一部分，我们按作者给出了一些影响我们思想的 AI 内部和外部出版物的指南。（我们将自己称为 RJB 和 HJL。）有关这些出版物的详细信息可以在参考书目中找到。这些笔记是根据本书的章节组织的，可以作为对提出的问题进行更全面研究的起点。

This book draws to a great extent on what we have learned about AI over our long research careers. In this section of the book, we give pointers by author to a number of publications inside and outside AI that influenced our thinking. (We will refer to ourselves as RJB and HJL.) Details on these publications can be found in the bibliography. These notes are organized according to the chapters of the book, and can serve as starting points for a more comprehensive study of the issues raised.

虽然这本书在很大程度上依赖于可追溯到 1950 年代的广泛人工智能研究，但它更直接地受到最近三本书的启发：加里马库斯和欧内斯特戴维斯的重启人工智能，梅兰妮米切尔的人工智能：人类思维指南，以及HJL 早期的一本书名为常识、图灵测试和对真正人工智能的探索。这三者的共同点是他们都关注当前人工智能研究的目标如何与该领域的最初愿景相去甚远。所有人都认同常识作为当前人工智能工作中未解决的主要因素之一，尽管在其他方面取得了如此多的成就。然而，这三本书都没有试图深入分析常识这一概念。这是什么常识？它是如何工作的？构建拥有它的 AI 系统需要什么？在我们看来，这些是需要调查的基本问题，并促使我们尝试填补一些缺失的细节。已经有一些关于常识的 AI 书籍，例如Davis 1990 年的Representations of Commonsense Knowledge ， Jerry Hobbs 和 Robert Moore 的Formal Theories of the Commonsense World ， John McCarthy 和 Vladimir Lifschitz 的Formalizing Common Sense ，以及Commonsense Reasoning由埃里克·穆勒 (Erik Mueller) 提出，但他们倾向于几乎完全专注于常识背后的知识的形式化。

While this book leans heavily on a broad spectrum of AI research going back to the 1950s, it was more directly inspired by three recent books: Rebooting AI by Gary Marcus and Ernest Davis, Artificial Intelligence: A Guide for Thinking Humans by Melanie Mitchell, and an earlier book by HJL titled Common Sense, the Turing Test, and the Quest for Real AI. What these three have in common was their focus on how the goals of current AI research fall short of the original vision of the field. All of them identified common sense as one of the main ingredients not being addressed in current AI work, despite so many achievements on other fronts. None of the three books, however, tried to analyze this idea of common sense in any depth. What is this common sense? How does it work? What would it take to build AI systems that had it? These, it seemed to us, were essential questions that needed to be investigated, and motivated us to try our hand at filling in some of the missing details. There are already some AI books on common sense, such as Representations of Commonsense Knowledge by Davis in 1990, Formal Theories of the Commonsense World by Jerry Hobbs and Robert Moore, Formalizing Common Sense by John McCarthy and Vladimir Lifschitz, and Commonsense Reasoning by Erik Mueller, but they tend to concentrate almost entirely on the formalization of the knowledge considered to lie behind common sense.

我们同事最近写的另外两本书也影响了我们的方法。Judea Pearl（与 Dana Mackenzie 合着）关于因果关系的Book of Why让我们相信有可能为普通读者编写一本包含小技术示例的 AI 书籍。我们的好朋友 Brian Cantwell Smith 在 2019 年出版的《人工智能的前景》一书让我们认真思考了我们和其他 AI 方法背后的哲学问题。

Two other recent books by colleagues of ours also influenced our approach. The Book of Why by Judea Pearl (with Dana Mackenzie) on causality made us believe it was possible to have a book on AI for general readers that included small technical examples. And the 2019 book The Promise of Artificial Intelligence by our good friend Brian Cantwell Smith made us think hard about the philosophical issues behind our and other approaches to AI.

最后，我们应该提到的是，这本书也受到了最近由不直接参与 AI 工作的人撰写的大量文章的推动。如今，很难阅读杂志和报纸的技术或商业版块，却找不到对 AI 当前技术水平的评论。其中一些将出现在下面的各个部分中。有关常识的早期报告，请参阅 1982 年的文章“计算机如何获得常识？” 由科普作家吉娜·科拉塔 (Gina Kolata) 撰写。值得注意的两篇对人工智能的一般性批评是社会学家哈里·柯林斯 (Harry Collins) 撰写的《人工智能》一书，以及科技记者蒂姆·克罗斯 (Tim Cross)在经济学人杂志上发表的 2020 年文章“对人工智能局限性的理解开始深入人心” 。

Finally, we should mention that the book was also spurred by the large number of recent pieces written by people not directly involved in AI work. It is hard to read the technical or business sections of magazines and newspapers these days without finding commentary on the current state of the art in AI. Some of these will show up in the various sections below. For an early report on common sense, see the 1982 article “How Can Computers Get Common Sense?” by the science writer Gina Kolata. Two general critiques of AI worth noting are the book Artifictional Intelligence by sociologist Harry Collins, and the 2020 article “An Understanding of AI’s Limitations Is Starting to Sink In” in the Economist by the science and technology correspondent Tim Cross.

第 1 章：常识之路

Chapter 1: The Road to Common Sense

这一介绍性章节激发了我们的方法，并提供了本书其余部分的概述。约翰·麦卡锡 (John McCarthy) 于 1958 年发表的开创性论文开启了人工智能对常识的所有思考，被恰当地称为“具有常识的程序”。更为人所知的版本包括后来的文章“情境、行动和因果律”，该文章出现在 Marvin Minsky 的语义信息处理中，并在 RJB 和 HJL 的读物书中重印。有关这些论文的更多信息，请参阅第 4 章和第 8 章的注释。Gary Marcus 和 Ernest Davis 的引述摘自他们六十年后撰写的Rebooting AI一书的第 94 页。

This introductory chapter motivates our approach and provides an overview of the rest of the book. The groundbreaking 1958 paper by John McCarthy that started all the thinking in AI on common sense was called, appropriately, “Programs with Common Sense.” Much better known is a version that included a later article, “Situations, Actions, and Causal Laws,” which appeared in Marvin Minsky’s Semantic Information Processing, and was reprinted in RJB and HJL’s Readings book. For more on these papers, see chapter 4 and the notes on chapter 8. The quote from Gary Marcus and Ernest Davis is taken from page 94 of their Rebooting AI book, written sixty years later.

正如文中所指出的，关于 AI 应该走向何方，以及最终什么最重要，该领域内外一直存在激烈的争论。要了解当前的观点，请参阅Architects of Intelligence，这是 2018 年由未来学家 Martin Ford 对 AI 研究人员进行采访的书。福特的书中奇怪地混合了洞察力和夸大其词，但肯定没有什么类似于共识。我们的意见是关于人工智能研究应该如何进行的问题最好在竞争环境中解决，而不是通过争论。管用就管用。

As noted in the text, there have always been heated debates within and outside the field as to where AI should be going, and what will end up mattering the most. To get some idea of current opinions, see Architects of Intelligence, the 2018 book of interviews with AI researchers conducted by futurist Martin Ford. There is a curious mix of insight and overstatement in Ford’s book, but certainly nothing resembling a consensus. Our opinion is that questions about how AI research should be conducted are best settled on the playing field, not by argumentation. Whatever works, works.

在这本书中，我们不会讨论在 AI 中追求哪个方向，而是探索一条通向常识的特定道路，即使只是为了更好地理解这段旅程需要什么。我们首先了解人类的常识（第 2 章）、包括深度学习在内的人工智能系统的历史（第 3 章），以及使用符号的想法及其背后的科学假设（第 4 章）。然后，在我们尝试与实际的常识行为建立联系（第 9 章）之前，我们将更详细地检查这个假设（第 5-8 章）。然后我们考虑剩下的两个问题：我们如何将这些想法付诸实践（第 10 章），以及我们为什么要这样做（第 11 章）。

In this book, we will not be debating which direction to pursue in AI but instead exploring one particular road to common sense, if only to better understand what the journey entails. We first look at common sense in humans (chapter 2), the history of AI systems including deep learning (chapter 3), and where the idea of using symbols comes from along with the scientific hypothesis behind it (chapter 4). We then examine this hypothesis in some detail (chapters 5–8) before we try to make a connection with actual commonsense behavior (chapter 9). Then we consider two remaining questions: How we might put these ideas into practice (chapter 10), and why we might want to (chapter 11).

我们认为，这些都不能解决关于人工智能研究应该或不应该如何进行的争论。但我们希望它能以有益的方式阐明与常识有关的问题。

In our opinion, none of this settles the debate about how AI research should or should not be conducted. But our hope is that it will illuminate the issues having to do with common sense in a helpful way.

第 2 章：人类的常识

Chapter 2: Common Sense in Humans

常识长期以来一直是大众评论的主题，但对详细解释相对抗拒。有时，该术语仅用作良好判断力或逻辑思维的代名词。在本章开头的引述中，我们阐述了几个有趣的观点，并且可以在网上找到许多其他观点。然而，令人惊讶的是，除了对人类常识可能是什么的模糊描述之外，很难找到更多的东西。关于它何时使用以及它的常见（或不常见）之处有很多猜测，但几乎没有关于它到底是什么的猜测。

Common sense has long been a subject of popular comment, but has been relatively resistant to detailed explication. Sometimes the term is just used as a stand-in for good sense or logical thinking. In the quotes at the start of this chapter, we illustrate several interesting perspectives on what it is about, and many others can be found online. Surprisingly, though, it is hard to find more than vague descriptions of what common sense in humans might be. There is a lot of speculation about when it is used and what is common (or uncommon) about it, but virtually nothing about what it actually is.

很难找到对人类常识现象的科学研究。也许这是因为很难将常识与其他更专业的思维模式区分开来。丹尼尔·卡尼曼 (Daniel Kahneman) 的《思考，快与慢》中提出的系统 1 和系统 2 的区别是理解人类心理的一种有用方式，但似乎是一个不同的切入点。有趣的是，Kahneman 的书调查了他与 Amos Tversky 在认知偏差方面的工作（包括此处讨论的 Linda 实验），甚至没有将“常识”作为其索引中的项目。

It is hard to find a scientific study of the phenomenon of common sense as it occurs in humans. Perhaps this is because it is difficult to draw a firm line separating common sense from other, more specialized modes of thinking. The Systems 1 and 2 distinction presented in Daniel Kahneman’s Thinking, Fast and Slow is a useful way of understanding human psychology, but appears to be a different cut. Interestingly, Kahneman’s book, which surveys his work with Amos Tversky on cognitive biases (including the Linda experiment discussed here), does not even have “common sense” as an item in its index.

正如本章所提到的，也许直接处理常识的心理学中最重要的工作与所谓的实用智力有关。Robert Sternberg 及其同事出版了一系列与该主题相关的出版物，包括一本名为《日常生活中的实用智能》的综合性书籍，还有一项由 Sternberg 的合作者 Jennifer Hedlund 撰写的名为“实用智能”的最新调查。（文中的引文是斯腾伯格书序言的第一行。）斯腾伯格更广泛的自适应智能理论涵盖在他 2021 年出版的《自适应智能》一书中. 文献中很多关于实用智力的讨论都是关于测量的，主要是为了回应对g 的不满，g 是一个据称由 IQ 测试测量的“一般智力”因素。还有一个问题是常识能不能教？有一些指南和网站旨在解释如何提高实用智力。虽然我们在这里将所有这些放在一边，但这些辩论中的见解最终可能对 AI 有价值。

As mentioned in the chapter, perhaps the most substantial line of work in psychology that deals directly with common sense is connected to what is termed practical intelligence. Robert Sternberg and colleagues have a series of publications related to the subject, including a comprehensive book called Practical Intelligence in Everyday Life, and there is a more recent survey, titled “Practical Intelligence,” by Sternberg’s collaborator Jennifer Hedlund. (The quotation in the text is the first line of the preface in the Sternberg book.) Sternberg’s broader theory of adaptive intelligence is covered in his 2021 book, Adaptive Intelligence. Much of the discussion of practical intelligence in the literature is about measurement, largely in response to dissatisfaction with g, the single “general intelligence” factor supposedly measured by IQ tests. There is also a question regarding whether or not common sense can be taught; there are guidebooks and websites purporting to explain how to improve practical intelligence. While we leave all that aside here, insights from these debates may eventually prove valuable to AI.

肯尼斯·哈蒙德 (Kenneth Hammond) 关于认知连续体的工作在可追溯到 1980 年的一系列出版物中有所体现。他与同事一起撰写的 1987 年文章“直觉和分析认知在专家判断中的功效的直接比较”就是一个很好的例子。哈蒙德认为，直觉的认知模式是形象的，而分析模式则更倾向于口头表达。请注意，有证据表明，与控制常规自动驾驶活动的部分（杏仁核和小脑）相比，人脑的不同部分（前额叶皮层）处理的分析能力更多。颞叶作为记忆的所在，可能对人类常识很重要，但神经科学将不得不等待另一本书。

Kenneth Hammond’s work on the cognitive continuum is featured in a series of publications dating back to 1980. His 1987 article, “Direct Comparison of the Efficacy of Intuitive and Analytical Cognition in Expert Judgment,” written with colleagues, is a good example. Hammond suggests that intuitive modes of cognition are pictorial, while analytical modes tend to be more verbal. Note that there is evidence that the more analytical capabilities are handled by a different part of the human brain (the prefrontal cortex) than those that control the routine autopilot activity (the amygdala and cerebellum). The temporal lobes, as the seat of memory, are probably important to human common sense, but the neuroscience will have to wait for another book.

另一方面，反映心理学的常识强调行动的观点，哲学家有时会区分与世界真实情况有关的推理和他们所谓的实践推理，与应采取的行动有关。哲学家以利亚·米尔格拉姆 (Elijah Millgram) 编辑的著作《实用推理的多样性》(Varieties of Practical Reasoning)提供了有关该主题的多种观点。有关理性主题的更多信息，请参阅Steven Pinker 于2021 年出版的名为《理性》的书。

On a different note, mirroring psychology’s view of common sense emphasizing action, philosophers sometimes distinguish between reasoning that is concerned with what is true about the world and what they term practical reasoning, concerned with the actions that should be taken. Philosopher Elijah Millgram’s edited volume Varieties of Practical Reasoning provides multiple perspectives on the subject. For more on the topic of rationality, see the 2021 book entitled Rationality by Steven Pinker.

邓肯·瓦茨 (Duncan Watts) 在他富有洞察力的《一切皆显而易见》(Everything Is Obvious)中从社会学的角度对常识进行了有用的解释。我们同意他的许多特征，例如他强调快速、简单、基于经验的解释和常识的实用性。但我们在几个关键点上与 Watts 不同。首先，正如我们对该术语的定义所表明的那样，要表现出常识，它必须能够有效地利用其经验知识来实现​​其目标。瓦茨只关注知识——当然重要，但在我们看来，推理方面同样重要。其次，Watts 推测常识的实用性意味着没有必要理解为什么某些事情是常识性的：“一个人不需要知道为什么 [某事是真的] 就可以从知识中获益，并且可以说一个人过得更好不要太担心”（第 9 页）。我们认为，至少对常识为何有效有一个直觉的理解是至关重要的，并且正如我们在第 11 章中所观察到的那样，能够根据它所依赖的基础知识来解析它。

A useful account of common sense from the perspective of sociology is due to Duncan Watts in his insightful Everything Is Obvious. We agree with much of his characterization, such as his emphasis on quick, simple, experience-based explanations and the practical nature of common sense. But we differ from Watts on a couple of key points. First, as our definition of the term makes clear, for something to exhibit common sense, it must be able to make effective use of its experiential knowledge to achieve its goals. Watts focuses on the knowledge alone—important of course, but in our view, the reasoning aspect is equally crucial. Second, Watts speculates that the practicality of common sense means that there is no need to understand why something is commonsensical: “One does not need to know why [something is true] in order to benefit from the knowledge, and arguably one is better off not worrying about it too much” (page 9). We believe that it is critical to have at least an intuitive understanding of why a piece of common sense works, and as we observe in chapter 11, be able to unpack it in terms of the underlying knowledge it leans on.

弗雷德里克·巴特利特爵士 (Sir Frederic Bartlett) 在心理学中重建记忆方面的工作涵盖在他关于该主题的经典著作《记忆：实验心理学和社会心理学研究》中。我们在第 7 章中再次提到这一点，并提供有关目击者记忆的参考资料。

Sir Frederic Bartlett’s work on reconstructive memory in psychology is covered in his classic book on the subject, Remembering: A Study in Experimental and Social Psychology. We mention this again in chapter 7, and provide a reference there about eyewitness memory.

在本章的最后一节中，我们提到了一些与常识不同的事情。例如，我们说，专家获得的专业知识通常需要复杂的分析思维模式。但专家们似乎也倾向于对他们的专业领域以及他们狭隘的同事群体所共享的一种常识形成更直观的理解。在他的《直觉的力量》一书中, 心理学家加里克莱因以令人信服的方式谈论专家的直觉决策，以及专家使用直觉而不是理性、有序的分析做出关键决策的频率。我们也提到拼图模式思维；有关此想法的初步分析，请参阅 HJL 1988 年的论文“逻辑与推理的复杂性”。最后，关于模式识别，本章中提供的示例涉及在线性字母序列上查看模式。计算机科学家 Mikhail Bongard 提出了一项涉及二维视觉结构的有趣相关任务，并在 Melanie Mitchell 的《人工智能》一书中进行了详细讨论。

In the last section of the chapter, we mention several things that diverge from common sense. We say, for instance, that experts acquire specialized knowledge that often requires complex analytic modes of thinking. But it appears that experts also tend to develop a more intuitive understanding of their specialized worlds and what amounts to a kind of common sense shared by their narrow community of colleagues. In his book The Power of Intuition, psychologist Gary Klein talks in a compelling way about intuitive decision-making by experts and the frequency with which experts make critical decisions using intuition rather than rational, orderly analysis. We mention puzzle-mode thinking too; for a preliminary analysis of this idea, see HJL’s 1988 paper, “Logic and the Complexity of Reasoning.” Finally, regarding pattern recognition, the example presented in the chapter involves seeing a pattern over a linear sequence of letters. An interesting related task involving two-dimensional visual structures was proposed by computer scientist Mikhail Bongard and is discussed at some length in Melanie Mitchell’s book Artificial Intelligence.

第 3 章：AI 系统的专业知识

Chapter 3: Expertise in AI Systems

本章涉及各种不同的人工智能系统和项目。Pamela McCorduck 和 Nils Nilsson 都撰写了内容丰富的文章AI 历史概述：分别是“会思考的机器”和“人工智能的探索”。回顾整个领域的文章出现在AI 杂志2005 年和 2006 年的特刊中（由 David Leake 编辑），后者是为了纪念该领域成立 50 周年。该杂志 2020 年一期（由 Ashok Goel 主编）调查了美国 DARPA 资助的研究人员做出的重大贡献。

This chapter refers to a wide variety of different AI systems and projects. Pamela McCorduck and Nils Nilsson have both written informative overviews of the history of AI: respectively, Machines Who Think and The Quest for Artificial Intelligence. Articles with retrospectives on the field as a whole appear in special issues of the AI Magazine in 2005 and 2006 (edited by David Leake), the latter commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the field. A 2020 issue of this magazine (edited by Ashok Goel) surveys the significant contribution made by researchers funded by DARPA in the United States.

早在 20 世纪 40 年代末，艾伦图灵就提出了关于机器需要具备哪些条件才能被视为智能的重要推测。图灵对确定机器是否可以思考的方法的思考（通过文中提到的他的模仿游戏）及其所有优点和缺点，是思考 AI 的重要早期驱动力。HJL 的Common Sense一书以及 Gary Marcus、Francesca Rossi 和 Manuela Veloso 的AI Magazine 2016 年特刊提供了对图灵测试的见解。鲜为人知的是，图灵在其 1953 年的文章“应用于游戏的数字计算机”中也考虑了如何将计算机应用于战略游戏，该文章建立在克劳德·香农 (Claude Shannon) 的“为下棋编写计算机程序”的工作基础上。

Important speculation on what it would take for a machine to be considered intelligent was offered by Alan Turing as far back as the late 1940s. Turing’s contemplation of a way to determine if a machine could think (via his imitation game, mentioned in the text), with all of its pros and cons, was a crucial early driver of thinking about AI. HJL’s Common Sense book, and the Gary Marcus, Francesca Rossi, and Manuela Veloso 2016 special issue of AI Magazine provide insight into the Turing test. Less known perhaps is that Turing also contemplated how computers might be applied to strategic games in his 1953 article, “Digital Computers Applied to Games,” building on the work of Claude Shannon in his “Programming a Computer Program for Playing Chess.”

许多人认为人工智能领域始于著名的达特茅斯暑期研究项目，该项目于 1956 年在新罕布什尔州举行，为期八周，基于约翰麦卡锡的“达特茅斯人工智能夏季研究项目提案，1955 年 8 月 31 日” 、马文·明斯基、纳撒尼尔·罗切斯特和香农。向洛克菲勒基金会提交的会议提案先见之明地谈到了当今该领域仍然关注的许多主题，包括使用抽象和概念进行推理、学习（包括神经网络）、创造力、解决问题和玩游戏. Allen Newell、Herb Simon 和 Cliff Shaw 实际上从达特茅斯会议前一年就开始研究一个名为逻辑理论家的 AI 程序。1956年初，匹兹堡邮报，2006 年 1 月 2 日）。

Many consider the field of AI to have begun at the famous Dartmouth Summer Research Project, an eight-week workshop in New Hampshire in 1956 based on “A Proposal for the Dartmouth Summer Research Project on Artificial Intelligence, August 31, 1955” by John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Nathaniel Rochester, and Shannon. The proposal to the Rockefeller Foundation for the meeting talked presciently about many topics that have continued to be of central interest to the field today, including reasoning using abstractions and concepts, learning (including neural nets), creativity, problem-solving, and game playing. Allen Newell, Herb Simon, and Cliff Shaw had actually been working on an AI program, called the Logic Theorist, since the year before the Dartmouth conference. In early 1956, Simon is reputed to have told one of his classes that “over the Christmas holiday, Al Newell and I invented a thinking machine” (quoted in an article by Byron Spice in the online Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, January 2, 2006).

游戏和与游戏相关的搜索在 AI 的历史上一直扮演着重要的角色。Newell 和 Simon 在他们的图灵奖演讲中提出了他们关于搜索的想法，该演讲发表于 1976 年，题为“计算机科学作为实证研究”。关于西洋跳棋，关于 Arthur Samuel 贡献的一个很好的视角，副标题为“机器学习的先驱”，发表在他的约翰·麦卡锡和埃德·费根鲍姆去世。Jonathan Schaeffer 在 2007 年与人合着的《科学》杂志上发表的文章“Checkers Is Solved”中记录了 Jonathan Schaeffer 最终战胜跳棋的故事。Deep Blue 在国际象棋中的成功更为人所知。（例如，参见 Monty Newborn 的书《深蓝》。）西洋双陆棋和扑克的成功在 Hans Berliner 的文章“西洋双陆棋计算机程序击败世界冠军”和 Noam Brown 的“单挑无限扑克的超人人工智能”中有所描述和 Tuomas Sandholm。

Games and game-related search have always played an important role in the history of AI. Newell and Simon offered their ideas on search in their Turing Award lecture, published in 1976 as “Computer Science as Empirical Inquiry.” Regarding checkers, a nice perspective on Arthur Samuel’s contribution, subtitled “Pioneer in Machine Learning,” was published on his death by John McCarthy and Ed Feigenbaum. Jonathan Schaeffer’s eventual triumph over checkers is documented in his coauthored article “Checkers Is Solved” in Science in 2007. The success of Deep Blue in chess is much better known. (See, for example, Monty Newborn’s book Deep Blue.) The backgammon and poker successes are described in the article “Backgammon Computer Program Beats World Champion” by Hans Berliner and “Superhuman AI for Heads-up No-Limit Poker” by Noam Brown and Tuomas Sandholm.
